Title: Will the Hubballi Ankola railway project be doomsday for the Kali Tiger reserve?
Content:
‘We will take the issue to the Supreme Court again’

Cannot support such harm to the environment: Sowmya Reddy

Activists urge citizens to support the protest

A hub of protected species

‘Wildlife board has a moral responsibility to protect forests’

In yet another testimony that development projects take precedence over the environment, the state government on Friday approved the controversial Hubballi-Ankola rail line, a project that environmentalists have been opposing for over two decades. Ironically, the decision to okay destruction of close to 600 hectares of forest area came on the eve of the International Forest Day (celebrated on March 21), the theme for which was forests and biodiversity.It also comes not long after it was proposed to reduce the eco-sensitive zone around the Bannerghatta Biological Park by 100 sq km, and at a time when forest land in Kodagu district continues to be under threat. Naturally, environmentalists are peeved that the government has allowed a railway line that will cut through the Kali Tiger Reserve.J Manjunath, the secretary of the Wilderness Club, which has been at the forefront of the protests against the project and taken the issue to the Apex Court earlier, says, “The issue at hand is not just about a railway line. As part of the project, 327 bridges would be constructed, 50 of which will be inside the sensitive zone, as well as 12 railway stations. The 168.4-kilometre line will also have 34 tunnels of 3.4 kilometers length each, for which the Railways wants 594 hectare of land. The state claims only 2.34 lakh trees would be destroyed, but in my estimation, twice that much will be gone. Forests take a million years to evolve and all that will be lost, which will have a direct impact on the rainfall patterns. The people of Karnataka will suffer, as we depend on the Ghats for water. 63 rivers flow through the Ghats and are a source of life for the state.”He adds that they were the first to file a petition with the Central Empowered Committee in 2006 against the diversion of Forest Land falling in the ecologically sensitive Western Ghats . "Everyone rejected the project. It was rejected the by Central Empowered Committee, The National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) and the National Board for Wildlife (NBWL) back then. So, I do not understand why the state wants to revive it. But if they try to go ahead with it, we will write to the Asian Bank, UNESCO, World Bank and other organisations that are giving them money for conservation purposes and show them just what the Indian government is doing. We went to Supreme Court earlier, we will seek justice again if required," he adds.MLA Sowmya Reddy, who was a member of the State Wildlife Board, resigned from the post in protest against the decision. "I have decided to resign from the state wildlife board because the board with the leadership of Hon’ble CM BS Yediyurappa has decided to implement the Hubli-Ankola Railway project which is harmful to the environment and wildlife. I am not against development, but I cannot support something that is harmful to the environment where there was an alternative, my conscience will not allow me to. Natural disasters in the recent past have shown us that nothing is bigger than preserving the exciting nature" she wrote online.Other environmentalists have also come in support of protests againsts these attacks on the state’s forest cover. On Saturday, an online petition against the Hubballi-Ankola railway line was floated, seeking the prime minister’s intervention in the matter, which notched up a few thousand signatures within hours. Urging more people to raise their voices against the project, environmentalist Akhilesh Chipli from SWAN and Man (Save-Wild-Atmosphere--Nature and Man) says, "This is a totally unnecessary and disastrous project, which will affect some 600 hectares of pristine forest and destroy over two lakh trees, some of which are 200-300 years old. The repercussions of such a move would be unimaginable, so it is time to come out and let our voices be heard, at least online, if not on the ground."The forests where the Hubballi-Ankola railway zone has been earmarked are rich in fauna, represented by 29 species of mammals, 256 species of birds, eight species of reptiles and 50 species of butterflies. Majority of the mammals belong to IUCN Red List and are protected under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 .(Source - 2018 Site Inspection Report on the Diversion of 595.64 ha of forest land in Karwar, Yellapura and Dharwad Divisions for the construction of new broad gauge railway line of Hubballi – Ankola to Ministry of Environment and Forest)Yhe members of the Karnataka Wildlife Board Members should quit en masse, as the chief minister and the chairman have gone ahead and approved a project that will spell doom for the Western Ghats. It is their moral responsibility and duty to protect the forests and remaining wildlife habitat of Karnataka. No amount of afforestation can bring back what would be lost in a tiger reserve. We are looking at irreversible damage to the biodiversity, with animals losing their habitats as well as losing threatened species- Vijay Nishanth, tree doctor and biodiversity management committee member for BBMP.

Title: Capturing the game of light on lens
Content: A doctor by profession and a photographer by passion, Dr Shobhit Chawla ’s solo photography exhibition titled A Game of Light was organised at the art gallery of prominent hotel in the city.(L) Bani Chawla and Shobhit Chawla (R) Prachi Singh (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)This treat for art lovers, the exhibition was inaugurated by Anil Risal Singh , former President of Federation of Indian Photography and was curated by Dhananjay Varshney and Vandana Sehgal.(L) Anil Risal and Reena Singh (R) Deepak Agarwal and Mukul Singhal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Soon after the formal inauguration was over, various guests were spotted clicking selfies with the photographs and discussing them. The exhibition was based on the play of light as the medium in photography. A total of 55 images displayed in the exhibition were clicked in Nepal, Jaisalmer, Spiti, Tanzania, Paris, Hyderabad and some from various other places.— Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui(L) Dolly and Lokesh Rastogi (R) Bjorn Wallander (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Doretti and Hennie (R) Vicky (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Dr Rajat and Sheena Bharwani (R) Dr Rajat and Sheena Bharwani (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Dr DN Kapoor and Dr SM Zaheed (R) Julia Simlai and Vandana Sehgal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Kiron Chopra and Vijay Sahi (R) Mansi and Anurag Didwania (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Nayab and Dr Qamar Rahman (R) Abhishek Mishra and Swati Mishra (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Title: Soundarya Sharma stuck in LA amid the coronavirus outbreak
Content: Soundarya Sharma, who's currently studying acting in LA, is stuck there because of the coronavirus outbreak and cannot step out of her apartment. When we spoke to the actress, told us that she is unable to come back home, and her flights have been cancelled thrice, without any refund. "We are in a state of lockdown. I go out early morning to get my groceries, but the stores are a few miles away. They're also mostly empty, and even basics like potatoes, salt, lentils etc aren’t available. I don’t even have a mask as it's out of stock and not even available online. I've also seen people fighting over toilet paper and sanitisers. I can’t even travel back home because of travel restrictions, and already, three of my flights have been cancelled without refund. My parents are extremely worried for me," she rues.Soundarya's troubles, however, aren't limited to the lockdown. She shares, "I rented an apartment here, obviously on contract, and now I need to vacate it. I don’t know where to go in such a situation. Though I have requested the owner to take note of the current situation, he has further bookings and moreover, people here are very practical."Talking about how she's dealing with the situation, Soundarya tells us, "I'm trying to keep myself engaged in this house-arrest situation. I’m using the time to rejuvenate myself, read, watch movies and cook. I hope that things come back to normalcy soon. I’m praying that we come out of this, and for that I urge everyone to listen to experts and the government, who are doing an amazing job during such a troubling time."

Title: Coronavirus shutdown: With gyms shut, UPites find other ways to stay fit at home
Content:
Sazid Ahmed Qureshi (BCCL)

Sazid Ahmed Qureshi

Ravish Ahmed

Ravish Ahmed (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Sargam Gupta

(L) Karan Singh (R) Naveen Singh (BCCL)

Asfar Tahir (BCCL)

(L) Ritu Pathak (R) Sargam Gupta (BCCL)

With the threat of growing coronavirus COVID-19 cases, a safety directive has seen public hotspots in Mumbai — such as cinemas, malls and gyms — close. While people might find it easier to make the switch by watching a movie or two at home, it’s not going down as easily with hardcore gym lovers and fitness freaks who are feeling the workout blues already. Speaking to us, peple from Lucknow, Varanasi and Kanpur including celebs, share on how they’re trying to adapt to other forms of working out and more...“Whenever possible I go for a game of lawn tennis. Since it is not a team game so it is safe and at the same time you burn a lot of calories. Yoga is also a great regime to keep oneself healthy, so I am practicing it every day. So even though yoga studios and gyms are closed, I am trying my best to keep myself fit with the basic workout techniques that I know of," says the actor better known as Beera of Na Bole Tum Na Maine Kuch Kaha 2 and who hails from Varanasi.Sazid Ahmed Qureshi (BCCL)“It’s very difficult for a person like me, who works out for most part of the day to be told to sit at home without working out. Since I have closed the gym, I am now working out in the morning and evening with the basic equipment that I have at my home. Plus, for my clients, on special request, I am regularly making videos of workouts and diets to follow and sending to them on Whatsapp or uploading them online,” says Sajid, a gym owner in Lucknow.Exercising is a very important part of my daily routine. I do weight training andcardiovascular exercises in the gym but now after they hav ebeen closed, I am working out at home. I try to follow a basic work out regimen and do weights, pilates, and strength training. It’s much less than what I do in the gym, but it’s something. It’s not making me feel that I am wasting my time, says Ahmed, a gym owner from Lucknow.Ravish Ahmed (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Gym jaa kar exercise karne ka toh abhi option hi nahi hai. But this does not mean that I will leave exercising. Being a fitness freak, I am gyming at home. Though I am missing on heavy weight exercises but with yoga, cycling and rope skipping, I ensure that I burn out same amount of calories that I used to burn out in the gym. I will now only go to the gym once the scare of Coronavirus ends and the gym is properly sanitized,” says Karan, a fitness enthusiast from Kanpur.“Exercising is now a part of my life and I can’t even think of giving a miss to my exercise schedule for a day. I have been regularly exercising for past two years and this sudden break from the gym was surely a shock for me. Nowadays with the lockdown, I am working out at home. My trainer sometimes guides me through videos he sends on mobiles which are really helpful,” says Sargam a student from Kanpur.(L) Karan Singh (R) Naveen Singh (BCCL)Naveen Singh“Till the time it is not happening, I have chalked out a schedule with my trainer. I take out at least half and hour in the morning for the workout. It is mixture of yoga asanas and push-ups. I make a good use of staircase and climb up and down the stairs several times to make up for working out on the treadmill,” says Naveen, a businessman from Varanasi, who works out in agym regularly. Asfar Tahir (BCCL)Asfar Tahir“We can still try to maintain a healthy fitness routine with a few basic workout exercises like the push-ups, squats, mountain climbing, etc which require least space at home in doing. Foraddicts like me, I workout thrice a day or sometimes increase the repetitions of the sets of exercises,” says Asfar, a gym trainer in Luycknow.(L) Ritu Pathak (R) Sargam Gupta (BCCL)Ritu PathakAs soon as the cases of Coronavirus patients started increasing, I stopped going to the gym. I chose to work out at home. I have also hired a personal trainer who trains me every day. Now, in place of weight training and other tough exercises, I am focusing on aerobics for maintaining my fitness,” says Ritu, a homemaker from Kanpur.

Title: Covid-19 scare: 35,000 foreign returned persons under scanner in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government has asked all the DMs to undertake a thorough verification exercise of around 35,000 foreign returned persons who have been staying in Delhi since March 1, 2020.In an order issued on Sunday, the health and family welfare department said "in the view of the global outbreak of Covid-19, it has come to the notice of the government that approximately 35,000 foreign returned persons have been staying in Delhi." Many of them have travel history to Covid-19 hotspots in different parts of the world.The DMs have been asked to ensure that all such persons remain in home quarantine for a minimum period of 14 days besides their contacts. Any person found disobeying the order shall be punished with fine or imprisonment under suitable laws, the order stated.

Title: Opposition demands relief for daily wagers, small businesses
Content: PANAJI: Supporting the state government’s decision to continue the imposition of voluntary curfew in Goa for three days, the opposition on Sunday also urged chief minister Pramod Sawant to provide financial relief for daily wage workers and small businesses that have suffered.Congress, GFP and independent MLA Rohan Khaunte demanded that the government also ensure that basic food items and essential commodities are provided to those in need.“Preventive measures on Covid-19 need to continue as it is now clear that social distancing is the only effective step in controlling its spread. The need to extend Janata Curfew is the right decision,” opposition leader Digambar Kamat, said.The sentiment was echoed by Khaunte who said an “immediate lockdown”, similar to ones declared by Maharashtra and Rajasthan, was the only “scientific way of controlling” the spread of the infectious disease that has claimed six lives in India and infected over 350 individuals.The opposition also urged Sawant to roll out support measures for citizens, especially the poor and elderly who do not have a steady source of income.“We need to unhesitatingly use Goa chief minister’s relief fund and disaster management fund to make sure essentials are provided to every affected Goan,” Khaunte said.Kamat, while stressing on the availability of essential commodities like milk and vegetables also asked the government to provide a “financial package” for those who depend on daily wages.GFP president Vijai Sardesai was a bit more specific. While praising participation in the Janata Curfew, he also stressed on the loss of wages by casual workers and those engaged in the informal sector.“When there is a janata curfew, those who depend on daily wages and workers in the informal economy need income support. The government must think of a package for small and medium businesses and the tourism sector. This could include tax breaks and a moratorium on loan repayments,” Sardesai said.

Title: Bodhisattwa plays the guitar to thank wife and others in emergency service
Content: In the middle of the thanksgiving cheer at 5 pm on Sunday, residents of Jodhpur Park could hear a bit of music too. Bodhisattwa Ghosh , the guitarist of Lakkhichhara and Bodhisattwa Trio, played an improvisation piece at his balcony as his thanksgiving gesture.“It was primarily to thank my wife, Poulami Mukherjee , who is a doctor at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital. She has been on her duty all these days and I am so proud of her. I also would like to thank all the other people, who are in emergency service and working day-in-and-day-out to combat the crisis,” said Bodhisattwa, who also admitted that this piece was to beat the lockdown blues too.

Title: Lockdown in India: Officially or unofficially, India in lockdown, restrictions put in place in 82 districts
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Even as the day-long nationwide “janata curfew” called for by Prime Minister Narendra Modi drew to a close on Sunday evening, much of India came under a lockdown with most state governments extending total public transport shutdown and other restrictions for varying periods to fight the spread of Covid-19.While many governments brought entire states or Union territories under the lockdown, some others ordered that those districts which have reported Covid-19 cases will continue to remain shut. However, essential services like hospitals, telecom, pharmacies, grocery, milk and vegetables will remain open.In Mumbai, the administration swung into action immediately after the “janata curfew” with the police virtually imposing a curfew till 5am on Monday.According to the police order, “presence or movement of one or more persons is prohibited” in the limits of Mumbai city. The railways have also announced cancellation of all local trains on Central and Western Railway, while Section 144 of CrPC was imposed in all urban areas.According to the health ministry, at least 82 districts in 23 states across the country were shut by 8pm on Sunday.The decision on lockdown followed a high-level review meeting chaired by the cabinet secretary and principal secretary to the Prime Minister with chief secretaries and health secretaries of all states where the Centre emphasised the need to break the transmission chain to contain Covid-19. The Centre also empowered the states to extend the list of districts for shutdown based on their risk assessment.“This lockdown is a natural and logical extension of the ‘janata curfew’ and is vital to break the chain of transmission,” said health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal after the meeting. All public transport, including train and Metro rail services and local and inter-state bus services, have been suspended till March 31. Good trains, however, will continue to ensure availability of essential commodities.Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Punjab, Uttarakhand, Jharkhand, Jammu and Kashmir and Chandigarh were among the states and Union territories that were completely brought under lockdown on Sunday till March 31. On Saturday night, Rajasthan was the first state in the country to come under complete lockdown.In Madhya Pradesh, 20 districts, including Bhopal, have been put under lockdown.UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced that 15 districts in the state, including state capital Lucknow and Noida and Ghaziabad in the NCR, will come under complete lockdown till March 25. The other districts are Agra, Varanasi, Lakhimpur Kheri, Kanpur, Aligarh, Gorakhpur, Azamgarh, Saharanpur, Bareilly, Prayagraj, Meerut and Moradabad.“The lockdown has been announced to sanitise cities to counter the spread of Covid-19,” said Yogi. The CM indicated that more districts will be brought under lockdown in days to come when he said that “people should be prepared for more measures like ‘janata curfew’ in future to contain the spread of the disease”.In Bengal, the Mamata Banerjee government declared a complete lockdown in Kolkata, Salt Lake and New Town cities as well as the districts of Howrah, Malda, Murshidabad, North Dinajpur, Hooghly, Birbhum and West Burdwan from 5pm on March 22 till the midnight of March 27. Almost all municipal towns in 16 other districts of the state have also been brought under the shutdown. Apart from essential commodities and medicines, the state government has also exempted “e-commerce of groceries and food items and home delivery of food” from the shutdown.While entire Punjab and Chandigarh were brought under lockdown, in the neighbouring Himachal and Haryana, districts where Covid-19 cases have been reported were put under curbs. Of the total 22 districts in Haryana, lockdown was announced in seven — Gurgaon, Sonipat, Panchkula, Rohtak, Jhajjar, Faridabad and Panipat. In Himachal, Kangra district was brought under shutdown.The Bihar government ordered lockdown in the headquarters of all 38 districts, 101 sub-divisional towns and 534 blocks with immediate effect till March 31. Karnataka brought nine of its districts under lockdown till March 31. Odisha imposed week-long lockdown in five districts and nine urban local bodies from Sunday. The Naveen Patnaik government has also suspended all interstate bus services.Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Mizoram – which have remained Covid19-free so far — became the first northeastern states where lockdown came under force from Sunday midnight. While in Nagaland it is for an indefinite period, the Arunachal Pradesh government said it will start at 5pm on Monday and extend till March 31 midnight. In Mizoram, the lockdown will run for a week beginning Sunday.However, while most of governments ordered lockdown in their respective regions, Kerala the second worst affected state in the country, dithered on the Centre’s advisory to shut down 10 of its districts. “At present, we have a shutdown in Kasaragod and restrictions in other select districts. We will discuss if such a shutdown is needed in other districts too… There will be restrictions and they will be decided on Monday,” chief secretary Tom Jose said.The Covid-19 infection claimed three more lives in the country on Sunday, taking the toll from the disease to seven, even as states continued to report a high number of cases, which have now touched 400.On Sunday, 68 new cases were reported by 14 states in all, the second highest for a single day after 77 cases reported on Saturday.

Title: Coronavirus in India: 3 deaths, 68 new cases as total infected count hits 400
Content: NEW DELHI: The Covid-19 infection claimed three more lives in the country on Sunday, taking the total toll from the disease to seven, even as states continued to report a high number of cases which have now touched 400. On Sunday, 68 new cases were reported by 14 states in all, the second highest for a single day after 77 cases reported on Saturday. Bihar became the 22nd state to be affected by Covid-19 in the country with three confirmed cases and one death reported on Sunday. The Bihar victim, Saif Ali, 38, had returned from Qatar recently.He was admitted to Patna’s AIIMS with chronic kidney problem on March 20 and given ventilator support. “Ali also had symptoms of Covid-19 so we sent his samples for testing and it came positive,” AIIMS-Patna director Dr PK Singh said.Before being referred at AIIMS, Ali was admitted to the emergency ward of Patna Medical College and Hospital on March 19, which has led to fears that he may have infected some of the hospital staff. One death each was reported from Maharasthra and Gujarat, respectively. The ICMR, in an update, confirmed 396 Covid-19 cases in the country. The health ministry said 23 persons have recovered from the disease and one has migrated.

Title: Coronavirus: No ‘indiscriminate testing’, breaking chain is key, says govt
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: After expanding its testing policy to all hospitalised patients with pneumonia or severe flu symptoms, the government said its strategy remained adequate and there was no need for “indiscriminate testing” as isolation and breaking the chain of transmission were the key to containing the spread of Covid-19 in India.India’s approach to testing will remain largely focused on symptomatic cases with travel history or those who have come in contact with positive cases. The travel history and home or institutional quarantine list is, however, fairly extensive even as all international arrivals have been suspended till March 31 when the situation will be reviewed.At a briefing on Sunday, the health ministry and the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) maintained that there was no need for panic as government labs had the capacity to test 50,000-70,000 samples a week, apart from additional capacity being ramped up in private diagnostic labs. Some 60 private labs have applied for permission, which is being granted. “Indiscriminate testing is not to be done. Isolation, isolation, isolation is the key to controlling spread,” ICMR director-general Balram Bhargava said. India has so far tested over 17,000 samples, of which 360 tested positive till Sunday. At present, it is testing around 5,000 samples a week and the number should rise with the involvement of private labs and wider testing criteria.Compared to India, other countries are testing more samples and most of them have still failed to stop transmission. According to Balram Bhargava, the US was testing 26,000 samples a week, whereas France was doing 10,000 and the UK was testing 16,000 every week. India’s government sector labs alone could do around 10,000 samples every day, Bhargava said. Bhargava said those who were in isolation and who showed symptoms must be tested.There remains a possibility that in many cases, as much as 80%, the symptoms do not proceed beyond mild manifestations. Currently, 111 public labs are testing Covid-19 suspects, whereas 60 private labs have applied to ICMR for approval. The council has already started registering these labs, which will expand the network of labs and collection centres significantly. The government has also capped the price for Covid-19 testing at Rs 4500 for private labs, while urging them to do it for free or at subsidised rates.India has, so far, adopted a conservative approach on testing, maintaining that unnecessary testing will not help but only spread panic and waste resources. In response to a question, Lav Agarwal, joint secretary in the health ministry, said 1,200 ventilators had been ordered.He also said norms of personal protection equipment were in place and had been recently revised. As per the current testing protocol, all those with international travel history in the last 14 days should be in quarantine and get tested only when they are symptomatic with fever, cough or breathlessness. Besides, all direct and high risk contacts, including those who live in the same household and healthcare workers who came in direct contact of a confirmed case, should be tested once between day 5 and day 14 of coming in contact with a positive case.

Title: Delhi Lockdown & Section 144: A first: Delhi under prohibitory orders
Content:
Essential services exempted

Action against those violating home isolation orders

Only vehicles carrying essential goods allowed through borders

NEW DELHI: The national capital is entirely under prohibitory orders for the first time. Delhi Police imposed Section 144 of the CrPC from 9pm on Sunday to implement the lockdown necessitated by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The order will remain in force till March 31.With all of Haryana under Section 144 and Noida and Ghaziabad as well, it means the restrictions that don’t allow five or more people to gather in one place now extend across the vast urban sprawl of Delhi-NCR. Delhi Police will allow no demonstrations, processions, protests or social gatherings.Only shops selling essential commodities such as milk and vegetables will remain open. “Any gathering — social, cultural, political religious, academic, sports, seminar, conference — is prohibited. Organisation of weekly markets (except for vegetables, fruits and essential commodities), concerts, exhibitions, etc is prohibited. Guided group tours, conducted by various private tour operators, are prohibited,” said the order signed by the Delhi Police chief.Police have also specified that any individual who has tested positive for Covid-19 or is suspected to have it has to take measures for prevention and stay in home or institutional quarantine.“The person shall co-operate to render assistance or comply with the direction of the surveillance personnel,” said the order. Violations of this are punishable under Section 188 (disobedience of an order duly promulgated by a public servant).Asked about the impact of the prohibitory orders on the ongoing Citizenship Amendment Act protest at Shaheen Bagh, a police officer said, “We went to the protest site and hardly three to four people were present. If more people gather and violate the order, action will be taken.”Besides, with state borders also being sealed, Delhi Police will keep a check on any vehicle entering the capital. Delhi Police spokesperson Mandeep Singh Randhawa said, “Apart from emergency and essential services, we will prevent all vehicles from entering. If any commuter wishes to enter the city, they would be screened and asked about their urgency to travel before being allowed to enter.”According to the order, police will also not allow any goods carriers except ones carrying food or other essential items. Gurugram police did not issue any orders but police chief Mohammad Akil told TOI people had willingly complied with lockdown and they did not want to put unnecessary restrictions.Police have advised Delhiites to avoid travelling to NCR cities like Gurugram, Noida, Faridabad and Ghaziabad unless it is for essential work. Vehicles belonging to doctors, army personnel and the media have been exempted from the curbs.

Title: Delhi Lockdown News: Delhi shuts, no movement of vehicles between city & NCR
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi will be under a complete lockdown from 6am on Monday till the midnight of March 31, as part of strict measures to check the spread of coronavirus . chief minister Arvind Kejriwal announced on Sunday.People engaged in non-essential services who are not going out to avail essential services will not be allowed to travel even in private vehicles, the government said. Delhi’s border with Haryana and UP will be sealed. “People who come out to provide or avail essential services will be allowed on their self-declaration,” the order said.The government has clarified that no document will be sought from a person who is out to provide or avail of any essential service. Taxis, autos, e-rickshaws, rickshaws, buses and public transport facilities, including inter-state bus and Metro services, will be suspended.Only 25% of DTC buses will run. “Extraordinary times call for extraordinary measures. Delhi will be under lockdown from tomorrow 6am until March 31. Certain exceptions have been made to ensure essential services,” Kejriwal tweeted after a joint presser with LG Anil Baijal.All offices, shops and commercial establishments, factories, workshops, weekly bazaars, religious places, construction works will remain closed and any gathering of more than five persons will continue to remain banned, Kejriwal announced in a joint press conference with lieutenant governor Anil Baijal at Raj Niwas on Sunday evening. The government has exempted diaries, grocery shops, milk plants, cashier and teller services in banks including ATMs, municipal and water services, general provision stores, home delivery from restaurants, print and electronic media, e-commerce of all essential goods, medical shops, petrol pumps, law enforcement agencies, police, health services, fire, electricity, and other essential services from the lockdown.“Delhi has 27 confirmed coronavirus cases, out of which six are via local transmission, and 21 are those with travel history. There has been no community transmission of the virus. But if we do not take stringent measures now, the cases might surge to 1,000-1,500 in a few days,” Kejriwal said.Domestic airlines are continuing to operate although the city government order mentions domestic and international flights in the list of services that are barred. The order has also been sent to the Airport Authority of India chairperson for compliance. Those taking domestic flights will obviously face the problem of commuting to or from the airport at a time when Metro, taxi and bus services won't be available. The government found it imperative to adopt strict social distancing and isolation measures to contain the spread of Covid-19 in the city. The Delhi government has already issued the Delhi Epidemic Diseases, Covid-19 Regulations, 2020 under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897 for prevention and containment of coronavirus. Under these a slew of measures have already been announced by the government.“We are lucky that the virus hit India late. We have examples of countries which have dealt effectively that clearly shows that the sooner its spread is checked the better. We know people will face difficulties, but lockdown is necessary to contain the spread of coronavirus,” Kejriwal said.The lockdown order approved by the LG will be enforced by various authorities including Delhi Police and DMs. Any congregation of more than five people prohibited and punishable and any person found violating the lockdown order will be punished under relevant laws, the government order stated.

Title: ‘Janta curfew’ keeps many flyers stranded at Patna airport
Content:
File photo

PATNA: Flyers had a harrowing time at Patna airport on Sunday as there was no public transport available owing to ‘janata curfew’.

Ravi Kumar, who returned to Patna from Delhi, complained that there was no bus at Patna airport till 1pm. “I had to call one of my friends to city airport after I waited there for nearly two hours. I would go to my native place Ara after the ban on public transport is lifted,” he said.

Arun Kumar, a native of Sitamarhi said he was unable to reach Patna airport for his flight to Kolkata and had to cancel his ticket. “The airline deducted huge amount of fare and refunded only Rs1,500,” he said.

Many angry passengers were complaining about the cancellation of GoAir flights on Sunday and poor health check-up at city airport.

Jawed Khan, who works in Delhi metro and hails from Hajipur and was to board the GoAir flight for Patna, tweeted: “Cancelled the flight suddenly and now not responding to calls and emails. Please don’t create panic in this situation and inform us. Please connect to the customer care at least (sic).”

Anuragg Verma complained about poor health check-up being done at Patna airport. “There is no screening at Patna airport. There is a small desk near the entry gate where people are stopped purely on suspicion. Doctors sitting there are gossiping among themselves (sic),” he tweeted.

Patna airport director Bhupesh CH Negi, however, claimed that the thermal screening and other necessary check-ups of passengers were being done by the medical team provided by the state government.

Meanwhile, the autorickshaws in the state would remain off the road on March 23 as well in view of Covid-19 spread.

Bihar State Auto Chalak Sangh’s general secretary Raj Kumar Jha said autorickshaws remained off the road in the state on Sunday and the situation would remain the same on Monday as well. “After the meeting on Monday, we would further decide whether to suspended the services till March 31 or not,” he told this newspaper.

Title: A clarification
Content: The report ‘Withdrawal curbs for PMC Bank a/cs extended by 3 mths’, carried in the March 22 edition, inadvertently reported that the withdrawal limit is Rs 75,000. The general withdrawal limit for PMC Bank continues to be Rs 50,000. The error is regretted.

Title: A ‘productive’ Sunday for Patnaites
Content: PATNA: People from cross sections of society spent the 14-hour ‘janata curfew’ inside their houses in an anxious manner on Sunday.As the day was not like normal Sundays, people spent their time reading, watching movies and ensuring cleanliness in their homes. Some said they utilized the time through productive and fun activities.Shantanu, a resident of S K Nagar, said he taught ‘tabla’ to his seven-year-old son Sabtak Kumar. “I utilised the time with my family members and kids. They got scared after hearing the news about death of a patient due to coronavirus at AIIMS-Patna,” he said.Hansika (16), a Class XI student of Notre Dame Academy, who began her day by calling her friends to know whether they would participate in the ‘janata curfew’, said, “The first thing I did was to call my friends and ask them to support the curfew. This has been by far the longest Sunday for me as I couldn’t go out or meet my friends.”Aditya Pathak, a German language teacher at Litera Valley School and resident of Saguna Mor, said, “I spent the day making question bank for classes VI to VIII and discussing the coronavirus precautionary measures with my family members. Throughout the day, I attended several calls from friends and relatives after one death due to the virus in the city.”Nidha Kumari, a resident of Raja Bazaar, started her day by performing yoga with her neighbours and family members. “I cleaned my home and watched news channels,” she said.Sudha Yadav (45), a homemaker and resident of Mandiri said, “Since my children who are studying outside have returned home, the day didn’t feel very heavy. In addition, I cleaned my pet dog.”

Title: No religious activity performed in city
Content:
PATNA: From Sunday mass in churches to ‘sangats’ and ‘katha’ at temples, all religious activities were cancelled on Sunday during the ‘Janata Curfew’.

Mahavir Mandir Nyas Samiti secretary Kishore Kunal said, “Live streaming of the temple activities is being done. The temple generally witnesses huge crowd of devotees from across the city and elsewhere in the state on days like Sunday, Tuesday and Saturday. We only wanted the devotees who visit the temple on a regular basis to get a sight of the lord. Hence, the initiative was taken by the temple authorities.”

ISKCON (International Society for Krishna Consciousness) Temple sources said that public visit to the temple has been suspended till April 2. “Over 5,000 families are connected to ISKCON temple. For the ‘curfew’, we had asked the devotees to perform several rituals at their homes,” said temple spokesperson Nand Gopal Das.

“We have suspended all our programmes, including prayers services. Besides, entry of local people has been restricted till March 31 following state government’s orders,” said Pastor Pramod K Sebastian of India Pentecostal Church of God at Rajendranagar.

Meanwhile, the Takhat Sri Harmandir Sahib gurdwara also wore a deserted look on Sunday Takhat Sri Harmandir Ji Prabandhak Committee secretary MS Dhillon said, “Though the entry of devotees has been stopped till March 31, pilgrims from other states are staying at the gurdwara. However, there is no mass gathering. People in the ‘langar’ hall have also been advised to maintain a distance.”

Title: Cops stop e-commerce staff despite ‘essential business’ tag
Content: BENGALURU: Online grocery retailers like Bigbasket and Grofers besides e-pharmacy players said their delivery executives were stopped by police personnel across states like Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu on Sunday during the curfew announced by PM Narendra Modi The development comes days after Modi recognised the role played by delivery executives as “essential service” and the ministry of consumer affairs issued a notification on Friday to allow these players to continue operating. “Our delivery executives are selflessly putting their safety at risk to ensure people stay indoors and get all their essentials at home. And then they get stopped and harassed by police and local goons. Who are we really clapping for at 5pm today?,” tweeted Saurabh Kumar, co-founder of SoftBank-backed Grofers.These companies feel that state-level enforcement agencies are not on the same page as the central government on e-commerce deliveries. On Saturday, TOI reported that the consumer affairs ministry urged all the state and local governments to exempt e-commerce operations, including their warehousing and logistics facilities and services, from any type of prohibitory orders amid the coronavirus scare so that there is no shortage of essential items for consumers.“We get geared. All delivery staff geared. Happy to serve the nation. They start deliveries and cops stop them, some got beaten also. We had to shut down,” said a Bigbasket spokesperson.Online grocery players are seeing a spike of 80-100% in orders over the weekend as customers across metros start stocking up staples like flour, rice and pulses besides disinfectants, hand sanitisers, diapers, and personal care items, TOI had reported last Monday.These companies have also started taking precautionary measures, like getting delivery personnel checked for temperatures every day, educating them about sanitising before and after deliveries, besides offering the option to consumers of contactless deliveries.

Title: Patna residents say no to home deliveries
Content: PATNA: As the global outbreak of Covid-19 is driving people away from restaurants, most residents have also stopped ordering food, clothes, apparels and other products for home deliveries through web portals or mobile applications to avoid any contact with delivery boys.Rachna Kumari of Ashiana Colony said she loves to eat out with friends but avoiding it since the Covid-19 outbreak. “I even avoid home deliveries of food because it all comes from a restaurant. We do not know how much cleanliness they maintain while cooking,” she said.Kamlesh Kumar Sinha of Hanuman Nagar said it is better to avoid meals from restaurant at this time. “We need to maintain hygiene at home. I even cancelled the products and clothes I had ordered online,” Sinha said.In several localities, the security guards have been told to allow only contactless deliveries. Suranjana Singh, a resident of Boring Canal Road, said the security guards had been asked to don protective gears while receiving any parcel. “So, we are rest assured that the parcel coming from warehouse of any brand would not affect us,” she said.A delivery boy of a private platform, Mukesh, said he had never witnessed such a huge dip in home deliveries. “Usually, I got up to 12 orders for home delivery, but now hardly get even three,” he said.Meanwhile, the city restaurants and eatery shops claimed 85% drop in order of meal for home deliveries, even though a number of restrictions have been placed in the eateries to prevent the spread of the Covid-19.Nishant Singhan, owner of a fast food outlet on Bailey Road, said hardly 8-9 persons were visiting his restaurant per day. “Earlier, more than 40 people used to dine at our restaurant,” he claimed.Manish, a sales executive at a restaurant near Dak Bungalow, said they stopped home deliveries for lack of demand for the last couple of days.

Title: Coronavirus scare: ‘My employer told me to return home’
Content: PATNA: People from different districts in the state, who were working in Mumbai, Pune and Gujarat, heaved a sigh of relief after somehow returning to Patna in crowded trains on Sunday.Devendra Raut, a passenger, said he somehow managed to board the train at Lokmanya Tilak Terminal in Mumbai along with five more people to return to Patna. “I work as mason at a construction site in Mumbai. We all reached here stuffed inside coaches and lying on one another,” Raut said. “Our contractor gave us Rs 2000 each to travel to Patna,” he added.Vijendra Kumar Thakur, a daily wager who reached Patna Junction from Pune, said his employer told him to return home in the wake of coronavirus outbreak in Maharashtra. “We were without food for the last four days. Our employers have told us that they will contact us after the situation normalises,” he said.Hans Lal, a resident of Koili village in Muzaffarpur, said he and three others returned after their family members in Bihar sent them Rs 8,000. He complained that they were not screened by anyone at Danapur railway station.Amit Kumar, employee of an MNC, who reached Patna Junction from Mumbai in a Guwahati-bound train, said the AC coach in which he was travelling had become a general one with daily wagers also travelling in it.Shriniwas Mangalam, an UPSC aspirant, said all passengers were taken to a railway school from Danapur for screening.

Title: Lockdown hits plan to get skeletal staff at banks
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Banks will be open for only essential services, such as cash and cheque deposits, cash withdrawal and government transactions.

However, with the lockdown in 75 districts, senior bankers say that manning all branches, even with a skeletal staff, will pose challenges.

State governments like Maharashtra have announced a lockdown except for essential services. So, banks are excluded as they come under essential services. Banks can only shut shop if the necessary orders are issued by the government under the 139-year-old Negotiable Instruments Act.

A statement by the Indian Banks’ Association on basic services was issued before the government on Sunday announced a lockdown in 75 districts, including most of the metros. Bank officials say that in cities like Mumbai, getting staff to branches would be a challenge as most are dependent on public transport, which will be skeletal.

Many branches are looking at getting employees to work in branches by rotation, although this will end up exposing all employees to risk. One branch manager said that employees who were at higher risk because of health conditions were allowed to stay at home. Some banks are looking at asking staff to report to the nearest branch. But even in such cases, the attendance will have to be in pairs as the core banking system follows a ‘maker’ and ‘checker’ system using biometric authentication.

While no ‘work from home’ option has been extended to frontline staff, branch staff say that they fear exposure. Not all staff members are willing to take up the cashier function and some even fear that handling currency notes may not be hygienic.

Private banks are allowing personal bankers and relationship managers to work from home. While most banks provide ‘anywhere banking’, some customers were upset at being slapped with hefty charges for depositing cash in a ‘non-home’ branch.

Title: India Inc steps up to fund fight against coronavirus
Content:
More on Covid-19

MUMBAI: Corporate India is increasingly revealing its generous side to commit assistance in various forms in the country’s fight against the virus. Billionaire Anil Agarwal said his company Vedanta is setting aside Rs 100 crore initially to support daily wage workers and contract employees working at the mining giant’s factories in India. If the need arises, the company will increase the corpus, said its chairman Agarwal.Industrialist Anand Mahindra will contribute 100% of his salary over the next few months to a fund created by his automobile-to-hospitality group’s philanthropic arm, which will assist those who have been hit hard in the value chain, such as small businesses and the self-employed. The chairman of Mahindra & Mahindra earned a remuneration of Rs 9 crore in fiscal 2019.Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma is committing Rs 5 crore to help accelerate development of medical solutions. “We need more Indian innovators to start building indigenous solutions for potential ventilator shortage...Paytm commits Rs 5 crore to teams working on Covid-19 related medical solutions,” Sharma said in response to a message floated on Twitter by an IISc professor that his small team of engineers are working on a prototype ventilator using Indian ingredients.The announcements come after Jack Ma Foundation and Alibaba Foundation announced their support to affected geographies. Bill Gates also committed $100 million to aid global research on the treatment of Covid-19. With global billionaires announcing large commitments, Indian entrepreneurs faced some criticism for not thinking along similar lines soon enough.Mahindra said his enterprise will “immediately” begin work on how its manufacturing facilities can make ventilators. “At Mahindra Holidays, we stand ready to offer our resorts as temporary care facilities. Our project team stands ready to assist the government and the army in erecting temporary care facilities,” tweeted Mahindra. Some hotels are serving as quarantine centres following a shortage of rooms in hospitals because of the rise in numbers of suspected Covid-19 patients.Vedanta said it will not cut salaries or fire any of its employees, including casual workers during this crisis period. Besides, it will provide a special one-time insurance to cover employees and their families against Covid-19. Tata Group, too, said earlier that it will not cut the wages of temps working in its offices and sites.Hindustan Unilever was the first to announce a Rs 100-crore commitment to tackle the Covid-19 outbreak.

Title: Markets to have normal hrs today
Content:
Mumbai: Despite mounting pressure to shorten trading hours for stock and debt markets as brokers are working with a skeletal staff, Sebi on Sunday evening said markets will continue to function in regular trading hours. On one hand, there was pressure on the regulator to shorten trading hours, which would allow office staff to cut down on exposure to other people, on the other hand, in the government , there were concerns if such a move could send wrong signals to global investors about one of the largest economies of the world.

There was demand for a complete closure of trading for a few days too, however, that was opposed by a large section of brokers, especially those carrying large open positions. Also the expiry of this month’s derivatives contracts are due on March 26, which also weighed on the regulator and the government, sources said.

Through similarly worded statements, the NSE and the BSE said all segments of the exchanges “will operate as usual on Monday”.The government, Sebi and the stock exchanges are expected to take a decision about the trading on the exchanges on Monday, sources said.

Title: Kolkata markets limit sale of veggies to curb hoarding
Content: KOLKATA: Several wholesale and retail shops in Kolkata — including the 145 state-run Sufal outlets and the 47 KMC-run markets — have set a limit on vegetables to be sold per person to prevent hoarding and panic buying in the lockdown phase next week. The Bengal government has allayed fears of any problem in the availability of essential items during the lockdown period from March 23 to March 27.State food and civil supplies minister Jyotipriya Mallick said, “I am convening an emergency meeting at noon on Monday with all the ration dealers, LPG dealers, kerosene dealers, petrol pump operators and representatives of oil marketing companies. I will issue a guideline for emergency services. I have withdrawn the weekly closure of ration shops; they will be operative all seven days.”The agriculture marketing department will ration potato and onion sales from Monday through the Sufal outlets. “We have decided to allot 3kg potato and 1kg onion, which will be sold below the market price,” said an official.Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s market department has constituted a team to check that people don’t indulge in panic buying or hoarding. At Koley Market, buyers will be allowed to buy only 5kg each of potato and onion and 2kg each of ginger and garlic. Retailers will be allowed to buy a sack each, sources said.Traders said there will be a slight shortage of vegetables in the city markets as 90% of the day’s supply comes by train. These small vendors and farmers have no capacity to hire goods vehicles to reach out to city markets. “If the government can find some way out for these marginal farmers and vendors, they will be saved from losses,” said West Bengal Farmers and Vendors’ Association president Kamal Dey.“They need to carry a board saying ‘essential items’ on their vehicles so that they are not blocked by law-enforcing agencies,” said Mallick.He added that all fuel stations will be open, but the employees of these emergency services must take adequate measures — like use of masks, gloves and frequent use of hand-sanitizers.Pradip Mazumdar, agriculture advisor to the state, said, “There will be no dearth of commodities and we have enough supply of staples. The government will take measures if any person faces any issue on availability or prices.”Consumer affairs minister Sadhan Pandey said, “If people have any problem with price, quality and quantity of essential items, they can lodge a complaint with my office.”However, some commodities which come from other states may face some issues. Fish and egg, much of which come from Andhra Pradesh, as well as some fruits and onion come from Maharastra , may be short in supply since interstate freight movement is stopped.“The government has allowed movement of essential items and we hope there will not be any trouble in supplying goods to the city. But we are facing trouble with the interstate movement of essential goods, like medicine and fish. Some of our trucks carrying medicine are stuck in Mumbai while several trucks are stranded in Karnataka . We have sought the state’s help to ease the situation. Cereals and oil are also brought from other states. There are 4 lakh-5 lakh trucks that bring both essential and non-essential supplies into the state,” said Subhas Bose , president of Federation of Truck Operators’ Association.

Title: Covid-19 scare in West Bengal: Govt asks hotels to assign self-isolation rooms for guests returning from abroad
Content: KOLKATA: In an unprecedented development, the state has sought help from hoteliers to arrange rooms for self-isolation of guests. The health and tourism departments have asked Hotel and Restaurants Association of Eastern India (HRAEI) to request their members to assign rooms for this purpose and HRAEI secretary Sudesh Poddar told TOI the association has already written to its members.“We need to help the health department fight this threat of Covid-19 . We have been asked to request our hotel owner members to allocate rooms in their establishments for self-isolation of the large number of people returning home from various countries. Currently, some of them are housed at government facilities at New town,” he added, pointing out that some of these people would prefer to stay in hotel rooms.T S Walia, former national president of Federation of Hotels and Restaurants Association of India (FHRAI) told TOI that it has received positive response from many of its members. “We have arranged 300 rooms for this purpose. Our association is confident that in another two-three days, we can arrange 600-700 rooms in the city for self-isolation,” he said. Walia added that all members who have agreed to assign rooms are ready to offer the facility on a cost-to-cost basis. “The charges will be Rs 3,000-Rs 5,000, depending on categories (3-4 star or 5 star), which would include breakfast, lunch and dinner,” he said.Poddar said that at present there are 2,500-2,600 rooms in five-star and five-star deluxe categories in the city while there are 2,000-plus rooms in 3-star and 4-star categories.

Title: Companies cover may lapse on shutdowns
Content: MUMBAI: Large corporations risk lapsing insurance policies for their plant and machinery as well as people since both insurers and corporates are forced to shut shop because of the coronavirus lockdown.Insurance brokers have approached the regulator Irdai on behalf of their clients, asking for a law to be diluted that prevents the insurers from providing cover until the premium is received. Most non-life policies are annual contracts. While they can be purchased at any time of the year, on most occasions it is done to coincide with the fiscal as it makes accounting for the premium much easier.The Insurance Brokers Association of India ( IBAI ) has written to the regulator to consider permitting extension of existing policies for a minimum of 60 days by paying pro-rata premium at existing terms and rates. For this extended cover to be seamless, insurance companies need to receive the premium before the earlier policy expires.“The Indian insurance market adheres to Section 64VB of the Insurance Act, which further increases the complexity of policies expiring on March 31, 2020,” said IBAI president Sanjay Kedia in a letter to the chairman of sector regulator Irdai.According to Kedia, Lloyds of London has already allowed an extension to existing policies due to the Covid-19 threat. Most global insurance markets have also provided relaxation to policyholders through an auto-extension clause.“Administratively ensuring compliance to Section 64VB will be very challenging for both policyholders as well as insurers. Thus, we request the authority to consider temporarily waiving the 64VB clause for another 30 days, so that policyholders may continue their coverage and make premium payable at a later date,” IBAI said.

Title: Bodh Gaya temple driver’s death fuels Covid-19 fear
Content:
GAYA: Death of one Arjun Kumar, a driver working in the Bodh Gaya Temple Management Committee (BTMC) office, has fuelled Covid-19 fear in the district.

The driver died early Sunday morning. The medical staff who handled the dead and his immediate family members have been quarantined and the man was in his early 40s. Confirming the driver’s death, district magistrate Abhishek Singh, ex-officio chairman of BTMC, said the driver’s employer has claimed that as per medical reports, the driver had a history of bronchitis.

Agreeing that such people are more vulnerable to Covid-19 virus, the DM said that all measures are being taken to ascertain whether the deceased person had made any contact with the virus. He said that swab has been collected from the dead man’s body and sent to biological lab for testing. As a precautionary measure, the doctor and other medical staff along with the immediate family members of the deceased driver have been quarantined.

“The driver’s body would be cremated as per the Covid-19 protocol that stipulates proper covering of the body and segregation of the bereaved people, who would not be allowed near the body during the cremation,” he said.

As per available statistics, 19,095 passengers of Air India international flights and several foreign airlines disembarked at the Gaya International airport between January 29–March 20. Most international fliers were foreign nationals. Two Bodh Gaya hotels have been notified as quarantine centres.

Earlier, on Saturday, two passengers of the Thai Smile Airways flight number WE327, who landed at the Gaya airport with Covid-19 symptoms were sent to the isolation ward of the ANMMCH. Samples collected from the two air passengers, both of them residents of Gorakhpur (UP) have been sent to the virological lab for examination. The 10 other passengers of the flight were advised home isolation. The plane was thoroughly disinfected at the Gaya airport before boarding for the return flight.

Title: DTOs told to register BS-IV vehicles online
Content:
PATNA: The registration and tax payment of vehicles running on Bharat Stage-IV (BS-IV) technology will be done only through online mode in order to prevent gathering at district transport offices to prevent the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19).

The transport department issued a notification on Sunday regarding the online registration and tax payment on www.vahan.nic.in portal from March 22 till March 31. The deadline for the registration of BS-IV vehicles in India is March 31.

The district transport officers (DTOs) have been asked to complete the registration of BS-IV vehicles on priority basis, while the other work (like permit and driving licence) will remain suspended till March-end.

State transport department secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said entry of common people was banned in all district transport offices to prevent spread of coronavirus. “Besides registration of BS-IV vehicles and tax payment, no other work would be carried out at district transport offices till March 31,” he said.

Agarwal added, “Such vehicles cannot be registered from April 1 as the Supreme Court has ordered that no new motor vehicles with BS-IV emission norms can be sold after March 31.”

Meanwhile, district transport officers (DTOs) have been asked to ban entry of people at district transport offices till further order.

“People have to upload all the required documents, including vehicle papers, on Vahan portal. Papers will be scrutinised by the staff at respective district transport offices and accordingly registration slip will be issued to them. Now, there is no need of hard copies of documents. The tax payment can also be done online,” Agarwal said.

He said people, who purchased new vehicles, would have to coordinate with the automobile dealers. “They will fill the online form and upload the other required documents. Meanwhile, we have waived off technical inspection of the fully-built vehicles till March 31,” Agarwal said.

Title: D-St sees weak trades today
Content: Mumbai: Amid exponentially increasing number of coronavirus infections around the world, global markets — including Dalal Street — are expected to witness fresh selling when they open on Monday. This is mainly because traders are unsure of the economic costs of the Covid-19 pandemic and how both global as well as Indian economies will be hit.Dealers said that the lower closing of Wall Street on Friday — Dow Jones ended down over 900 points, or 4.6%, and the S&P 500 was down 104 points or 4.3% — will weigh on sentiment here on Monday morning. Also, since most brokerages will be operating with a skeletal staff, trading volumes are expected to be much lower than usual, they said.Sebi’s decisions on Friday to tighten trading rules with the aim of making the market safer for investors, which were announced after the exchanges had closed, is also expected to deter traders and speculators from taking risks, dealers said.Institutional dealers also expect foreign institutions — who have net sold stocks, debt and hybrid instruments worth over Rs 1 lakh crore in the Indian market — to continue their selling. This could, on the one hand, pull the benchmark indices down while, on the other, would put pressure on the rupee, they said.

Title: Lockdown in Kolkata: Metro, local trains and cabs to go off the roads
Content: KOLKATA: For the first time since its inception in 1984, Metro Railway services will be suspended for such a long period. On Sunday, the ministry of railways cancelled all services, including those of Kolkata’s Metro, till March 31. All suburban services under Eastern Railway (ER) and South Eastern Railway (SER) will also remain cancelled. The West Bengal State Transport Corporation (WBSTC) has also announced that only a skeletal fleet of buses will be run for those attending to emergency services. Private buses will also remain off Kolkata streets, though operators have said that some vehicles will be prepared to attend to emergencies if the state orders.“No trains started from Howrah, Sealdah or other stations in the state on Sunday, but some that had left other stations before the start of the ‘janata curfew’, arrived during the day. Some special trains are also being run for migrant workers, some of which arrived on Sunday. The remaining will arrive subsequently. We shall run no suburban services. To avoid gatherings at booking counters and stations, cancellation rules have also been tweaked to allow for more time. Those whose trains have been cancelled will get a full refund,” a railway official said.While freight trains will continue to operate, supply of some items, like fish and eggs, may be hit due to cancellation of passenger trains. Fish and eggs from the southern states come to Bengal in trucks, as well as in parcels in mail/express trains. People from the suburbs employed in the emergency sector are also facing uncertainty due to cancellation of local trains. The supply of vegetables and other food items to several locations are also likely to be affected. Railway officials have, however, maintained that the primary objective now is to prevent the spread of Covid-19, even if it leads to some difficulties.“We will run a bare minimum number of buses for people engaged in essential services. We may follow the night-service model where hospitals, IT and ITES hubs will be connected. Normal bus services will be suspended,” a WBSTC official said.The Bengal Taxi Association (BTA), the city’s largest association of taxi operators in Kolkata, will run a fleet of 1,000 vehicles on a demand basis. “People in an emergency can call us at 033-24753505, 033-24742249, 9339053605 or 9831364824. On Sunday, during the ‘janata curfew’, we ferried people to hospitals. During the lockdown, we will provide doorstep services to those in need,” a BTA official said.App cab services are likely to remain cancelled during the lockdown, but some vehicles may be available for essential demand-based trips. Autos will also be off the streets at most places. Some that operate within localities may ply for emergency passengers.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Uttar Pradesh: People of three villages isolated after one tests positive
Content: VARANASI: After confirmation of a Covid-19 positive patient in Chitaura village on Saturday evening, over 10,000 villagers of Chitaura and two adjoining villages were home quarantined.Thermal scanning and sample collection of the villagers were also conducted and villages were sanitised.On Saturday late evening, the district’s first coronavirus positive case was confirmed after the Banaras Hindu University’s laboratory report was released. District magistrate said that a 30-year-old man from Chitaura village of Pindra area under the limits of Phoolpur police station was detected as Covid-19 positive.The man, who worked as a cook on a cruise, had boarded a flight to Delhi from Dubai on March 17. On March 18, he reached Varanasi by train, said the DM adding that, on reaching home he complained of cough. He reached DDU district hospital on March 19 from where his sample was sent to BHU laboratory and his report confirmed a positive case of Covid-19 on Saturday late evening. The health teams were rushed to Chitaura village on Saturday night to quarantine the villagers at their home.Apart from Chitaura, its neighbouring Odhar and Rajpur villages were also isolated. Total population of these villages, including 1,678 of Chitaura, 3,421 of Odhar and 5,694 of Rajpur has been quarantined, said the DM adding that thermal screening of each villager had been done in Chitaura by late afternoon while the process was in progress at Odhar and Rajpur.Samples of six family members of Covid-19 positive man had been collected and sent to laboratory for test, said Sharma, adding that sanitisation work and distribution of pamphlets containing complete details and precautions on coronavirus in the villages has also been completed.A total of eight barriers have been installed to stop the movement of people from these villages while 31 policemen have been deployed to monitor the situation in three shifts, said the DM. Apart from sanitary staff team, three medical teams have also been deployed there.

Title: Bihar: RJD questions Nitish Kumar government’s preparedness to tackle Covid-19
Content: PATNA: Leader of the Opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav on Sunday questioned Nitish Kumar government’s preparedness to tackle Covid-19 pandemic.In a series of tweets on Sunday morning, the RJD neta raised concerns on state government’s approach and availability of resources with regard to conducting tests for corona virus. “There is no Corona testing Centre in Bihar , only sample collections, then samples are sent to Kolkata that takes 12 hours. These samples if tested after 6hours doesn’t show the real result. That's why many results are showing negative. Why Central & state governments are not coordinating? (sic),” Tejashwi stated in a tweet.In another tweet he said: “With one testing centre, which is actually a sample collection center for 12 crore population of Bihar, #COVID19 will wreak havoc. Either fight it hard now or face a massive epidemic. Testing and Testing alone can mitigate the eventual outbreak. Buy testing kits, setup labs! (sic).”Apart from testing centres, Tejashwi also expressed concern over shortage of several other essential medical equipment. “The third most populous state, Bihar, needs to build its capacity manifolds to fight #Corona. Few testing kits, few personal protective equipment (PPE), not enough ventilators, not enough ICU beds, not enough ECMOs. Ramp up procurement of these or else exponential outbreak is looming (sic),” he tweeted.Meanwhile, health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar told a news channel on Sunday evening that the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has approved sample collection kits to be provided to the Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS), Patna, as well.“As of now, we have connected all government hospitals in all 38 districts to nine medical college and hospitals for collecting samples. The samples are being tested at Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI), Patna and Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital (DMCH). But I have been told this evening that ICMR has given its nod to conduct the test at IGIMS as well. Thus, we now have three testing centres,” he said.A senior official in health department, however, said it will take around 10 days for commencement of the process of tests for Covid-19 at DMCH and IGIMS owing to some technical issues.Health experts also claimed that though samples, including throat swab, remain effective for tests for more than 12 hours, the government needs to open more testing centres.“The tests for Covid-19 and many other viruses require Real-Time Polymerase Chain (RTPCR) reaction kits and machines. Given the reports of positive cases coming in Bihar from Sunday and a large number of migratory population and the the high population density, it is needed that RTPCR machines be made available in different districts or at least divisions and the testings be decentralized,” Patna-based physician Dr Diwakar Tejashwi said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Over 3,000 reach Bihar from Mumbai, Pune
Content: PATNA/ARA: Two special trains carrying about 3,000 passengers from Mumbai and Pune reached Danapur station on Sunday. Soon after the two trains stopped at Danapur station, the passengers were taken to the railway high school in Khagaul for screening. Later in the day, the passengers were sent to their home distriicts in 60 buses provided by the transport department. Those with coronavirus symptoms got ‘home quarantined’ tag on their hands.Danapur divisional railway manager (DRM) Sunil Kumar said the special train from Mumbai brought 1,400 passengers. While 46 of them got down at Buxar and 36 at Ara stations, the rest reached Danapur station around 10.30am. The passengers who got down at Buxar and Ara were allowed to go home after screening. However, those who complained of mild fever were segregated from others and a team of doctors conducted further medical check up on them.At Danapur, the state government had set up a makeshift medical camp on the campus of the railway high school for thorough thermal screening of the passengers. RPF, RPSF and GRP personnel were deployed at Danapur station to assist the passengers on their arrival. Patna DM Kumar Ravi and SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma personally supervised the screening process.The special train from Pune carrying about 1,600 passengers reached Danapur around 2.15pm. A mobile medical team of railway doctors and paramedical staff conducted their primary check-up aboard the train after it left Pt Deen Dayal Upadhaya Junction.Meanwhile, state transport department secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the buses which carried the passengers to their home districts were sanitized in the morning. “The district magistrates have been asked to ensure that the passengers marked with ‘home quarantined’ tag remain in their homes,” he said.Bhojpur DM Roshan Kushwaha advised the passengers who reached Ara station from Pune and Mumbai to stay indoors at least for the next 14 days. He added that passengers coming from Bengaluru were also screened.

Title: Nagpur: Five held for gang-raping teen, thrashing her friend
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: The local crime branch (LCB) of rural police have arrested five persons for gang-raping a 19-year-old girl and thrashing her friend in a jungle near Navegaon village on March 17.

The call, made by the accused, threatening the survivor of putting her gang rape videos on social media if she reported the matter to the cops, was traced and five arrests were made. The LCB sleuths, led by PI Anil Jittawar, busted the gang within 24 hours.

The accused have been identified as Akash Lende, Sunil alias Sumit Gawli , Suraj Mane , Chandrashekhar Kadav and Pankaj Kuthve .

According to the police, the survivor and her friend, who hails from the city, had gone to a temple in Khairi village on March 17. They were returning to the city when suddenly their bike suffered a breakdown. They were trying to start the bike when five accused approached them. The accused started abusing the duo and snatched their mobile phones.

While one of the accused was busy thrashing the survivor’s friend, the others took her to a secluded place where they took turns to rape her. Later, the accused took the duo to the Kuhi bus stop from where they fled.

The accused also took the mobile number of the survivor from her friend’s mobile. They later called and threatened her.

On Saturday, the survivor approached tehsil police and lodged a complaint. Tehsil cops sent a zero FIR to Kuhi police station as the incident took place in their jurisdiction. After the rural police swung into action, LCB sleuths nabbed the accused by tracking the mobile number from which they had called the survivor.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Pune: Light rain likely in next few days, forecasts IMD
Content:
The empty JM Road on Sunday afternoon

PUNE: The city will get very light to light rain along with thunderstorm, dusty wind and hailstorm in isolated locations in the next few days, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said on Sunday.

“There is a high chance of very light to light rainfall in the city and the district between Tuesday evening and Wednesday. It will also be associated with some thundery activity. Occurrence of hailstorm in isolated locations in the district is also likely,” head of the forecast division of IMD, Pune, Anupam Kashyapi told TOI on Sunday.

The Met department said these conditions could impact the day and night temperatures. “The maximum temperature would hover between 32-33°C. The night temperature would remain between 17-18°C for the next few days,” Kashyapi said.

“There would be wind discontinuity in the easterlies that will develop over Madhya Maharashtra to coastal Karnataka, and it will fluctuate between Vidarbha, coastal Karnataka and Goa. As a result, there will be an interaction between winds coming from the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal. This will bring light rain over the Madhya Maharashtra region, including Pune,” Kashyapi said.

On Sunday, the Shivajinagar and Lohegaon observatories recorded maximum temperatures of 36.2°C and 36.6°C day respectively. The minimums recorded were 17.6°C and 19.6°C respectively.

Employees continue work

As many as 100 staffers and experts working for the weather forecast division of IMD will work as per the daily schedule. “Monitoring daily weather phenomenon is essential and our staffers and experts will continue their work with due precautions in place. Working under the current circumstances is a challenging task but they have responded positively to the national cause,” Kashyapi said.

Title: Corona threat: Family postpones terahvi
Content:
Varanasi: At a time when celebrity like Kanika Kapoor, who tested Covid-19 positive, and her high-profile admirers showed utter carelessness by partying is such a sensitive situation, a family in remote village of Ballia district set an example of responsible citizens by postponing the last rituals of their mother to maintain social distnacing.

Family of Premchand Gupta, Motichand Gupta and Lakhichand Gupta in Amrit Pali village in Dubahad area of Ballia postponed the ‘Brahmbhoj’ and ‘Terahvi’ of their mother earlier scheduled on Monday in the wake of Covid-19 threat and the call of janata curfew given by the PM . They have informed their relatives about the change in the plans

“We did not want to pose a threat to the lives of invitees,” said Premchand adding, “We have informed all our relatives and friends about the change.” he said.

Meanwhile, the district witnessed a tremendous response to janata curfew on Sunday. All the shops and eateries will remain closed till March 25 in Azamgarh district.

Title: Maharashtra: Court grants interim bail to actor in Rs 97 lakh cheating case
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Additional sessions judge S M Agarkar on Saturday granted interim protection till March 31 to noted actor Vikram Gokhale in a Rs 96.99 lakh cheating and forgery case.

The complaint had been lodged by an investor in a plot scheme at Girivan project in Dongargaon and Hotale villages in Mulshi taluka, about 40km from here.

The court also directed notices to be issued to the police for their written submission on the pre-arrest bail pleas moved by Jayant Mhalgi and Sujata Mhalgi, the two directors of the Sujata Farms Private Limited, which floated the Girivan project. These two pleas are scheduled for a hearing on March 24.

Judge Agarkar observed, “Documents on record show that, land mentioned in sale deed is mutated in the name of the complainant. Memorandum of Association and Article of Association (of Sujata Farms) shows Jayant Mhalgi and Sujata Mhalgi are the first directors of the company. There is no reference of the name of the applicant (Gokhale) or post of chairman therein.”

“Thus, considering the nature of the accusation in the FIR and the submission made by counsel for the applicant, it prima facie appears to me that, the immediate custodial interrogation of the applicant is not necessary. It also appears to me that, if interim protection is granted, it will not adversely affect the investigation. Hence, applicant has made out case for interim protection till next date.”

The court directed that in the event of his arrest, Gokhale must be released on interim pre-arrest bail against a personal bond of Rs15,000 and a surety in the like amount. The actor has been directed to make himself available as and when called for questioning by police officer and shall not, directly or indirectly, influence witnesses, besides, he shall not leave India without the court’s permission.

Gokhale’s lawyers — Upendra Khare, Rushikesh Ganu and Shivraj Joshi — had argued that their client is neither chairman nor director of Sujata Farms nor does he hold any rights in the company; that he is not related with the company but on the latter’s request, had allowed the use of his name and celebrity status for the purpose of promoting the project campaign in 1997 against a minor honorarium.

The lawyers argued that the actor was not party to any documents executed between the company and the plot holders and did not receive any consideration in the plot scheme. Nowhere did he indulge in any of the company’s affairs, they submitted.

Title: Covid-19: Metro shut till end of month; just 25 per cent of DTC buses to ply
