Content: NEW DELHI: With the capital getting locked down from 6am on Monday, all public transport in Delhi will also come to a grinding halt, except for one-fourth of Delhi Transport Corporation buses, which will also ferry only those involved in essential services.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday evening announced the lockdown to ensure that the spread of Covid-19 is minimised in the capital. Earlier in the day, Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) had already announced that its train services, which were closed on Sunday too, will be suspended till March 31. Delhi government added all public service vehicles to the list while announcing the lockdown.Other modes of transport such as autorickshaws, app-based cabs, kaali-peeli taxis, private buses, e-rickshaws, cycle rickshaws, Grameen Sewa, maxi cabs, eco-friendly, Phat Phat Sewa etc. will not be permitted to operate either. Movement of interstate buses have been suspended and train services were deferred till the end of the month earlier in the day by Indian Railways.Delhi government has allowed only 25% buses of the DTC fleet to operate from Monday. As a result, around 950 buses will ply in the capital, only for helping those involved in essential services to reach their workplace and then back home. Private vehicles ferrying those involved in essential services will be exempted from the lockdown order. People who come out to provide essential services shall be allowed on their self-declaration.In neighbouring Noida too, public transport services, interstate trains and buses have also been suspended till March 31. The Noida Metro Rail Corporation, which operates the Aqua Line, has announced that all its metro and the city bus services will not function.Delhi Metro, which is the lifeline of the capital and also connects it to neighbouring Gurgaon, Noida, Ghaziabad and Faridabad, had announced earlier on Saturday that its train services will remain suspended till the end of March. DMRC had already announced a slew of measures to reduce footfalls in metro trains on Thursday and then said it will not operate trains on Sunday in the wake of janata curfew, followed by the announcement that metro services for general public will be only available for six hours on Monday. Finally came the announcement of a complete closedown“The Delhi Metro system will continue to be powered for essential internal operational maintenance activities during this duration and security of the system will continue to be taken care of by CISF,” a DMRC spokesperson said.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: CM Nitish Kumar urges Centre to suspend air services to Bihar
Content:
Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: CM Nitish Kumar on Sunday urged the Centre to suspend the operation of all Bihar-bound flights for some days in the wake of Covid-19. Nitish spoke to civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri over phone in this regard in order to check further spread of coronavirus in the region, an official at chief minister’s office (CMO) told TOI. Bihar has two operating airports at Patna and Gaya.

Nitish also thanked the Centre for accepting his request to suspend the operation of all passenger trains and interstate buses from Sunday. “I had made a request to the Centre for suspending operation of passenger trains and interstate-buses in the wake of Covid-19,” Nitish said in a press note issued on Sunday.

The CM expressed grief over a person’s death due to coronavirus in Bihar and ordered payment of prescribed financial assistance (Rs4 lakh) to the next of kin of the victim from the CM Relief Fund.

Title: Delhi Budget 2020: Delhi budget today in one-day session
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Delhi government will present the budget for the financial year 2020-21 on Monday in a session that has been curtailed from five days to one day due to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

Soon after the House meets at 2pm, finance minister Manish Sisodia will present Economic Survey 2019-20 and the status report of the outcome budget 2019-20 (up to December 2019), following which the first annual budget of the third Kejriwal government will be tabled and passed.

Following the outbreak, visitors have been barred from attending the session, which had been earlier scheduled from March 23 to 27.

‘Kejriwal Ki Guarantee’, promised by AAP during the assembly election campaign, is likely to form the base of the budget. Its size is likely to increase by 10% from last year’s Rs 60,000 crore, a source said.

The budget is likely to focus on boosting the public transport system by increasing the number of buses and expanding the Delhi Metro network; reducing pollution by one third of the current level; releasing funds for specific purposes such as sanitation to the municipal corporations; providing infrastructure in unauthorised colonies and houses to slum dwellers; and ensuring 24x7 water supply across Delhi. Steps to improve education and healthcare facilities and make Delhi safer for women will also be incorporated.

Sisodia, who will present his sixth budget, will separately present the supplementary demands for grants for 2019-20 and 2020-21, and the appropriation bills 2020, which will be considered and passed by the House.

The consultative process began soon after the formation of the government after AAP’s landslide victory. The revenue generating branches like excise, trade and taxes, and revenue departments are likely to be given higher targets instead of the usual increase of 10%, a source said.

Under the AAP governments, the size of the Delhi budget has grown steadily. In 2015-16, the size of the budget was Rs 41,500 crore, which grew to Rs 46,600 crore in 2016-17, Rs 48,000 crore in 2017-18 and Rs 53,000 crore in 2018-19, before touching Rs 60,000 crore in the last year.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: No metro in off-peak hours tomorrow
Content: NEW DELHI: In what could be a sign of things to come, Delhi Metro is going to regulate train services on Monday after these remain closed on Sunday because of the ‘ Janata curfew ’. Parking, however, at all metro stations will remain closed.On Monday, Delhi Metro services for general public will be available only from 8 am to 10 am and again from 4 pm to 8 pm. From 6 am to 8 am, only those involved in essential services will be allowed to enter metro stations and there will be no metro services from 10 am to 4 pm and after 8 pm.“Metro train services will start from 6 am across originating stations of all lines and will be available at a frequency of 20 minutes till 8 am. During this period, only people involved in essential services like hospitals, fire, electricity, police etc. will be allowed to enter metro stations on producing their identification cards before security personnel,” said Anuj Dayal, executive director (corporate communications), Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC).From 8 am to 10 am, trains will be available at a normal frequency and general public will be able to travel without requiring any identification. Though there will be no metro serviceS between 10 am and 4 pm, all trains which start at 10 am from the originating stations will continue to run till they reach their destination. Similarly, there will be no metro service from 8 pm onwards but the last train starting at 8 pm from the originating station will continue to run till it reaches its destination.“The objective of this staggered service plan on Monday is aimed at facilitating all stakeholders with effectiveness and promote ‘social distancing’ which is very much required to contain spread of coronavirus ,” said Dayal.“DMRC again appeals to and advises general public not to panic and stay at home and use the metro only when it is essential and unavoidable,” said Dayal.“In the prevalent scenario where authorities have shut malls, restaurants and major markets to prevent spread of the virus, it is responsibility of our passengers also to cooperate with DMRC and help fight the coronavirus collectively,” he said.Dayal said that while the plan for the modified metro services are applicable for Monday, March 23 only, if there was any further requirement to continue it in the larger public interest, people will be informed.

Title: 17 security personnel killed in deadliest Maoist ambush in Chhattisgarh in 3 years
Content:
ANI photo

RAIPUR: Maoists ambushed security forces in Elmaguda forest of Sukma district late Saturday, killing 17 of them, injuring 15 and looting a light machinegun and 12 AK47s. This is the biggest death toll among the forces in Chhattisgarh in three years, and the first major attack in the current Congress regime. All those killed were from District Reserve Guards — comprising mostly local youth and surrendered Maoists who are at home in inhospitable terrain and are very tough fighters — and STF.

Police believe several Maoists were also killed in the five-hour-long gunfight — one of the most intense in years — but no body has been found yet. The rebels are believed to have used UBGLs — rife-fired grenades —which acted as a force multiplier and had a devastating effect. The encounter took place in the forests close to Minpa and Kasalpad, in the Maoist hotbed of Sukma.

The site of ambush is not far from where the April 2017 attack in Chintagufa, in which 25 CRPF jawans were martyred, took place. “We recovered 17 bodies from the encounter site on Sunday. All the 15 injured personnel are undergoing treatment at a hospital in Raipur after they were airlifted from Sukma,” DGP Durgesh Madhav Awasthi told TOI on Sunday. Maoists — apparently from dreaded 1 Battalion — had set up IED traps for securitymen and taken firing positions on high ground.

Senior police officers told TOI late Saturday night that a 150-strong team of CRPF’s CoBRA commandos, STF, and DRG set out on an operation following intelligence inputs about the presence of a large number of Maoists in the region. Maoists — apparently from the dreaded 1 Battalion — had set up IED traps for the securitymen and taken firing positions on high ground. When the forces came within range, the rebels triggered explosions and laid down heavy fire from well camouflaged positions.

Though taken by surprise, the forces retaliated strongly and a five-hour gunfight ensued. Initial reports said many Maoists were also killed in the ambush but police said they are yet to find any of the bodies as the rebels drag away their dead and injured.

After the gunfight, when police took stock of the situation, 17 personnel were found to be missing, including 12 from DRG. Senior officers clung to hope that the DRG personnel — battle-hardened tribals who know the jungle very well — had dispersed during the encounter and would make their way back to base. This has happened earlier. But not so today. CoBRA commandos led a search party into the encounter site early Sunday morning.

They moved cautiously since Maoists are known to ambush rescue teams. Security personnel flew drones over the encounter spot. Rescue ops were complicated by rain but by afternoon, the grim reality was out. The bodies of 17 jawans were found on the forest floor. Maoists had looted an LMG, 14 assault rifles and an under-barrel grenade launcher (UBGL) from the martyred troops.

The bodies were shifted to a nearby base. This is the first time that DRG suffered such a heavy toll. The unit comprises mostly local youth and surrendered Maoists who are at home in inhospitable terrain and are very tough fighters. DRG has added muscle to counterinsurgency operations, particularly in South Bastar, say police.

This is the first major Maoist attack after in December 2018, and the biggest since the Chintagufa ambush of April 2017. About 90 CRPF jawans were sanitising a road that was being built in the area when 300-odd Maoists, divided into multiple groups, attacked the CRPF party. Only a month before, 12 CRPF men were killed in a Maoist ambush in Sukma.

Title: One booked in Pune on charge of harassment
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kothrud police registered an offence against a software engineer on Saturday for allegedly stalking and outraging the modesty of a 33-year-old woman.

An officer from the Kothrud police said the woman and the suspect met through a matrimonial website. “The suspect had proposed marriage to her,” the officer said.

The officer said eventually the woman decided against marrying him after she came to know that the man was married.

He said she thus stopped responding to the techie’s calls.

“When the woman was on her way to work on Saturday the suspect blocked her way at Kothrud and started abusing her. He also touched her inappropriately,” he said.

The terrified woman rushed to the Kothrud police and lodged the complaint.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Pune: Four youths snatch woman’s purse
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Four youths wearing masks snatched a 35-year-old woman’s purse comprising Rs 5,200 on Saturday afternoon.

The incident occurred near Triveninagar in Nigdi, when the woman was walking back home.

SS Ohol, the sub-inspector of the Nigdi police station, told TOI that the complainant was working as a domestic help in the Nigdi Pradhikaran area.

“The woman started walking home around 11.30am on Saturday. When she reached near the Triveninagar Chowk, four youths riding on a black two-wheeler stopped near her,” the officer said.

He said that the youngster who was sitting in the middle on the scooter snatched the woman’s purse, which comprised Rs5,200.

The scooter driver took a U-turn and they then went in the opposite direction.

“The woman raised an alarm. but, there were very few people on the road,” Ohol said.

The woman told the police that all the four youths were wearing masks. “We have started checking criminals on police records. But, most of the houses are locked as people have gone out of the city,” Ohol said.

He said most of the establishments were locked as well because of which they had to wait for the CCTV camera footage, which would help ascertain the identities of the suspects.

“We are working on some clues. Our investigation is on,” the sub-inspector added.

Title: Nagpur: Janta curfew hits railway, bus, air travellers hard
Content: NAGPUR: The ‘janta curfew’ hit commuters hard with curtailed air, railway and bus transportation on Sunday.According to airport sources, as against 30 flights operating from the city, the number came down to 12 on Sunday. Similarly, till 9pm, the number of trains that arrived at station was 28. Over 125 trains, including originating ones, operate from the city.Even as the number of air passengers travelling to Nagpur on Sunday has to be compiled, the traffic was evidently low. “In the normal course on an average daily passenger flow at Nagpur airport is 3,500. This has come down by 50% after the virus outbreak,” sources said.Similarly, Nagpur railway station, which daily witnesses traffic flow of over 75,000 passengers, wore a deserted look on Sunday. Only 1,541 passengers arrived from 28 mail/express trains that arrived till 9pm on Sunday.The last train to leave the station on Sunday was 12626 Kerala Express. Though the Indian Railways had cancelled all the trains from originating stations from the midnight of Sunday for 24 hours, there were several passing trains which had already started in the evening and reached Nagpur during the day. Those trains that arrived had very low occupancy.Air India that used to operate 4 flights from Nagpur, reduced it to one. Indigo Airlines cut 10 flights as against 17. Go Air suspended all its 4 flights. Besides, 2 international flights by Air Arabia and Qatar Airways reaching Nagpur have been stopped.Air and railway passengers were worst hit as there was no public or private transport available to ferry them. Till 11am, 8 trains arrived at railway station but passengers were stranded for lack of transport.Navin Purohit, who arrived by an Indigo flight, said, “Cabs were unavailable. Some private cars charged as much as Rs700 per person.” Two NMC buses were later deployed at airport to ferry passengers.“We arrived at Nagpur from Nellore. We preferred to exit from east side of the station but there was a lone auto rickshaw driver who was reluctant to ferry us saying due to curfew he would be imposed a fine of Rs2,000 and did not want to take any risk,” said Vaishnavi Adelwar, a resident of Reshimbagh.“My family members were ready to come at station to pick up but they were not allowed by policemen,” said Mayuri Chouhan, a resident of Manewada. The four girls were seen walking on deserted Cotton Market Road. There were others like them walking with luggage scouting for private transport at east side.However, on west side of the station, the situation was slight better. “We sought NMC’s help to deploy buses. Three buses were deployed after 11am. Besides, 4-5 railway vehicles were there to ferry passengers. Announcements were being made for passengers who were in need of transport to reach their homes,” said Central Railway spokesperson SG Rao.During a visit to the station TOI found the premises, which is usually abuzz with activity, wore a deserted look due to cancellation of trains. Those waiting were mostly travellers to West Bengal and several others waiting for connecting trains to reach their native place. The food stalls were also not operating due to thin presence of passengers.The pantry cars too did poor business due to low occupancy. “In one way trip from Delhi to Chennai, we usually make Rs40,000. In the last 10 days, we are not earning even Rs10,000. There is exodus of passengers and no new ones are boarding,” said pantry car manager Indresh Singh with GT Express.There were several passengers who wanted to come to Nagpur anyhow. Despite railway closing ticket counters owing to ‘janata curfew’, many travelled without tickets. “I have emergency at home. I came to Nagpur by AP Express. I’m travelling to my hometown Rajnandgaon by LTT-Shalimar Express but as counters are closed, I will travel without ticket,” said Ravi Ranjan. Same was the plight of Sagar Sudame and Piyush Bokre, who came from Pune and was waiting for connecting train to Bhandara.Sanket Gupta of Nagpur too travelled in Jaipur Express without ticket from Chandrapur to Nagpur. “I was fined by a TTE but I refused to pay as ticket counters were closed. It was not my fault,” Gupta said.Manish Baghele, Bhandara, who left the job from a Pune-based firm to join at Butibori, said, “Pune Garib Rath had good occupancy till Badnera. Many from the region are returning from Pune due to coronavirus scare.” Baghele took a cycle rickshaw to ST bus stand at Ganeshpeth to reach Bhandara but as buses were off the road, he had to call a friend to pick him up.MSRTC divisional controller Nilesh Belsare manning the bus stand said, “Since morning only two night halt buses with 18 stranded passengers departed to Paratwada and Deori. We allowed these buses to go as a social service. Bur to massive support to ‘janata curfew’ from people in the entire district there was no demand for buses.”MSRTC’s deputy general manager (DyGM) Shivaji Jagtap said, “As per government orders, entire fleet of 3,800 public transport buses from Vidarbha will come to a standstill from Monday till March 31. Over 22,000 staff will sit idle now. These buses will be available in case of emergency service if sought by the district administration.”The situation of private transport buses was not different either. Mahendra Luley, president, Nagpur Private Travels Association (NPTA), said, “Despite coronavirus scare there is some demand from passengers from Pune but we too have stopped entire operations till March 31. Over 150-200 private inter-state buses operate from the city.”Luley added, “Owing to the precarious situation, we have urged the state government to relax payment of EMIs, give sops in tax and insurance payment as there will be no business now for an indefinite period. Yet, we welcome the government decision in larger public interest.”

Title: Admin, police arrange vehicles for passengers stranded at rly stn, airports
Content:
Varanasi: Despite large scale cancellation of trains, passengers of over 100 trains, which passed through Varanasi junction and Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyaya junction in Chandauli districts, left the district administration officials and police sweating in making arrangements of special buses and even police trucks for sending them to their destinations in adjoining districts.

Similar, problem was witnessed at LBS International airport as many passengers of the flights which landed on Sunday had to struggle hard to find vehicles for reaching their places.

Though passengers who reached Varanasi junction from Mumbai by Mahanagri Express succeeded in getting transport for their destinations as it reached the city before the commencement of the curfew hours but problems started after overcrowded trains from Delhi, Amritsar, Okha, Jammu and other places started reaching the station.

Director of Varanasi junction, Anand Mohan said that major load came following arrival of seven trains including two special trains from Mumbai. He said that each passenger was allowed to go out of the station only after going through thermal scanning.

As the public transport including auto rickshaws were unavailable outside the railway station, massive crowding in and around the railway station started challenging the directives of maintaining social distancing. Alarmed by it ADG Varanasi zone Brij Bhushan, IG Varanasi range VS Mina, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma, SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary and many other officials also reached there.

Sharma said that in view of the high load of passengers arriving from different trains 50 buses including UP state transport corporation and private were arranged to send them to their destinations in different districts of east UP. In view of more requirement of vehicles five trucks of police were also engaged in the service of those passengers, he added. For those, who had to go to different areas of the city over 30 auto rickshaws were arranged by the officials.

Similar, challenge was faced by the officials of district administration and police at PDDU junction in Chandauli, where 64 trains brought huge passenger load from Mumbai, Delhi and other points.

The aerial connectivity was also affected badly. According to senior manager (operations) of airport Sanjay Kumar, as many as 22 flights, including four of Air India, one of AI Express, seven of Indigo, four of Go Air and Spicejet each and two of Vistara airlines were cancelled on Sunday. A few flights from Mumbai and other destinations landed here. Those passengers, who had not called their family members, faced serious problems in getting conveyance for reaching there destination as no taxi was available even at pre-paid booth and also outside the airport premises. In view of the problem of passengers some buses were arranged by the district officials.

Title: Unorganised sector bears the brunt of lockdown
Content:
Aurangabad: The ongoing coronavirus scare and the imposition of section 144 till March 31 have hit thousands of workers in the unorganized sectors, autorickshaw drivers, handcart pullers, porters, hawkers, domestic and farm workers hard.

Anticipating the tough times ahead for several lakhs of workers in the drought-prone Marathwada region, activists said that even if these people survive the coronavirus, they may die of hunger.

On the instructions of the state government, the state labour commissioner has already issued directives to the private employers asking them to neither cut salaries not fire their employees.

On Sunday, none of the workers gathered at the spots where they usually come looking for work. The region has more than 50,000 autorickshaws, and they too have gone off the roads, affecting an equal number of families directly dependent on them. The activists working for the unorganised sector, fear that it would be impossible for the poor to sustain the restrictions, stretching up to 8 days at a time.

Maharashtra Rajya Hamal Mapadi Mahamandal general secretary Subhash Lomte, who has been fighting for the cause of unorganized workers for decades, demanded immediate measures for workers, domestic helps and farm workers. Almost 93% of the workforce in India is in the unorganised sector. They include porters and other workers directly or indirectly connected with essential services. The district administration and the state should immediately initiate measures to address their problems. Health check-ups of the workers should be carried out.”

CPI district joint secretary Abhay Taksal said, “The state government is doing a good job, but considering the situation we are facing, these steps are not enough.” He demanded special packages, apart from unemployment wage.

Title: Owners from gunthewari areas to get property cards
Content:
Aurangabad: The long-pending demand of issuing property cards to the property holders of gunthewari areas in the city has been accepted by the state government.

In the latest communication to the town planning section of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation, the state government has asked to initiate measures for issuing the desired document.

Acting on the directives from the government, the civic authorities have approached the revenue department to do the needful together.

As per the official records, Aurangabad has around 118 Gunthewari areas with a minimum of around 40,000 properties.

Many of these property owners were either having 7/12 extracts of their property or notarised agreement showing ownership, putting limitations on the real estate transactions besides putting a curb on availing loan against property.

‘Gunthewari’ is the traditional method used for measuring land and one Guntha land is a plot of around 10m by 10m or 33ft by 33ft. The plots are sold in multiples of a ‘guntha’, this is sometimes referred to as Gunthewari development

Corporator Raju Vaidya, who has been demanding the issue of property cards for the owners of Gunthewari areas, said many properties from the areas have not been registered yet due to the previous regime of rules. “Despite being legitimate owners of their houses, property holders from Gunthewari areas were deprived of property card. The issue was brought to the notice of the chief minister and senior ministers recently, who ordered the desired solution,” he said.

In 2015, BJP-led government in Maharashtra had diluted Gunthewari Act, relaxing the norms of purchase and construction of houses on these properties.

Parts of localities from Pundalik Nagar, Vishranti Nagar, Mukund Nagar, Padegaon, Mitmita, Chikalthana, Harsul and Surewadi among other areas have Gunthewari areas.

Real estate agent Santosh Gaikwad said the property card certifies the real owner of land in an urban area. “Properties from Gunthewari area are prone to a false claim of ownership and the owners are at a risk of facing problems. The property card can help in avoiding legal issues,” he said.

The property card, which is issued by the local civic body, has the name of the land owner and changes in ownership, if any, survey number, plot number and the size of the land among other details.

Suhas Patil, a property owner from Gunthewari area in Pundalik Nagar, said, “The property card must be issued through online to avoid the possible influence of middlemen,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: Cops takes pregnant woman after no-show of ambulance
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Going a step ahead in assisting the common people, police from the region on Sunday used their official vehicle to help a pregnant woman .

Authorities informed that police always help the citizens, but considering the situation resulting from the outbreak of Covid-19, several unit commanders were issued standing instructions asking their men on duty to proactively assist and help people in need.

A 35-year-old woman, Sheetal Thote, in advanced stage of pregnancy was admitted to Navandar Hospital, but considering her situation she was referred to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH).

Despite making calls on state ambulance service number 108, no ambulance came to her rescue. At the same time, a traffic police vehicle was passing from outside the hospital. The woman’s husband Santosh stopped the vehicle and requested for help.

The police team readily agreed and rushed the woman to the GMCH where a couple of hours later she delivered a baby girl. Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said, “In cases of emergency, our men patrolling the streets would readily assist the citizens.”

The officer, however, warned of initiating stringent action, including slapping of offence against those found loitering on the streets without genuine reason.

Even in case of Beed police led by Harssh Poddar and Aurangabad rural police led by Mokshada Patil have officially issued statements appealing people to contact police control room in case of facing any untoward incident.

Police authorities in other districts of the region said they are open to cater to the citizens during these testing times.

Title: Pune pupil first in KYPY exam
Content:
Pune: City student Vedang Asgaonkar has stood first in the country in the Kishore Vaigyanik Protsahan Yojana (KYPY), a national programme for fellowship in basic sciences.

Asgaonkar had also topped the joint entrance exam (JEE) Mains 2020 in Maharashtra, phase I, with a perfect 100 percentile in physics.

He has been preparing for the exams at Bakliwal Tutorials since standard VIII.

Asgaonkar is a student of DAV Public School, Aundh, and his father is a software engineer and his mother is a professor in organic chemistry at All India Shri Shivaji Memorial Society College of Pharmacy.

Vedang said his immediate focus now would be on the JEE Mains, phase II.

Bakliwal Tutorials’ director Vaibhav Bakliwal said, “Vedang has been a consistent performer in all the exams. He cleared the first round of Kishore Vaigyanik Protsahan Yojana for science scholarships, and physics and chemistry olympiads with extremely high scores. In the chemistry olympiad, he scored 222/240. We are proud of him.”

A statement issued by Bakliwal Tutorials said that, another std XI student, Arnav Kalgutkar, from the coaching institute has got all India rank of 45 in general category and top rank in persons with disability(PWD) category.

Earlier, 24 students from Bakliwal Tutorials had cleared the KVPY round 1.Of these, 18 students cleared the round 2 and have become the KVPY scholars.

Title: Drawing contest held via WhatsApp on curfew day
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Rotary Club of Kovilpatti conducted an online drawing competition for school children on the occassion of ‘ World Water Day ’ on Sunday. The competition was held via WhatsApp in the wake of ‘Janata Curfew’ being observed on Sunday.

The Kovilpatti Rotary Club officials asked the participants to send their pictures via WhatsApp. “We hold awareness events for major UN observance days. For ‘World Water Day’ observed on March 22, we wanted to create awareness about saving water. We came up with the idea of a drawing competition for school students between ages 6-18. However, in view of the curfew we decided to hold the event via WhatsApp since no one could come outside,” said Muthu Murugan , Secretary, Kovilpatti Rotary Club.

Hence, on Sunday at around 10 am, the organisers shared the message that entries for the drawing competition could be sent via WhatsApp to a common number till 9 pm. “The participating students were asked to draw on A4 sheet, clicked a picture of the drawing and WhatsApp it with their name, address, phone number, school name, and class,” explained Muthu Murugan. More than 100 entries were received participants from across Kovilpatti. Notably, some of the participants tried to include Covid-19 prevention measures in their drawings clubbing it with the theme of saving water.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Being young may not save you, but precautions will
Content: NEW DELHI: You are not invincible and are vulnerable to the novel coronavirus; the virus could put you in the hospital for weeks or even kill, World Health Organization (WHO) director general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said on Friday in a message to young people.His statement follows a significant US study that found 38% of the Covid-19 patients who required hospitalisation till March 16 were in the age group of 20 to 54 years. Some of them even required ICU care, the data shows. In France, more than 50% of the cases are under 60 years old. Even children can end up with severe infection, revealed another study published in the journal ‘Paediatrics’. The study, carried out by doctors in China where the Covid-19 outbreak started, found 11% of the infants who tested positive turned severe or critical. Their survival rates were better compared to the adults, and especially the elderly, but the study shows children, too, could be seriously ill.“There is no scope for complacency in the fight against Covid-19 and younger people have to be equally cautious,” said Dr Vivek Nangia, director and head of pulmonology at Fortis Hospital, Vasant Kunj.The coronavirus that causes Covid-19 is new and people haven’t developed immune response to it, he pointed out. “It is difficult to predict how will it affect someone and, therefore, everyone needs to be extra cautious,” Dr Nangia said.Another senior doctor from AIIMS said younger people would spread the disease faster if they didn’t follow the physical distancing rules.Prime Minister Narendra Modi has urged people for self-curfew on Sunday, unless it’s an emergency, to break the chain of transmission. Experts said while staying at home people could follow follow certain tips to reduce the risk of infection and related complications. These include eating a healthy and nutritious diet to boost the the immune system, limit alcohol consumption, and avoid sugary drinks and smoking. “Smoking can increase your risk of developing severe disease if you become infected with Covid-19,” according to WHO. It also recommends 30 minutes of physical activity daily for adults, and one hour a day for children.Previous reports of the Covid-19 spread in China suggested the elderly were at maximum risk to develop serious complications such as pneumonia and respiratory failure on getting infected.According to a study published in the American Medical Association journal, which analysed the epidemiology data of China, the overall case-fatality rate (CFR) was 2.3% (1,023 deaths among 44,672 confirmed cases). “No death occurred in the group of 9 years and younger, but the cases in 70-79 years had an 8% CFR, while those in the 80-year-and-older bracket had a 14.8% CFR,” found the study conducted by Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Maharashtra: 10 fire cases in Pimpri Chinchwad
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Ten fire incidents were reported in different areas of Pimpri Chinchwad from Sunday morning.

The incidents occurred in Chinchwad, Chikhali, Akurdi, Wakad and Pimpri. The first incident was reported around 9.30am in Chinchwad. While the firemen were dousing the fire, a rubber godown in Chikhali caught fire. Later in the afternoon, scrap on the premises of a private company caught fire. “In total, we had 10 calls of fire in Pimpri Chinchwad. No one was injured,” an officer of the Pimpri Chinchwad fire brigade said.

Title: New isolation ward work at GH to be over in a week
Content:
Madurai: The work for the additional COVID-19 isolation wards being set up at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) and government hospital for thoracic medicine at Thoppur is likely to be completed within a week, said GRH dean Dr J Sangumani on Sunday.

Isolation wards are being multiplied across the state, especially with the COVID-19 positive cases going up to seven in the state as of Sunday.

At GRH ward no. 120, there is an already-existing eight-bedded COVID-19 isolation ward. “The new ward, which is being constructed at the old building of the school of nursing, is set to have 17 beds and will be fully-equipped. All officials and workers are trying their best to complete the ward as soon as possible,” said Dr Sangumani, speaking to TOI.

The ward, which is being built at a cost of around Rs 96 lakh, would be well-equipped as per specifications given by the health ministry. The hospital would also keep ready all personal protective equipment required. Once the ward is complete, the capacity of COVID-19 isolation wards at GRH would be 25.

Meanwhile, at the government hospital of thoracic medicine at Thoppur, a similar 20-bedded COVID-19 isolation ward is being set up for a cost of Rs 96 lakh. “On Saturday, the district collector Dr T G Vinay inspected the works underway for the isolation ward at Thoppur GH. He has instructed everyone to complete the work as soon as possible. Both the wards currently under construction will likely be completed within 7-10 days,” added Dr Sangumani. So far, there have been no COVID-19 positive cases in Madurai district.

Title: Woman who died in Covid-19 isolation ward in TN hospital tests negative
Content: MADURAI: Blood samples of a 59-year-old woman who died on Saturday while being in the isolation ward at Kanyakumari Government Medical College Hospital tested negative for Covid-19 on Sunday, said hospital authorities.Though hospital dean Dr R Suganthy confirmed on Saturday that the woman did not have any travel history, she suffered a heart failure. As a precautionary measure, the hospital had kept her body in the mortuary until the results are out.On Sunday, the samples of the woman and four others sent to Tirunelveli Medical College Hospital came back with negative results.The four other patients admitted to the isolation ward on Saturday in Kanyakumari and later tested negative for Covid-19 are an eight-month-old baby who returned from abroad, a 49-year-old man who returned from abroad, a 26-year-old man from Kerala and a 52-year-old woman with no travel history. So far, no person from Kanyakumari district has tested positive for Covid-19.

Title: Bhopal’s AQI shoots to highest level in 14 days
Content:
Bhopal’s AQI on Sunday was recorded at 142 at 1pm by the Central Pollution Control Board’s website, the highes... Read More

BHOPAL: While experts said that the level of pollution has gone down in many places, Bhopal’s AQI on Sunday, during the ‘ janata curfew’, was recorded at 142 at 1 pm by the Central Pollution Control Board ’s website, the highest in the last two weeks.

Experts at the MP Pollution Control Board as well as the CPCB were at a loss to explain the anomaly as there was hardly any movement of vehicles on the roads, which contributes to around 70% of the pollution. Members of the CPCB said burning of waste might have increased the pollution level, affecting the city’s air quality index. Interestingly, the levels of PM 2.5 and PM 10 were “poor” from 8 pm on Saturday to 4 am on Sunday, when there is hardly any vehicular movement.

"Vehicle emission contributes to 70% of the pollution, leading to increase in levels of PM 2.5 while dust scattered by the wheels increases the level of PM 10. But the increase in the levels of the particulate matter at night is a matter of analysis, as people don't generally go out in such large numbers after midnight,” said environmentalist Suresh Pandey.

When TOI contacted the regional office of CPCB, the board’s regional director said that the high level of particulate matter may be because of burning of waste as movement of vehicles was not more than usual on Saturday. On Saturday, Bhopal’s AQI was 116.

"Even if we say that people went out to get supplies for their houses for Janata Curfew, it will only increase the level of pollutants from 8 pm to 11 pm, but the rise in PM 2.5 and PM 10 between 12 am to 4 am is only possible due to burning of waste in large amounts near the real time monitoring device in TT Nagar,” said P Jaga, regional director of CPCB.

Rajendra Chaturvedi, scientist at MPCB, said, “Since AQI is calculated for 24 hours, it’s possible that the pollution was more on Saturday, which is being reflected in Sunday’s AQI. According to the pollution monitors of MPCB, we have found the level of PM 2.5 to be under 50 at all centres, while PM 10 was under 100 at all 6 centres in Bhopal on Sunday.”

After referring to the data on the CPCB website, Pandey further said, “There may have been some fault in the instrument as the level of PM 2.5 and PM 10 for the last 20 days is much lower after midnight."

Title: 12 quarantined voluntarily at MLA Hostel in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Amid occupants complaining of poor amenities, the quarantine facility at MLA Hostel also has persons voluntarily turning up for a stay. As the number of occupants reached 154 on Sunday, there were 12 who have come in voluntarily, said officials here.

On Saturday, six persons came voluntarily, followed by four on Sunday. This takes the number to 12 after taking into account those who had comer earlier, said an official managing the facility. They have preferred to stay here to avoid spreading infection to others in the family and neighbourhood. The number increased as awareness spread, said the officials.

Some have travelled from abroad, but reached Nagpur through a domestic flight or any other mode where the screening is not done, said the official. Such passengers too are expected to remain home quarantined, some of them have come here, the source said. From Monday onwards, there will be no international flights till March 29.

TOI came across a couple who had travelled from Dubai but had reached Hyderabad first and reached Nagpur by train. The husband, a fitness trainer, said, “I already have patients at home and I don’t want to add to their troubles by staying with them. I have a home at Nagpur but will spend time at the quarantine facility first,” he said.

The officials said they will have to stay for 48 hours at least. Rounds by psychiatrists continued at the facility. Source said occupants have been provided with religious books and sessions on stress management are being carried out. They have been advised to practice yoga and breathing exercises. No clinical signs of mental stress has been seen in the occupants so far, the source said.

Title: Aurangabad: Disruption in water supply leaves citizens stuck at home high and dry
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Several parts of the city did not receive water on Sunday, making it more difficult for people confined to their houses due to the janta curfew. Private water tankers were also not available in most of the affected areas, adding to the water woes.

HUDCO, Mukundwadi, Chikalthana, Naregaon and some other parts of the city, which account for a considerable geographical portion of Aurangabad , did not receive tap water on Sunday.

Kiran Dhande, in-charge of water supply at the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation, said that a technical snag developed at water treatment plant at Farola which disrupted the water supply in many areas.

“A few systems had a sudden breakdown on Saturday morning and the restoration work lasted for almost four hours. It had affected the city’s water supply,” he said.

Aarti Relgaokar, a resident of N-11 sector, that said her family had exhausted all stored water anticipating tapped water supply on Sunday. “The situation was so bad that we had no water to take a bath. The private supplier expressed inability to supply water citing janata curfew as the reason,” she said.

Aurangabad city gets water after a gap of every four days hence the residents are forced to store the water.

Rupali Wagh, a resident of Mukundwadi area, said keeping hands clean amid Covid-19 scare went for a toss due to water scarcity.

“The civic body must ensure smooth supply of water during the current crisis. The disruption in water supply has become a norm even if the Jayakwadi dam, which supplies water to the city, has sufficient water,” she said.

The local civic body draws nearly 160 MLD to 170 MLD water from Jayakwadi dam in 24-hours for the water supply in Aurangabad.

Meanwhile, door-to-door waste collection of AMC took place on a usual note on Sunday despite ‘janata curfew’, drawing appreciation from citizens.

Title: Medicos praised with claps, thalis and conchshells
Content:
Varanasi: People in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s parliamentary constituency, following his appeal for self-imposed curfew to combat Covid-19, stayed indoor on Sunday.

As suggested by the PM, a large number of people also showed grattitude to corona warriors by clapping, ringing bells and utensils and even blowing conch shells in the district at 5 pm.

With the beginning of janata curfew hours at 7am, no one could be seen on the city roads and even service providers like milkmen and newspaper hawkers went back to their places. Movement was evident only on the roads linked with railway station and highways with people, who arrived by train or other means of transport, heading to their destinations.

By noon some onlookers gathered at crossings and roads while some children also came out to play but were soon sent back to their places by policemen. The officials including district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma, SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary, ADM City VK Singh, SP city Dinesh Kumar Singh and other officials took rounds of the city localities and also took a stock of railway stations, hospitals and other places.

People of Kashi seemed to be eager to response to the call of honouring the coronavirus warriors as they came out on their balconies and houses with bells and utensils to ring minutes before the scheduled time (5 pm). UP ministers Neelkanth Tiwari and Ravindra Jaiswal could also be found blowing conch-shells with their family members at their houses.

After chief minister Yogi Adityanath made the announcement of lockdown in Varanasi and Azamgarh districts of the region, the DMs at both places issued details of the establishments including outlets of essential commodities, petrol pumps, banks and other, which will remian functional during the three-day lockdown.

Title: Covid-19 facility in hospital run by AIIMS at Jhajjar
Content: NEW DELHI: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) in Haryana’s Jhajjar , which is run by AIIMS, will work as a Covid-19-specific hospital for the NCR.NCI, with around 800 beds, started both out-patient and in-patient services for cancer patients recently. However, in view of the Covid-19 crisis, the government has decided to use it specifically to manage patients who are moderately or severely ill, the Union health ministry announced on Sunday.All states have been asked to identify hospitals that can be turned into Covid-19-specific health facilities, said joint secretary Lav Aggarwal. “We have also asked the states to ramp up infrastructure needs such as ventilators. The central government has placed orders for 1,200 ventilators too,” he added.As per the plan, prepared by AIIMS in consultation with the ministry, the institute will triage Covid-19 cases requiring acute management at its 20-bedded isolation facility in the Jai Prakash Narayan Apex Trauma Centre, following which they will be transferred to NCI.“We plan to create 125 beds in NCI. Of this, 25 will be ICU beds and the rest will have advanced facilities for monitoring and acute management. Depending on the patient rush, the numbers can be expanded,” said an AIIMS official.At present, most Covid-19 suspect and positive cases are being kept at Safdarjung, RML, Lok Nayak and GTB hospitals among others. Though the isolation facilities have been created in separate blocks, other patients and staff are still scared, said doctors at these hospitals.“At Lok Nayak Hospital, triaging is being done on the ground floor and then symptomatic ones are being shifted to the sixth floor of the emergency block. For X-Ray or CT scans, the suspects will have to be taken from the sixth floor across the OPD and pharmacy areas. All regular patients also use these areas. This strategy needs to be reviewed,” a senior doctor explained.

Title: Maharashtra: Truck driver, cleaner killed in accident
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A truck driver and a cleaner were killed on Saturday after a truck rammed into them from behind at Bhumkar bridge on the Katraj-Dehu road bypass.

The Sinhagad Road police have identified the deceased as Annasaheb Sukhdev Jadhav (35) and Vijaykumar Mahadev Kashid (39) of Sangli district.

“The duo had alighted from their trailer truck after it developed some technical snag. They were alerting the vehicles on the road about their stationary trailer when the other truck rammed into them from behind,” an officer from Sinhagad Road police said.

Title: Dubai returnee tests positive for Covid-19 in Tirunelveli
Content: MADURAI: A 43-year-old man from Tirunelveli has tested positive for Covid-19, state health minister C Vijayabaskar said on Sunday. This is the first case to be tested positive in the southern districts of the state.“The man landed at Madurai airport on March 17 from Dubai. He is said to have travelled to Tirunelveli from Madurai by road. Efforts are on to track his movements before he was hospitalized and identify those he may have been in contact with,” Shilpa Prabhakar Satish Tirunelveli district collector, told TOI.She also confirmed that the patient’s condition was stable. He is in intensive care as he has undergone bypass surgery in the past, sources said.The man, a native of a village near Radhapuram in Tirunelveli district, works in the Gulf.As he grew suspicious of his symptoms, he went to the Tirunelveli Medical College Hospital on Saturday afternoon and got admitted. Swabs were duly collected and sent for testing.On Sunday the test results confirmed Covid-19 infection.

Title: Another FIR against women at Roshanbagh
Content:
Prayagraj: An FIR was registered against 18 named and 100 unidentified persons on Sunday for protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) at Mansoor Ali Park in Roshanbagh area of the city and violating orders prohibiting gatherings to check the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19).

The complainant sub-inspector Kalimullah got an FIR registered with Khuldabad police under section 188 (violating section 144 of CrPc), section 269 and 270 of the Indian Penal Code (likely to spread the infection of any diseases dangerous to life) and section 3 of the Epidemic Diseases Act.

This would be the sixth FIR against the protesters at Mansoor Ali Park — most of whom are women. The other charges against the protesters include unlawful assembly while violating section 144 of CrPc. The complainant alleged that, on Saturday night, a police team tried to peacefully convenience protesters at Mansoor Ali Park to call off their agitation as the assembly of such large number of people could help the deadly virus spread.

He said the protesters were not ready to lend an ear to their appeals and were adamant to continue with their agitation. The agitation, which was launched over two months ago, against the new citizenship law and the National Register of Citizens is still underway at Mansoor Ali Park in the city.

Title: Whatsapp turns key tool for arms smugglers
Content:
Prayagraj: Whatsapp has become a thriving centre for the smuggling of illegal weapons across Uttar Pradesh. Prayagraj police busted six interstate gangs in the trans Gang and Yamuna pocket involved in the sale of illegal weapons through whatsapp groups where pictures of models of country-made arms were shared and orders received. Ther smugglers used the popular messaging app in a bid to evade police.

Prayagraj SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj told TOI, “A team of crime branch and police of Naini, Cantt, Daraganj, Shahganj and Ghurpur unearthed this clandestine mode of smuggling and seized a cache of over 35 illegal weapons within a span of two months. A total of 17 arms smugglers were arrested”

“Investigations revealed the arms smugglers had circulated half a dozen designs of conutry-made pistols to clients across the state through their WhatsApp numbers and smuggled the consignment after their approval,” he added.

Title: Madhya Pradesh governor cites tradition, asks Prajapati to resign from the Speaker’s post
Content:
Madhya Pradesh governor Lalji Tandon with Speaker NP Prajapati.

BHOPAL: A day after BJP’s complaint against Speaker N P Prajapati and demand to appoint a protem Speaker after the resignation of chief minister Kamal Nath , Governor Lalji Tandon in a letter to the Prajapati has suggested him to quit the post to honour the tradition after the Congress government fell in Madhya Pradesh .

Tandon also cited a no-confidence motion moved by BJP in the assembly against the Speaker and said that it should be taken up on priority when the session is convened. “I have received a memorandum dated March 21 from the Leader of Opposition (LoP) Gopal Bhargava stating that presently there is neither a leader of the House nor the House is functioning. In such a situation, when the House is in sleeping state, policy decisions should not be taken by the Speaker, which is hurting or helping anyone. But, decisions are being taken every day with political motives which are contrary to the interests of the common man,” reads the letter.

Tandon further said that BJP has submitted a no-confidence motion against the Speaker, but no action was taken till date. “Until the no-confidence motion is decided by the house, I expect you to work in accordance with the Constitution, assembly rules and morality by studying the legality of every subject,” the Governor stated.

The Governor also referred to the resignation letter of BJP MLA Sharad Kol on March 6, after which he had claimed that he had sent another letter on March 16 requesting the Speaker not to accept his resignation, but it was not entertained.

Tandon said, “BJP has demanded that a protem Speaker should be appointed to ensure that constitutional values and democratic traditions are followed. The LoP has also said that the Speaker has followed unlawful procedures to accept Kol’s resignation.”

Besides attaching copies of complaints by BJP, the Governor also quoted a constitutional expert’s opinion stating that when a government falls, the Speaker and the deputy Speaker appointed in that regime should resign.

Both Speaker Prajapati and deputy Speaker Hina Kaware are from Congress.

“The opinion of the constitution expert is attached with this letter for your observation, in which he has stated that the Speaker and deputy Speaker elected from that party must give resignation after being ousted from power as per the tradition,” states Tandon’s letter.

Tandon said after the (Speaker’s) resignation, the principal secretary of the assembly will carry out the normal day to day work as per the (Speaker’s) instructions. “I expect you (Speaker) to work on the statutory position of each subject on the basis of the Indian Constitution, legislative rules and ethics, till the decision on the no-confidence motion presented against you is taken by the House,” the Governor said.

Amid the political crisis, Governor Tandon and Speaker Prajapati were engaged in a war of words over missing legislators, who had sent their resignations through BJP leader Bhupendra Singh from Bengaluru. Later, the Speaker also accepted the resignation of BJP MLA Kol, ignoring his appeal to withdraw the same.

Title: Kanpur: Educationist offers campuses for setting up isolation wards
Content:
KANPUR: As the entire country is making concerted efforts to keep Covid-19 at bay, a city-based educationist and chairman of Maharana Pratap Group of Institutions has offered to handover 10,000 rooms of its institutes in Delhi, Uttar Pradesh , Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan for isolation of patients.

“We have written to Union health and family welfare minister Dr Harshvardhan and the governments of UP, MP, Rajasthan and Delhi offering that our educational campuses be used as temporary hospitals and our hostels and staff residence as isolation wards,” chairman of Maharana Pratap Group of Institutions Shailendra Bhadauria told TOI on Sunday.

“The campuses have the capacity of isolating 50,000 people. We have already given our medical college and hospital located at Kolar Road in Bhopal to the district administration for a 500-bed isolation ward. The administration has decided to use this isolation ward for Indians coming from Saudi Arabia , Iran and other countries,” he said.

The group’s institutes in Kanpur include Maharana Pratap Dental College and Hospital (Mandhana), Maharana Pratap group of institutions campus and Maharana Pratap Education Centre (Keshavpuram). It has also offered Maharana Institute of Technology in Mohanlalganj in Lucknow.

The institutes in Rajasthan include Pratap University Chandwaji in Jaipur while Madhya Pradesh’s institutes are Advanced Medical College and Hospital (Bhopal).

In Delhi, the group has Pratap International School in Rohini and Pitampura.

“Not only we are ready to provide space and infrastructure, we have also constituted a team of 1,000 employees to assist medical teams in case of emergency,” Bhadauria said.

Title: Auto-thefts continue unabated in Prayagraj
Content:
Prayagraj: Auto-theft is rampant in Prayagraj and its adjoining districts with at least 3-4 vehicles being stolen daily from the Sangam city alone, according to the data released by police department.

In first two months of this year, at least 228 of total 351 cases of auto-theft were recorded in Prayagraj which was the highest in eight districts comprising Prayagraj police zone.

These eight districts include Prayagraj, Pratapgarh, Kaushambi, Fatehpur, Banda, Hamirpur, Mahoba and Chitrakoot.

Prayagraj is followed by Pratapgarh (62), Kaushambi (26), Fatehpur (16), Banda (7), Mahoba (5) and Chitrakoot (4). Hamirpur figures at the bottom of the list with only three cases.

Concerned over the fact that highest cases were recorded in Prayagraj range, IG (Prayagraj range) KP Singh has directed his subordinates to pull up socks and initiate result-oriented operations to tighten the noose around auto-lifters.

Title: On move till yesterday, life comes to standstill
Content:
Prayagraj: Doors of homes closed and shutters of shops pulled down, an otherwise bustling city came to a standstill on Sunday as Prayagraj residents chose to stay indoors in compliance with the janata curfew to arrest the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19).

On Thursday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi gave the call for a janata curfew (lockdown) for March 22, wherein he appealed to citizens to stay indoors between 7am and 9pm to stop the infection from spreading.

All streets in the city wore a total deserted and only a few vehicles, mostly two-wheelers were spotted on roads. With hardly any passengers, drivers of autorickshaws, private taxis and rickshaws also stayed away from work.

Following government orders, bus and train services remained suspended throughout the day. A few passengers who did reach bus depots and railway stations ended up going back disappointed.

Small eateries like dhabas and tea and paan shops were closed too. An eerie silence replaced the usual chaos of honking cars and two-wheelers on city roads.

Similar conditions were observed in neighbouring districts like Kaushambi and Pratapgarh, wherein residents supported Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s appeal for a 14-hour lockdown.

The residents were joined by traders’ associations and social, religious and spiritual organisations in extending support to PM Modi’s appeal.

President of Civil Lines Vyappar Mandal Sushil Kharbanda said that city traders welcomed the move and pledged their support to the initiative.

Many residents took to social media to laud the curfew and urged people to stay indoors.

Markets like Civil Lines, Chowk, Kotwali, Bahadurganj, Mutthiganj, Kydganj, Katra, Sulemsarai, Rajapur, Ghantaghar, Allahapur and Teliyarganj were closed. Only shops selling essential commodities like groceries and foodgrains were open for business.

Civil Lines resident Manish Mehrotra said, “The people of this country must unite to fight against Covid-19. The janata curfew is a great way to stop the virus from spreading further.”

“It has already claimed six lives in India and we need to be very careful about the way deal with novel coronavirus,” he added.

Ravi Kesarwani, who lives in Mutthiganj, said, “As individuals, we should understand our responsibility towards the society in such testing times.”

Meanwhile, police patrolled the streets on Sunday afternoon to keep people from gathering unnecessarily on roads.

Police arranged for roadways buses to ferry passengers who had arrived at Prayagraj Junction after de-boarding three trains. The passengers belonged to different parts of the country and were headed to Prayagraj and adjoining districts.

IG (Prayagraj Range) KP Singh said, “When people from different parts of the country arrived at railway station, they started moving towards Civil Lines bus stand. Some of them were also looking for public transport. We arranged for eight roadways buses for those who wanted to go Kaushambi, Pratapgarh, Jaunpur and other neighbouring areas.”

“For around half an hour, a chaos-like situation prevailed at Civil Lines bus stand till the roadways buses arrived,” he added.

“We have sanitised buses which were ferried the passengers to their destinations. They were also screened by a team of doctors..”

Meanwhile, Prayagraj SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj and district magistrate Bhanu Chandra Goswami took stock of the situation.

Title: Bareilly Municipal Corporation carries out spraying operation to sanitise city
Content: BAREILLY: Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) on Sunday launched a drive to spray disinfectant in the city as a precautionary measure against coronavirus . A health department team along with field workers of BMC hit the city roads and carried out the spraying in several prominent areas, including Ayub Khan, Chowki Crossing, Kaalibadi and adjoining areas.Officials at BMC said the spraying exercise continued till late evening as roads were deserted due to the janata curfew called by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. With virtually no traffic or vendors on the roads, it was easier for the BMC staff to cover maximum area, which is otherwise difficult. The drive to spray disinfectant would continue in the days to come, said the civic body officials.Abhishek Anand, Bareilly municipal commissioner, told TOI, “A team comprising members of the health department and BMC field workers has been constituted to carry out and monitor the spraying of disinfectant in the city. Directions have been issued to sanitise the city. On Sunday, the spraying exercise was carried out in prominent areas and main junctions, including Chowki Crossing Ayub Khan Crossing, Civil Lines, Kaalibadi and surrounding areas. The civic body will continue to carry out the spraying in the coming days and all city wards and all streets will be covered under the exercise. Special focus is on areas where hospitals, schools, hotels and marketplaces are located.”BMC’s chief sanitation and food inspector Mahendra Pratap Singh Rathod said, “A total of seven machines, including two fogging machines and five cold fogging machines (which uses chemical with water), have been deployed to carry out intensive spraying. Besides, sanitisation of public and religious places frequented by hundreds of people is also being done. It is also being ensured that surroundings remain clear while drains and pits are also being unclogged frequently.”BMC officials said the drive is likely to intensify in order to ensure that all city areas get covered and sanitised properly as a precautionary measure against the coronavirus.

Title: Shivraj Chouhan thanks PM Modi for Rs 350cr relief to fight coronavirus
Content: BHOPAL: BJP leaders across the state rang bells, clanged cymbals, blew conch shells and clapped hands at their residence at 5pm as part of social distancing to check the spread of the deadly coronavirus as Prime Minister Narendra Modi suggested.Former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan observed ‘janata curfew’ and clanged cymbals to send a message of appreciation towards all working professionals — nurses, doctors, cleaners, transport workers, police personnel, journalists and others — who have been helping battle the contagion.“We should be vigilant and thankful to all those who have been helping us to fight the corona spread. We are sending a message as suggested by Prime Minister Narendra Modi,” said Chouhan.Chouhan, who is also learnt to have spoken to Prime Minister Modi said, “Discussed in detail about the corona spread. The Prime Minister is keeping a vigil on the situation in Madhya Pradesh . He has approved Rs350 crore budget for virus control in the state, which would be utilised by the collectors against fighting the coronavirus spread. I am thankful to him,” he said.State BJP president V D Sharma, who passed his day doing yoga while observing ‘janata curfew’, blew conch shell as the clock struck 5pm. He also appealed to Governor Lalji Tandon and the acting chief minister Kamal Nath for strict vigil to control coronavirus and said that BJP will extend all possible support and cooperation.BJP chief whip Narottam Mishra shared a video clip on social media blowing a conch shell, while the former minister Sanjay Pathak shared a video with his family members ringing bells and clanging ‘thalis’ in appreciation towards the corona warriors.A video shared by former Union minister Jyotiraditya Scindia showed him clapping with his family members at his Delhi residence. Union minister Narendra Singh Tomar also posted a video with his wife blowing a conch shell.

Title: Nine-day lockdown can be turning point against Covid-19, say experts
Content: NAGPUR: Citizens have welcomed chief minister Uddhav Thackeray ’s move to extend the complete lockdown by another nine days with the exception of essential services. They feel it is much-needed and everybody must cooperate with the government because of the coronavirus crisis. According to medical professionals, the lockdown could be a turning point in the fight against Covid-19.Khamla resident Rajesh Sanghani, who owns a garment shop, said he is ready to cooperate with the government for even the next 15 days. “I love filter coffee at a particular South Indian restaurant in Gokulpeth . I am addicted to it and can’t stay without it. But I have no qualms as the lockdown is for a good cause. I’m ready to give up my favourite coffee for another 15 days. Everyone is serious. We have been seeing what happened in other countries. So if we have to do this for some days it shouldn’t be a problem,” he said.Medical store owner Yakub Fazal said, “It’s a good decision. It should be extended to the entire country because everyone is going to be affected. The government should come forward and help the poor and daily wagers who have no savings. It is much needed.”Laxmi Nagar resident Dhananjay Duragkar said coronavirus is dangerous and research is under way. “CM’s guidelines need to be followed. Safety comes first. Financial markets can be revived, but not human beings. The main threat that we face today is the threat of our existence. So far, our city’s administration has done well to control the situation. It is our duty to care for our own safety as well as the safety of others. The casual approach of other countries is a lesson for us. It is important to remain indoors as mush as possible,” he said.Pulmonologist, Dr Sameer Arbat, said, “In view of the events in Italy, it will be prudent for all of us to continue social distancing and isolation for at least a month or so till we get a grip over this pandemic. The decision of imposing section 144 is good and must be implemented very strictly.”Dr Sanjay Deshpande , a functionary of state IMA, said that a complete lockdown was necessary to control the spread of coronavirus. “This is the only way to stop this virus. It’s difficult for the mob mentality to accept a lockdown and stay at home for long periods of time. But we must follow this religiously. It’s for the greater good of people,” he said.Dr Sushant Meshram, HoD of pulmonary medicine at the Super Speciality Hospital, said that people should use this period to build their immunity.“The most important natural immunity booster is quality sleep. Deep and uninterrupted sleep will help a lot. Recent researches have shown that individuals who sleep less than six hours and voluntarily get exposed to the common cold virus are more prone to contracting diseases. Similarly, the population working in shifts has a disturbed circadian rhythm and hence, is also prone to developing diseases,” he said, adding that the lockdown will provide professionals with the opportunity to get good sleep.“I appeal to all the young professionals to ensure that they sleep well, eat well and maintain their health during the lockdown,” he added.Vice-president of Maharashtra Medical Council and paediatrician, Dr Vinky Rughwani, said the lockdown is a remarkable move and the only way to stop this pandemic.“Sunday’s Janata curfew has been a grand success. This proves that people have got the message loud and clear and are fully with the authorities to fight coronavirus with all their might. They will cooperate with the government for the additional lockdown too,” said Dr Rughwani.

Title: Kanika’s uncle, 10 kin test negative
Content:
Kanpur: The samples of 11 of the total 35 occupants of Kalpana Tower that was visited by Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor on March 13 tested negative for coronavirus on Sunday. District authorities heaved a sigh of relief even though 24 reports are still awaited.

Kanika had visited Kalpana Tower to attend the house warming party of her maternal uncle Vipul Tandon’s flat no 902 in the building.

District magistrate Brahma Deo Ram Tiwari said, “As many as 56 people had attended the ‘grah pravesh’ function hosted by Kanika’s maternal uncle Vipul Tandon on March 13.”

CMO Ashok Shukla said 35 samples were collected on Friday and Saturday and the test results of 11 came on Sunday. “Eleven people, including Vipul Tandon, Radhika Tandon, Meena Tandon, Mukul Kumar Tandon, Nandini Tandon, Yash Tandon, Manvi Tandon, Khyati Tandon, Subhash Mehrotra, Ruchi Mehrotra and Sonal Mehrotra have tested negative and the reports of 24 others are awaited,” Shukla said.

“Kanika had stayed at Tandon’s flat from 1.30pm to 4.30pm on March 13. It is indeed a sigh of relief considering the infectious nature of the virus. We are working on warfooting to implement all preventive measures,” the CMO said.

“We have formed several teams which are being trained to educate public on coronavirus and spread awareness about precautionary steps to be taken to prevent its spreading,” he added.

Title: Curfew success: Kanpur shuts doors on coronavirus
Content:
KANPUR: City streets, on Sunday, remained deserted as denizens observed ‘ janata curfew’ on the call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to fight against coronavirus.

People participated with full vigour to self-quarantine themselves. They did not move out for the entire day except when the clock struck 5 and they came on their balconies to clap and blow conch shells in an act of displaying appreciation for those who work round the clock to fight Covid-19.

People also rang bells, beat plates and some even beat dhols to cheer for the warriors including doctors, nurses, mediapersons and policemen. Even children participated in this exercise with full enthusiasm . For over half an hour, the city echoed with the sounds of bells and conchshells.

Except for police, no one could be seen on city streets, barring a few who were out due to some or other emergency. Cops were witnessed standing guard at prominent city crossings.

The areas which usually witness heavy rush like Mall Road, Naveen Market , PPN Market, Parade crossing, Bada Chauraha, Kidwai Nagar, Govind Nagar , Lala Bangla , Kalyanpur, Baradevi, Naubasta, areas in South city and entire city were deserted as the city observed janata curfew.

People spent their time by watching their favourite shows, movies, playing games with their family members or on their smartphones. While for many it was a good time to read books or complete several pending work at their home.

District magistrate Dr Brahmadev Ram Tiwari, DIG Anant Dev, City magistrate Himanshu Gupta and other district officials inspected different places including isolation wards raised at LLR hospital and Infectious Disease Hospital.

Later at 5 pm, DM, DIG and other officials visited Kalpana Tower, Emerald Garden and other city localities and raised enthusiasm of denizens by waving at them while they clapped to pariase the work of corona warriors.

The officials thanked the citizens for following the advisory and suggestions given by the PM.

Title: Masks, sanitizers being sold without bills to evade action
Content: NAGPUR: A day after the special squad of district collector inspected a couple of medical stores, owners started selling the much-needed personal hygiene products — masks, gloves and sanitizers — without bills to skip action.On March 21, incidents of overcharging were reported to the squad who then went around the city and penalized the erring medical stores. Since the action was based on holding bills as proof of violation, stores started selling them without invoice.As per new central government norms, sanitizer can't be sold for more than 50 paise per ml and the rates for 1, 2 3 layer mask too have been fixed. But the main issue is regarding N95 mask said to be effective against coronavirus Shahid Sharif, executive member of Consumer Protection Council Nagpur at district collector office, said, “Stores are not giving bill. Black marketing is legalized and violation of the norms is rampant. Action must be taken. A crisis is going on and they are saying Sunday is a holiday for not taking any action. Then why was the squad was formed,” he asked.He added many people were forced to visit government hospitals on Sunday during the Janata Curfew as no private doctor was available. “These hospitals are ill equipped. Now, people need sanitizers and masks to go there so they are being looted. There is total lack of communication between the collector and the officials,” Sharif said.He said there is another belief that N95 mask will prevent Covid-19. “In the March 21 advisory, N95 is not included. It means adminsitation is not sure. Then they talk of making it a prescription item. There is complete chaos,” he said.Officials admitted the notification issued by Centre must have specific guidelines to stop overcharging.Medical shops in the city are selling premium N95 and simple masks and sanitizers at 150% profit margins, making them quite expensive.

Title: Lord Ram’s footprints: Sarbhanga sites in Satna declared protected
Content:
Artefacts that date back to the 10th & 11th Century BC have been plundered and smuggled out around Sarbhanga a... Read More

BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh government has finally notified five locations around Sarbhanga ashram in Satna district as protected sites to put a check on illegal miners who were plundering rare artefacts dating back to the 10th and 11th Century BC. The artefacts were buried near the ashram at Chitrakoot, which bears Lord Ram’s footprints during his 14-year exile. The notification was issued last week.

The government had in 2016 decided to notify five sites around Sarbhanga ashram as a protected site by invoking powers of Madhya Pradesh Ancient Monuments, Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1963, and the state’s culture department had said the area would be declared ‘state protected monument’ after two months from date of issue of the notice on May 26.

Once notification is issued under Section 3(1) of the said Act, a final notification has to be issued within next two months.

A study by the state’s archaeology department had pressed panic buttons regarding the loot of relics in Satna district. The area is rich in bauxite , laterite and ochre. Sources said many antiques on Sanwar hill, where Sarbhanga ashram is located, have been stolen and smuggled out during mining operations in the last five years. Several idols have been damaged due to the use of heavy mining machinery and the damaged ones were found abandoned.

The epic legacy around another hillock near Sarbhanga ashram known as ‘Siddha Pahar’, where Lord Ram vowed to eliminate demons and spent nearly 12 years of his exile, has almost vanished following illegal mining. The area is spread across 100 acres. Sanwar and ‘Siddha Pahar’ are located within a 2-kilometre radius.

On August 17, 2015, the Madhya Pradesh high court had ordered the state’s archaeology department to study in detail the ‘Ram Van Gaman Path’ (route used by Lord Rama as per the Ramayana during his exile) in three months and conserve sites of archaeological importance. According to the report, some ancient idols were damaged during mining.

The study was ordered by a division bench of the high court, while hearing a petition alleging that no inquiry or study has been conducted and these sites were not declared as protected.

“This notification would now help government secure antique idols from being smuggled,” said Nithyanand Mishra , an advocate who had taken up the matter in the high court.

Title: Despite orders, pharmacies, milk booths shut down
Content:
Guntur: An unprecedented lockdown was observed in Guntur on Sunday following the call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy. The city wore a deserted look following the closure of shops and other establishments. With buses and private vehicles going off streets, the city went quiet.

In fact, people voluntarily confined themselves to homes bringing normal life to a halt. Even medical shops and milk booths remained closed in several parts of the city, although, authorities exempted emergency services like pharmacies to remain open. The pharmacies attached to hospitals sold medicines to only inpatients.

With Indian Medical Association suspending out-patient services till March 31, hospitals have closed their doors for patients. Doctors, however, have continued to attended emergency services, including surgeries.

Despite losses, roadside eateries and fruit stalls did not put up shop on Sunday and extended their support to the government’s mission to contain Covid-19. Interestingly, a majority of domestic help were also allowed to skip work. “It is heartening to see that people have extended an overwhelming support to the call given by the PM and CM to tackle COVID-19. It fosters a sense of confidence that we can certainly beat this dreaded virus,” observed NV Dr NV Sundarachary, a senior professor at Guntur Medical College (GMC).

Guntur Municipal Corporation also brought supply of drinking water to halt from 7am to 9pm in the city. The supplies were resumed only after 9pm. Meanwhile, the emergency wing staff of Central Power Distribution Company Limited (CPDCL) remained in sub-stations to manage uninterrupted power supplies.

Title: Govt puts admin on high alert to tackle Covid-19
Content: Amaravati: The state government is readying a plan to tackle Covid-19 situation.The government has directed district collectors to put the administration on high alert.Although the government is confident of handling the situation, it wants to avoid any slip up at this stage.
