With the Centre declaring that the nation is witnessing the stage 2 of Covid-19, health experts think it might be very difficult to contain the virus if it goes to stage 3.In stage 1, persons travelled to Covid-19 hit countries and test positive, in stage-2, people get infected after coming to contact with foreign returnees who were tested positive for Covid-19.With several people with no foreign travel history getting tested positive, Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) had declared that the virus entered the stage-II. The government is leaving no stone unturned to see that no patient goes out of its hands as it would make the situation complicate to handle.AP has reported very less number of positive cases for Covid-19 thanks to extensive surveys carried out by the health department much in advance.The department had tracked down nearly 13,000 foreign returnees since February and directed them to remain in home isolation. Besides, the health department had deputed staff to residences of the foreign returnees to keep a tab on their movements. With the government not allowing any foreign returnee to go out of its watch and home isolation, the situation is said to be largely under control.The district collectors have started giving training to municipal commissioners, tehsildars and police officials along with the health department officials as per the containment plan readied by the state government. Sources said that the areas in which a Covid-19 positive case is identified will be sealed for about 3km radius and make people in the entire colony to stay at home till further instructions.The cluster mapping management plans are ready for every village and ward secretariat. All the households were tagged to the secretariat portal and police would be deployed in the area to prevent the people contained area to move out.Emergency response teams would reach the area and area marking would be done for effective implementation of containment measures as per WHO guidelines. “We will conduct a mock drill regarding cluster containment on Monday in the city and take corrective measures depending on the feedback,” said Guntur district collector I Samuel Anand Kumar.

Title: Kanpur: Essential Commodity Act court declares fresh dates of cases
Content:
KANPUR: The essential commodity Act court of Kanpur judiciary has declared the general dates of cases listed in between March 23 to 27 in compliance of order of Allahabad High Court .

The Allahabad High Court had closed all distict courts of the state in view of coronavirus threat.

The dates fixed by the Court are as under: The cases listed on March 23 will be heard on April 17. Similarly, cases listed on March 24, 25, 26 and 27 will be heard on April 18, 20, 21 and 22. The execution case 366/19 Prahlad Kaur v/s M/s Uday Construction will be heard on March 30.

Title: Delhi Coronavirus Update: How Delhi’s case No. 10 may’ve set chain reaction
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: If you want to know how one Covid-19 patient can set off a chain of infections, Delhi’s case No. 10 is a good example. The patient is a woman with a history of travel to Saudi Arabia.According to government data, five of Delhi’s 30 novel coronavirus cases so far, excluding her, are linked to her. This includes the Dilshad Garden resident’s two daughters, her brother, mother and a doctor who attended to her before she was taken to Guru Tegh Bahadur Hospital with high fever, cough and shortness of breath.While the woman’s son is in self-quarantine at home since he hasn’t exhibited symptoms of Covid-19, according to sources, the doctor himself became the city’s case No. 30. The doctor’s wife and daughter too have shown signs of infection and are in GTB Hospital awaiting the results of testing.District health officials disclosed that 74 people living in the neighbourhood of the Dubai-returned woman are under surveillance. “When the woman tested positive for Covid-19, we rushed to her residence to ask her family for names and addresses of people who had visited them since March 10, the date of her return from Dubai,” an official said. “They weren’t very cooperative, so we had to seek the help of the local police to get information. We also used footage from the CCTV cameras installed near their home to identify some people who needed to be put under surveillance.”The woman’s brother and mother live in northeast Delhi’s Jahangirpur. People the two came in contact with are also being screened, sources said. But one particular area which may prove to be a veritable hub of disaster can be the mohalla clinic where the doctor who came in contact with the woman consulted patients.Between March 12, when the feverish and coughing woman visited him, and March 17, when the woman tested positive for the coronavirus, the doctor continued seeing patients at the mohalla clinic. The clinic has since been shut down and the district surveillance team is trying to get the list of patients that visited the facility over the five days. It is likely the number will over 100 cases, all possibly infected by the doctor.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Madhya Pradesh on lockdown from today, borders sealed
Content: BHOPAL: Amid the coronavirus threat and increasing positive cases in Madhya Pradesh , acting chief minister Kamal Nath on Sunday directed top officials to maintain a complete shutdown by closing all business establishments in the state.“After discussions with chief secretary and the DGP, the acting chief minister has asked to maintain adequate vigilance in the state in view of the Covid-19 outbreak. He also directed a complete shutdown by closing all business establishments in the state as per the requirement,” said Congress media coordinator Narendra Saluja . Nath, who resigned on March 20 amid the political crisis in the state, also called upon the public to voluntarily close their establishments and stay at their homes, not to organise social gatherings and undertake trips to prevent the coronavirus epidemic from spreading in the state.“People should avoid crowded places and immediately inform the authorities about any suspect or infected person. I reiterate that due to preventive measures to control coronavirus, such as closure of markets, closing of commercial areas and offices, small shopkeepers, traders and daily workers are facing problems to earn their livelihood,” said Nath.

Title: Rayalaseema dists remain indoors to break virus chain
Content:
Srisailam is nearly empty due to janata curfew on Sunday

Tirupati: People across the four Rayalaseema districts extended their solidarity to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call, and observed janata curfew to fight against the outbreak of COVID-19, by remaining indoors throughout Sunday.

At 7 am, an eerie silence pervaded across the four districts of Chittoor, Kadapa, Kurnool and Anantapur, as people confined themselves to their homes.

In the temple city of Tirupati in Chittoor district, where all major temples including, Lord Venkateswara temple, have been shut down to pilgrims, hotels, restaurants, fast-food joints and eateries, commercial establishments and shops, educational institutions, colleges and universities, state and central government offices, banks and other financial institutions, etc, remained shut throughout day. Consequently, all important arterial junctions wore a deserted look.

Similarly, janata curfew was observed in chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy’s home district Kadapa. The ever-busy Koti Reddy Circle, bus stations, railway stations, vegetable markets, commercial streets etc, wore a deserted look throughout the day.

In Anantapur district, people who completed their last minute purchases of essential goods by Saturday, did not venture out of their homes, and extended complete support to janata curfew.

In Kurnool district, prominent places of worship at Srisailam, Ahobilam and Mantralayam and other parts of the district remained closed. The famous Konda Reddy Buruju circle, which is always abuzz with activity remained empty throughout the day, except for the presence of a few police personnel.

Around 5pm people came out in the balconies and on to the streets to applaud and express their gratitude towards doctors, nurses, paramedics, municipalities and airport workers, who have been rendering round-the-clock services at a time when the pandemic is wrecking havoc across the globe.

Title: 50% state govt employees to work from home till April 14
Content:
Vijayawada: In an effort to stop the spread of Covid-19, the state government has decided to let 50 per cent of its employees to work from home .

Sets of employees will have to attend office in alternate weeks. This order will be in force till April 4.

All departments of the secretariat, heads of departments, district offices have been asked to ensure that 50 per cent of employees attend office, while the remaining 50 per cent should work from home. The departments have been advised to draft a weekly duty roster.

At the state secretariat, all section officers, assistant section officers and others will be grouped into two, with each having 50 per cent employees who will come to office in alternate weeks. Remaining officers will be required to be in office regularly.

Non-gazetted officials at the head of departments, district offices and others will work from home on alternate weeks.

Gazetted officers have been asked to work from office.

Officials who have been appointed as advisors, chairpersons and consultants and are above 60 years of age have been allowed to work from home by taking permission from heads of departments without adversely affecting their consultancy fee or honorarium.

Officials above 50 years of age and having underlying medical conditions such as diabetes, renal diseases, respiratory problems and other life-threatening illnesses and wish to self-quarantine will be granted committed leave without being required to produce a medical certificate.

Contractual or outsourced staff will also be allowed attend office on a rotational basis like regular employees. Employees attending office will be grouped into three and work in three shifts to minimise large gatherings.

However, all staff permitted to work from home need to be available over telephone and other electronic modes of communication. These instructions will not apply to essential services.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Two flyers with ‘flu-like’ symptoms sent to hospital
Content: BHOPAL: Two flyers who got off at Bhopal’s Raja Bhoj airport on Sunday were rushed to JP Hospital as they were showing ‘flu-like’ symptoms, said officials.A 20-year-old suspect along with 17 other passengers alighted from an Air India flight from Delhi. After she complained of cold and cough, she was rushed to the the hospital, officials said.Another passenger from Bengaluru on an IndiGo flight too was sent to the hospital along with his kid. “He was sent to the hospital on suspicion of symptoms,” said a senior airport official.The Air India flight which was to take off for Pune after a brief stop here, was delayed for around one hour, said Air India acting airport manager Shamsher Khan. “All 44 passengers who flew for Pune at 11.40am were properly sanitized and screened,” he said.“All the procedure were followed before the flight took off,” he added.Officials said that flight was sanitised completely before it was allowed to move as the authorities did not give them permission.CMHO, Sudhir Kumar issued a press statement where he said that a suspect who came in the morning has been isolated and her condition is stable. He said that all possible facilities have been arranged to tackle any situation. Asked the stopping of flight movement, director airport Anil Vikram said there were no instructions on grounding the flights at Bhopal airport . “Air travel is not covered in the order,” said director Vikram.

Title: Kanpur: 25 identified as suspect at railway station, quarantined
Content:
Representative Image

KANPUR: As many as 25 rail travellers coming from Delhi and Mumbai were quarantined as suspected cases of corona at Kanpur Central on Saturday night.

According to health department, a medical team deployed at Central railway station conducted thermal screening of 1,200 railway passengers. The department had deputed teams of two doctors and paramedical staff at the Central railway station for screening of the passengers arriving in the city.

A medical team has also been deputed at the Kanpur airport for thermal screening of passengers.

Dr Ashok Shukla, on Sunday evening, issued a medical bulletin and apprised that around 12 suspected foreign travellers had been identified and all of them have been quarantined. One of them had been sent to isolation while samples of two cases had been collected.

He informed that health teams had so far collected as many as 65 samples and 11 out of them were found negative.

One sample was rejected. Since rest samples were not as per the norms for lab examinations they were not found fit for examinations. So far not a single positive case was found in the city, he added.

Shukla said that a mock drill regarding the treatment of corona patients was conducted under the supervision of officers of the World Health Organization at UHM hospital.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Not enough laser thermal scanners in MP, state tells HC
Content: BHOPAL: The state government has admitted in the M P high court that it doesn’t have enough laser thermal scanners and that they are being purchased from wherever they are available. The state government presented a status report on the coronavirus situation before the double bench of Chief Justice A K Mittal and Justice V K Shukla The court, which is hearing petitions relating to the coronavirus menace, will next hear the case on March 26.Sunil Jain, an advocate from Gwalior, who is also among the petitioners, had stated in the court that the state government is ill-equipped to handle the situation arising out of the spread of COVID-19 in the country. It doesn’t have adequate medical facilities to isolate coronavirus-infected persons for treatment, the petition said. Besides, it does not have laser thermal scanners to check people at public places, including government offices, district courts, bus stands and railway stations, it added.The court, in this context, had asked the state government to present a status report and asked whether it has enough laser thermal scanners.

Title: Hundreds defy ‘janta curfew’ in Aligarh & Moradabad to protest against CAA
Content:
AGRA/BAREILLY: While their cities wore a deserted look, women in UP’s Aligarh and Moradabad defied the self-imposed curfew and gathered in hundreds to protest against CAA, notwithstanding appeals given against it by religious leaders, police and administration. In Moradabad, police have decided to book the protesters who had gathered at Eidgah on Sunday.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi had given a call for ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday to curb the spread of now novel coronavirus-- a highly-contagious disease. Even in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh-- which inspired similar sit-ins across UP and other parts of the country-- the protest became symbolic and the size was cut to just five.

In Deoband, the home to one of the largest Islamic seminaries of the world, the anti-CAA protest was called off. Several religious and political leaders of the community have asked people not gather for any protest. Moradabad MP Dr ST Hasan had also asked people of his city to stay indoors.

But, not heeding to the appeals, the protesters, mostly women, came out and staged a sit-in at Moradabad’s Eidgah, putting local police and the health department in a fix, which is already facing a tough time after surfacing of positive case of coronavirus in the city.

“Around 500 protesters reached Eidgah ground and started a sit-in protest there. Their act may fuel the epidemic. We are going to book them under IPC section 188 (disobedience of order duly promulgated by a public servant) and other relevant sections for posing threat to others’ lives,” said Amit Kumar Anand, additional superintendent of police (city).

One of the organisers at the sit-in site, Waqi Rashid, said, “Coronavirus cannot be controlled by a one-day curfew.”

While in Aligarh, over 500 women protesters continued with their sit-in against the Citizenship (amendment) Act (CAA). The protest against CAA is going on at Aligarh’s Shah Jamal Idgah ground since January 29.

The district administration had served a notice to the organiser two days ago asking them to vacate the place for 10 days amid coronavirus fears or “face legal action”. However, neither the protesters nor the organizers have paid heed to it.

Talking to TOI, Aligarh district magistrate (DM) CB Singh said, “Action will be taken against them.”

However, remaining parts of Aligarh, including Muslim-dominated areas of Jeevangarh, Jamalpur and Upper Kot, followed the appeal of PM Modi and stayed at home.

The administration has, meanwhile, decided to screen people coming from Delhi, Noida, Agra and Mathura.

‘Munadi’ (announcement) was also made by the municipal corporation officials urging people to stay indoors to combat spread of Covid-19. Confirming this, municipal corporation sanitary enforcement inspector Bishan Singh, said, “Munadi was organised in seven zones on Sunday to make people aware about the disease.”

Title: Tirupati SP asks foreign returnees to get tested
Content:
Tirupati: Tirupati SP Avula Ramesh Reddy has appealed to foreign returnees to come forward and get themselves tested and stay in isolation as per the Union government’s protocols. Reddy inspected several important arterial junctions in the temple city, which observed janata curfew.

Elaborating on the measures being taken by the officials of the district administration in coordination with the local police to identify foreign returnees, the SP said the district administration has identified over 670 foreign returnees in the district. “We have initiated a process to visit each one of them personally, get them tested for COVID-19 and put them under isolation,” he said.

Speaking to reporters, Tirupati SP thanked the people for showing solidarity to PM’s call. tnn

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Smoke from fire in godown kills 3-year-old
Content:
Representative Image

BAREILLY: A three-year-old girl died and her 27-year-old aunt was rendered unconsciousness after they inhaled smoke billowing out of the floor below. The two were trapped in the room when a fire broke out in a godown in the basement of the house in Quila area of Bareilly district on Sunday night.

Godown owner Aftab sold grass padding for air coolers and, therefore, had stored large quantity of grass in the basement of his house. On Sunday night, the dry grass in the godown caught fire. His wife, Shahana, and niece, Falak, were sleeping in the room when the fire broke out. The child died of asphyxiation while her aunt fell unconscious.

The fire was doused by firefighters, who prevented it from spreading in the neighbourhood. Both victims were rushed to hospital where Falak died while undergoing treatment. Shahana had not regained consciousness at the time of filing the report.

Manoj Kumar, SHO of Quila police station, told TOI, "The fire was doused soon by fightfighers and we provided them required support from our end. The three-year-old girl died after inhaling smoke but her aunt was saved. We may file a complaint against the godown owner for showing negligence and putting neighbours’ lives in danger.”

Title: Russian embassy to the rescue of couple selling photos at Lodhi Garden
Content: NEW DELHI: The foreign couple stranded in India after cancellation of their flight back home is now in safe hands. Russian embassy officials went looking for them after a TOI story showed how Viktor and Anna were selling pictures from their travels across the world in Lodhi Garden to fund their indefinitely extended stay in Delhi. The woman is a Russian while Viktor is a Ukranian. Anna is now registered with her embassy, which is taking care of her.“Anna is now staying with a friend,” said Yevgeny Bezeka, press secretary of the Russian Embassy in Delhi.“Overall, around 10,000 Russian citizens are presently in India. (Of them,) about 1,000 have informed us about their whereabouts and shared their details. Some Russians are unable to leave the country, most of who are in Goa and Rishikesh. The embassy of Russia keeps updating the advisory on its website. Telephone hotlines were launched at the embassy as well as at every consulate general of Russia,” Bezeka said.India has restricted schedule international flights for a week till next Sunday to prevent the spread of infection by the novel coronavirus in the country.However, India is operating a number of special flights to fly back its citizens from other other countries heavily affected by the pandemic like Wuhan in China, Italy and Japan. It is also allowing special flights by foreign airlines to fly Indians home and take back their stranded citizens from here.Viktor and Anna had told TOI they were to fly back home on Air Astana of March 23. But since no schedule international flight is allowed this week, they got stuck in Delhi.

Title: Buses at half strength, daily items available
Content: New Delhi: The Centre and Delhi government have made elaborate arrangements to ensure Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call to observe a janata curfew on Sunday keeps people indoors. While all offices – government and private – markets and other facilities will remain closed, essential services like hospitals and repair and maintenance offices of power and water will function as usual.The country will be observing an unprecedented shutdown on Sunday following Modi’s appeal for a janata curfew during which people have been urged to voluntarily stay indoors to check the spread of coronavirus While Delhi Metro services will not be available, most autorickshaw and app-based cabs will also remain off the road. All autorickshaw unions said they support the curfew and will not ply their vehicles. The app-based cab services, however, said, they will be available for essential and urgent travel.“In line with the Government’s advisory, we urge riders to observe the janata curfew on Sunday, March 22. However, we will offer services to meet the essential and urgent travel needs of the communities we serve,” said an Uber Spokesperson. An Ola spokesperson said: “As per the Hon'ble Prime Minister's appeal to the nation to take part in the janata curfew, we encourage all our users across India to avoid all non-essential travel from 7am to 9pm tomorrow. We will have limited availability of vehicles to support essential and emergency travel during this period.”Addressing a press conference, Kejriwal said only 50 per cent of the total DTC and cluster buses will be running on Sunday. “A lot of public transport such as autos and taxis will not be running. We have deliberated on the decision to suspend bus services for tomorrow. However, that will cause a problem in case of emergencies,” he said.No passenger train will originate from any railway station in the country from midnight to 10 pm on Sunday.All market associations have agreed to keep their shops closed the entire day. Essential services, such as pharmacies, groceries and vegetable shops, have been allowed to remain open.From suspending regular prayers in shrines of various faiths, including Sunday mass, to disallowing jail inmates from meeting their families on the day, organisations and institutions in every sphere have announced restrictions for Sunday.At 5pm, the cops, using police vehicles, will sound a siren for a minute except in the silent zone.BJP leaders, including Delhi state chief Manoj Tiwari, leader of the oppositition in Delhi Assembly Ramvir Singh Bidhuri and several MPs and MLAs have urged people to follow the janata curfew and remain indoors.

Title: Agency quiet during janata curfew, checkposts in place
Content: Visakhapatnam: Opposed to other days, which usually see almost a lakh floating population in the Agency, Sunday turned out to be an eerily silent day, with not a person to be seen. Locals observed janata curfew by staying at home.Officials claim that in the Agency areas, the awareness programmes have done the trick, with the public more than willing to cooperate. From shopkeepers to local residents, everybody ensured that the janata curfew was a success.“A majority of residents are aware of the dangers posed by coronavirus . Although public mobility has been checked due to the checkposts, which have been set up, they have adhered to the rules,” project officer DK Balaji said.Meanwhile, in order to stop the spread of Covid-19 in the Agency areas of Visakhapatnam district, coronavirus checkposts have been set up at Vaddadi-Paderu Ghat Road, S Kota to Araku Ghat Road and the Narsipatnam Ghat Road. The checkposts are meant to prevent outsiders from entering the Agency area.The checkposts are being manned by panchayati raj, police and revenue officials. These officials are only allowing residents of the Agency into ghat roads. Officials of the Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) confirmed that these measures will go on till March 31 to prevent flow of traffic into the Agency.Speaking to TOI, ITDA project officer DK Balaji said, “We have ensured that no tourists and merchants step into the Agency. In order to prevent the flow of merchants, we have also contained the village shanties in the Agency as a secondary precaution.”“Even those being allowed to come in are allowed only after verifying their identity. We are also keeping track of them, taking down their addresses and telephone numbers, thereby alerting local officials of their arrival,” Balaji said.ITDA sources said that thermometers that don’t require touching are also being procured.

Title: Kanpur: Father, brother arrested for honour killing
Content:
Representative Image

KANPUR: Father and brother of a 21-year-old girl, who was hacked to death in an alleged case of honour killing, have been arrested by Maharajpur police of the district on Saturday.

Chaman Lal and his son Luvlesh were arrested on Saturday for killing the girl on December 25, 2019 over her alleged affair and her court marriage with a youth outside her caste, inspector Maharajpur Raghvendra Singh said.

The girl, Reem Pal , was allegedly having an affair with a youth from Yadav community, he said.

“The two got married in court on November 27, 2019, however, she came back home the same day, but went missing thereafter,” said police.

Sensing trouble, her alleged boy friend Dharamveer Singh Yadav lodged an FIR on December 28 accusing her father and siblings, besides her uncle of kidnapping Reema. Subsequently, the police launched an investigation in this regard.

The police thereafter arrested girl’s uncle Chande Lal and her brother Divesh on January 9 and March 5 and sent them to jail.

“During interrogation the accused father-son duo, who were arrested on Saturday from nearby Chatmara village, told the police that they took the girl to Industrial area in Chakeri and hacked her to death with a hammer and threw her body in a sewer tank. On the basis of clues provided by them, we have recovered the badly decomposed girl’s body stuffed inside a sack,” said inspector further, adding that they have confessed to their crime.

The duo was sent to jail on Sunday, the officer added.

Title: Police ‘force’ grocery, medical storeowners shut down in Shahjahanpur
Content:
Bareilly: Even as people were expecting that grocery and medical stores would remain open during the ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday, police in Shahjahanpur allegedly made these store owners shut their outlets

A senior police officer told TOI, “The department has been instructed to ensure complete shut down for the safety of locals as a large number of people, mainly labourers, are returning to their native place from Metro cities and screening everyone is not possible. In such a situation, the movement needs to be restricted.”

Rameez Khan, owner of a medical store near the railway station, told TOI, “I opened my store considering people need medicines in emergency, but two policemen from Ashfaqnagar police outpost forced me to shut down my store. When I refused then they threatened to thrash me. They were extremely arrogant. The policemen said that they had clear instructions from their SHO to ensure that all shops were closed. ”

Mahesh Gupta, a grocery shop owner in Jalalnagar locality, said Modi Ji said it was a ‘Janata Curfew’ and would not be forced upon the people, but the way policemen behaved “it appears that we are criminals. In this fight against coronavirus, we must ensure that residents’ get their daily needs fulfilled.”

When asked about the matter, Shahjahanpur SSP Shivasimpi Channappa told TOI, “I have not instructed policemen to close the medical stores. My subordinates told me that medical store owners closed down voluntarily.”

Title: Staying At Home To Keep Corona Out
Content: Vijayawada: The city came to a standstill on Sunday as residents stayed indoors as part of the nation-wide call for a janata curfew to counter the spread of Covid-19 Mahatma Gandhi Road (Bandar Road), Karl Marx Road (Eluru Road), Sambamurthy Road, Tikkle Road, Besant Road, Museum Road and other main roads in the city remained deserted through the day.Except for pharmacies and hospitals, business establishments stalled operations. Milk booths and vegetable stalls completed sales by 7 am joined the curfew.An awareness programme was held by the Indian Red Cross Society at Benz Circle junction, urging the public to make the curfew a success. City police put up checkposts at multiple locations in the city and requested motorists to return home.Kanaka Durga temple and other temples including Mutyalampadu Sai Babu temple and Siva Rama Krishna Kshetram remained closed in support of the curfew.Pandit Nehru Bus Station (PNBS), the state’s largest bus terminal, was empty from the early hours of Sunday as officials suspended services. Some passengers were seen at Vijayawada Junction railway station, even after the Railways announced that all trains were cancelled till March 31.Private taxi operators and autorickshaws also stayed off the roads while the movement of heavy vehicles on National Highway (NH)-16 lessened from Saturday night. On average, around 25,000 vehicles pass through the city on the NH-16 every day. To mark Sunday’s curfew, truck drivers parked their vehicles at locations specified by National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) authorities.

Title: Cops look for threewho travelled with Covid-19 patient
Content: Vijayawada: With the first corona positive case being confirmed in the city, officials of Krishna and Guntur districts are on the lookout for three others who travelled with the person in the same car to Guntur from Vijayawada. The car was hired by the 23-year-old person who had returned to Vijayawada from Paris Krishna district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz said after the person deboarded at Vijayawada, three people, including the cab driver , travelled to Guntur. “We appeal to those who travelled from Vijayawada to Guntur on March 17 to come forward and undergo tests and stay in isolation as they might have contracted the disease. It would be easier for the authorities if they come forward voluntarily instead of them being tracked down and shifted to isolation,” he said.The collector said the district administration is on high alert and a community screening is being done in the neighbourhood of the person who has tested positive. Officials are trying to trace the people who came in contact with the person, said ImtiazMeanwhile, city police commissioner Ch Dwaraka Tirumala Rao said section 144 has been imposed in the city in view of the first positive case being reported.

Title: Day before curfew: Metro, buses, streets empty out
Content: New Delhi: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has given a call for a ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday to make the masses show self-restraint and isolate themselves in order to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus . But Delhi appeared to have entered the curfew mode on Saturday itself.Most roads in the city were unusually empty for a weekend and in many parts of south and central Delhi, not many vehicles were spotted on the roads in the morning. Growing awareness about Covid-19 meant that Delhiites stayed home. Closure of the usual haunts, such as malls, markets, cinema halls and restaurants, deterred those who wanted to venture out.The lifelessness in the capital was reflected in Delhi Metro seeing such a massive dip in passenger numbers that at peak hours there weren’t any standing commuters even on the busiest Blue (Dwarka-Noida/Vaishali) and Yellow (Samaypur Badli) Lines. While the average ‘passenger journeys’ recorded in February was 57.1 lakh, the figure slid to 37 lakh on Thursday and further dipped to 30.9 lakh on Friday. The figures for Saturday were not available at the time of filing this report, but according to footfall monitoring sources, the numbers have plummeted.Bus transport, which has recorded a dip of four lakh passengers per day in the first 15 days of March compared with the figures of February, also reported a substantial fall in ridership on Saturday. “The number of bus passengers has been consistently dipping because people are not coming out of their homes now unless compelled by urgent requirements,” a Delhi Transport Corporation official told TOI. “Though the ridership figures for Saturday are yet to be compiled, occupancy in the buses was visibly low.”The popular Sarojini Nagar market, where a sea of humanity congregates every weekend, was so eerily deserted on Saturday that some shop owners could be seen driving their vehicles inside the market lanes. Normally this is impossible due to the crowds. “Only medicines stores and shops selling fruits and vegetables were open on Saturday,” said Ashok Randhawa, president, Sarojini Nagar Mini Market Traders’ Association. “As most people are aware about the market closure, there were very few shoppers. Our volunteers informed even the few who were here about the shutdown.”Randhawa added it was perhaps for the first time in decades that not only was the market closed but even the hawkers were absent. “Due to the coronavirus fear, sales are down 80%. People come only to buy essentials,” said Randhawa. “Shop assistants and employees have left for their homes in UP and Bihar.”The scenes were similar in Defence Colony and Connaught Place, with only shops dealing in essential goods operating. Some restaurants had their shutters half-down, but had only takeaway service.

Title: Family of Covid-19 patient in isolation
Content: Kakinada: East Godavari district is on high alert with the first case of coronavirus in the district being confirmed. A 22-year-old student from Rajahmundry who returned from London was confirmed to have Covid-19, on Saturday night.The student’s friends called Hyderabad on Friday night and informed him that they had tested positive for coronavirus, following which he contacted Rajahmundry municipal corporation who admitted him at the Government General Hospital in Kakinada.Speaking to TOI, Dr Ramesh Kishore, district coordinator of health services, said that the coronavirus-affected youth from Rajahmundry has been admitted in isolated ward in GGH, Kakinada and four family members—his father, mother, younger sister and grandmother—have also been shifted to isolated ward on Saturday at midnight. Dr Kishore said that the police managed to trace the auto driver who brought the affected from the airport and kept in a special room set up at Rajahmundry government hospital. He added that the driver’s 18 friends with whom he interacted closely were being kept in isolation ward set up at Bommuru in Rajahmundry.Superintendent, GGH, Kakinada, Dr. Raghavendra Rao said that in all, nine people had been admitted in the isolated ward, including the coronavirus-affected student, his parents and his friends. The hospital superintendent said everyone was stable.Meanwhile, a high alert has been declared at Veerabhadrapuram area in Rajahmundry where the student lived. A 500-m radius area has been declared as a containment area and people in the area have been urged stay indoors for 14 days. An area of three kilometres radius has been declared as buffer zone.According to authorities, 1,590 persons out of 1,600 who returned to the district from foreign countries are under home quarantine. The remaining 10 have been admitted to hospitals.

Title: Coronavirus in Bhopal: On ground zero, anxious locals & questions for administration
Content: BHOPAL: The state capital’s first Coronavirus case sparked anxiety in the city on Sunday, especially in the colony where the patient lives.The locality was abuzz with rumours since the afternoon of March 21 when neighbours spotted an ambulance at her house. When they inquired with the ambulance staff, they were apparently told it was a swab sample collection.As the residents knew that she had returned from London, they were worried. Soon messages started appearing on social media groups of the colony about a “positive case” in the colony though the test report was yet to come. Some residents even called the local police station. A team of cops had accompanied the medical staff while the swab samples were taken, but police denied any information.“Aisa kuch nahi hai”, ( there is no such thing),” they told residents over phone when asked about the “corona case”.Till Sunday afternoon, police continued to deny. After the media broke the story, local residents called up Bhopal municipal corporation and demanded fumigation around the house of the patient. Around 3pm, two BMC personnel arrived and fumigated the area around the house.In a video message in the evening, district collector Tarun Pithode said, “There is no need to panic as the protocol required to check the further spread of the disease is followed and safety measures taken. The colony where it has happened is being sanitized and cleaned”.Barely 10 minutes before the confirmation of the positive case by the media, four cops were posted near house of the family.A local resident Vinay Sharma said,” I talked to the cops but they said it was a negative case.”Dhrupad maestro and the family’s neighbor, Umakant Gundecha said “ I learnt about the positive case through media reports in the afternoon and not through the district administration. I expected the administration to be around in the colony to handle the anxiety of the local residents.”Mahesh Sahu, an advocate and resident of the colony said , “ I expect that the administration must be knowing about status of the case much before the media broke the news of positive case. But no one from the administration was seen in the colony. A fumigation unit of BMC arrived after local residents made the calls.”Many residents also rushed to the medical stores for “ preventive medicine”. Owner of a pharmacy in New Market, Suresh Agrawal, said, “People were buying Hydrochlroquine or Chloroquine along with Azithromycin to combat Covid 19.” This was due to a WhatsApp forward that claimed this was a magic cure for Covid-19 though there is no official confirmation of this.

Title: US-returned woman dies in Haridwar; cremated as per Covid-19 guidelines
Content: Haridwar: A 58-year-old woman, who had returned from the US on March 8 with her husband, died at the BHEL hospital in Haridwar on Sunday. A resident of Shivalik Nagar, she had subsequently developed symptoms of sore throat, cold and cough and on Saturday evening complained of uneasiness.Chief medical officer Saroj Naithani told TOI that her case can at best be described as “a suspected Covid-19 case as she was not examined for it at any stage.” She added: “Her samples had not been taken for Covid-19 testing and autopsies are not conducted in such cases as per guidelines, so we are terming her as a suspect Covid-19 case. Since she was diabetic and suffered from hypertension and kidney trouble as well, the death might have taken place due to cardiac arrest.”The health department, however, oversaw her cremation as per guidelines laid down for Covid-19 patients; only five people were allowed to participate in the last rites. The woman's husband and their two tenants have been asked to remain quarantined in the house for the next 14 days. A list is being prepared of all those who might have come in contact with her so that they can be quarantined as well as a precautionary measure, Naithani said.Meanwhile, in another development, Haridwar Mela Hospital chief medical superintendent Rajesh Gupta told TOI that five students (between 18 and 22 years) from a hotel management institute in Udaipur were put in the hospital's isolation ward on Sunday “on suspicion of being infected with Coronavirus.” Their blood samples were being sent for examination, he added. The students, all from Uttarakhand, had returned to the state recently after completing their course.

Title: ‘Don’t spread misinformation’
Content: Visakhapatnam: The 24-year-old male from Vijayawada, who tested positive for COVID-19 on Saturday, requested the public to not emotionally drain his family and him by spreading misinformation.In a social media post on Sunday, the youth, who is currently receiving treatment at a special isolation ward, said that he first arrived in Delhi airport from Paris on March 16. After showing no symptoms in the screening tests, the officials there granted him permission to take a connecting flight to Hyderabad.“After landing in Hyderabad, I took a private cab to land in Vijay- awada. The municipal officials, who approached me, asked me to self-quarantine, which I did. After developing a fever like symptoms, I informed the health officials and later tested positive. I urge the public to support me for a speedy recovery to be a role model for others,“ said the youth in a video.Krishna district collector A Md Imtiaz said that they alerted people in a radius of 3 km surrounding the home of the COVID patient in the city. tnn

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Railways relaxes refund rules for cancelled tickets
Content: BAREILLY: After railways cancelled trains to curb Covid-19 from spreading, rules relating to refund against cancellation of passenger reservation system (PRS) tickets have been relaxed in order to avoid crowding at the counters. Railway authorities said all rules for e-ticket will remain same so that a passenger does have to come to the station to collect the refund amount.Officials said full refund of tickets for all cancelled trains can be collected till June 21. Earlier, the refund had to be collected within three days of cancellation.Senior commercial manager (SCM) of Moradabad division, Rekha, said adequate arrangements are being made to facilitate hassle-free refund to passengers affected by train cancellation.Railways officials said passengers who want to cancel their ticket on their own through railway telephone service --139-- can also get a refund across the counter till June 21.“We advise passengers to avoid coming to the railway station and avail of the said facility once the situation is normal,” said the SCM.All passenger trains have been cancelled till March 31. Only those trains that commenced journey prior to 4 am on March 22 will run up to their destination. Officials said to ensure the essential supplies in various parts of the country, goods trains will be allowed to continue plying.

Title: Delhi Protest News: Clashes break out at two protest sites in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: There was ruckus at Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia protest sites since Saturday over the continuation of the anti CAA-protests amidst the Covid-19 scare. Two groups clashed over the decision to halt the protest, and later, one of them even hurled molotov cocktails at the barricades near Shaheen Bagh on Sunday morning. Police said no one was injured and recovered an empty cartridge near the Jamia protest site.Locals claimed that they saw two men throwing a molotov cocktail at Shaheen Bagh tents and setting a placard on fire. A similar incident was reported from Jamia protest site too. DCP (South East) R P Meena said two cases were registered and efforts were being made to identify the men.The Sunday’s incident was reported at 9.15am when police were informed about an alleged firing near Shaheen Bagh. A police team reached the scene and found some items were set on fire near the police barricade, while a few white substances were lying around.Locals claimed they had seen two bikers setting bamboo logs and ropes on fire before throwing molotov cocktail at the barricade. The men fled towards Jamia University, they added. The CCTV footage from the area are being scanned to identify the bikers.“We suspect it to be a ploy to dislodge us from the spot. Our protest has been peaceful all along. There are also enough precautions taken against the spread of the virus,” said Imran, one of the protesters.On Saturday, some of the protesters held a meeting with police and agreed to call off the protest for a few days. However, soon after, another group, unhappy with the move, started an argument claiming that they were not consulted and the protest would continue. Following this, a clash broke out between the groups, which was resolved only after police intervention.

Title: Vizianagaram man tests negative for Covid-19
Content: Vizianagaram: The swab results of the 32-year-old man from Vizianagaram suspected to have novel coronavirus came back negative on Sunday.Vizianagaram authorities said that the man had been under treatment for the last four days and responded well. Officials added that he would be kept under medical watch at the district hospital, till he recovered completely.“The situation is under total control in Vizianagaram district. The only suspect patient so far has tested negative. To keep things tight, apart from the dedicated 28 isolated beds in both Vizianagaram and Parvathipuram hospitals, we also have 17 dedicated ventilators in case of emergency,” G Nagabhushan Rao, district hospitals coordinator said.Dr Ramani Kumari, district medical & health officer, added that the medical staff and district administration are keeping a strict watch on each and every household. “The door-to-door survey taken up has covered almost 90% of the households,” Dr Ramani Kumari said. She added that the five foreigners who have been quarantined at their hotel for the last four days were asymptomatic and healthy.Sources in the district administration stated that the Janata Curfew was a complete success, with people not venturing out of their households at all.

Title: Student with quarantine mark offloaded from Rajdhani at Nagpur
Content: NAGPUR: A student with quarantine stamp on his hand was stopped from travelling further, and offloaded at Nagpur station, on Sunday. He was taken to MLA Hostel quarantine facility as a precaution in an ambulance of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC).On Saturday, a New Delhi-based couple was detrained at Kazipeth from Bengaluru-New Delhi Rajdhani Express The 21-year-old student, travelling in New Delhi-Chennai Express, had returned from Russia to Delhi. He had a ticket to Chennai and was in AC-3 tier B2 coach. He is a resident of Vijayawada.The student, travelling alone, was screened at the Covid-19 test booth set up by Central Railways near Platform 1, which is manned by Railway Protection Force (RPF) and medical team of the railway hospital. His temperature recording was ‘normal’, said a railway source.Though the railway personnel tried their best to convince the student, tension and disappointment were writ large on his face as he pulled his luggage into the ambulance before it sped away.Some co-passengers spotted the home quarantine stamp on his hand at Itarsi when the train reached there around 10.30am. Panicked, they immediately informed TTE Sunil Kumar Singh, who alerted commercial control room and Nagpur railway station.At Nagpur, assistant commercial manager (goods) SG Rao and a nursing team led by Central Railway hospital’s divisional medical officer Dr Chandrashekhar were ready for assistance along with deputy station superintendents Manish Gaur and Atul Shrivastav. The commercial department personnel had alerted the state government control room, seeking assistance to shift the passenger to the quarantine facility at MLA Hostel.“When the train reached Platform 2 at Nagpur railway station at 2.30pm, we de-trained the passenger. There was no panic as the passenger has not yet tested positive for coronavirus ,” said Rao. “We sanitized the entire coach at Nagpur before the train left for further journey,” Rao added. “Every part of the coach passengers may use was sanitized thoroughly,” he said.Sources from MLA Hostel said the student would not be tested as he was not a ‘patient’ but only identified as ‘home quarantine’. He would be released after at least 48 hours as per the latest government guidelines, if no symptoms surface. “He (the student) would be tested if he develops symptoms. Under no circumstances would he be allowed to use public transport before 14 days, and will have to stay back at the quarantine facility at MLA Hostel,” said a health official.As thousands of people use railway network, passenger trains are seen as the biggest means of spreading coronavirus. It is becoming very difficult for even officials and front-line staff to detect suspect cases.On Saturday, after co-passengers observed a home quarantine seal on a man’s hand, a Delhi-based couple was offloaded at Kazipeth in Telangana on Saturday. The AC compartment in which they were travelling was sealed after sanitization and passengers adjusted in other compartments.

Title: Total bandh in Jhansi during Janata Curfew
Content:
Jhansi: An unprecedented calm prevailed in the city for the entire day because of self-isolation by the denizens on the appeal of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

At 5.00 pm people came out on terrace and balconies to clap as a gesture of thanks to all those unsung heroes who are fighting day and night to fight against coronavirus.

A strict vigil was maintained at bus stands and all the major crossings while police vehicles took round requesting people to stay inside.

At railway station, all the passengers arriving in the city had to undergo therma screening. Senior administrative officials including commissioner Jhansi division Shubhash Chandra Sharma and IG Jhansi range Shubhash Singh Baghel took rounds monitoring the entire city. During the day Nagar Nigam workers spryaed sanitiser in various localities of the city. Talking to TOI, Jhansi DM Andra Vamsi said, “Let us fight Covid-19 collectively by social distancing ourselves and maintain the same momentum till April 2”.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Unprecedented response to ‘janta curfew’
Content: BHOPAL: Eerie silence prevailed on the roads in Bhopal city on Sunday as people responded overwhelmingly to Prime Minister, Narendra Modi ’s call for 14-hour ‘Janta curfew ’ across the country from 7.00 am to 9.00 pm.It was a virtual curfew-like situation with police and security personnel seen at some places and barely one or two vehicles seen in a distance of about a Km on roads. The extent of undeclared lockdown could be gauged by the fact that in some areas, even newspapers were not distributed in the morning. In several localities milk booths, petrol pumps and medical shops were also closed, though they had been exempted from ‘Janta curfew’.Vinod Shrivastava, who runs a medical shop at Mandakini shopping complex in Kolar, said he had opened his shop but it was difficult sitting in the completely deserted complex and even customers were not coming to buy anything. “I closed the shop after an hour and went home. I didn’t see a single person on the road in that one hour”, he said.In the entire stretch from Trilanga to M P Nagar Zone I at 4.00 pm, not a single shop was open including milk booths, medical shops and pan shops.Alok Tiwari, who stays in an apartment on Hoshangabad Road said it was a strange feeling watching some boys playing cricket on road towards the evening, the same roads which usually remain clogged with traffic.Shops stayed closed in markets of the old city as well, but movement of people and traffic was much more than in new Bhopal areas.Sunday remains a holiday in any case, but knowing that everyone has to remain indoors, people had made plans on how to pass time without boredom.Manas Mishra, a government employee told TOI that his day started with a family prayer. “After worshipping our ancestral idol, we recited Hanuman Chalisa for positive vibes, which was live streamed on our extended family WhatsApp group. In the afternoon, we settled down to make ourselves a typical Malwa meal of ‘daal baati’ which everyone relished. We took a nap and watched a film. In the evening, we all assembled on our front porch with our thalis to extend support to the brave souls, who are out there offering services for everyone’s protection.”The self-imposed curfew also gave time to everyone to do something which they are not able to do otherwise due to lack of time. Rishi Manuja said, “Being a professional I don’t get to spend a lot of time with myself. Whenever possible, I spent a lot of time busting myths on WhatsApp because fake news is so dangerous. People don’t understand that there is a difference between holding on to positive thoughts and staying in denial. My family WhatsApp group was bustling with discussions around Corona and I actively participated because I think awareness starts with our families.”If the response to call for “Janta Curfew” was unprecedented so was the call to express gratitude to people engaged in essential services braving the threat from Coronavirus . People clapping, banging thalis or ringing bells (ghantis) appeared on their terrace in several societies and colonies as a gesture of gratitude towards them. At some places, though, people while doing so assembled on the gate of a society or a playground in the midst of the houses, which wasn’t advisable.People also felt that the “Janta Curfew” also turned out to be successful in terms of spreading awareness about Coronavirus and how it spreads as far they were not taking interest in the matter, thinking it’s not a big deal.Angel Saxena, a photographer said, “Being a citizen of the nation, I understood the importance of the Janta curfew. It united us all in a sense. Now we know that it’s almost our duty not to go out and stay inside homes and this is the bare minimum that we all can do at this point of time. It’s a collective fight. The non-suspected citizens have a greater role to play so let’s not panic and hope for the best.”

Title: Coronavirus in Bhopal: Race to trace 22 who came in touch with city’s ‘patient zero’
Content: BHOPAL: The woman who tested positive for Coronavirus in Bhopal may have ended up infecting 22 people in train, her family members, people who attended a party at a farmhouse in city and others who came in her contact along railway station and airport.A kin of the patient is said to have attended a press conference at CM office in Bhopal during the political upheaval in the state last week.“We are appealing to all those who came in contact with the COVID-19 patient to come forward and get themselves tested,” said CMHO, Sudhir Dheriya Unconfirmed reports said the patient attended a party after arriving in Bhopal. Similar instances of ‘isolated patients’ attending parties are under investigation in Indore. Police has been asked to trace GPS location of the suspects.The huge task of contact tracing is the process of identifying, assessing and managing people who have been exposed to a disease to prevent transmission. “Details of movements of the family members are being shared with respective agencies. Affected and exposed peoples phone is being traced to contain any spread of the contagion,” said a senior district administration official.As a first measure, Indian Railways has been contacted and the people in the Shatabdi Express coach have been contacted, claimed district administration official. ‘Patient zero’ of the state capital and ‘the contacts’ would be under scanner for next 14-days.As per ICMR guidelines, people who may have been exposed to the contagion are to be tracked for 28 days. It is from the date of contact or exposure. Any person who has had contact with the COVID-19 positive patient is monitored symptoms. A mandatory self-quarantine for to be set in place.

Title: CAMIT seeks govt relaxation
Content:
Nagpur: Chamber of Associations of Maharashtra Industry and Trade (CAMIT) has requested the central government to relax few things for medium and small enterprises following various types of restrictions amid Covid-19.

In a letter sent to finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, Dipen Agrawal, President CAMIT, said, “Trade and industry were already in distress due to the worldwide economic slowdown during the last two years. Now, the world is going to confront the economy collapse due to the Covid-19 pandemic. In these hard times, Indian business enterprises, particularly the Small and Medium Enterprises, will be hard hit in short to mid-term. Besides its worrying effects on human life, this pandemic has the capability to slow down the economy. The impact of the same is clearly visible in trade and business. India is among the 15 most affected economies by COVID-19. Demand of goods is vanishing day by day as the number of affected cases are increasing. The situation will worsen due to lockdowns announced to prevent India from entering stage 3 of pandemic.”

Agrawal added, “Government should consider six points. All EMIs, including those of term-loans, should be extended by 90 days without penal interest or late payment charges and the borrower should be saved from adverse rating by CIBIL. Banks and financial institutions should be directed not to take adverse action and relax the conditions related to maintenance of margin against working capital limits obtained to run businesses for at least 90 days. Payment of Letter of Credit (LC) should be extended by atleast 90 days without any penal interest against Letter of Assurance from beneficiaries to avoid any mischief and chaos so as to protect the interest of banks as well as business entity. All time bound commitments under Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) such as collections from foreign debtors, export commitments, payment to foreign creditors, etc. which fall due between March 15 to April 30 should be extended by 90 days from their due date. Payment of GST for the month of February to April should be extended by 90 days without any penal interest and GSTIN should allow submission of returns without insisting on payment of GST. All regulatory compliances under substantive laws such as Income Tax, GST, PF, ESIC, Registrar of Companies (ROC) etc. and filling of returns should be extended for 90 days without there being any late fee due, he said.

Title: 30L houses for EWS, to have Swiss tech
Content:
Vijayawada: For the first time in the history of Andhra Pradesh, the government has decided to provide 30 lakh houses to Economically Weaker Sections ( EWS ) with the world-class ‘Indo-Swiss energy-efficient building technology’ which helps considerably reduce temperatures inside the house, enhance thermal comfort (cooling) and substantial reduction in energy consumption.

After the state cabinet took the decision to construct 30 lakh houses for EWS in 14,097 YSR Jagananna colonies, Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE) had swung into action and communicated with APSECM, SDA of AP and deputed Building Energy Efficiency Project officials who met principal secretary for AP Housing department Ajay Jain recently conveyed their willingness to implement the BEEP with the help of federal department of foreign affairs (FDFA) of the Swiss Confederation and assistance of AP State Energy Conservation Mission (APSECM), state-designated agency for Energy Efficiency of AP.

In this context, during a video conference with housing department and BEE and APSECM on Sunday, Ajay Jain said the government has decided to construct 30 lakh houses for weaker sections in next four years starting April 2020 that may be the biggest in the country and one of the biggest in the world. Jaganmohan Reddy has directed the department to use the best energy efficiency technologies while constructing the houses and provide the best living standards to the poor, Ajay Jain said.

Title: Narendra Modi: PM Modi bats for e-payment, ‘will aid social distancing’
Content:
This is the time to ensure Social Distancing. Digital Payments help you do that. Let’s listen to these stalwarts… https://t.co/1EY911dFug — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1584856907000

More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday nudged citizens to use digital payment tools as these are safer during the coronavirus pandemic.“This is the time to ensure social distancing. Digital payments help you do that. Let’s listen to these stalwarts and adopt digital payments,” the PM tweeted on Sunday, citing social media posts by four individuals — badminton player Srikanth Kadambi, cricketer Smriti Mandhana, Sequoia India’s Rajan Anandan and Aarin Capital chairman Mohandas Pai Separately, the finance ministry and banks too have been pushing citizens to use e-payment tools. “If you have to make payments, do it digitally and stay safe,” financial services secretary Debashish Panda too said in a video released on Twitter . Several banks have waived charges for digital transactions.Banks as well as ATM operators, however, said that some of the lenders are refilling ATMs more frequently, although there is no surge in cash withdrawals. A private sector bank said that last week it had increased the amount of cash by 20-25%, which was partly linked to the lifting of the moratorium imposed on Yes Bank as many lenders were expecting higher withdrawals from the troubled bank’s accounts.“With lockdown imposed in many parts of the country, the demand for cash is going to be lower in the coming weeks,” said a bank executive. Most banks have asked for additional safety measures at ATMs in the wake of Covid-19 with employees asked to clean the cashdispensing machines more frequently and use sanitisers.

Title: Self-isolation mandatory for foreign returnees: DGP
Content:
Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradessh police has issued an advisory to foreign returnees to be in self-isolation, besides reporting to local authorities, as mandatory precaution. DGP D Gautam Sawang said in a statement that most of the reported positive cases are foreign returnees.

In view of the available facts, the police have made it mandatory for foreign returnees to inform local authorities about their travel and undergo necessary tests by staying in home isolation. The DGP further said it is a mandatory precaution that everyone has to take according to law.

The DGP said local police stations have increased surveillance of foreign returnees and will be tracking their movements. If anyone is found violating the self-isolation directive, penal action will be initiated against them, Sawang said in a statement on Sunday.

He added that hiding travel details will amount to a crime and cases will be filed against them. As the situation demands emergency measures to be taken up, it is essential for everyone to fall into line and cooperate with the authorities, the DGP said, adding, that negligence by one person could result in a community being affected.

Title: Undecided on shutdown, govt prefers stringent restrictions
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The state reported 15 more Covid-19 cases – its highest single-day number, so far — on Sunday. The total number of positive cases in the state has now touched 67.Even though the government has not confirmed a community spread in any district, demands for a total shutdown of the state, due to the sudden spurt in cases, have grown shriller. In the last three days alone, 39 cases were reported.Meanwhile, the state government is yet to take a decision on the advisory of the Union government on closing down districts worst affected by Covid-19. The advisory calls for the shutdown of seven districts in the state.On Sunday, Kasaragod reported five new cases with Kannur accounting for four. Kozhikode, Ernakulam and Malappuram had two each. This is the first time that cases have been reported from Kozhikode.Overall, Kasaragod has 19 cases, followed by 12 in Ernakulam, 10 in Kannur and Pathanamthitta with nine. The other districts where positive cases have been reported are Thiruvananthapuram (4), Kottayam (2), Thrissur (1), Malappuram (4), Idukki (1) and Kozhikode (2).The state has 314 people in the isolation wards of various hospitals, while 58,981 people are under home quarantine. Of the 4,035 samples sent for testing, 2,744 have returned negative.Meanwhile, Indian Medical Association and Kerala Government Medical Officers’ Association have demanded a statewide shutdown taking into account the spike in the number of case over the last three days.IMA has also sought the testing of all people in home quarantine to avoid further spreading of the virus.Shutdown advisoryThe Union cabinet secretary in his video conference with chief secretaries of states issued the advisory on the need for a total shutdown of all high-risk districts. However, the decision was left to the respective state governments to implement.Based on this, the state government has decided to hold a high-level meeting on Monday to take a decision.“At present we have a total shutdown in Kasaragod district and restrictions in other selected districts. We will discuss whether a total shutdown on the lines of Kasaragod is needed in other districts as well,” said Kerala chief secretary Tom Jose.Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan denied reports that the government has decided to shutdown the seven districts. Sources said the state government is against a total shutdown and is only for restricting the movement of people and large gatherings.“There cannot be a total shutdown of shops and establishments as this would paralyze normal life. Instead of a total shutdown there will be restrictions. What this will entail will be decided in the meeting scheduled for Monday,” the chief secretary said.

Title: Tobacco auctions deferred: Board
Content:
Guntur: The tobacco board has put off ongoing tobacco auctions in the state as part of the measures to contain the spread of COVID-19. After discussing the issue with stakeholders, farmers and merchants, tobacco board executive director K Sunitha has decided to defer the auctions till March, 31.

She has asked officials to close down the auction centres with immediate effect. However, the farmers are also worried that the delayed auctions might result in damage of the leaf and prices may further dip. tnn

Title: Coronavirus: Delhi government puts a stop to most services at RTOs, for now
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government has suspended the issuance of learner’s licences and other ‘non-essential’ services at the 13 Regional Transport Offices of Delhi to reduce crowding and help stop the spread of infection by the novel coronavirus.The suspended services include issuance of learner’s licences, public service vehicle badges and conductor licence. For transfer of ownership of a vehicle, a box has been installed outside RTOs, where documents can be deposited and the new registration certificate will be mailed home. Also, driving tests and issuance of permanent driving licenses is being carried out only for those whose learner’s license or permanent license is on the verge of getting expired.The south zone RTO , located at Sarai Kale Khan, is one of the busiest in the city and usually sees a footfall of around 1,200 a day. On Saturday, with the new measures in place, the number came down to around 150.“Most of the busy RTOs usually cater to more than 1,000 applicants a day but due to these new measures, the number has come down drastically. We are also ensuring that applicants keep a distance of one metre between them while waiting or queuing up outside counters,” said Nand Gopal, motor licensing officer, south zone. “Before opening the RTO, we are thoroughly sanitizing it. Personnel at the entry gate are giving out hand sanitizer, which all applicants have to rub on their hands before entering the office,” he said.Gopal said that just 70 tests were conduted on Saturday compared with 250 usually.Another work that is going on at Delhi’s RTOs are the registration of BS-IV vehicles as BS-IV vehicles can’t be sold or registered after April 1 as per a Supreme Court ruling.

Title: Dubai returnees ignoring guidelines a concern: Min
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: It is not Spain or Italy that are giving nightmares for the health department now. Thousands of people coming back from Dubai is a matter of concern.

“We used to receive only limited passengers from Italy or Spain in the airports and hence it was easy for us to screen them and also to track their contacts. But now the scene has changed. Thousands of people are coming from Dubai,” said health minister K K Shailaja.

The minister expressed concern over people coming from Dubai not adhering to the quarantine rules of the health department. Hence, she anticipates a community spread.

“We cannot say that we are totally safe and cannot even rule out a community spread. Look at the person who had come to Kasaragod and where all he had travelled. Because of him there is a panic situation in the district,” said the minister.

Home quarantine has to be strictly maintained or else the government will be forced to take action. The chief minister has made it clear that the government is now going to go ahead with the action against those who violates this. All powers have been given to the district collectors to invoke section 2 of Epidemic Disease Act of 1897 to maintain public health and order.

The minister, who is not ready to rule out a community spread, has said that the health department has readied two plans (Plan B and C) in the event of any emergency.

“We have 126 hospitals ready to accommodate the people who are tested positive and also the suspect cases. This includes 55 private and 71 government hospitals. In the Plan A we had readied 1,000 isolation beds. Now, Plan B is being implemented and we have 1,408 beds under this,” said the minister.

“In Plan C we have kept ready 3,028 isolation beds in the state, which include 81 government hospitals and 41 private hospitals. Apart from this, 147 corona care centres have started functioning in the state. We can accommodate 21,866 people at a time in these centres,” said the minister.

But even after the state government equipped all these facilities we are not getting the support of the people who had to go for compulsory quarantine for 14 days once they have reached from places like Dubai. “We are asking them to obey the order for their safety and also for the safety of the society,” said the minister.

Title: JMC Preparing to Upgrade Community Centres as Quarantine Ward
Content:
Jaipur: The 80 community centres across the city are being prepared to be upgraded into quarantine wards in case of an emergency. Jaipur Municipal Corporation, which was asked to identify structures which can be used as quarantine wards, is now cleaning up and disinfecting the community centres.

At present, the city has two centres for quarantine – RUHS and SMS Hospital. There more than 600 beds in both the places.

JMC additional commissioner Arun Garg confirmed that the community centres would be used in case of emergency. “We are keeping them on stand-by in case the number of people suffering from coronavirus increase. We have looked into the arrangements that need to be made – lights, sanitation, garbage disposal facilities. Extra precautions have been maintained to keep the things in control and keep these buildings ready on short notice,” said Garg.

Many of the 80 community centres lack toilet facilities and some are not in proper shape. There have been complaints of lack of hygiene and sanitation in the centres as well.

An official said these centres are usually located in residential areas where people may object to keeping the patients over there. “Almost all the community centres are situated in the centre of colonies and we fear that people may object of using them as isolation wards. However, in case of emergency, these are the only options for us. They will be properly covered and packed from all the sides for to prevent spreading of the virus,” said a JMC official.

The civic body has started disinfecting many areas in the city including the community centres. At present, 30 teams are busy disinfecting public places for which the JMC had procured 1% sodium hydrochloride solution. Most of the malaria staff of JMC is busy in disinfection work.

Title: RCC defers all planned treatments
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The Regional Cancer Centre ( RCC ) has decided to postpone all the surgeries planned from Monday to March 28. The surgeries will be rescheduled after March 28.

RCC director Dr Rekha A Nair said chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery can induce immunosuppression (suppression of immune system and its ability to fight infection) in cancer patients. This may be deleterious to the patients in the current scenario of Covid-19 and hence, it has been decided to postpone the surgeries, the director said.

The chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery scheduled have been deferred by a week; however emergency ones will be undertaken, she said. Patients who are already on radiation will continue with the treatment as scheduled.

For fixing the new dates, patients are requested to contact the helplines: surgery (8289893454, 0471-2522902), radiotherapy (0471-252 2273/2442541/2445069/2445079) and chemotherapy (0471-2442541/2445069/2445079).

Already the RCC management has imposed restrictions on the people who have travelled from foreign countries on coming to the hospital. The management has asked such passengers not to accompany the patients to OP wings.

The Medical College Hospital in Thiruvananthapuram has also regulated the OP timings in view of the Covid-19.

The regulations have been brought to avoid the overcrowding of people at the OP wings. All the non-essential surgeries have also been postponed here.

Title: Provide relief to industries, weaker sections, labourers: CM to PM
Content:
Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Sunday wrote to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and requested him announce a relief package for unorganised sector workers, to ensure food and social security for weaker sections of society and offer relief to tourism industry, hotels and other MSME units affected by Covid-19 crisis in the country by giving concession in payment of GST or through moratorium.

Gehlot said the beneficiaries of food security, who live on daily wages, should be provided free wheat for the coming four months. He also demanded that the Centre should provide unemployment allowance to the MGNREGA labourers who cannot reach their work site to maitain social distancing.

In a letter to the PM , Gehlot pointed out that about 23 lakh construction workers in the state, 5 lakh registered factory workers and around 1lakh street vendors in urban areas are facing a major employment crisis.

“The central government should announce a relief package for these workers so that they can sustain their livelihood. The registered construction workers and street vendors should also be brought under the purview of food security,” he added.

In the letter to the PM and finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, Gehlot urged, “The central government, using its jurisdiction, should provide relief to tourism, industry, hotels and other MSME units by giving concession in payment of GST or by consider postponing it. The banks should provide support to the industries by rescheduling their loans installments. It should either give concession in payment of income tax for the current financial year or postpone it."

Box

CM gives relief to tourism and hotel business

Jaipur: Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot on Sunday approved the proposal to reduce license fees of the hotel and restaurant bars in order to provide relief to tourism industry and hotel businesses. Gehlot has also approved the proposal regarding reimbursement of the state GST for the first quarter of the coming financial year.

The chief minister, considering the demands put forward by the hotel association delegation, had reduced the annual bar license fee to provide relief to the businesses. He also approved to reimburse SGST from April 2020 to June 2020.

Title: Coronavirus in Andhra Pradesh: AP registers sixth case as 49-yr-old tests positive
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh registered its sixth case of Covid-19 as a 49-year-old woman from Visakhapatnam, relative of the 65-year-old Covid-19 patient, tested positive on Sunday.On the other hand, the first Covid-19 patient in the state from Nellore was tested negative on Sunday. The 65-year-old man from Alipuram in Vizag city had travelled to Saudi Arabia in March. He returned to the city in a train after arriving in Hyderabad and staying at a relative’s home for a day. He subsequently approached a private hospital and private diagnostics centre in Visakhapatnam after developing some symptoms.He was finally referred to Government Hospital for Chest and Communicable Diseases in Vizag city. He was tested positive for Covid-19 on March 19. The Vizag district authorities had carried out door-to-door survey in nearly 26,000 houses in the vicinity of the patient’s home.

Title: Nagpur central jail inmates supplying handmade masks to government offices, other prisons
Content: NAGPUR: The Nagpur central jail inmates are saving lives from behind the bars by providing handmade masks to several government offices and their own counterparts lodged elsewhere.Though the task is part of their rehabilitation scheme to help them earn wages, the inmates of the sewing unit of the jail have won appreciation by churning out good quality masks which are priced in the range of Rs8-Rs15 each.Till date, inmates at Chandrapur prison have got 300 masks made by their Nagpur counterparts, Buldhana and Morshi jails 500 each, Washim 350 and Bhandara 200 masks. Department of social justice was supplied 300 masks, government press 130, tribal department 100.For the forensic science laboratory , 300 masks are being readied while the sessions court and family court too are among on the customers’ list.Even the high court is expected to place order. City police chief BK Upadhyay, who headed the unit earlier, too has shown interest in procuring masks for his personnel.Anup Kumar Kumre, superintendent of the Nagpur central jail, said that masks have also been supplied to inmates as well as officials at his prison. “We have also made elaborate arrangements at the prison against the viral infection,” said Kumre who is a postgraduate in social work.The SP also said that since March 18 they have stopped the ‘mulaqat’ or personal meetings of the inmates with their kin as a precautionary measure.Kumre said the Nagpur central prison (NCP) FM radio (works on the principle of community radio) is twice a day airing awareness messages on coronavirus and means to stop its spread. “Our inmate RJ is keeping everyone updated about the significance of personal and community hygiene.
