The inmates in their barracks enjoy songs and also get to know about ways to stop spread of the virus,” he said.An infra-red thermometer is being used to screen the body temperature of the inmates entering the prison. “We are also taking information about every inmate walking in, including details of the case, the court he or she attended, names, barracks and so on,” said Kumre.Outside the gate, the jail authorities have kept a water drum along with antiseptic soaps and solution for police personnel and inmates going to courts. “We have given soap kits to every barracks and also a spray machine for washing hands and cleaning face,” he said.Kumre said the bathing water is being diluted with antiseptic solution twice a day. “We have also kept big drums of hot water near each barrack for the inmates to wash and clean their belongings,” he said.“A mini isolation ward has been set up inside our 20-bedded prison hospital. It has around 5-6 beds and adjoining bathrooms,” he said.

Title: Two corona suspects at Bhopal airport; sent to hospital
Content:
A health employee checks a passenger at Bhopal airport

BHOPAL: Two flyers who alighted at Bhopal’s Raja Bhoj airport on Sunday were rushed to JP Hospital after they were diagnosed with ‘flu-like’ symptoms, officials said.

A 20-year-old suspect along with 17 other passengers alighted from an Air India flight from Delhi. After she complained of cold and cough, she was rushed to the the hospital, officials added.

Officials said that another passenger from Bengaluru on an IndiGo flight too was sent to the hospital along with his kid. “He was sent to the hospital on suspicion of symptoms,” said a senior airport official requesting anonymity.

The Air India flight which was to take off for Pune after a brief stop here, was delayed for around one hour, Air India acting airport manager Shamsher Khan said. “All 44 passengers who flew for Pune at 11.40am were properly sanitized and checked thoroughly,” he said.

“All the procedure were followed before the flight took off,” he added.

Officials said that flight was senitised completely before it was allowed to move as the authorities did not give them permission.

CMHO, Sudhir Kumar issued a press statement where he said that a suspect who came in the morning has been isolated and her condition is stable. He said that all possible facilities have been arranged to tackle any situation. Asked the stopping of flight movement, director airport Anil Vikram said there were no instructions on grounding the flights at Bhopal airport. “Air travel is not covered in the order,” said director Vikram.

Title: Gurudwaras distribute meals to homeless and poor
Content: Jaipur: At a time when all religious places have shut down following the lockdown, the Sikh Gurudwaras in Jaipur have started distributing two meals a day to homeless and poor families living in slums.Rajasthan Sikh Sabha has announced to continue the meal distribution until the lockdown period in the state while following all lockdown guidelines.Anticipating the effects of Janta Curfew and possibility of closure for longer days, the Sabha held a meeting couple of days ago to take a call on serving people like daily wage earners who will not be able to earn a penny during the lockdown period. They started food distribution from Saturday evening in collaboration with NGOs.They have been serving high-calorie diet, including rice, rotis, pulses and vegetables through the volunteers at places which have a good concentration of homeless and low-income families.“How can we sleep when our city, state and nation is going through the worst time. A simple call to the Sikh community and we were filled with food grains for weeks. We have kept local administration in the loop before we started a distribution programme,” Singh said.Jaipur has 28 Gurudwaras and food is being distributed from almost 7-8 religious places, including Gurudwaras at Raja Park, Mansarovar and Ajmer Road.The food is being distributed by volunteers covering face with a proper mask and also educating the beneficiary of the new diseaseat places like 22 Godown, Ajmer Pulia, railway and bus stations and below every flyover.A group of Sikh volunteers, including women, have divided the work among themselves. “From cooking to distributing and bringing raw material is being done by our volunteers. We have enough volunteers to serve thousands of poor and homeless,” Singh added.The committee has requested citizens who are willing to contribute by donating food grains and fresh vegetables at any of the Gurudwaras

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Allow students to stay back in hostels, MHRD tells institutes
Content: NEW DELHI: The ministry of human resource development (MHRD) on Saturday advised all educational institutions to let students, especially foreign scholars, who are still in hostels to stay put and take necessary precautions in view of the novel coronavirus outbreak . The ministry also said that faculty members, researchers and non-teaching staff be permitted to work from home till March 31.“Students who are still in hostels, particularly foreigners, should be allowed to continue in their hostels and were advised to take all necessary safe precaution,” said Amit Khare, secretary, MHRD in a letter to the institutions.The universities and colleges have been issuing advisories to students to leave for homes and not stay in hostels as classes have already been suspended in view of the Covid-19 outbreak.The ministry had already directed that all exams in schools and colleges be postponed till March 31 and evaluation work be suspended.Permitting the faculty and non-teaching staff to work from home, the ministry states that they will be considered on-duty during this period.“The faculty members should utilise this period for academic activities such as development of online content, online teaching and online evaluation,” said Khare.The teaching and non-teaching staff is required to be available on phone and email, the institutions have been directed to count the period as being on duty. Union HRD minister, Ramesh Pokhriyal has also sent the message for all the students, teachers and parents and appealed them to support ‘ janata curfew ’ on March 22.

Title: ‘Can’t rule out chances of more positive cases’
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The Pathanamthitta district administration is not ready to rule out the possibility of getting more Covid-19 positive cases in the district. Even though the fear of community spread is far from over, the results of more samples , which have been sent for testing , are expected to test positive.“We cannot rule out that there will not be more positive cases in the district. For the past few days, no fresh cases have been reported. But we expect that a few samples which have been sent for testing might test positive,” said district collector P B Nooh.Pathanamthitta district administration registered cases against 13 people who defied directions of the health authorities to go into home quarantine.At present, 12 people are in the designated isolation wards of different hospitals in the district. Till date, nine positive cases were reported from here.The district administration had tracked down 5,257 people who had arrived in the district from different foreign countries.All of them were under home quarantine and are being monitored by the district administration and the health department. tnn

Title: Curfew total in state, people remain home even after 9pm
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The all-India ‘ janata curfew ’ called by the Centre amid rising concerns over spread of Covid-19 was total in the state on Sunday. People chose to remain indoors even after the curfew time, which ended at 9pm, on an appeal from the state government.All institutions and commercial establishments, except for some medical shops and petrol pumps remained closed for the entire day, and the roads and streets wore a deserted look. Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan and political leaders, including state ministers, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala and BJP state president K Surendran, hailed the people for observing the curfew.In a statement, state chief secretary Tom Jose appealed to people to continue observing the curfew even after 9pm, besides directing police to take action against those who come out and gather in large numbers.After staying indoors, people were seen standing in front of their houses on several streets in various cities and suburbs exactly at 5pm to clap their hands, clank utensils and to ring bells, saluting health workers fighting Covid-19. Residents in various apartments stood on their balconies to clap hands and declare their solidarity with the government’s initiative for social distancing during the time of Covid-19.Even police personnel, deployed at various junctions in the capital city, stood up and clapped their hands for several minutes saluting the health workers.In the state capital, only police vehicles and a few two-wheelers and private cars were seen on roads. Places like Palayam, Statue, Pulimoodu and East Fort, which usually witness large crowds even during hartals, were deserted. People also opted to stay away from Sunday mass. Many believers watched mass on TV channels.Roads in Kochi too wore a deserted look, with every street and junction coming to a standstill on Sunday, as residents responded positively to the ‘janata curfew’. Apart from a few two-wheelers on the road, there was no traffic movement.All shops, including restaurants remained shut. Even some medical shops remained shut. With KSRTC shutting down operations, the bus stand, which witnesses footfall even during hartals, was completely deserted. A few cars were seen picking up passengers who arrived at the railway stations. With even the Kochi Metro shutting down services, there was literally no public transport available.Churches held mass even in the absence of devotees. Masses were live streamed for devotees. Kochi, which is otherwise abuzz with devotees going for Sunday masses, was silent in the morning.Health services personnel and police were deployed at railway stations to monitor passengers who arrive in the city in trains. Traffic personnel were deployed on roads, even though few motorists could be spotted in the city. All major junctions including Vyttila, Kaloor, Kathrikadavu, Kacheripady and Edapally remained deserted.Reports from the suburbs also showed a positive response to the self-imposed curfew. Most residents kept to their houses. In towns like Angamaly, Kalady, Perumbavoor, Muvattupuzha and Aluva, shops remained shut. Not even private vehicles were seen on the road .Malabar also witnessed a total shutdown, with people voluntarily participating in the curfew by remaining inside their houses. The streets wore a deserted look as public transport and even private vehicles remained off the roads, barring a few two-wheelers.Shops and business establishments and even most of the medical shops and petrol pumps remained closed in Kozhikode. Police personnel were seen flagging down some vehicles and asking travellers to avoid non-essential travel.In Kannur too it was total shutdown and barring a few people who provide essential services, others stayed home. “Though we have seen many hartals in Kannur, this kind of a total shutdown was for the first time and I saw some trucks on the roads only in the evening,” said Jobil Sebastian, a professional working in the hotel industry.In Malappuram, shops remained closed and vehicles including two-wheelers kept off the roads. When a few two-wheeler riders came out in Malappuram town, a police team blocked them and asked them to return home.(With inputs form Kochi and Kozhikode)

Title: Gujarat cops charge man under NSA for ‘spreading lies’
Content: AHMEDABAD: City police late on Saturday night booked a man, who had returned from Canada and put under home quarantine, under the National Security Act (NSA) for allegedly spreading false information about healthcare facility in the country.The man, identified as Abhimanyu Acharya, resident of Gopal Park Society in Ghatlodia had returned from Toronto via Abu Dhabi on Saturday. He alleged in a tweet that there was a lack of proper checking facility for signs of coronavirus at the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International airport in the city. His allegation was proven wrong by CCTV footage shared by the airport authorities.According to the FIR registered with Ghatlodia police, the state government brought the Epidemic Diseases Act into effect on March 13, 2020 directing that any person who comes from Covid-19 affected countries shall be put under home quarantine for 14 days.At around 9.15pm on Saturday, Shiva Parmar a multi-purpose health worker of Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) along with a medical team visited Acharya's house in Ghatlodia and found he was roaming outside his house without any mask, states the FIR.The FIR states that Acharya was directed to remain quarantined for 14 days. But he did not do that and even spread falsehood about the country’s efforts to tackle Covid-19. Acharya claimed in his tweet that he did not go through a temperature scan at the airport checkout and was only asked to fill a self-declaration form and advised to self-isolate for two weeks.Acharya had also alleged if this continues, then India will be in real trouble, states the FIR. The FIR states that Acharya had created fear in people by making such false allegations about the authority’s attempts to prevent the spread of Covid-19.Inspector Pushpa Gamit of Ghatlodia police said that Acharya was also booked under IPC sections 270 (likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant) along with Section 3 of the National Security Act.

Title: 2 held for defying home quarantine
Content:
Rajkot: Two men from Junagadh and Jamnagar cities, who returned from Dubai last week, were arrested for violating the mandatory home quarantine rule.

In Junagadh, 40-year-old trader was advised to stay at home for 14 days after he returned from Dubai. However, when local health department team went to check at his house on Saturday, he was not present. “They were informed that he had gone to Maliya-Hathina town where he has a shop,” said Pradeepsinh Jadeja , deputy superintendent of police, Junagadh.

The man was immediately arrested by Junagadh C-division police station team and sent to a government quarantine facility. He was booked under sections of Epidemic Diseases Act and sections 269, 270 of IPC (whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life) and section 188 (violating public notification).

Similarly a 34-year-old resident of Jamnagar’s Momainagar area, who was advised home quarantine, attended a marriage function in Maliya-Miyana town of Morbi district. When health department team went to his house on Saturday evening, they were shocked to know that he was attending a wedding.

Title: MCH to soon become Covid treatment centre
Content: Kochi: District administration is on an effort to convert Government Medical College, Ernakulam, into Covid-19 treatment centre , an exclusive and first-of-its-kind facility in the state for the treatment of the disease. Around 400 beds will be made available in the hospital for the purpose.Patients who have already been admitted to the hospital with other ailments will be shifted to other hospitals in the district. “We will be convening an urgent meeting to chalk out the plan in this regard on Monday morning,” said medical college superintendent Dr Geetha Nair. Apart from the Covid-19 treatment centre, emergency outpatient services and dialysis centre only will function from the medical college.Authorities have identified Ernakulam General Hospital, Mattancherry taluk hospital, Indira Gandhi Cooperative Hospital and some other taluk hospitals for shifting the patients. “The chances of increasing the number of Covid-19 positive cases and suspected cases are going up. Due to the proximity of airport and certain other features, patients from other districts also are being admitted to the medical college. That’s why it was decided to set up such a centre,” said National Health Mission district programme manager Dr Mathew Numbeli. “There are already some Covid-19 positive cases admitted to the medical college. They will have to avail the facilities like CT scan, x-ray, laboratory, cath lab, etc. This creates problems. Once the centre is converted into a Covid-19 treatment centre, the treatment of the patients can be streamlined,” Numbeli said.The hospitals like Indira Gandhi Cooperative hospital have facilities on par with a medical college to a certain extent. “Moreover, some patients having complexities and require advanced treatment will be shifted to a couple of private hospitals. Most of such cases are reported from the paediatrics department. There are certain schemes which help cover the cost and so there won’t be need of additional funds for the treatment at the private hospitals. The private hospital authorities have also promised to offer free treatment to some patients. More private hospitals have promised to offer their facilities. We are considering their offer too,” Numbeli said.Officials with Ernakulam general hospital said they have started preparations for the purpose. “We have a well-equipped gynaecology and paediatrics department. So, patients in these departments can be shifted to general hospital,” said hospital superintendent Dr Anitha.As of now, the medical college has around 500 beds, including the intensive care units. There are 30 beds dedicated for isolation facility for Covid-19 cases. The new facility will also help imparting training to more doctors, nursing staff, paramedical staff and others.

Title: 4 booked for violating quarantine in Palakkad
Content: Palakkad: Police have registered cases against four persons who were moving outside in the open during their observation period for Covid-19 They have not followed the instructions of the authorities and went out in the open, mingling with people and going places, the police said. The Kollengode police registered cases against two persons and the Town South and Kotai police registered cases against one person each.The health and police authorities received information that the two persons who were under observation went out and attended two or three public programmes.The two persons had returned from abroad and the health authorities had directed them to be placed under observation in home quarantine and not to go out during this time.A youth in Vadakkumcherry is under police surveilliance for posting a social media message that another person is having Covid-19.Cops book 14 masjid officialsIn another incident, Anchal police registered a case against the Alanchery Juma Masjid office bearers of Thadikkad for violating the restrictions and allowing over 500 people to conduct juma prayers on Friday. Cases have been registered against the president, secretary and 12 members of the Juma jamaat committee. tnn

Title: Two test positive in Ahmedabad
Content:
Ahmedabad: On Sunday, of the five cases declared positive by the state government, two each were from Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar. The remaining case was from Kutch where a 59-year-old woman had a history of travel to Saudi Arabia.

Both patients from Ahmedabad had returned from Saudi Arabia: a 66-year-old male and a 62-year-old female. With these cases, Ahmedabad district currently has the highest number of positive cases at 7.

Two cases from Gandhinagar included an 80-year-old woman who is suspected to have got the infection locally. The other case is of a 26-year-old woman with travel history to Dubai. Gandhinagar and Ahmedabad are already locked down after notifications under the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897.

Four special COVID hospitals are being set up — in Ahmedabad with 1,200 beds, in Surat with 500 beds, in Vadodara and Rajkot with 250 beds each. Private hospitals have pledged support.

Title: 250 in home quarantine, 10,000 food packets to meet emergency in Udaipur
Content:
Udaipur: Around 250 people have been quarantined in their homes here while medical teams are reaching out to over 3,000 others who arrived here from different cities of Maharashtra and other states. So far, there have been no positive cases reported from Udaipur .

Meanwhile, people confined themselves indoors throughout Sunday. The streets and markets of the lake city were completely deserted. Talking to the media collector Anandhi said that the district administration is taking all necessary measures to check the outbreak of Covid-19. The collector also ensured the people that ample food and essential goods supplies are there.

“We will ensure that no one should starve due to lockdown. In the first phase we have arranged for 10,000 food packets to be distributed to the needy through Sahkari Upbhokta Bhandar in case of any emergency,” the official said. A helpline and control room would be set up soon and modalities would be developed to manage supply of essential goods and services during the lockdown period, Anandhi said.

She said that all public and private transport services would remain suspended during the period, however, limited vehicles would be permitted to carry patients to hospitals. Similarly, to avoid rushes and gatherings in vegetable markets, Udaipur will follow Bhilwara pattern of vendors going door-to-door in colonies for vegetable supplies.

The official also appealed to people not to unnecessarily rush to banks for non-commercial activities such as updating passbook. They should visit banks only for necessary transactions, she added. SP Kailash Chandra Bishnoi said that not more than 5 persons would be permitted to assemble at public places during the lockdown. Numbers limiting the assemblage of persons permitted during Section 144 has been amended and curtailed from 20 to 5 now, in view of few instances where some groups were found distributing kaadaa (herbal decoction) and masks at public places.

The SP also appealed to people not to fall prey to rumours on social media and spread them. “We have received two cases and arrested 8 persons so far for spreading false news,” Bishnoi said.

Title: Two arrested for partying in self-isolation
Content:
Ahmedabad: A 23-year-old youth, who had returned from Oman (Muscat) in March 21 and his 26-year-old cousin, were found throwing a birthday party at their house in Maninanagar at 12 in the night on March 22, though the younger one was under home quarantine for 14 days. According to the complaint there were 10 other persons in the house for the party.

Inspector S M Patel of Maninagar police station said both have been booked under Epidemic Act 1897, Section 270 of IPC and Section 188 of CrPC for violation of the notification issued by the city police commissioner.

“Both the brothers have been handed over to the health department of the AMC,” Patel said.

According to the FIR lodged by Dr Tejas Shah of AMC, at about 1.01am on the wee hours of March 23, he got a call from a local resident that a youth who had returned from Oman ( Muscat) and was under home quarantine for 14 days is celebrating birthday party at his house located in the same society.

TNN

Title: Goan janata still under curfew, CM extends it by 3 more days
Content: PANAJI: As a precautionary measure against the spread of novel coronavirus in the state, the Goa government on Sunday decided to extend the Janata Curfew by another three days, till March 25 midnight. During the three-day period, the state will be under total shutdown except for government-run essential services.Chief minister Pramod Sawant thanked the people for the 100% success of the Janta Curfew on Sunday.Over the next three days only fuel pumps, milk supply, medical shops, government and private hospitals will be open, Sawant said. “Rest everything will be closed,” he said.Sawant said that the decision has been taken in consultation with Union home minister Amit Shah and that he has also held a discussion with his counterparts in Karnataka, B S Yeddyurappa, and Maharashtra, Uddhav Thackeray.Under Section 144 CrPC , both district collectors R Menaka and Ajit Roy ordered a shutdown on all services except for essential ones.The collectors said that any person contravening their order will be punishable under Section 188 of the IPC.“All government departments, state government industrial departments, industries, private establishments, including factories and companies, any business/trade, industrial undertaking or any other establishment will remain closed,” the order stated.A paid holiday has also been announced for state government employees, industrial workers, daily wage workers of government departments and state government industrial departments, employees of commercial establishments, industrial workers of private establishments, all private establishment and workers of semi government bodies, the order stated. The paid holiday will also be applicable under the explanation to Section 25 of the negotiable instruments act.The government has also ordered all stage carriage and contract carriage bus operators not to operate private and Kadamba buses for the next three days.Sawant thanked the people of the state for their 100% participation in Sunday’s Janta Curfew. “Till now we do not have a single positive case of coronavirus. As we do not want any positive case of Covid-19 in Goa, the state government has taken a decision to extend the Janta Curfew by another three days,” he said.Seeking similar support from the public for the next three-day period, Sawant said, “Except for all essential services of the government, all departments will remain closed. Also, there is a need for all establishments in the private sector, including companies and factories, to shut operations.”The chief minister said that already the state’s borders have been sealed and that the entry of people, including tourists, has stopped. Following the Union government’s decision, railway service, too, have stopped.“Restricted numbers of aircraft are landing at Dabolim airport and the people coming are given entry after being screened or quarantined,” Sawant said.He also requested the people who had returned to Goa from neighbouring states to get themselves screened and home quarantined.

Title: Spike in people under surveillance in Thrissur
Content: Thrissur: The number of patients under Covid-19 surveillance has recorded a rise in the district on Sunday.According to an official release, as many as 8,792 people are under surveillance as on Sunday. The figure was 6,815 on Saturday. The number of people under hospital quarantine has also gone up from 24 on Saturday to 40 on Sunday. The release said that 19 people were admitted to hospital for quarantine on Sunday itself, while five were discharged today. The number of people under home quarantine is 8,752 as on Sunday while it was 6,514 on the previous day.District medical officer Dr K J Reena said that surveillance has been intensified.The release said the results of the 40 samples sent for tests were received on Sunday and all of them were negative.Out of the total 387 samples sent for tests the results of 354 have been received so far, the release said. Results of 25 samples were yet to be received.

Title: Cial ground handlers face crisis
Content: Kochi: With the aviation industry going through one of its worst dips due to travel restrictions and decrease in passenger flow in the wake of Covid-19 , the ground handling agencies based at Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) too are bearing the brunt. The employees working in the sector are facing the threat of unemployment as Cial has suspended international services. Many employees are being asked to go on leave. Also, sources said that cost-cutting measures like loss of pay, lay-off, etc. may be initiated if the situation persists.At present Cial has two major players in the ground handling sector – Celebi Aviation Holding and AIATSL, the fully-owned subsidiary of Air India that is into ground-handling services that include baggage, cargo handling and all other services. More than 1,000 staff are working in both the international and domestic sectors as ground handling staffs.“Airlines’ revenue had cut down drastically over the past 15-20 days and no flights have been conducting services with full passenger capacity. The chance of revival anytime soon is dismal as more countries are strengthening travel restrictions. No termination has been started but if the situation continues, agencies will have to start severe cost-cutting measures,” said a source.According to sources, 30 contract workers hired by Celebi for extra work at night time due to runway recarpeting at Cial were asked to leave already by cutting short their contracts. Meanwhile, Celebi had granted its pregnant and aged employees paid leave due to Covid-19 situation.Meanwhile, the challenges faced by the ground handling staff in the wake of Covid-19 alert are serious too. “Our team is at the forefront of the situation. Ground handling staff in general face issues with passengers who may be ignorant about the precautions that must be taken by every individual during such crisis. Employees come in contact with passengers at ticket counters, help desks, wheel chair assistance, buggy operation, coaches and also are exposed to risk at areas like cabin cleaning,” said a Celebi official.Celebi passenger service executive Chithira said: “I have encountered different types of passengers here during the past few days. People who are very careful and serious about the situation and those who are completely ignorant of it. Last day, a passenger blew on to my face and said, “you should also get corona”. It is tough to manage such situations.”

Title: Awareness of Covid-19 helped public mark curfew
Content: Vijayawada: Increased awareness about Covid-19 and social responsibility made the Janata Curfew a success in Andhra Pradesh on Sunday.Irrespective of political affiliations and differences of view, people from all walks of life joined the initiative and stayed home to make it an unprecedented shutdown in the history of the state.The ongoing Information Education Communication (IEC) activities of the government on Covid-19 and increasing number of suspected cases have made people aware of the importance of social distancing.Several NGOs and political parties also called upon the public to participate in the curfew. When TOI visited various parts of Vijayawada on Sunday, there were few persons or vehicles on the roads. Almost all shops, commercial establishments and organisations voluntarily shut their operations, making it an informal lockdown.Speaking to TOI, Singaluri Srikrishna, an IIT-JEE maths coaching faculty said the 14-hour curfew was called by the Prime Minister in the best interests of the people and to contain and break the chain of Covid-19. “The curfew received an overwhelming response due to the underlying positive message attached to it,” said Srikrishna.However, a few people suffered on Sunday due to the closure of restaurants and other eateries, particularly job aspirants and students staying in rented accommodations.A few NGOs came to the rescue of the homeless by distributing food packets in various parts of the state.

Title: Entrepreneur duped of Rs 25 lakh in deal involving 2 lakh masks
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 33-year-old woman entrepreneur from Shahpur on Saturday filed a complaint with Madhavpura police stating that she was duped of Rs 25 lakh from a Vapi-based man who promised her to give around two lakh masks.

Manali Sheth, the entrepreneur, states in her FIR that she has been into import-export business for three years. Sheth states that she has been running a firm named Ankit Internationals at Shahpur. On February 28, 2020, she received a call from a man named, Dipen Patel based in Vapi, who told Sheth that he manufacturers masks and will provide a huge stock of masks at reasonable rates.

She said that she had asked to provide 50,000 masks but Patel insisted that he will only take her order if she will buy two lakh maks. Patel also said that he will take payment in cash only. Patel had later sent a photograph of a mask and as Sheth insisted to get a sample, Patel had sent his aide with a sample of mask. After analysing the sample, Sheth had decided to buy masks from him. Patel insisted that he would take cash and demanded Rs 17.50 lakh as advance payment.

For this advance payment, he told Sheth that she will have to give money to an angadia firm named P Vijaykumar in BG tower at Delhi Darwaza . On March 5, Sheth deposited advance payment of Rs 17.50 lakh to the angadia firm and Patel sent a receipt of the payment. When Sheth sought masks from him, Patel told her that if she will pay rest of the money, then she will get stock of masks shortly. She had then paid rest of Rs 7.50 lakh through online banking on March 6. . Sheth states that Patel went incommunicado after which she filed a complaint of cheating and breach of trust .

Title: Arrested coaching centre organiser in Telangana hosted Indonesians
Content: HYDERABAD: A 39-year-old coaching centre organiser, arrested by Karimnagar police on March 17 for conducting classes in violation of government orders issued as part of precautionary measure to contain Covid-19 , has reportedly hosted the ten Indonesians who tested positive for Covid-19.He violated the station bail rules and went absconding on coming to know that the foreign guests had tested positive and police nabbed him on Saturday. He was placed in quarantine at a Karimanagar hospital.On March 17, Karimnagar II Town inspector Ch Deva Reddy along with education department officials conducted a surprise check at Institute of Mathematics (IOM), a coaching centre run by Jameel Ahmed at Mukarrampura in Karimnagar. “As Jameel Ahmed was operating the coaching centre in violation of the government orders, we had registered a case against him and the coaching centre was closed,” inspector Deva Reddy said.The organiser was later arrested and released on station bail. Subsequently, while tracking the movement of Indonesian preachers , who came to Karimanagar town via Ramagundam from Delhi, police came to know that Jameel had hosted them and took them to various places of worship and educational institutions in the town. They launched a manhunt and nabbed him on Saturday. “He was caught from a hideout at Mukarrampura and shifted to a quarantine facility in Karimnagar,” the inspector said.

Title: Delhi corporations release norms for last rites of coronavirus patients
Content: NEW DELHI: The municipal corporations have started sensitising crematorium and burial ground staff in case more Covid-19 deaths occur in the capital.After the confusion around the cremation of the capital’s first virus victim at Nigambodh Ghat last week, the Union health ministry has sent a standard operating procedure for handling such bodies. A senior public health official said all major crematoriums were run by NGOs and their management and staff were being sensitised. “We are hoping that things will not deteriorate much but we are prepared for all contingencies,” he added.As various precautions such as use of personnel protection equipment will have to be followed, all bereaved families will be advised to use one of the bigger crematoriums at Lodhi, Punjabi Bagh, Green Park or Nigambodh.Another official said the ministry had allowed viewing of the body at the face end, but the body bag can be unzipped only by the staff using standard precautions for the relatives to see the deceased one last time. “Bathing, kissing, hugging etc. of the body should not be allowed,” the guideline states. “Religious rituals such as reading from scriptures, sprinkling holy water and any other last rites that don’t require touching the body can be allowed”, but everybody should carry out hand hygiene after the funeral, the official said.An officer of the South Delhi Municipal Corporation added that large gatherings won’t be allowed to stick to the social distancing norm. “The guideline tells us not to allow crowding and the number of a gathering in Delhi has already been restricted by the state government,” he said.Many officials, however, said there was no clarity about burials. “In the old manual, it was clearly stated that cremation is advisable against the burial in case of death due to an infectious disease. The fresh guideline doesn’t clarify this issue,” he pointed out.The last rites of the first Covid-19 casualty in the capital had got mired in controversy at Nigambodhghat crematorium due to lack of clarity on the protocol for such cases. Her family had to wait for several hours before civic officials stepped in to facilitate the cremation.Dr Sudhir Gupta, professor and head of forensic sciences at AIIMS, had told TOI that there was nothing to worry about cremation by electrical or traditional burning or even burial as per the religious faith. However, in case of burial, the upper portion of the burial spot should be cemented and plastered, he clarified.

Title: Coimbatore: School teachers seek work from home till March 31
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: With the ministry of human resource development directing all higher education institutions to ask their faculty members, teachers, researchers and non-teaching staff members to work from home till March 31 in view of Covid-19 pandemic, schoolteachers from the state have sought that the Tamil Nadu government too allows them to work from home till this month-end.

With Class X exams, which were slated to be held on March 27, being postponed, teachers said there was no point in them visiting schools to do preparatory work for the next academic year and creating online learning material amid the virus scare.

They said except those who were on exam duty, all other teachers should be asked to work from home. All schools, except those which are examination centres for the ongoing Class XI and XII exams, be locked down till March 31.

State secretary of Tamil Nadu Post Graduate Teachers’ Association (TNPGTA) VM Michaelraj said elementary schools, said, “Elementary schoolteachers and other teachers who have been asked to carry out preparations for the next academic year can be asked to work from home. This would prevent the possibility of teachers getting infected and thereby subsequent community spreading of the disease.”

President of Tamil Nadu Government Employees Teachers Association S Arunan said the state government should follow MHRD’s move and allow school and college teachers and other staff members to work from home till March 31 as a precautionary measure.

The Tamil Nadu High and Higher Secondary School Graduate Teachers’ Association too urged the state allow schoolteachers to work from home till March 31. In a communication, the association said around 3.25 lakh teachers were being made to visit schools, which were declared leave till March 31. "Just like how the Union ministry of human resource development has asked personnel working in its institutions to work from home till 31st, we want the state to order schoolteachers to work from home in the interest of students and public."

Title: City sees curfew after 3 decades
Content:
Vijayawada: The last time the people of Vijayawada saw a major curfew, which lasted for over a week was in 1988, following the death of Kapu community and Congress leader Vangaveeti Mohana Ranga. The city had witnessed widespread violence before the curfew was imposed.

On Sunday, residents of Vijayawada stayed indoors for Janata Curfew.

“I have been in the police department for over three decades in Vijayawada city. I saw the curfew in 1988, which was the result of unrest following the murder of Vangaveeti. Over three decades after the incident, I am seeing a curfew-like situation in Vijayawada on Sunday,” said a sub-inspector of police, Ch Koteswara Rao.

He added, “There is a difference between the past curfew and present Janata Curfew, as people voluntarily supported the latter to fight against Covid-19 and we didn’t struggle to keep the people at homes.” A few youngsters tried to roam the streets on their bikes. They were counselled and sent home, said a senior police officer.

Title: Masks distributed to people free of cost
Content:
Jaipur: Amid lockdown and Janata curfew in the city in response to COVID-19 crisis, some people at Badi Chaupad in the walled city, mostly medical-shop owners, were distributing masks to the passers-by free of cost. They said they already distributed at least 1,800 masks till Sunday afternoon.

"We are distributing these masks and sanitisers free of costs to autowallahs, rickshawpullers, security guards, policemen and other others who are providing essential services to the people. We are distributing these masks to those people who are not aware about the spread of the virus," said Divyan Goyal of Goyal Medical.

"We are distributing these masks free of cost because we want to ensure that people in the city are safe. We have no ulterior motive in this or an intention to earn money. We wanted to contribute in some way to the cause," he added.

They also said they might distribute more masks to the people in the coming days. They also complained that some people took these masks from them and indulged in blackmarketing.

Another shop owner of the Ajay Surgical Naval Agarwal said, “We have been distributing the masks since morning. We may distribute more masks to people in the coming days. We have also got complaints that unknown people are coming on bikes, taking away masks, and selling it others.”

Title: To soften coronavirus blow, Delhi government increases ration, doubles pensions
Content: NEW DELHI: With the spread of novel coronavirus restricting the movement of people and affecting their livelihood, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal , in his first digital press conference on Saturday, announced a slew of measures, including free foodgrains for about 72 lakh beneficiaries, doubling the pension amounts for senior citizens, widows and differently-abled, and providing free meals to the homeless at night shelters in April.Kejriwal also increased the quantity of wheat, rice and sugar given through the public distribution system by one-and-a-half times, restricted the number of people gathering at one place from the existing 20 to five and waived the tax on hotels where quarantine arrangements had been made.The chief minister also warned people that the city could be completely locked down if the need arose to ensure “safety and security” of the people of Delhi and the country. He urged senior citizens to give up their morning walks and isolate themselves even in their own houses. Stressing on social distancing, he said, “Only you can save yourself from coronavirus. You must give up shaking hands and must wash your hands multiple times, maintain a distance from others and stay at home as much as possible. That’s how we can save ourselves and our families from Covid-19 .”Meanwhile, food and civil supplies minister Imran Hussain said face masks, gloves, soaps and hand sanitisers, which have been declared essential commodities, could be sold at fair price shops.The chief minister said the recent restrictions were putting a financial burden on the poor and daily wage labourers. The government had initially thought of setting up kitchens to provide them free food but it would have resulted in mass gatherings. “We have decided to provide 7.5kg free foodgrains to 72 lakh people through PDS to beneficiaries attached to our ration scheme for one month. We will start distributing ration for April from March 30. I would request people to maintain a distance of one metre between each other in ration queues,” he said.Kejriwal said his government had decided to double the pension to 2.5 lakh widows, five lakh senior citizens and one lakh differently-abled. The beneficiaries will get the pension amount for March and April by April 7.“Corona restrictions causing terrible financial stress to poor. Following decisions taken to provide them relief - 1. Rs 4000- 5000 pension will be paid to 8.5 lakh beneficiaries by 7 Apr. 2. Free rations, with 50% more quantity than normal entitlements, to 72 lakh beneficiaries,” he tweeted. “We are also arranging free lunch and dinner at 220 night shelters,” the CM added.Kejriwal said the government had strengthened the ban on public gatherings by reducing the number of people allowed to gather at one spot from 20 to five. “The orders will be issued soon. In case there is a queue, people are requested to maintain a distance of five metres between each other,” he said.The chief minister added that if people followed the dos and don’ts — such as not shaking hands, regularly washing hands, social distancing and staying at home — they will be able to save themselves and their families from coronavirus.He urged senior citizens to remain indoors and skip morning walks for the time being.

Title: 'Ensure Class X question papers’ safety'
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: With the Class X board exams, which were scheduled to be held from March 27 to April 13, being postponed in the wake of Covid-19 pandemic, the directorate of government exams (DGE) has instructed all district school education departments to tighten security at custodian points where question papers are stored.

Thedirectorate of government exams has also directed all chief education officers not to open the custodian points until further orders.

“The chief education officers must also ensure that there are armed police personnel and a staff member from the chief education office at the custodian pointsround the clock,” the communication said.

There are 13 custodian points in the district.

A total of 41,148 students had enrolled to appear for the Class X exam in the district. A total of 148 centres were allocated for them.

Title: Door-to-door, tracking nCoV path
Content:
Ahmedabad: The first death due to Covid-19 infection in Gujarat was not of a person who had travelled abroad – the 69-year-old had visited Jaipur and Delhi. Likewise, an 80-year-old woman from Gandhinagar, who was reported positive on Sunday, also did not have any foreign travel history.

According to health department experts, the death fit in the pattern of a person having co-morbidity and old age, but the pattern has raised concerns on whether Covid-19 has entered stage III where it’s spreading in communities.

Thus, on Sunday, health commissioner Jai Prakash Shivahare sent a letter to all district collectors, district development officers and municipal corporation commissioners to initiate a door-to-door survey, not leaving possible cases to chance.

According to the letter, the survey will commence from Monday and it will be done through Innovative mobile-phone Technology for Community Health Operators (ImTeCHO) application. ‘Those returned from abroad will get precedence in the survey. Afterwards, the entire population is to be covered,’ stated the letter.

The district health official and medical officers will conduct the micro planning for the exercise. The survey will include paramedical staff and ASHA workers. Suspected cases will be included in a module which will be reviewed daily.

“We are already covering every possible person who might have come in contact with the positive cases. But it’s not a foolproof method and thus the thorough door-to-door survey is required.

Areas around quarantine houses will also be checked thoroughly,” said a health department official. “Application of the stickers on the quarantine homes has already begun to ensure compliance.” Officials said they are tracing all contacts of the positive cases with no foreign travel history.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: PSC exams deferred, SSC to go on
Content:
Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission (APPSC) has postponed all examinations scheduled in March and April 2020.

In a press release issued on Sunday, APPSC secretary said the decision was part of the containment measures to arrest the spread of Covid-19.

Degree college lecturer examinations (on April 3, 4) and Group I examinations (from April 7 to 19) to were postponed.

The new dates of examinations will be announced shortly.

Meanwhile, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy announced that the SSC examinations will continue as per schedule. He said officials will arrange special rooms in examination centres to facilitate the sick students.

Title: Will Help Those Stuck In London, Says Councillor
Content:
Hyderabad: With at least 19 Indian students, most of them from the two Telugu states staying put at the High Commission of India (HCI), London, and refusing to leave until they were flown back to the country, local authorities are trying to convince them to leave the premises. The HCI has already made it clear that since the Indian government has announced that no flights would be operated to India till March 31, the students should go back to their accommodation.

Councillor Geetha Morla, a public representative from Shenley Church End, Milton Keyens, told TOI on telephone that she would be able to assist the students find accommodation if they find it difficult to go back to their universities. Geetha, who is the first-ever Telugu person in the UK to be elected as councillor, spoke to the students and also offered to help. “In fact, PM Boris Johnson has announced three-month of rent relief for all those who do not have jobs. The HCI and local government are ready to do everything to keep the students safe,” Geetha said.

As the students had been insisting that the Indian government operate a special flight to take them home, the lawmaker said since the situation in Rome was different perhaps India chose to operate a flight from there as the place was severely affected. “In London, if one takes precautions and stays at home, there is safety,” she said. “They are safer and better looked after here than in India at this point of time,” she said.

A large number of Indian students had come to the High Commission office after they got to know that their flights were cancelled when they arrived in London. Since they too said they had no accommodation, the public representative said she assisted students in Leicester, Bournemouth, Eastham and Luton find a place to stay.

The students, who had stayed back at the HCI premises, fear that that they might not have a chance of getting tested for coronavirus. “The HCI and local council will help the local students in every possible manner. NHS is free in this country and helps anyone who requires help in relation to coronavirus. Tests are free of cost, so everyone who requires help will be treated. I can help if anyone needs. Any student can contact me. I am happy to help students who require help in connecting to the local people in the area or, if need be, personally calling and helping them,” she said. Geetha said she could be reached on email geethamorla@gmail.com or telephone: +447908589209.

Title: From dancing to cooking, they had a blast at home
Content:
Citizens made the most of the ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday.

NAGPUR: Citizens made the most of the ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday. Some helped out their mothers in the kitchen, some shook a leg to foot-tapping dance numbers, some binged watched their favourite TV shows and some enjoyed home-cooked food with their families. This Sunday was quite different from the usual ones as people did not go out to have fun at restaurants and discos but were alert, smart and cautious and spent their first day of janata curfew inside by indulging in creative activities. Abheek Ghosh from Growill Foundation came up with an innovative idea where over twenty people participated in meditation in the comfort of their homes. They were connected through a WhatsApp group called ‘Yoga Corona’. “Today we find ourselves quarantined in our homes. It is important to find the calm in our inner self and hence, we made this group and many participated in the meditation,” he said. The session was broadcast live on their Instagram page too. Tanushree Neware, a student who loves to shake a leg on dance numbers, spent her time making tik-tok videos on the ‘go corona’ theme. “I was on a conference video call with my family members in Mumbai and we were having a virtual dance party. Later, we decided to make a funny dance video on the ‘go corona’ tune,” she said. For Pushkar Bokarey, an engineer, the day was filled with productivity and innovation as he tried his hand at making the 3D-Printed masks shield that are used by doctors during the treatment of Covid-19. “I tried making a few masks. The mask acts as an outer shield and protects one from germs. Hence, I just tried making it and using my time to the fullest,” he said. Sarang Jajoo, who is an architect by profession, is spending quality time with this family. He also visits his friend’s place, Yudodhan, where they spend time chatting and relaxing. “Home quarantine via the janata curfew is a great way to spend time with parents and family. I’m just relaxing with my friend in his office. He is a lawyer and we spend hours talking and watching movies,” he said. Student Sugandha Rohatgi was looking forward to the 5pm community call. “I cooked myself a nice breakfast and have been binge watching Netflix. It’s my definition of a perfect Sunday,” she said. Earlier, family members would watch a movie or a show together, but these days, preferences have undergone a sea change. “My family is glued to the TV ever since the CM extended the lockdown by a few more days,’ added Rohatgi. Rebecca Peter, an expert in the Korean language, is also a fan of its dramas. She was glued to her computer screen and was enjoying the latest episodes. She also bonded with her parents. “I’m a student and hence, having a good time completing my notes and assignments, but not at the cost of meeting deadlines, which is a welcome relief. Korean dramas always come to my rescue as I am a huge K-Pop fan.” she said. “My ideal day included playing carom, reading my favourite books and watching movies. I also utilized the time to study for my exams,” said Rishabh Mutholkar. For Ajinkya Uike, who runs a steel factory, the ‘free time’ was dedicated to making accounts books for his venture and also cooking. “I’m helping my mother in her daily chores. I’m also enjoying cooking meals for my family too,” he said.

Title: Local bodies take steps to keep virus in check
Content: Kochi: Local municipalities have strengthened measures to keep Covid-19 in check. These include monitoring those under home quarantine and bleaching and cleaning roads.Most local body offices have closed multiple entries, set up hand-wash booths and placed sanitizers at the single entrance, and arrangements have been made at each desk where public needs to visit.Thrikkakara municipality has the largest number of persons under home quarantine – 216 persons. “We have a team, including ward councillor, Asha and anganwadi workers and government officials, to monitor these people. Most of the people are foreign-returned, mostly from official and personal trips,” said municipality vice-chairperson K T Eldho.He said that all IT companies, including those inside Infopark, SmartCity and Special economic zone (SEZ), have suspended all outside travel and many have adopted work from home for some time now. “We had a meeting with all these company heads right after the first alert itself, said Eldho.”In Aluva, the local body has been sanitizing junctions and markets using bleach and soap solution. “We have set aside Rs 1.5 lakh for the anti-Covid activities. “Manappuram has been closed long ago. We will now ensure that all parks, playgrounds, libraries and health clubs are closed,” chairperson Lissy Abraham said. “The number of vehicles and people on the roads have come down. We have not given instructions to shut down shops.”Kalamassery municipality chairperson Rukiya Jamal said that 63 persons are under home quarantine and the local body keeps in touch with all of them to enquire about their requirements. “Five families have sought help and we provide food and provisions to them,” she said. Following Covid-19 alert, all marriage functions scheduled to be held in various halls in the local body have been called off.Eloor municipality has called for a meeting of heads of all companies in the area to review the situation and the steps being taken by them to manage the crisis. “Every alternate day, we will be cleaning up all junctions, markets and bus shelters with soap solutions with the help of the fire force,” said municipality chairperson CP Usha. She said that instructions will be given to banks to sanitize their ATMs.

Title: IRCTC orders curbs on food services in trains
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation ( IRCTC ) has issued a directive to close all food plazas , refreshments rooms , Jan Aahars and cell kitchens until further advice.

The onboard catering services in mail, express trains and trains with train-side vending will also be closed. Only proprietary article depot items, tea and coffee can be sold by licensees of mobile units in case of demand.

Also, fast food units and water vending machines will be available at stations.

Static units supplying meals to pre-paid trains which are in operation are permitted to function. The retiring room under Thiruvananthapuram division can supply meals.

The units are not permitted to sell or provide catering services in the units other than pre-paid trains.

Regarding train services, 66 trains were cancelled by Southern Railway on Sunday, in view of the outbreak of Covid-19 and the ‘janata curfew’. tnn

Title: Rajasthan: FIR against two stores for selling masks, sanitisers at high costs
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: Jhalawar city kotwali police on Saturday night lodged a case against proprietors of two medical stores under sections of Essential Commodities Act for selling masks and sanitisers at inflated prices to customers.

One more medical store in Bhawanimandi town was found selling masks and sanitisers higher than the actual price and on the receipt of factual report by subdivisional magistrate (SDM), an enforcement inspector lodged a report.

On the report of sale of masks and sanitizer at inflated prices, a decoy was sent to Om Medical Store and Mahima Medical Store in front of SRG Medical College Hospital of Jhalawar city where the salesmen at the two medical stores were found selling the masks and sanitisers at bloated prices, enforcement inspector of Jhalawar district Vinod Kumar said.

A Rs 10 face mask was being sold at Rs 20 and a 100 ml sanitiser with an actual price of Rs 100 was being sold at Rs 150 at the two medical stores, he added. He has lodged a case against two medical stores in Jhalawar city Kotwali police station, he added.

Bhawanimandi SDM on Sunday sent a factual report of her visit to Shivalaya medical store where the higher than actual prices of face masks and sanitisers were being charged from customers, the inspector said.

On the report by enforcement inspector, police lodged a case against Om Medical Store and Mahima Medical Store under Section 3/7 of Essential Commodities Act, circle inspector of Jhalawar city kotwali police station Laxman Singh said.

Title: Sasikumar murder trial to lag by 6 more months
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The trial in the murder case of Hindu Munnani spokesperson C Sasikumar is unlikely to be completed before March, 31, 2020, the deadline set by the Supreme Court. The case is being heard by the special court for NIA ( National Investigation Agency ) cases in Poonamalle, Chennai.

Earlier, the apex court had ordered the presiding officer of the special court for NIA cases in Poonamalle to wrap up the case on or before this March-end. According to an NIA source, a few more prosecution witnesses are to be examined in the court and it will take at least six more months to complete the trial.

The source said, “We are handling more than more than 100 cases from across the state. While the trial in Sasikumar murder case has begun, it will take at another six months to conclude the trial. The state government should set up another court to deal Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act cases exclusively.”

The source said one more accused - Mohammed Rafiqul Hassan , 33, of Kamarajar Street at KK Pudur - was yet to be arrested. Presently, he is settled in Oman with his family.

NIA has issued red corner notice against Mohammed Rafiqul Hassan to all the airports in the country and alerted immigration officials as well. “He will be detained by immigration officials if he were to land in the country. We have also approached the Oman government to deport him to India,” the source said.

Sasikumar, of Subramaniyampalayam near Thudiyalur, was hacked to death near his residence by a gang on the night of September 22, 2016. The case was first handled by the rural police and then transferred to the special investigation division of CB-CID, who arrested Syed Abuthahir, Saddam Hussain, Subair and Mubarak. The case was, however, transferred to NIA in January 2018.

While the agency filed chargesheet against the five, including Mohammed Rafiqul Hassan, on April 7, 2018, charges were framed against four on June 21, 2018. tnn

Title: Societies shut their gates
Content:
Ahmedabad: Several residential societies have banned entry of all the non-residents as a move to fight against Covid-19 spread. With paranoia gripping various areas with news of positive and suspected cases, the societies have also put in stringent rules for posting information internal social media groups.

“More than 50 housekeeping and service staff members including domestic help as well as cooks, gardeners and cleaners are employed at our society. We have decided to only allow housekeeping staff to clean the society and that too for restricted hours in the morning. The entry of all other members will be prohibited for the coming three days,” said Nishtha Patel, a resident of Vejalpur .

A residential society in South Bopal has asked its members to collect their newspapers from the mail boxes on the ground floor and milk from the gate of the society so as to prevent the entry of the delivery personnel in society. Another society also put in hand sanitizer in the lift. “I have not been able to deliver most of the parcels today because I was not allowed to enter. Thankfully, at a couple of places, security guards took the parcels,” said Pranav Makwana , a delivery personnel. The societies have made arrangements to receive groceries, fruits and vegetables outside the society.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Passengers stranded at Secunderabad railway station due to curfew
Content: HYDERABAD: More than 100 passengers were stranded at Secunderabad railway station due to the janata curfew on Sunday. Most of them had started their journeys on March 21 and reached their destinations on Sunday. With most cab and auto services shut down due to janata curfew, passengers found it hard to go home.“There are no cabs available, and the taxis and autos are also not running. We don’t know how long we will have to wait. Most of the cab services are also cancelling our bookings saying that the distance is too far,” said Rajshri M, resident of Banjara Hills road number 10 who had arrived from Guntur.While some online cab aggregator services were taking bookings, they were unwilling to take passengers to faraway destinations in the city. Along with that, passengers also complained that due to dynamic pricing, they were forced to pay twice the amount of money that they usually pay. “I live in Begumpet and usually it takes me around Rs 120 to go from Secunderabad railway station to my home, the prices have gone up today. I will have to pay Rs 300 for such a short distance,” said Venkat Sai, another passenger who was found waiting at the station.With most passengers wore masks and maintained distance from their fellow passengers, they were faced with a dilemma when buses to their destinations offered to take them. “These buses are filled with many people. It is not safe to travel like this,” said another passenger. While some passengers were screened thermally at the stations, a major portion were left unattended. Heavy deployment of railway police was done at Secunderabad railway station.Taking buses and overpriced cabs, most of the stranded passengers found a way or another to travel to their destinations as most of the crowd had dispersed by 2 pm. With citizens voluntarily participating in janata curfew and South Central Railway (SCR) cancelling more than 200 trains for the day, most railway stations in the city wore a deserted look on Sunday after 1 pm. “I was supposed to travel from Lingampally to Falaknuma in an MMTS train at 11.30 am but I could not find a single vehicle to take me from Chandanagar to the station,” said Vijaya Kaveri, another passenger.With all train services cancelled till March 31, a number of people whose offices and colleges have been shut down had booked tickets to their home destinations but are now stuck in the city. “I had booked tickets to Kolkata for Tuesday but the ticket was rescheduled and then cancelled. Now, all the train services have been cancelled. We will be under a lockdown soon,” said Prachi Sharma.

Title: 400 textile units, 250 factories in Bhilwara shut
Content:
Ajmer: Around 400 textile units and 250 factories have remained closed in Bhilwara for the last three days where the number of positive coronavirus patients increased to 12 on Sunday.

The district administration has made teams of 300 people, specialized in different sectors, which will carry out a door-to-door survey of 30 lakh people in Bhilwara district. On Sunday, eight mobile vans were used to supply groceries, milk and other essential items through the upbhokta bhandar. “There is now no panic as the administration is doing good work,” said Amit Kakara, a resident of Subash Nagar.

A team member of the distribution van, Rekha, said they have flour, pulses, lentils, spices, biscuits, vegetables and fruits. People have been asked not to hoard eatables. Small towns like Gulabpura, Mandal and others remained completely shut on Sunday. Even petrol pumps remained closed. Jewellery and textile shops and all the markets were closed.

Sunil Mittal of metal factory in Hamirgarh said it was the first time in his life he relaxed with his family for long three days but was worried when this nightmare would get over.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Municipality gives food kits to families in isolation
Content: KOCHI: To address the shortage of provisions in the houses of people in home quarantine, Kalamassery municipality reaches out to them with food kits.Around 82 people, who had travelled from abroad and other parts of India, have been undergoing home quarantine within the limits of the local body.“When there is nobody to buy provisions for a family under home quarantine, the municipality steps in to purchase and transport the essentials to respective houses. We buy as per the requirement of each family. One food kit is only for 14 days. If the provisions run out before 14 days, they can raise it with us. the local body spends around Rs 1,000 for a food kit. Initially, we got some food kits from the district administration. But that has run out and we decided to buy the kits ourselves,” said Bindhu Manoharan, chairperson of the health standing committee of the Kalamassery municipality.A sanitizer, which has become a prized possession, is also part of the kit. “If a person is in home quarantine and his/her family is not in a position to come out of home, they can contact the health inspector of the respective areas. The official will inform the municipality health officer, who in turn buys the kit from a shop, identified earlier,” said a health official.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: IIT-Delhi says no to request for quarantine shelter
Content: NEW DELHI: Even as institutes like Indian Institute of Technology-Bombay and Maulana Azad National Urdu University (MANUU) in Hyderabad were chosen to be quarantine shelters, IIT-Delhi refused to become one.The name of IIT-Delhi was also proposed. However, many in the institute allegedly objected to the idea raising concerns about the safety of their international students and faculty.In Mumbai, the buildings that were taken over included the hostels of Bhaba Atomic Research Centre. Many students and the administration were actually opposed to the idea. At MANUU too, many students had objected to the idea alleging that this would put them at risk.A senior member of IIT-D, on condition of anonymity, said, “We received a mail from the lieutenant governor’s office informing us that they would be needing our campus to be used as a quarantine centre. But we informed them that it cannot happen as we have a huge number of international students still in campus and we also have our faculty whom we cannot put at risk.”The administration also informed the LG office that they have only 45 rooms in their guest house which would not be sufficient for them. IIT-D is however yet to get a response from the government on this. The institute had already asked their students to vacate the hostels by March 15 midnight.

Title: Three more sent to prison for swindling Rs 33.89 crore from bank in Coimbatore
Content:
COIMBATORE: Three more people were arrested on Saturday for swindling Tamilnad Mercantile Bank out of Rs 33.89 crore. With this, the number of people arrested in the case has risen to seven. Another 26 accused are, however, still at large.

The city crime branch police identified the arrested as Krishnakumar, 52, a realtor, Selvakumar, 37, a civil engineer and Nandakumar, all residents of Selakarichal near Sulur. They have been lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

Earlier, J Lakshmi Prakash , assistant general manager, Tamilnad Mercantile Bank, Trichy Road branch, had in January lodged a complaint with the city crime branch police stating anomalies to the tune of Rs 33.89 crore was detected in the loans issued by former assistant general manager T Sivasubramanian , 55, of Thoothukudi, during his tenure between March 2018 and December 2019.

The complaint said Sivasubramanian had conspired with other staff of the bank and civil engineers to misappropriate Rs 33,89,39,840. During his tenure he had sanctioned 12 loans amounting toRs 33.89 crore to start nine poultry farms and two poultry feed manufacturing units.

In one of the cases, the complainant said, Gomathi, of Selakarichal near Sulur, had taken a loan of Rs 2.89 crore to buy new machineries for her spinning mill and construct a few buildings by pledging 1.71 acres land, the value of which was just a few lakh rupees.

When the complainant visited Selakarichal, he didn’t find any spinning mill and realized that Gomathi had duped the bank with the help of a realtor, civil engineers and bank officials, an investigation officer said.

“Likewise, Nagarathinam took a loan of Rs 4.24 crore to set up a poultry farm by pledging 9.91 acres land at Varapatti, while Venkatesh borrowed Rs 4.26 crore by forging various documents. The remaining cases aren’t any different either. None had set up poultry farms or poultry feed manufacturing units. The borrowers submitted forged documents and increased the guideline value of their lands by at least four folds. They also submitted photos of buildings, while there were none,” the complaint said.

The officer said it was Nandakumar who forged all the documents. Two weeks ago, the city crime branch police had arrested Sivasubramanian, Gomathi, Mahesh, a realtor from Vilankurichi Road, and K M Pandian, 37, a civil engineer from Sulur, in connection with the case. While Pandian came out on bail, the remaining three are languishing in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Anaj Mandi fire: Report calls for new task force
Content:
The report also suggested creation of a task force, and an assessment of the working conditions of Delhi’s mig... Read More

NEW DELHI: Buildings in Anaj Mandi area need a revamp and constant fire audits to avoid any other major disaster in the locality in future. This was among the several suggestions made in the fire safety report prepared by IP University ’s Centre for Disaster Management Studies (CDMS).

The report also suggested creation of a task force, and an assessment of the working conditions of Delhi’s migrant workers.

In the study which was conducted along with Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration,Mussoorie, it was found that several factors played a role in the accident that left at least 43 dead and several others injured last year.

The report which was shared with Delhi government recently stated that the blaze took place in a factory where school bags, bottles and other materials were stocked. “The building was packed with cardboards, plastic toys, garments, rexine and other packaging items. This aggravated the fire and resulted in dense smoke, which suffocated the people trapped inside.”

According to the CDMS report, the incident “exposed the poor working conditions of industrial workers employed in thousands of such illegal and ill-managed factories operating from the residential areas of Delhi & NCR. It also highlighted the lackadaisical attitude of various regulatory authorities, government departments and individuals.”

Absence of inspection and inadequate buyer policies pose several threats, the report warns. As per its recommendations, there should be a task force with decision makers, such as local factory owners, industry trade associations, retailers, civic bodies, civil society organisations and unions, NGOs and philanthropic organisations.

“The task force needs to conduct a comprehensive census of all unorganised factories in the city as the existing data are weak and unreliable. It will have to develop an equitable model for determining the financial responsibility of each stakeholder group in meeting the post-disaster overall funding requirement,” the report, prepared by the students, added.

“The decision-makers should focus on developing models to track the migrant population of workers from each part of the country working in the unorganised clusters. And there should be a nodal department to keep a tab on how many workers enter Delhi and how their livelihood takes place, so that they can be identified in case of an emergency.”

“Facilitation centres should be established in zones where people from unorganised sectors and poor economic background live. Problems of livelihood must be solved so that the poor workers can also live in a safer environment,” the report suggested.

Title: T students in Kazakhstan told to stay put there
Content:
Hyderabad: With the state government taking up the issue of Telangana students stranded at Almaty airport in Kazakhstan, the Consulate General of India in Astana, Kazakhstan has said it was wrong to say the students were stranded at the airport.

In a letter to the Telangana state government, CGI, Astana, advised that the students be informed to stay back until the situation improves and travel ban was lifted. “Their hostels are still operational and mess facilities are available. The embassy has also advised all universities and educational contractors to continue to run hostels and mess facilities,” CGI, Astana said.

“If students are from cities other than Almaty, which will enforce entry/exit measures from tomorrow, please advise them to go back to their cities urgently. Their student contractors can help in this regard. Staying in large groups at public places like airports might pose problems for Kazakh law and order officials,” the letter issued on March 21 said.

The CGI explained that since the students have semester holidays, they wanted to visit India. The official said Kazakhstan was not highly infected with Covid-19 and the government there was taking all steps to contain the spread of the virus. “When students know that there are government restrictions/quarantine measures, which were announced well in advance, they could have undertaken their travel when the situation improved,” the official said.

The letter was in response to a letter from Telangana government on March 21, mentioning that 14 medical students from the state were stranded at the Kazakhstan airport for the last three days without flights, food and accommodation. The general administration (NRI) department wrote a letter to the Indian embassy in Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan, seeking help for the students to return.

Title: Coronavirus crashes wedding plans
Content:
Kochi: His daughter's wedding was a dream, and Murali Rajan (name changed) was preparing for a big bash in April. However, the spike in Covid-19 cases and the resultant restrictions imposed by the government have forced a change in plans.

“In the changed circumstances I am unsure whether it will be possible to hold even a low-key affair. If we are forced to postpone the event, I don't know long we will have to wait,” said Rajan.

His initial plan was to scale down the event. Instead of the convention centre that was booked, the venue was shifted to a local temple. “Our families are religious and we don’t want to miss the auspicious day that has been chosen. I plan to take a decision after March 31,” he said.

Why March 31? “Current restrictions are in place till then,” says Rajan.

He is keeping his friends and relatives updated over phone, email and WhatsApp about the change in plans. With travel restrictions in place Rajan is not keen on visiting them to convey the news.

Similar sentiments are shared by many families that have scheduled weddings in the months of March and April.

Lalitha Mohan had scheduled her daughter’s engagement for April 16. “There is so much uncertainty. The family is keen on postponing the event to a future date. But, we are unable to finalize a date,” she said.

Cancellations and postponements have adversely affected the wedding industry. Most pre-wedding shoots have been cancelled.

“Families of brides and grooms have already communicated the cancellations or postponements. In most cases they have not given a final date. All large-scale photo shoots are being avoided. In low-key weddings, very few photos are taken, which are mainly for the purpose of documentation,” said Ananthu G Prakesh, a freelance photographer based in Tripunithura.

Title: Vijayawada: Spitting in public to draw Rs 1,000 fine
Content: VIJAYAWADA: As part of measures to maintain hygiene in the city, the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) will impose a Rs 1,000 fine on persons who spit in public places. The civic body will also impose a fine of Rs 500 on persons who urinate or defecate in public.The move follows the first positive Covid-19 case reported on Saturday in the city. VMC authorities have intensified sanitation drives and health workers and sanitation staff cleared out garbage bins and sprinkled bleaching powder on the sides of roads and along drains.“Coronavirus can transfer from one person to others through droplets. Spitting in public places will increase the risk of infection. We want to prevent this and started imposing fines on the violators. The public can send the photographs of those who are spitting in public,” said Krishna district collector and VMC special officer A Mohammed Imtiaz.Around 100 volunteers will be deployed across key locations in the city to impose fines.
