Title: Erode district gears up for lockdown
Content: Even as the health department was awaiting the test results of 10 people who came in contact with the two Thai nationals tested positive for Covid-19 in Erode , the district administration geared up for a lock down.Erode was one of the three districts in Tamil Nadu identified by the Centre for a lockdown to prevent Coronavirus from spreading.Erode collector C Kathiravan said that a decision on sealing the borders of the district will be taken by the chief minister on Monday. “The Government of India’s direction on locking down certain districts including Erode is under the consideration of the state government. So, the status quo will remain until the decision is taken. For now, the district will function as usual after the curfew ends at 5am on Monday,” he said.However, police have placed barricades on the national highway at Pallipalayam, the district border, which links Erode with Namakkal, Salem, Dharmapuri and Krishnagiri. The roads connecting Erode with Karnataka at Thimbam were sealed a day ago.The collector also warned that all those coming to the district from abroad or other states should inform the tahsildar, block development officer or health officials in the locality. Those failing to intimate would face legal consequences. He also instructed the industrial units not to employ workers from other states or countries.Meanwhile, a health officer said that 126 people who visited two mosques in Erode the Thai nationals visited are under medical surveillance and none of them have shown symptoms of Covid-19 yet.Ten people, including a guide, driver and helpers of the Thai nationals, who came into close contact with them, are closely watched. The swab test results of the 10 was yet to come, the health officer said.TNN

Title: Lockdown: Many flights at RGIA cancelled
Content:
Hyderabad: Many flights from Hyderabad to various destinations were cancelled on Sunday. All the flight services (departures and arrivals) of GoAir and TruJet were cancelled. Some Indigo, SpiceJet and Air India flights to destinations such as Bengaluru, Mumbai, Kochi, Goa, Kolkata among others were also cancelled, leaving passengers stranded in the city. Due to the lockdown declared by the state government, many could not even take alternate modes of transport.

Among them were students of University of Hyderabad who were asked to vacate hostels and return home by March 23. “@HardeepSPuri I am a student of Hyderabad Central University. Please don’t cancel flights to Bihar atleast for tomorrow (March 23). Me along with few friends are stranded here with no other means to go back home since university has been lockdown and we are advised to vacate hostel,” tweeted Simpoo Kumar.

Title: Private hospitals to book 25 per cent beds for coronavirus patients
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

JAIPUR: Taking precautionary measures, the health department has directed all private hospitals having more than 100 beds to reserve 25% of the beds for Covid-19 patients.

Private hospitals and nursing homes society have already assured the state government full cooporation in fight against the virus. The society has assured that private hospitals will create awareness on Covid-19 apart from making full utilisation of the available resources in the fight.

The society has also issued an advisory directing the hospitals to ensure suitable isolated area for OPD for suspected Covid-19 cases. The private hospitals will also ensure indoor patient department as per availablity of space for such patients.

“The state government has decided that those private hospitals who have more than 100 bed capacity should reserve 25% of the beds of suspected and confirmed Covid-19 patients,” said Raghu Sharma, health minister.

Besides, private players are also offering their services to the state government for containing spread of Covid-19. Educationalist Shailendra Bhadauria has offered his Chandwaji situated campus for making its as a temporary hospital as well as isolation wards in the hostels and staff residences of the institute.

Title: Buses arranged for passengers at Sec’bad stn
Content:
Hyderabad: Amid the lockdown, Gopalapuram police arranged seven mini-buses for passengers who reached Secunderabad railway station to go to their destinations on Sunday.

Nearly 600 passengers utilised the service, said police. “The people who depend on public transport to reach their destination, especially elderly people and women with children were asked to use the buses. These vehicles are department buses,” said Gopalpuram sub-inspector, Srinivas.

The buses were provided between 11 am and 1.30 pm, while each bus made about four rounds from Secunderabad railway station to the passenger’s destination. This was taken as an immediate measure to help the public during the lockdown, the police said. “As all the public transport is shut, this was done to help the public,” added the officer.

Title: Coimbatore: District administration lends a helping hand to stranded migrant workers
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: As many as 200 migrant workers who reached the Coimbatore Junction railway station in the Dhanbad-Alappuzha Express on Sunday afternoon were shocked to find the otherwise busy streets eerily empty.

They had boarded the train two days ago, not aware of the state government’s decision to suspend the bus service in support of the Janta Curfew proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

“I have been working in the district for 19 years and it is with that confidence that I boarded the train from Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh on Friday morning. But even in my dreams I did not expect that I would be struggling to feed my one year old son. Fortunately, my fellow passengers arranged milk and some cookies for him,” said 40-year-old Madhan Kumar, who works in a machine manufacturing unit in Annur.

“I was not aware of the closure of eateries and the state government’s decision to stop the bus service in the city. Otherwise, I would not have boarded the train with my wife and son,” he told TOI.

Ranchana from Odisha was accompanied by eight of her family members who works at an estate in Coonoor. They waited at the bus stop in front of the station for five hours. “We had a harrowing time as we had children with us. We requested taxi drivers to take us to Coonoor and were ready to pay whatever they demanded. But they refused,” she said.

As groups of migrant workers sat in front of the railway station cursing their bad luck, a team consisting of non-governmental organizations led by Coimbatore collector K Rajamani reached there carrying food packets. He also arranged accommodation for them in the community hall of the CSI Immanuel Church at Uppilipalayam in the city after screening them for the symptoms of coronavirus.

Title: Coimbatore cops to verify British, Sri Lankan passports of women thieves
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police have approached the Foreigner Regional Registration Office (FRRO) after finding that three women who were arrested recently for stealing gold chains were carrying British and Sri Lankan passports.

The Big Bazaaar Street (crime) police had arrested Indhumathi, 27, wife of Pandiarajan from Thrissur in Kerala, Selvi, 36, wife of Chinna Thambi of Thiruvanmiyur in Chennai and Parasakthi, 36, wife of Ranjithkumar of Bharathi Nagar at Thiruvanmiyur in Chennai for stealing 6.5 sovereigns of gold from devotees during the Koniamman temple car festival. The Ukkadam police later arrested K Jothi,34, of Arasankadu on Mangalam Road and her husband R Karthik, 34, on the same charges and recovered nine sovereigns of gold ornaments from them.

“Indhumathi had reached Tamil Nadu from London. She is a frequent flyer. Selvi often flies to Colombo,” a police officer said. “Indhumathi told us that her husband is working in the UK. Selvi said she is a Sri Lankan citizen and her husband is working in Colombo. Jothi and Karthik also claimed to be Lankan citizens and had Sri Lankan passports.”

Police have seized their passports. “We have approached FRRO to verify their claims,” said deputy commissioner of police E S Uma.

The four women and Karthik are members of a gang led by Madan Kumar of Chennai, a police officer said. “A team is in pursuit of Kumar. The women confessed that they had snatched gold chains from devotees during the Karamadai Aranganatha Swamy temple car festival also. All of them have Aadhaar cards. We don’t know how they managed to get the cards.”

Title: Covid-19 outbreak in Jaipur: SMS Hospital’s Charak Bhawan will be made into care unit
Content: JAIPUR: As the Sawai Man Singh Hospital (SMS) is flooded with suspected Covid-19 patients, Charak Bhawan, a division of SMS Hospital, where facilities for ophthalmology and dermatology OPD available, will be converted into ‘Corona OPD and care unit’.Besides, 500 beds will be reserved for Covid-19 patients at main SMS Hospital building. At the Charak Bhawan, there will be a 150-bed facility for suspected Covid-19 patient. If any of the suspected Covid-19 tests positive for the disease, the patient will be shifted to the main building with 500-bed facility for Covid-19 patients or at ICU, depending on the care the patient needs. The decision will be taken by the board constituted at hospital level to decide on treatment. Moreover, 24-bed ICU will be reserved for Covid-19 patients. Also, a 30-bed ICU will be dedicated to Covid-19 patients, when requirement rises. Health minister Raghu Sharma said that 30 more ventilators will be provided to SMS Hospital for ICU.At Charak Bhawan, general surgeries will not be performed as these facilities will be shifted to other place in the hospital. Charak Bhawan will be completely dedicated to Covid-19.

Title: Neighbours inform health staff about foreign returnees
Content:
JAIPUR: In the past few days, health authorities have been flooded with calls from Jaipurities informing them about people who have returned from other countries.

Apprehensive that they might be infected, these people who have flown in from different countries are not reporting about their return to health authorities for Covid-19 screening. But alert neighbours are not wasting any time to call helpline numbers 104 and 108 informing officials about such people.

Since all the cases, barring Covid-19 cases from Bhilwara, have a history of travelling abroad, the residents of the city have become alert and are keeping an eye in their neighbourhood.

“We recieved a call from Malviya Nagar that a man travelled from Dubai and did not report about it to the authorities. We rushed our teams and conducted his screening. Over the past few days, we have recieved more than 200 calls from alert residents who have decided to fight the disease,” said Dr Narrottam Sharma, chief medical health officer (CMHO) Jaipur-I.

So far, six cases of Covid-19 have been reported from Rangoli Garden, Jagatpura, Gopalpura and Adarsh Nagar. “As these cases have been reported from different areas of the city, the residents have become extra cautious. Six persons who have tested positive for Covid-19 in the city, barring the two Italians, have travelled to Dubai, Spain, Switzerland and the US. People are aware that those who are returning from other countries might be carrying the infected, they make all possible measures to get their screening done,” said a health department official.

However, the health authorities also get information of Rajasthan residents who landed at Delhi airport. “There are more than 300 suspected Covid-19 patients who have entered Rajasthan,” said Raghu Sharma, health minister, while pointing out that they are keeping a watch on them and conducted their screening and testing for the virus.

He appealed to people to cooperate with the government by following the guidelines and advisories. He said with new cases are reporting every day, the disease is spreading.

Title: Delhi: Stranded Russian couple sells photos for funds
Content: NEW DELHI: An unusually deserted Lodhi Garden on a weekend wasn’t the only surprising sight that greeted the few who were at the popular spot on Saturday. It was also unusual to see a couple from overseas selling pictures of their travel across the world at the park. Viktor and Anna are stranded in India because the flight they were booked on has been cancelled. They don’t know when they will be able to fly home to Russia and need to think about their finances for stay longer than they had planned.A cardboard sheet in front of the pictures explained their predicament: “Hello! We travel and study the culture of India. We sell photos from our trip for a free (fair) price. You can take a souvenir and thank you from the heart, This, money we spend on food and hostel. Thank you.”In halting English Anna explained, “We have been touring India for three months and were supposed to fly back to Moscow on Air Astana on March 23. That flight has been cancelled and we are almost out of money. Some kind Indians are helping us by letting us stay in their homes in South Extension. But we need to raise funds because we don’t know when we will be able to return home. When we will be able to book tickets, on which airline, we know nothing at this time.”India has disallowed all scheduled commercial flights for a week from Sunday. Strapped for cash, Viktor said, “We are trying to raise funds by selling our pictures.” Viktor said. He even jokingly requested the people to buy water and potato chips for them. Asked if they had approached their embassy for assistance, Anna disclosed, “Many people are stranded like us and we couldn’t contact the embassy due to the rush.”The sight of two foreigners selling wares, like urchins often present here selling artificial jewellery, piqued the curiosity of people. There was soon a small gathering at the spot. But since this is something that is not allowed in these times of the coronavirus , the security staff asked the duo to pack up and leave.

Title: Bells ring out at 5 pm, residents come out to clap for doctors
Content: Vijayawada: Residents confined at home came out on to balconies and terraces at 5 pm on Sunday, clapping and ringing bells to express gratitude for and solidarity with healthcare and sanitation workers working round-the-clock to contain the spread of Covid-19 Responding to the call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, residents in apartment complexes came out to clap for doctors. “We should feel proud of our doctors and medical staff who are risking lives to save us from the dreadful coronavirus. They too have families, but they don’t have the chance to stay back at their homes. The services of the sanitation workers should be appreciated and the government should give them proper safety gear,” said Madasu Bhaskar, a resident of Lotus Landmark, an apartment in the city.Around 70 physically-disabled orphans from Ashajyothi Orphanage in Hanuman Junction came out of their hostel at 5 pm and clapped in support of doctors.Krishna district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz, VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh, joint collector Madhavi Latha, sub-collector Dhyana Chandra and others expressed their gratitude at a programme held at the collector’s bungalow in the city.

Title: Coimbatore: Curfew brings the best out of denizens
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: When the district was completely shut down in support of janata curfew on Sunday, some good Samaritans of the city stepped out of their houses and distributed food packets and water bottles to homeless and migrant workers.

“For the past three days, we have been distributing food to health workers who were at government hospitals and at screening centres that were set up by the government. When we realized that all the eateries would be closed due to janata curfew, we had decided to provide food to the homeless people, as well,” Roshan from Kirthigainatham Trust said.

As most of the catering services and restaurants were closed, the members of the trust had cooked food at their homes and distributed it to the migrant workers who were stranded in front of the railway station and to homeless people in front of Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH).

Shanmugaraja who works with Sudhar Trust – which provides final rites to the destitute corpses – said, “This morning when we returned after cremating a body, a group of people approached us and started to ask for food. It is only then we decided to arrange food for the homeless people.”

Within an hour after Vaishnavee Balaji , founder of food bank was informed that close to 200 people were struggling without having food, she rushed to the spot with biscuit and bread packets after planning to provide them a proper lunch.

Meanwhile, Mahendran from Eera Nenjam, a NGO, which maintains a corporation shelter for homeless at RS Puram, drove across the city to identify the homeless. He had accommodated 25 homeless people in his shelter after making several trips between his shelter and several places in the city.

Title: NGO: Provide food to orphanages
Content:
Hyderabad: Amid the lockdown, a city-based NGO has appealed Telangana government to provide adequate food for the children in the orphanages . Only a few days ago, the women and child welfare department has asked all child care institutes (CCI) to hand over the children to their guardian or relatives.

“Only children who have nowhere else to go are staying. We have already stocked up for the 25 children currently staying with us. But if any CCI needs essentials, the government should come forward to help,” said Purna Chandra from the Hyd Children Aid Society for Girls, a listed CCI.

“After the decision of lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus, however, we appeal the government to provide food for the children in orphanages,” said Achyuta Rao, president, Balala Hakkula Sangham, a child rights NGO.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: 6 test +ve for coronavirus, state total now up to 27
Content: HYDERABAD: Six more persons in Telangana tested positive for coronavirus on Sunday. The total number of cases in the state has now risen to 27. All six persons had a travel history from foreign countries. The state health department said the persons have been isolated and are receiving treatment.Among the six cases tested positive on Sunday, five are men and one a housewife from Hyderabad with a travel history to Dubai. Her husband and son have also tested positive and are in isolation centres. Authorities said several contacts including friends, family members and others were already quarantined as part of the containment process.“Again, all these people are with travel history to London, Dubai, Scotland among others,” said chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao. While two are from Andhra Pradesh, the remaining four are from Telangana. The two from AP include a 24-year-old from Guntur, who arrived from London via Dubai, while another student is a 26-year-old resident of Rajolu area in East Godavari district. He had returned from Sweden.Other male patients from Telangana include a 23-year-old student from Kukatpally, a 35-year-old from Manikonda who returned from Sweden and a 23-year-old student from Bhadradri Kothagudem who returned from London. Since March 19, the state government has stepped up its vigil and has placed thousands under quarantine.Following a rise in coronavirus cases, the Centre on Sunday notified five districts of Telangana as lockdown districts. The districts include Bhadradri-Kothagudam, Hyderabad, Medchal, Rangareddy and Sangareddy. More cases of people with travel history have been reported from these areas. In the afternoon health minister, Eatala Rajender reviewed the situation in the state with health department officials.

Title: 39 Qatar returnees halted at border, shifted to quarantine
Content:
Keeping Vigil

Hyderabad: Thirty-nine migrant workers who came from Qatar to Mumbai by flight and then reached Telangana state border in a private bus were intercepted at the inter-state checkpoint near Zahirabad. Police also intercepted two private buses carrying 60 people from Goa to Hyderabad near Kodangal.

Passengers in these buses were shifted to quarantine facilities at Gachibowli for screening. Cops stationed at the inter-state check point near Madgi in Sangareddy district stopped Shalimar Travels bus carrying 39 migrant workers who had returned from Qatar on Sunday morning.

“The workers are from Srikakulam district in AP. They reached Mumbai from Qatar by flight and boarded Shalimar Travels private bus arranged by an agent to reach Hyderabad and then go to Srikakulam.,” Sangareddy superintendent of police (SP) S Chandrasekhar Reddy said. Police said the passengers deliberately came to Mumbai airport instead of Hyderabad airport from Qatar fearing they might be placed under compulsory quarantine if they land at the RGI Airport.

Meanwhile, police also intercepted two buses of a private travels near Kodangal with 60 passengers coming to Hyderabad from Goa.At the 52 inter-state check posts, police along with health and revenue department officials carried out checks of all incoming vehicles. “Only goods vehicles and people who needed to travel due to personal or medical reasons were allowed to cross the border,” Narayanpet SP M Chetana said.

Title: When Coimbatore locked itself up to fight Covid-19
Content: COIMBATORE: The entire city came to a standstill on Sunday as never before with residents staying indoors as requested by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to fight the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.Busy stretches such as Mettupalayam Road and Thadagam Road and bustling areas like RS Puram, Gandhipuram and Raja Street remained deserted, barring an occasional two-wheeler or two.While all the commercial establishments were shut, pharmacies and petrol bunks were open. However, there were hardly any patrons. Traders’ associations said all members had closed their shops irrespective of political affiliations as this was a public health emergency.P Murugan, district president of Tamil Nadu Vyabarigal Sammelanam , said they had urged all the members to observe janata curfew. “Usually, during bandhs that are called for political reasons there would be one or two shops doing business on the sly. But as this was for an important public cause, everyone downed the shutters.”Petrol bunks across the city, meanwhile, worked with minimal staff. K Rajasekaran, a representative of Coimbatore District Petroleum Dealers’ Association, said bunks operated with just one or two staff members each. “We encouraged only ambulances and those who brought their vehicles completely dry. In general, there were not many customers.”In the morning, some online food delivery personnel were seen riding around the city. But after media reports, the few eateries that were delivering food downed their shutters. A delivery agent, who was spotted in RS Puram, said the eateries had stopped taking orders by noon. “They also cancelled the orders that were already placed.”Many churches in the city had called off Sunday mass. Some of them had announced that they would be open from 5.30am to 6.30am and interested people could offer prayers. Jamath organizations in the city had asked their members to hold prayers at home and avoid gatherings.A few residents, who were eager to see their city in an unusually deserted state, were seen taking selfies in areas which otherwise would have been crowded in daylight.Residents, who had arranged for functions such as marriages and other rituals, either cancelled them or made them low-key affair. A resident from Periyanaickenpalayam in the district had arranged his son’s marriage-related ritual on Sunday. He said they conducted the ritual at home with a very few close relatives. “We had also cancelled the grand arrangements for the marriage and reception.”As appealed by Modi, at 5pm, residents came out to their doors and balconies and clapped, clanged utensils and sounded gongs to show their gratitude to doctors, health and sanitary workers and other personnel, who are working to contain Covid-19 pandemic. On their part, the city police band performed in front of Gandhipuram bus stand, while fire and rescue services personnel clapped their hands at their stations.

Title: Curfew leaves Hyderabad’s homeless in the lurch
Content: HYDERABAD: While most in the city stayed home and observed the ‘ janata curfew ’ on Sunday, those dwelling on the streets were left with nowhere to go. “If I get the virus, I die,” said Sathayya, a homeless man who dwells on the streets near Nagarjuna Circle. “What about us? I have no home and I will definitely not survive if I get infected. Until today, I was not aware of how serious this problem really is but now I am terrified. There is not a single person on this road except me,” said Sathayya.In one of the parking lots near KBR park, a man in his mid-50’s was found sleeping on a bench which was kept in a bus bay for passengers boarding the bus. When asked if he was aware of the curfew, he said: “A traffic policeman told me to go home. He said we are not supposed to come out of the house today but where do I go? I do not have a house. I either sleep on this bench or the footpath.”When contacted, Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) officials said that there were posters at bus stops containing information on shelters and that teams are sent out regularly to identify the homeless. “Our officials go on rounds every two days to identify the homeless, enquire and bring them to the shelter. We did not get any separate instructions for the janata curfew,” a senior GHMC official said. When informed about the homeless in certain parts of the city, the official said that he will send a team and see that they are shifted to the shelter at the earliest.On the other hand, municipal corporations in parts of Kerala and Tamil Nadu have taken to measures to provide food to street-dwellers during the curfew. The Madras High Court had directed the Tamil Nadu government to accommodate the homeless.

Title: Passenger from Pune detained at Nampally stn
Content: Hyderabad: Another passenger with a home quarantine stamp was detained at Nampally railway station after he arrived in the city from Pune aboard the Hyderabad Express on Sunday. According to police, the man landed at Mumbai airport on March 21. He was returning from Nigeria via Abu Dhabi and was advised home quarantine.“The man boarded the train from Pune on the same day after he landed in Mumbai. He was wearing gloves to cover it up. A co-passenger from the same coach saw the stamp and alerted the railway police and officials,” DSP S Rajendra Prasad told TOI.

Title: Residents comply, cops ensure streets remain empty
Content: Hyderabad/Secunderabad: The ‘ janata curfew ’ across the twin cities was a resounding success with most residents abiding by the call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and subsequently the state government’s directives. However, even essential services such as fuel stations, grocery stores and a few others which were exempt from observing the curfew also kept their shutters down.Few services that did remain open were seen functioning with limited capacity. For instance, some fuel outlets ran with only unit. “Since not many customers were expected, only two of the total 12 staff was asked to report for duty,” said Raju, a worker at a petrol bunk in Sainikpuri.Those who came out to buy groceries, many of them daily-wage labourers, had to return empty handed. “Now, neither do we have money to buy vegetables nor are any stores open,” said Rajamma, a daily wage labourer. Pharmacies, hospitals along with fire departments and police stations remained operational.City comes alive at five Breaking the stark silence, the twin cities came alive at 5 pm on Sunday as people from all walks of life came out in large numbers to clap in appreciation of those providing essential services in wake of the coronavirus pandemic. CM K Chandrasekhar Rao, as per his promise, joined his family at Pragathi Bhavan to show appreciation. At Begumpet fire station, fire engines switched on their sirens and cops and firemen were seen clapping in front of it. In Sainikpuri, few residents took to bursting crackers. In temples, priests blew conches and held special prayers to contain the pandemic.Old City stands stillThe Old City, which is usually packed with people wore a deserted a look. The Mozamjahi market, Shalibanda, Falaknuma and areas in and around the GHMC’s Charminar zone witnessed minimal movement. Police were seen holding placards urging people to ‘pray at home’ and ‘avoid crowds.’ Some locals who had come out near Madina and Gulzar Houz were counseled by police and sent back home. “I am living here since childhood, even when police curfew was declared we could see few people and cops but on Sunday I could hardly see a human,” said 41-year-old Nadeem Ahmed.Colonies see movement While main roads across the city were being monitored by cops, lanes within colonies saw movement with residents going for walks and some even taking out their vehicles for a drive. Few, who were spotted by police, were told to go back home. “The roads are so empty, I came out to walk my dog. I never saw the roads so quiet. It was like three at night,” said Adhil Shaik, an Ameerpet resident.Police keeps vigilPolice across all three commissionerates — Hyderabad, Cyberabad and Rachakonda — were seen stopping sporadic motorists and asking them to return to their residence. At Rasoolpura, police were seen asking motorists who were out without valid reasons to hold placards, displaying preventive measures against coronavirus, on the road as punishment. In the IT corridor, traffic police caught one person for drunk driving.Sec’bad areas deserted Main roads and civilian areas in Secunderabad were mostly empty with only on-duty cops seen patrolling their areas. Meanwhile, 20 teams of Secunderabad Cantonment Board’s health and sanitation department took up disinfecting operations under its jurisdiction.

Title: Five booked for travelling with seal for quarantine
Content: Hyderabad: The Railway Police booked five passengers under the Epidemic Diseases Act for travelling on trains despite having a travel history of Covid-19 infected countries. Naresh Bhukya, 29, who came from the US to Hyderabad via Abu Dhabi, and suspected to have symptoms of Covid-19, was found travelling from Secunderabad station to Vijayawada on Krishna Express on Saturday. He was shifted to Gandhi Hospital and a case was booked against him.Ravi Kiran, who had travelled to Sydney and was going to Nagpur, was detained on Sunday when he got down at Bhongir station from KSR Bengaluru-Hazrat Nizamuddin Express. He was shifted to Gandhi hospital.Rohit Kumar, 24, and his wife Pooja Yadav, 24, both arrived in Hyderabad from Indonesia on Friday, and they were asked to home quarantine. The couple was handed over to the railway authority and police, after a co-passenger noticed stamps on their hands while they were travelling on Rajdhani Express, from Secunderabad to Delhi. Another person, P Harika, 29, from Kakinada of AP, reached Hyderabad Airport on Sunday from Dubai. She was stamped home quarantined by officials. However, Harika boarded Bhavnagar Terminus-Kakinada Port Express on Sunday, and was detained. The entire train’s coaches were sterilised, said officials.

Title: Telangana to permit companies to carry out essential, critical ops
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana government, which on Sunday evening announced a state-wide lockdown till March 31, will allow companies to run essential operations, a top state government official said here on Sunday. Telangana IT and industries principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan said the government had permitted companies to carry out critical functions during the ‘ janata curfew ’ on Sunday and will continue to permit the same in the days ahead.“The government has permitted any company that has essential or critical functions to carry them out. The curfew will not apply to them (essential staff). We are working with the DGP to work out a system of passes for essential staff. All essential staff in various companies, industries or factories, will be identified and passes issued. The GO on this will be issued soon,” Ranjan told TOI. He cited the instance of Sirpur Paper Mills, where 300 of the nearly 2,000 employees of the company, were allowed to come to the factory in Kagaznagar on Sunday to carry out critical operations.Few employees of some companies like Amazon went to work during the curfew. “As the Covid-19 pandemic continues, Amazon and our network of partners are helping communities...in a way that very few can...,” an Amazon spokesperson said.“While a significant number of these teams work from home, there are some whose work requires their physical presence... these individuals have access to all of their usual paid and unpaid time-off benefits should they, for any reason, choose not to come to work. We are going to great lengths to keep buildings extremely clean and help employees practice important precautions such as social distancing..,” the spokesperson said.

Title: Janata curfew: Jaipur residents show gratitude from balconies, terraces
Content: JAIPUR: The blue sky of Pink City on Sunday reverberated with the sound of claps, clanging of bells, steel plates, whistles, and conches as residents came out in their balconies to show gratitude towards all those who are relentlessly working to stop the spread of Covid-19.Prime Minister Narendra Modi had during his address to the nation urged the citizens to observe janata curfew and show their gratitude. However, in some areas people made mockery of the curfew and came out in large numbers on the streets.Ninety-three-year-old Anshi Devi, her 75-year-old nephew Balkishan Bandhana and around 50 other family members gathered at the balcony of their haveli in Johari Bazar and started blowing conches and clapped. “We live in a joint family and since the day we came to know about the Italian couple testing positive for Covid-19, we have been following social distancing,” said Bandhana, who was beating a drum. The Bandhana family, where six generations live together, has asked its relatives and friends not to visit them until the danger of Covid-19 vanishes.Likewise, people living in residential apartments also came out in their balconies and terraces to offer their gratitude. “It is a good initiative by the state and the Union government and we all must abide by it,” said Gaurav Nagar, who came from Ahmedabad to his in-laws house and is now stuck due to lockdown.However, at many places police had to intervene when people came out in large numbers on streets. At Hawa Mahal, Choti Chaupar, Badi Chaupar, Jhotwara, Murlipura and Chandpole Bazar people were seen taking undue liberty of the appeal. Policemen on bikes, jeeps and other vehicles with loudspeakers had to urge people to keep distance and reminded them that the time of offering gratitude was over. “There were people, especially youngsters, shouting and whistling on roads. We asked them to go back to their homes,” said a senior police officer who was at Johari Bazar.At many localities, people burst firecrackers and also played loud music. “This was not Modiji had expected while appealing for offering gratitude. Many of us have done it in a very unorganized and indisciplined manner,” said 64-year-old Ramesh Kewani, who runs a grocery shop at Chandpole Bazar.

Title: City makes right noises to salute virus fighters
Content:
Jaipur: People in Jaipur abided by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call on ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday with no vehicles, or even people on roads. The day ended with families coming out on their balconies to clap and ring bells to salute those involved in essential services.

Jaipur witnessed almost complete silence when people of every age, caste, creed and religion preferred to stay indoors. Hardly any vehicles were seen on the roads.

TOI visited various parts of the city to know how Jaipur was responding to the ‘janta curfew’.

The only shops that opened in the morning were a few milk parlours and some grocery shops in the interiors of housing colonies. Police vehicles with loudspeakers made the rounds of streets and requested people to stay indoor. Medical stores, diagnostic centres were among those that opened across the city.

A bike-borne 25-year-old youth was stopped by policemen when he tried to enter through Chandpole Gate. “I am clicking pictures. I have never seen Jaipur like this,” he told the policemen.

The Jaipur railway station that witnesses a footfall of nearly 4 lakh people daily was empty, so was the road in front of it. Some generous voluntary groups and policemen organised food packets for street dewellers including beggars.

“We have prepared 500 food packets and are distributing them among the beggars. We also visited government hospitals to distribute food packets,” said a volunteer at Badi Chaupar.

Title: Mumbaikars clap, clang metal, blow conches to salute docs
Content:
Mumbai: The eerie silence on streets, hit by the janata curfew, was broken with the sound of fervous clapping much before the clock struck 5 in the city on Sunday. Clangs of metals, cymbals, bells and blowing of conches rented the air, as people went to balconies and in some cases out of their homes, following an appeal by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to thank healthcare and sanitation workers. Some large gatherings in residential areas defeated the curfew’s purpose.

At Dosti Imperia (Thane), residents were urged to participate with metal instruments and conches. They were encouraged to wear clothes showcasing colours of the Indian flag, told to sing ‘Mile Sur Mera Tumhara’ and shoot selfies and videos. “We came out with an elaborate plan to engage the community. When most of us are reeling under the fear of infection and are confined to our homes, it was a very good activity to get the community together,” said Parikshit Lad, a resident.

Prathamesh Residency (Andheri) saw many people clap and ring bells. “Today, doctors are our soldiers, working selflessly in hospitals. We got a golden opportunity to thank them, as a community. This was needed,” said a resident, Ruhi Kapoor. Some societies sang ‘Hum honge kamyaab’, while others chanted ‘Go Corona’. Some organised prayer meetings to ward of the ‘evil’.

Lokhandwala Complex (Andheri) wore its heart on its sleeve. Ten minutes before the appointed hour, all four crossroads of the complex erupted in a show of gratitude. “Residents of Lane 4 went to balconies and windows, and beat metal plates, rang puja bells and blew conch shells. The enthusiastic show of solidarity, in large part for Modi, lasted approximately 15 minutes,” said a resident.

At Vastu Tower, Vastu Park and Abrol Vastu buildings at Evershine Nagar, Malad (W), the beating of utensils commenced at 4.50pm with a resident. While many rooted for doctors, nurses and police personnel, a family dedicated it to their son-in-law in the armed forces. Within seconds, several people, including children, were at their windows, in several nearby buildings, chiming bells, blowing whistles and conches, drumming boxes, and banging ‘’thalis’. The noise drowned the claps.

Two Italians, whose country is under lockdown, joined residents by clapping from their balcony at a housing society in Vile Parle. Diana Linda, a designer, in the country for 18 years, said it was the duty of all citizens to thank health workers, at the forefront of our fight against the virus. “We can only help by staying at home during this crisis,” said Diana. She said though India may have lost on four crucial weeks, it is more proactive than European countries. It may be a little late, but a complete lockdown is the only way to deal with this, she added.

At some societies, residents came out in large numbers on terraces and on streets, defying the purpose of social distancing. Smriti Nagaraj, who lives in Andheri (E), said few teenagers got out on streets to take videos and adults joined them shortly after that. “Police told them to return home. After repeated requests, when they did not budge, police said they would take them in a van. They returned home. But later, when police saw people on the terrace, they began to go around in their vehicle, announcing, “Terrace se neeche utro aur ghar jaao”. A police van, which patrolled the area, announced imposition of section 144 and appealed to residents to stay indoors in the western suburbs.

Title: Domestic carriers rationalize services, run fewer flights
Content:
A board displays domestic flight status on Sunday and (below) passengers after their arrival at the city airpo... Read More

KOLKATA: Around 50% of domestic flights operated at city airport on Sunday as international flights stopped operation for a week. Domestic operators said even they were in the process of rationalizing their flights in the days ahead as Kolkata goes into a lockdown from Monday.

“There has been around 50% domestic operation today. While the flights arriving still had decent passengers, those departing had very few passengers,” said a senior official at the Kolkata airport.

While IndiGo said it ran 80 out of 115 operations on Sunday, other domestic carriers like Vistara and SpiceJet said that they ran less number of flights than usual.

“Flights from cities like Bangalore, Hyderabad and Delhi were near packed with passengers. Though passengers at departing flights to Metro cities were less, flights to regional sectors like Patna and Guwahati ran full,” said an IndiGo official.

Meanwhile, passengers, who arrived in Kolkata on the last international flight — an Emirates flight from Dubai , that touched down in Kolkata at 7am — claimed harassment and confusion as they were taken to a quarantine centre in New Town on Sunday morning. They were, however, allowed to go home even without any “real test”.

“We were checked with thermal scanners at the airport following which we were asked to go to a quarantine facility in New Town. I was mentally prepared to stay there for a few days as per the protocol. But at the quarantine centre, the doctor simply asked if I had fever or any other symptoms of novel coronavirus and then allowed me to go home and stay in home isolation. If this was the only test we had to undergo, why take us all the way to New Town and make us wait for five hours?” said Srabanti De, who works at a hotel in Dubai and lives in Bankura.

Midnapore resident Samiran Hazra said he had even told the doctors at the quarantine centre that for returning home, they will have to avail public transport and if it was at all safe in this situation. “The doctors just said that I don’t need to get admitted or undergo any further test and that I should just go home and stay in isolation and that I should wash my own clothes,” said Hazra, who works at a private firm in Oman.

Both of them were, however, handed over a small piece of paper where it was written that they needed to stay in home-isolation for 14 days. “An official at the quarantine centre told us that the paper is a proof that we have undergone necessary tests and that we can show the paper to the cops or neighbours if we face any trouble from them,” said De.

There was also trouble at the airport after passengers of a domestic airline complained they had a co-passenger with a “home quarantine” tag on his hand in their flight, who had returned from USA to Delhi and then took a flight to Kolkata. The passengers claimed the airline didn’t take any step and only after the flight reached Kolkata, the youth was sent to the quarantine facility by the state government’s health department screeners in Kolkata.

Meanwhile, passengers arriving at the airport on Sunday complained of extortion by taxi and even app-cab operators. A passenger, Vinay Daga, posted on Twitter saying: “I just took a ride from Kolkata airport. App-cab drivers at airport are extorting extra money from riders in the name of ‘janata curfew’ and shortage of vehicles. Riders shown fare of Rs 279 were asked to pay Rs 400, while some, who were shown fare of Rs 450, were finally told to shell out Rs 800 to board vehicles.” The airport’s pre paid taxi counter was also closed down by afternoon following shortage of vehicles.

Title: Prepare 1 lakh isolation beds, Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot instructs officials
Content: JAIPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot gave instructions to officials to ready one lakh emergency isolation beds in the state on Sunday. "Gave instructions to officials to ensure there is an identified arrangement of 1 lakh isolation beds in an emergency. Our utmost priority is to save lives of people. It should be ensured that there is no negligence at this time of crisis," he tweeted.At a meeting with the armed forces at his residence, Gehlot also said that the support of the Army is important in fighting the spread of coronavirus.“Coordination is required between the civil administration, central agencies, armed forces and paramilitary forces to take on the present challenge,” said Gehlot. The representatives of the Indian Army, Navy, BSF, CISF, railway police and CRPF called on Gehlot to discuss their role in combating the spread of coronavirus.The railway police offered a space enough to quarantine 1,300 persons and isolated 200 Covid-19 positive. Also, a body of home guards has assured the CM of deploying 13,000 home guards in the battle against the virus. Seeking civil society participation, Gehlot asked donors to give generously in strengthening the state against the virus.

Title: Coronavirus in Gujarat: Home quarantine violators turn headache for Vadodara
Content: VADODARA: The violation of home quarantine order seems to have become a major concern for the health officials as well as the administration battling the coronavirus pandemic. Sources pointed out that the extreme measures like moving police complaints against violators as well as roping in the police to check them had to be taken in wake of the situation.According to officials in both the Vadodara city and Vadodara rural health systems, it had come to light in multiple cases that those who were home quarantined were not following instructions. When officials pointed this out to persons advised isolation at home, it often came to light that they were taking things casually as they were not taking ill.“They do not seem to understand that a person can remain asymptomatic for one to two weeks and still transmit the disease. Health teams even explain this to them, but they do not seem to care,” said an official.Sources said that the VMC had to start issuing notices to home quarantined people to make it binding on them to stay home else they would face penal action. This was also made public, but even then some did not care and offences had to be registered.Now the city police too will be joining the local administrators for strict implementation of self-quarantine for those persons who have returned from abroad recently.Teams of healthy policemen have been formed at local police station-levels under the supervision of deputy commissioner of police (administration) Saroj Kumari.“Our police staff will be part of teams of doctors and district administration officials which will go to every household where persons have returned from foreign countries,” said police commissioner Anupam Singh Gahlaut.He added that this will help in ensuring that the guidelines on self-quarantine are strictly followed.A decision in this regard was taken at a meeting attended by Gahlaut, district collector Shalini Agrawal and municipal commissioner Nalin Upadhyay.

Title: Citizens show gratitude towards emergency services
Content: Nashik: Citizens of all age groups stepped out in their balconies on Sunday evening in show of solidarity towards those who are working endlessly amid coronavirus scare across the country.As soon as the sirens blew at 5 pm, people across the city were seen clapping to display their gratitude towards the healthcare workers, policemen and other essential service providers, including media professionals, during the time of crisis.Preeti Shrotriya, a teacher, said “All of us stepped into our balconies to show respect towards the selfless fighters. We clapped, blew conch and also rang the temple bell. We thank them from the bottom of our hearts.”“I salute the true warriors who are fighting to save our lives. Hats off to them,” said Ritu Mathur, another teacher of a city-based school.Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in his address to the nation on Thursday, had said that everyone must respect and appreciate the endless efforts of health workers in trying to contain the spread of coronavirus. He had asked the citizens to spare a few minutes and applaud the efforts of all those working for emergency/essential services across the country.Prerana Deshmukh, an entrepreneur, said “I applaud the efforts put in by the healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, ambulance and other hospital staff and hospital authorities, for being in the frontline to fight the deadly virus. I also thank the staff at airport and cab drivers for providing safe commute to the passengers putting their life at risk.”Amit Patil, senate member of the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU), said “The doctors across the country are working very hard. It makes us proud and gives us more energy to fight during adverse times.”Anil Bhalerao, a resident, said “These people are working without asking our religion, caste or any political background. This is an example of their selflessness as they put life above everything.”Nikhil Saindane, additional civil surgeon, district hospital, said that he is grateful to the citizens for their expression of gratitude. “It was really moving to receive appreciation from everyone. The whole fraternity has come together in this fight against coronavirus,” he said.

Title: Sec 144 barring assembly of more than 4 people put in place
Content: Nashik: Section 144 (1) (3) has been implemented across all the urban areas of Nashik district by the relevant authorities. The aim is to contain the spread of coronavirus . Barring the essential services, all establishments will remain closed.Police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil and collector Suraj Mandhare have issued orders that will be in force from 5 am of March 23 till March 31.The police commissioner’s orders will be enforced in Nashik city (the commissionerate area), while the collector’s orders will apply to the Malegaon Municipal Corporation, municipal councils and municipalities.“There were prohibitory orders in the city under various clauses of section 144 on certain issues. The fresh orders from 5 am on Monday will restrict people from loitering, standing at public places for no reason, moving around for non-emergency reasons etc.” the police commissioner said.According to district collector Suraj Mandhare, section 144 will have to be implemented rigorously because the assembly of people would only lead to transmission of the disease.However, essential goods would be available to the people easily and they need not panic, he assured“People will not be able to step out of their homes more than once in three days as isolation is the key. We are trying to figure out ways and means that can be deployed to ensure there is no transmission of the disease here,” the collector added. He assured that in case the movement and transportation of goods are stopped, the district has adequate supplies to go on for a long period.Superintendent of police Arti Singh said the police would deploy teams at every inroad to the district to check if there is a movement of people. “More than four people travelling in a group or even otherwise without valid reasons will be prohibited from entering the district,” Singh said.Corona checkpostsIn order to ensure that the district remains coronavirus-free, the district administration has called for ‘Corona Checkposts’ that will check the movement of the people from one place to another.Nashik is surrounded by Thane, Pune and Ahmednagar and Aurangabad districts, where confirmed Covid-19 cases have been reported. “We have asked all sub-divisional officers to prepare squads comprising a medico, a police guard and a person from another department who will monitor entry points of every taluka and screen the health of the persons entering the local areas without any valid reason,” the collector said.The health employee of the squad will check for any “quarantine stamped” person and anyone with symptoms. All the details like address, phone number etc. will be registered with the squads. “If the person is clean, he will be allowed to proceed. If there is any health problem, the person will be asked to visit the nearest health centre. All details will be registered with local taluka health officer,” the officer added.The ones who fail to adhere to the norms will be prosecuted, the collector warned.

Title: Virus takes toll on Ramkund rituals
Content: Nashik: Hindu religious rituals at the sacred Ramkund, on the banks of the Godavari river in Nashik city, have seen a big dip due to the Covid-19 outbreak.On Sunday, during the nationwide janata curfew , Ramkund did not see a single ritual being performed — an unprecedented event in the site’s history.The Nashik Purohit Sangh said only about 50 rituals are taking place along the river’s banks every day now.“A total of 350 priests, who are associated with the group, usually perform about 500 different types of rituals daily. But since the outbreak, that number has dropped drastically,” Satish Shukla, the president of the Purohit Sangh, told TOI.Priests said there has been a substantial impact on earnings.“We are now only performing rituals that are mandatory. For example, those after death,” said Shukla.“If there is a death in someone’s family, they have to immerse ashes in the river. That involves a puja. Another ritual is also performed 10 or 13 days after a person’s death. These are the only mandatory pujas that need to be done,” he added.The Purohit Sangh has also cancelled bookings by devotees from other states. “We do not want to put anyone’s life at risk. One person from Kolkata had booked time for a puja two months ago. But we had to cancel the booking. Those who stay in Nashik or nearby locations are the ones coming to perform mandatory or urgent rites,” Shulka said.Mumbai resident Vikas Tiwari, who was in the city on Saturday with family to perform the last rites of his father, said he had no other option but visit Ramkund. He returned after completion of the rituals.

Title: Three more test positive, take coronavirus infected to 28 in Rajasthan
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

JAIPUR/JODHPUR: Three more persons tested positive for Covid-19 in the state on Sunday. One each positive case was reported from the two curfew affected districts of Jhunjhunu and Bhilwara, while a third was reported from Jodhpur. A total of 28 persons have been diagnosed with Covid-19 so far in the state. However, three of them have cured of the disease.

In Bhilwara, one more paramedical staff tested positive for Covid-19, who worked in the same hospital where 12 other hospital staff had been diagnosed with the disease. In Jhunjhunu, one person, who returned from Dubai and tested positive for the disease.

A 39-year-old, Jodhpur resident, who travelled by a train from Delhi to Jaipur, was tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday. He had recently travelled to Turkey, from where he returned on March 18.

There are chances that he might have infected others who had travelled with him in the train.

Title: Covid-19 in Rajasthan: Mt Abu marks places of people in home quarantine
Content: JAIPUR: People returning from abroad to Mt Abu will now be marked on the back of their palm and will have a sticker stuck on their house for identification.Authorities in Mt Abu, the only hill station in Rajasthan, have started putting stickers in front of the houses of people in home quarantine. A stamp on the back of their palm have also been put for identification.Currently, 35 such houses have been identified in the town whose members have returned from different parts of the country and even abroad.There are people who have come to Mt Abu from New Delhi, Mumbai, Australia and South Africa. Since their arrival, all of them and their families have been put in quarantine for 14 days.Mt Abu SDM Ravindra Goswami said, “The stickers and seals will be useful in keeping people away from the people who have been quarantined. It doesn’t mean that residents have tested positive for coronavirus. It is just a precautionary measure. Residents of Mt Abu come from all across the country and these steps are necessary. The Apidemic Act gives the administration powers to take such preventive measure,” said Goswami.The seal reads, ‘Proud to Protect Rajasthan–Home Quarantine’, followed by the date. According to authorities, the people were cooperative.

Title: Janata curfew empties roads, markets without paralysing life
Content: Nashik: The bustling city of Nashik wore a deserted look all through Sunday as citizens observed the janata curfew , called by the Prime Minister in response to the coronavirus outbreak.Lakhs remained indoors as buses and autorickshaws stayed off the road. Trade bodies too called upon shops and businesses to down shutters.There was a noticeable quiet in the streets right from dawn on Sunday. “This is the first time I have seen empty streets in Nashik. Daily life is not paralysed as this is a voluntary curfew — one that is supported by the people,” said Kaushal Pardeshi, a resident of Cidco.Many managed to stock essentials at home. “We had a feeling there would be a likely extension of the curfew. Which is why we stocked up on essentials for the next few days,” said Numra Shaikh, a resident of Nashik Road.Raviwar Karanja, Panchavati, MG Road and the other prominent bylanes of the cities were empty. There were police personnel on patrol to ensure people remained indoors.“The old city area is a bustling marketplace. Thousands of people turn up here every day for shopping. This rare quiet made me step out of the house; I had to see it to believe it. I am going back home now,” said one resident of Raviwar Karanja.In the Deolali Cantonment area, the mood was similar. There were sounds many had not heard before. “I woke up this morning to birdsong. It was a surreal experience that was in sharp contrast to the daily cacophony from vehicular horns,” said Sushil Chavan, a resident of the Deolali cantonment who runs a shop in the area.Elsewhere, some citizens wrapped up wedding ceremonies late on Saturday night to avoid Sunday’s janata curfew. In Devgaon village of Trimbakeshwar taluka, Nashik district, Sachin Gohire and Sulabha Kamdi were to get married at 12.31pm on Sunday. But their ceremony was wrapped up around 3.30am, with just 10 guests attending.Commerce in the region too hit a pause. The two major industrial estates that make up the MIDC in the city — Satpur and Ambad — have over 3,500 small, medium and large units between them. All these businesses were shut on Sunday.“The owners of these industrial units had already informed their staff. Both Satpur and Ambad saw 100% participation in the janata curfew,” said Shashikant Jadhav, the president of the Nashik Industries and Manufacturers’ Association (NIMA).The Nashik Jewellers’ Association had already announced the shutting of shops from Friday through Monday. The Nashik Cloth Merchants’ Association too announced the closure of garment shops over the weekend. A total of 1,500 jewellery outlets and more than 2,000 cloth and garment shops have been shut for the past two to three days.Meanwhile, private airline TruJet cancelled its Nashik-Ahmedabad flight on Sunday.

Title: 63 of singer’s contacts test corona negative
Content:
Lucknow: As many as 63 persons who came in contact with Covid-19 positive Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor last week have been declared negative for the disease. Health teams listed 162 persons, including 35 from Kanpur, who came in touch with Kanika in these social gatherings. Swab samples of these persons are being collected and sent for testing at state designated labs. Of these, the reports of 63 have come so far.

Meanwhile, the search for people who attended different social gatherings with Kanika continued on Sunday. Sources in the health department said that more than 120-130 persons had been identified whose samples are to be collected.

The list includes Akbar Ahmed Dumpy at whose residence Kanika attended two parties, some of his relatives who came from New Delhi, Jhansi and Firozabad to attend the function. Health officials are also trying to contact Mumbai-based businessman , who had reportedly come to meet Kanika at the five-star hotel in the city where she stayed for three days.

Kanika, who travelled to India from London on March 9 and took a domestic flight to reach Lucknow on March 11 in alleged violation of the government of India’s self-quarantine order for those coming from abroad, tested positive to the infection on Friday. Between March 11 and 16, she attended several social gatherings besides visiting public places, thus putting everyone who came in contact at risk of the pandemic.

“Reports of as many as 20 samples in Lucknow and two of Congress leader Jitin Prasada and his wife Neha which were collected from Shahjahanpur have tested negative to the infection,” said chief medical officer, Lucknow Dr Narendra Agarwal adding that tests were being done in batches which takes time.

Kanika had also paid a visit to her relatives in Kanpur from samples of 35 persons were collected. “The report of 11 persons, mainly Kanika’s relatives, was found to be covid-19 negative,” CMO Kanpur Dr Ashok Kumar Shukla adding that the report was awaited.

Title: 70 trains passing through Nashik Road remain cancelled
Content: Nashik: All 56 trains originating from the Bhusawal division have been cancelled from March 23 till March 31 keeping in line with the decision taken by the railway ministry cancelling all trains across the country to contain the spread of Covid-19 While 56 trains originate from Bhusawal and travel in various direction including Mumbai, Solapur, Aurangabad, Surat, Nagpur and Khandwa, there are 70 train in each direction that halt at Nashik Road railway station on daily basis.“From Monday no passenger, mail or express train will pass through Nashik as all of them have been cancelled. The goods trains will continue to run. All tickets booked by the passengers will be cancelled and refunds will be initiated,” a railway official said.Since Sunday midnight, no train originated from its point of origin across the country and all trains in transit completed their journeys as they reached their destinations.“The last train going towards Bhusawal from Nashik Road Railway station left at 4.07 am following which all booking windows were closed. Thereafter canteens, fruit vendors and all others establishments on the platforms were closed,” Rakesh Kuthar, station manager of Nashik Road railway station, said.The station has a footfall of more than 45,000 and of them around 15,000 passengers travel with reserved tickets to and from Nashik. “As such there are daily bookings of around 7,500 outgoing passengers on an average and all these now stand cancelled,” the railway official said.The railway authorities have pointed out that people who have booked their tickets through the counters need not worry about their refunds as they will be processed till June 2020.The refund processing – usually has to be completed within 72 hours depending on the distance to be travelled by the train, but now the norms have been relaxed all together.“Since offices have now been closed till further notice, all the refunds can be processed till June and passengers need not rush to the office for the same. For those that were booked online, it will be settled within the regular period,” the official said.MSRTC shuts down servicesThe Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) has shut down its services across the state to control the spread of coronavirus . All buses have been parked at the respective depots. “The drivers and conductors who have come to Nashik will be staying in MSRTC arrangement till the services resume,” an MSRTC official said.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Nearly 50,000 students get stuck in Kota hostels
Content:
Stranded students being provided food at their hostels in Kota on Sunday

KOTA: Nearly 50,000 students from across the country, preparing for entrance exams in medical and engineering colleges in various institutes in Kota, are stuck in their hostels and PGs following lockdown of public transportation.

Several coaching institutes have come up with helpline and support staff to help the students. Although, many students are engaged in online tests for preparing for the NEET-UG and other engineering entrance exams.

While most of the students have left for their home towns, around 30-40% students are stuck in various hostels and PG since they could not get transportation to travel home due to the lockdown, Nitesh Sharma of Allen Career institute said.

Besides creating a support staff to help students staying in hostels, a round-the-clock helpline number has also been issued for the students to call if they need anything, so that they don’t have to step out and can focus on their upcoming exams, he added.

Title: Section 144 implemented in Chhota Udepur
Content:
Vadodara: The district collector of Chhota Udepur on Saturday implemented section 144 of criminal procedure code (CrPC) in the district banning gathering of more than four people.

District administration officials said that this has come in the wake of coronavirus pandemic scare so that the spread does not spread in the district. The tribal-dominated district has not reported any positive case so far.

However, since March 1, 23 people have been kept under quarantine as they had either returned from abroad or had come in contact with people who were tested positive.

“Of the 23 quarantined so far, restrictions have been lifted from 17 persons who did not show any symptoms of coronavirus for two weeks,” said district collector Sujal Mayatra. Of those quarantined, three persons in Sankheda are those who had come in touch with the 49-year-old man from Spain who had tested positive in Vadodara.

Title: Thunder at 5pm after daylong lull: Lucknow agog with taali, thaali and more
Content: LUCKNOW: The pin-drop silence that prevailed all day in a city of 35 lakh people was broken by resounding applause as the clock struck 5pm on Sunday. Thousands came out on their balconies and terraces or in the streets to clap and cheer for health and community workers working overtime to check the spread of the novel coronavirus infection.From high-rises to jhugghis, from bungalows to shanties and even at places of worship, the young and old expressed their gratitude to the heroes leading the fight against Covid-19. Residents drummed on utensils, blew conch shells, rang temple bells, played guitar and dhol, and burst firecrackers to mark the moment.“We thank health teams, emergency workers and those working in the essential services sector from the bottom of our heart. They are risking their lives to save ours,” said Ravindrapalli resident Mini Mukherjee as she drummed up support with a plate and spoon.In Indiranagar, people flaunted an assortment of traditional musical instruments — from dholak and majira to khartal and more. “We first blew a shankh (conch shell) to say we are ready to fight and win. We then paid a musical salute to the health heroes,” said Pankaj Dwivedi, a resident of Sector 11 whose daughter Nitya set the mood with her damru.Professor Poonam Tandon , a resident of Mahanagar, said the daylong silence allowed them to hear birds chirp. “And then, at 5 o’clock, it was an outburst of gratitude in the most unique of ways. We clapped, drummed on thaalis and cheered to congratulate our health and emergency workers,” she added.People in Hazratganj, Aliganj and Husainganj made a “goonj (echo)” by not only beating utensils, but also by bursting crackers and playing religious songs from their balconies. “It was our heartfelt tribute. We wanted to say thanks and show that we can get past this,” said Aliganj resident Avinash Chandra Bajpai Senior citizen Anil Kumar Singh of Vikasnagar said every resident of his society used a different instrument to make a medley. “The young struck the right chord with their guitars while the elderly clapped and drummed on utensils,” he said.Classical music teacher K Lahiri said it was like a cultural gala in his Kaiserbagh neighbourhood. “Some sang and others played instruments. It was an evening like no other.”

Title: Maharashtra: Deolali Camp police book 13 people for rioting
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Deolali Camp police have booked 13 people on the charges of unlawful assembly, rioting and violating the prohibitory orders issued under the Disaster Management Act.

The suspects are residents of Donwade in the Vinchur Dalvi area of the city.

Police said that a 61-year-old resident of Vinchur Dalvi lodged an FIR in this regard, adding that most of the suspects are the complainant’s relatives.

The complainant said that he and his relatives were at loggerheads over the distribution of their farm land. They also have an on-going case in the court. Meanwhile, the compliant had also registered another offence against his relatives for picking sand and murum from the joint land without his permission. The relatives of the complainant, therefore, felt offended with the latter.

On Saturday at around 12.30 pm, when the complainant was visiting a temple, one of his relatives stopped him and began arguing. According to the complainant, his relative alleged that the former was responsible for breaking his daughter’s proposed marriage.

After heckling and abusing the complainant over the issue, the relative took the complainant to other relatives and insisted that the issue be taken up at the village level. The villagers then heckled and abused the complainant.

Title: Nation says thanks with ‘taalis & thaalis’
Content:
मां... मां आप जैसी करोड़ों माताओं के आशीर्वाद से कोरोना वायरस से लड़ रहे डॉक्टर, नर्स, मेडिकल स्टाफ, पुलिसकर्मी,… https://t.co/CU6tUFWNI2 — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1584889236000

NEW DELHI: India’s gratitude to its foot soldiers in the fight against the novel coronavirus on Sunday found expression in a choreographed yet chaotic nationwide chorus of clapping, clanging of utensils and conch shells being blown as the “janata curfew” that had started 10 hours earlier entered its final lap.PM Narendra Modi tweeted his approval by tagging a video clip of his mother Heeraben beating a plate in her Gandhinagar house. “With the blessings of crores of mothers like you, the doctors, nurses, medical staff, police personnel, security personnel, sanitation workers and members of the media fighting coronavirus are encouraged,” he wrote.In some places, including Mumbai, Pune and Bengaluru, the goal of social distancing was quickly forgotten as groups of people spilled over from balconies and terraces to the streets to shout slogans and march with the Tricolour.While there was outrage on social media over the benefits of the 14-hour shutdown being negated, the country’s response to PM Modi’s appeal appeared to leave most people overwhelmed. “Take a bow, India,” said Pune-based equity researcher Aditya Kondawar. “Never thought would see such a sight. Clapping, banging utensils, shankh being played, temple bells ringing continuously. And what amazing energy!”Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath joined in the thanksgiving, as did his Haryana counterpart Manohar Lal Khattar, deputy CM Dushyant Chautala and their colleagues Anil Vij , Ranjit Chautala and Banwari Lal. A bevy of celebrities from showbiz to sport did the same. Perched on a wall, Bollywood actors and neighbours Akshay Kumar and Hrithik Roshan were spotted clanging utensils and clapping.Former India cricketer Virender Sehwag tweeted: “A big salute to all the warriors who are working tirelessly. May this pass soon and may there be peace, peace and peace. Om Shanti Shanti.”Wrestler Bajrang Punia posted a video showing several people clanging utensils. National men’s team coach Sjoerd Marjine posted a video of all the players clapping in tandem from different floors of their training centre in Bengaluru.Sachin Tendulkar urged people to continue to stay disciplined. “Today, India came together even while staying in our homes. While we are at home, there are many who are selflessly performing their duties. Thank you to each one of you for putting us before yourself. The discipline & commitment we showed today needs to continue,” he tweeted.Shooter Heena Sidhu shared a video shot from the balcony of her house, along with a tweet that read, “Here is the video from my balcony! What atmosphere!! Thank you everyone for fighting back, and our heartfelt appreciation to all those who are fighting this disease by putting their lives on the line.”Golfer Sharmila Nicollet was amazed “at the unity Indians showed”, but also dismayed to find “people stepping out in numbers after 5.05pm to celebrate the success of the janata curfew”.In UP’s Aligarh and Moradabad, a large number of anti-CAA protesters defied appeals from religious leaders, the police and the administration to continue their agitation. Moradabad police booked the protesters who had gathered at the Eidgah there.In Deoband, an anti-CAA protest scheduled for Sunday was called off following the intervention of religious and political outfits.The Indian Medical Association wrote to PM Modi, thanking him for motivating people to show their gratitude towards those working to contain the spread of Covid-19. “The IMA, on behalf of all its members, appreciates your gesture of motivating the public to show gratitude towards doctors, nurses and healthcare workers of the nation who are tirelessly risking their lives to contain the disease,” it said. “We promise not to let down the nation in this fight for survival along with the government.”

Title: Will Help Those Stuck In London, Says Councillor
Content:
Hyderabad: The 19 Indian students, most of them from the two Telugu states, who were staying put at the High Commission of India (HCI), London, and refusing to leave until they were flown back to the country, have left the premises of the commission on Sunday.

Local authorities were trying to convince them to leave the premises. The HCI had already made it clear that since the Indian government had announced that no flights would be operated to India till March 31, the students should go back to their accommodation.

Councillor Geetha Morla, a public representative from Shenley Church End, Milton Keyens, told TOI on telephone that she would be able to assist the students find accommodation if they find it difficult to go back to their universities. Geetha, who is the first-ever Telugu person in the UK to be elected as councillor, spoke to the students and also offered to help. “In fact, PM Boris Johnson has announced three-month of rent relief for all those who do not have jobs. The HCI and local government are ready to do everything to keep the students safe,” Geetha said.

As the students had been insisting that the Indian government operate a special flight to take them home, the lawmaker said since the situation in Rome was different, perhaps India chose to operate a flight from there as the place was severely affected. “In London, if one takes precautions and stays at home, there is safety,” she said. “They are safer and better looked after here than in India at this point of time,” she said.

A large number of Indian students had come to the High Commission office after they got to know that their flights were cancelled when they arrived in London. Since they too said they had no accommodation, the public representative said she assisted students in Leicester, Bournemouth, Eastham and Luton find a place to stay.

The students, who had stayed back at the HCI premises, fear they might not have a chance of getting tested for coronavirus. “The HCI and local council will help the local students in every possible manner. NHS is free in this country and helps anyone who requires help in relation to coronavirus. Tests are free of cost. Any student can contact me. I am happy to help students who require help in connecting with local people, if need be, personally calling and helping them,” she said. Geetha said she could be reached on email geethamorla@gmail.com or telephone: +447908589209.

Title: Good Samaritans supply items to self-isolated persons
Content:
A group of over 70 Barodians will start delivering milk and groceries to those who remain home quarantine

Vadodara: On Sunday evening people across the country applauded doctors, medical staff and all those involved in essential services. But there are also individuals in Sanskarinagri who are going the extra mile to help people who have self-quarantined themselves.

A group of over 70 Barodians will start delivering grocery and milk to all those who will remain inside their homes. “So far our group was delivering face masks and raising awareness among people to keep social distance. But in the coming days we will start delivery of essential items including medicines,” said Parth Purohit.

Purohit further said that the group, which consists of people from different walks of life, is also planning to launch a helpline.

“People in our group have showed readiness to give essential items. There are medical representatives, pharmacists and dentists among others who have agreed to deliver medicines and we are also planning to deliver vegetables and milk directly from the farmers,” Purohit added.

The group was also active during floods last year as they had distributed food packets and medicines to all those were in need.

Kushan Patel, a communications professional working in an engineering company, has also planned to help senior citizens. “I have stocked up some vegetables, oil and milk pouches which I will be delivering,” Patel said. He got the idea as several of his friends work in metro cities while their parents live in the Banyan City.

Like Purohit and Patel, Manish Vya, a photographer, met every cop on road and firemen on Sunday to serve ayurvedic decoction. “We prepared the decoction throughout the night with 15 to 20 natural herbs. We are giving one glass to police staff who are on roads and firemen so that they can have some immunity while working in public,” said Vyas, a resident of Wadi. By Sunday evening, he served at least 7,000 glasses of the decoction.

Title: Private labs await nod to collect samples from home, conduct Covid-19 tests
Content:
TimesView The private sector needs to be involved heavily in the fight against the disease. Government hospitals and diagnostic centres alone will not be able to take the huge load that experts say is more than likely.

KOLKATA: With the central government allowing NABL-accredited private laboratories to conduct confirmatory test on swab samples of Covid-19 suspects, at least eight private facilities in Kolkata are applying for registration with the ICMR . Once they get the approval, which is likely to come in the next couple of days, they will start taking samples.Once the ICMR allows private labs to collect samples from home, it could be a huge relief for many, especially those without symptoms or with mild symptoms, who are eager to avoid hospital isolation ahead of confirmation.
