But health experts said that collecting samples from home could pose logistic and safety challenges.“We will be registered with ICMR on Monday morning. We have trained our manpower and can start conducting tests to detect Covid-19 once we get the approval,” said Somnath Chatterjee, director Suraksha Diagnostics. Currently, ICMR-NICED and the IPGMER are testing Covid-19 samples across the state. Due to the rise in number of suspects and patients, the government has designated four more labs, including in Calcutta School of Tropical Medicine, North Bengal Medical College and Midnapore Medical College as testing centres. These labs are, however, yet to start taking samples.“With ICMR extending the category of people whose swab samples need to be tested, the rush for testing is going to be huge. It is impractical to restrict testing to just government labs,” said a health department official.According to guidelines so far, samples of only symptomatic suspects, especially those who flew back from the affected regions and symptomatic persons who had come in close contact with the confirmed case, were being examined. Now, the ICMR has extended this list to those, who are asymptomatic but had contact with a confirmed case, symptomatic healthcare providers, any patient admitted in hospital with respiratory illness. “Labs for PCR testing for virology with at least bio-safety level II can test Covid-19 tests. Since we have the facility, we are applying for ICMR registration,” said Bhaskar Narayan Chaudhury, microbiologist at Peerless Hospital. The city has at least eight labs in the private sector that confirms the specifications laid down by ICMR. Alok Roy, chairperson, Medical Superspecialty, also confirmed that they are writing to ICMR for the registration. The labs are allowed to use US FDA-approved kits while the government has capped the charges for each test at Rs 4,500. Those running these labs said that if the government provides the primer to conduct test, the charges could come down to nearly one fourth. Diagnostics chains like Suraksha are likely to come up with a helpline number where people can contact to get their samples collected from home for testing. Alternatively, the labs have been asked to create separate sample collection sites.“Ideally all labs should have an isolation facility for sample collection with dedicated manpower and proper personal protective equipment (PPE),” said Chaudhury. If any sample tests positive to Covid-19 at these labs, it will be double- checked by NIV Pune before coming to the conclusion.

Title: Nashik: Three booked for spreading coronavirus rumours
Content: NASHIK: City police have booked three people for spreading rumours about Covid-19 by displaying wrong messages through paintings on the river banks.According to police, the suspects have been booked under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) along with other sections of the Indian Penal Code, Disaster Management Act and Maharashtra Prevention of Defacement of Property Act.“The suspects had made a painting on a wall in Panchavati area that read that if one takes a bath in the waters of river Godavari, he or she will not be infected by coronavirus . Same thing was also circulated on the social media. Subsequently, we registered an offence regarding the same against the three persons,” a police official said.The city police also booked two bakery owners in the Dindori Naka area, three restaurant owners — two on Dindori Road, one in Market Yard, Panchavati area — and a vada pav centre owner on Dindori Road under Section 188 of the IPC.“Action is being taken under the Epidemic Prevention Act. Under this, establishments other than essential services have been instructed to remain closed in the city. To spread awareness about the same, we are also putting up the notices in various areas about the same,” a police officer said.Notices were also issued to a large number of establishments to prevent rush at their respective premises in view of the Epidemic Prevention Act being in force.

Title: Only emergency cases till March 31
Content: Nashik: The Nashik civil hospital will only take emergency surgery cases till March 31 to avoid overcrowding in its premises in view of coronavirus scare across the country.Additional civil surgeon Nikhil Saindane said, “A number of measures have been taken up by the hospital to avoid overcrowding. As part of this, all non-emergency surgeries which can be postponed to future dates have been deferred. The patients would be given medicines and would be informed about future appointments.”He said that nonetheless, other emergency cases, including accidents, maternal deliveries, surgeries related to it and other emergency cases, would be taken up. At least 15 to 20 maternal deliveries and surgeries are taking place at the civil hospital apart from 30 other surgeries.Saindane said that the aim is to do away with overcrowding at the 540-bed hospital where all the beds are occupied on a daily basis. The hospital also sees a rush of over 800 at its outer patient department (OPD).We have added additional counters at pharmacy and case paper counters. The security guards, too, have been instructed to ensure that those standing in queues at these counters maintain a distance of at least one meter between them.In addition, people approaching the hospital for various certificates such as fitness certificates or certificate of physical disability, which do not fall in the emergency category, have been postponed until March 31.Meanwhile, Saindane said that the work of maintaining cleanliness at the hospital is done all through the day to ensure that there is no scope of infection spreading from one person to another.

Title: Man booked for organizing function outside house
Content:
Vadodara: An offence was registered against a resident of Manjalpur, who organized a social function outside his house on Saturday evening, that was attended by nearly 60 people.

After Manjalpur police received information, they went to accused Harisinh Parmar’s residence near Darbar Chowkdi on Saturday evening and booked him for violating section 144 CrPC provisions.

Cops asked Parmar to close down the event and also dispersed guests present there.

According to police, Parmar had organized a get-together for his friends and relatives for the ‘shrimant’ ceremony of his daughter-in-law.

“However, he did not take permission from police department to hold the function outside his house and since section 144 of CrPC has been implemented in wake of coronavirus scare, the man has been booked for violating a public notification,” said a police official.

Title: Fear, panic, hope. A day spent indoors
Content: NEW DELHI/GURUGRAM: Cities are like sledgehammers. Every day they hit you hard with their sights, smells and sounds. The sights may not be the prettiest. The smells can be downright obnoxious and the sounds overwhelming. But that’s what gives a city its signature, its identity.But on Sunday during the nationwide “janta curfew”, the NCR morphed into another entity. Empty streets evoked a feeling of being someplace else. The odour lessened. And the cocktail of noise produced by cars, trains and people seemed to have disappeared overnight. This wasn’t the city one woke up to every day. “It was a different, almost surreal experience,” said marketing professional Madhur Mehrotra who lives in New Ashok Nagar.And it stayed that way till 9pm, barring a five minute interregnum at 5 pm when conchshells blared, bells rang, hands clapped and kitchen utensils became percussion instruments in a tribute that millions gave to those involved in the fight against the novel coronavirus.“The activity at 5 pm showed everyone is united in this fight against novel coronavirus. People know how serious the problem is and are determined to fight it,” said 72-year-old Manjeet Singh Seble.For Bali Nagar resident Aditya Vij, the day brought a pleasant surprise. “I haven’t felt such peace in years. I could hear birds and music in distance,” said the 47-year-old, who spent the day with his mother and sister.Many had a similar feeling in Gurugram. They spoke how, after a long time, they could hear the sounds of nature — the chirping of the birds and the rustling of the leaves — undistracted by the random everyday tumult that forms the aural soundtrack to everyday life. Even Noida sector-34 resident Dipti Jha saw a group of humming birds and heard them chatter as they flew from one corner to other in the park below.It was indeed a different weekend. Some took it as an opportunity to spend time with family without distractions, others spent the day in fear and panic. For GC Chatterjee, a retired central government employee who lives in Dilshad Garden, it felt like a lull before the storm. “I am a senior citizen, therefore more at risk. It is quite scary. I am feeling restless, trapped and this uneasy quiet is not helping me either. But hopefully it will help keep this deadly disease at bay or at least infect as few as possible,” he said. Chatterjee’s son stays in New Zealand and has been keeping tabs on his parents over the phone. “He is very worried about us,” the 69-year-old said.Confined to their homes different people found different ways to spend their day. Homemaker Jaghdhatri Mishra, who lives in Ghaziabad’s Kavi Nagar, said the lockdown actually added to her chores. “With no maid and no cook I started early. The day was spent preparing breakfast, cleaning floor and doing laundry. I have come to realize this could be the new normal for some days and there is nothing that can be done” she said.Kaushal Verma, a resident of Punjabi Bagh , said he spent his time playing the flute, a hobby he forsook a few years ago. “Generally on weekends there used to be pending work that kept me occupied. But now I am tension free. Of course the problem staring at us is much bigger and we need to address it from the front,” Verma added.For Shalini Khanna of Greater Kailash too, it was a day well spent. “My teenage kids and me began the day by sanitising the entire house. We did yoga and enjoyed a lavish breakfast. We even finished some long-pending chores such as re-arranging clothes in the cupboards and keeping the woollen blankets under the sun,” said Khanna, who works in a corporate house.“I usually don’t get to spend much time at home as I have a family business to take care of, but with the lockdown, I spent time with my children and read stories to them. The day just made me realise that I should spend more time with my kids. They are growing up, and after the situation improves, I will make it a point to spend every weekend with my wife and children,” said Kabir Singh, a resident of Karol Bagh.Arun Malik, a resident of Vasant Kunj, decided to watch his favourite series on Netflix with his family after lunch. “It was a lazy day as nobody could go out. So we got up late, and later watched television together. In the evening we even played board games, something we had not done for a long time. But no restaurant was open and the fact we couldn’t eat out was a dampener,” he said.However, not everyone had an option to stay at home. Mahinder, who works as a security guard at Vasant Vihar , said it was business as usual, the only exception being minimal footfall. “It is like a Bharat bandh. But we have to stand guard,” the 27-year-old said.

Title: 42 suspected patients sent to hospital in Warangal
Content:
Warangal: Around 42 suspected coronavirus (Covid-19) patients from Guntur, Hyderabad and Khammam were admitted to MGM Hospital in Warangal on Sunday.

According to the police, six from Guntur, 14 from Khammam and 20 from Hyderabad went on a tour to north india a few days ago and had booked trains tickets for their return. However, the prime minister announced ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday and all train services were cancelled. Later, they booked a bus to return to their hometown.

Local police stopped the bus in Adilabad on Sunday afternoon and found some of the passengers suffering from fever and cough. They immediately informed the hospital authorities and soon the district police station directed officials to stop all passengers arriving from from Nizamabad, Karimnagar and Warangal.

Meanwhile, panic spread in Warangal and Hanamkonda towns after rumours spread on social media that passengers from abroad have returned to the towns and were under quarantine.

Two cases were registered against social media posts based on directions of Warangal police commissioner V Ravinder. The police chief also cautioned the public to not create panic about Covid-19 else they will be sent to jail as per government orders.

Title: Big Jitters: No Medicines, Fuel Or Healthcare
Content:
Only a few women protested at the Clock Tower on Sunday

Lucknow: Looking for a medicine for his mother, Sanjay Pandey (25), a resident of Aashiana, had to visit 18 markets on Sunday. Finally, he found a medical store open near King George’s Medical University from where he bought the medicine.

Though essential services were exempted from ‘janata curfew’ many medical stores also remained closed besides petrol pumps and grocery stores, leading to inconvenience to many .

Rashmi Dubey (32) of Aliganj could not find any dairy shop or grocery store open to purchase milk for her 3-year-old son.

Manoj Singh (62) of Vrindavan Colony said, “My daughter and I had to go to Gonda to attend the funeral of a relative. As all petrol pumps were closed we had to drop the plan.” “I dragged my scooter for about 3km as it ran out of fuel while I was returning from hospital. No petrol pumps were open in my locality,” said Rajan Verma (25), a resident of Rajajipuram.

Verma had gone to Civil Hospital to meet his grandfather who is undergoing treatment there.

Anjani Pandey (46) of Telibagh said, “Since it was announced that medical stores will remain open, I went to buy insulin but could not find any medical store open. I had to go to SGPGI to get it.”

Nikita Agarwal (34) of Sarojininagar said her son suffered severe head injury while playing, but all private hospitals and clinics were closed. “We had to rush to community health centre for primary treatment,” she said.

S-I sent to lines for caning biker

A sub-inspector posted at Chowk police station was sent lines after a video showing him caning a motorcycle rider, who came out on the street despite ‘janata curfew’, went viral on Sunday. DCP, west, Arun Kumar Srivastava said: “Action was taken against S-I Prashant Kumar as there was no order to use force as it was a voluntary curfew.”

Title: NMC invites fresh request for proposal
Content:
DONE

SLUG: Collection of Construction & Demolition waste

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) bid to appoint a private agency to collect and transport construction and demolition waste failed to receive any response on two occasions.

Now, the civic body has invited a fresh Request for Proposal from private agencies to collect and recycle construction and demolition waste in the city.

“Earlier, we made two attempts but did not receive response. Now we have floated a request for proposal for the third time from private agencies for collection, transportation, processing and management of constructions and demolition waste in the city on design, build, operate, transfer (DBOR) basis along with onsite recycling facility,” an NMC official said.

The objective is to overcome the issue of construction and waste in the city. The forms will be made available online from March 26 onwards and the last day for submitting the bid is April 4.

Pre-bid meeting of private contractors, who will submit their request for proposals, will be held on April 7 and the bids will be opened on May 6.

Disposing debris from demolition and construction sites has become a major issue in the city. Taking the serious cognizance of this, the NMC came up with a solution to appoint a private agency that will collect and transport the construction and demolition waste.

The civic administration has no proper management or disposal system for the construction and demolition waste. As per the government guidelines, the NMC is planning to manage and recycle construction and demolition waste through private agency.

The civic will provide a land where to the contractor where construction and demolition waste would be recycled. The construction waste, which is not usable or can’t be recycled, will be sent to the dumping ground as identified by the municipal corporation.

The list of dumping grounds in all six divisions — Nashik East, Nashik West, Nashik Road, Satpur, Cidco and Panchavati — will be given the contractor for carrying out the work.

Title: From isolation to ovation
Content:
Ahmedabad: It would have been a mammoth task for any administration to keep lakhs of citizens at home. But Amdavadis responded to the Prime Minister’s call and observed a near-complete janata curfew on Sunday. The only people seen on the usually bustling city roads were police personnel, sanitation workers, those out on government work, or those headed to hospitals.

"I have been living in Ahmedabad for over two decades. But for the first time, I woke up to the calls of birds at 8am," said Ameya Joshipura, a resident of Anandnagar. "It was eerily silent. The general ambient noise of people working or chatting below my apartment was missing. The scene outside my window was straight out of an apocalyptic movie."

With milk distributors visiting homes earlier than scheduled, the day began early for many Amdavadis. Grocery stores remained closed in areas such as Satellite, Anandnagar, Prahladnagar, Vastrapur, and Bodakdev. Several medical stores that had remained open in the early hours shut in the afternoon.

"We received 120-odd crates of milk pouches. The entire stock was exhausted by 8.30am," said a milk booth manager in Vejalpur. "People purchased double the usual supply fearing a shortage. We had to turn a few down, asking them to inquire after 2pm." There was a rush for bread too. "One customer bought five packets of bread, which will expire in three days," said a milk parlour staffer on Judges Bungalow Road.

The usually active areas such as CG Road and SG Road were completely empty. Experts believe that with the majority of commercial establishments and offices ordered closed for the next three days, and with some providing the work-from-home option, the situation will not change drastically this week.

Many families took the voluntary isolation in their stride to celebrate family time. "We have seven family members and it’s generally not possible for us to catch up," said Darshan Dave, a resident of Vejalpur. "A family meal in the afternoon was followed by a card-games spree."

At 5pm, the community spirit brought residents of societies together. Harshad Patel, a social worker from Amraiwadi, said that many people made a noise to praise professionals and volunteers battling the COVID-19 pandemic. He said the gathering was unprecedented.

Khadia-type processions unacceptable, says CM

Chief minister Vijay Rupani termed a procession in Khadia on Sunday ‘unacceptable.’ Some residents of Khadia merged into a procession while coming out to pay tribute to those working in the time of COVID-19, at 5pm on Sunday. The procession took place when the city is in lockdown and CrPC Section 144 is in force. Specifically referring to the rally in Khadia, the CM remarked in a video message, "I am saying this with grief. Excess of enthusiasm is unacceptable. The very purpose of ‘janata curfew’ and lockdown of key cities gets defeated by such acts." He said, "It is a prolonged struggle against the pandemic and all our efforts to contain the virus will go in vain if people do not adhere to guidelines."

Title: NMC makes city swachh, lifts 575 tonne of garbage
Content: NASHIK: With most citizens staying indoors keeping in line with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s appeal to observe Janata curfew on Sunday, the civic administration cashed in on the opportunity and deployed all its resources to clear the black spots in the city.Officials from Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) said that the civic body has 1,900 sanitation workers, all of whom were pressed into service. They collected 575 tonne of garbage from the six divisions of the municipal corporation. On an average, 550 tonne of garbage is lifted daily from across the city.“Our major focus is on maintaining cleanliness and undertaking spraying activities across the city as part of the preventive measures to prevent the outbreak of coronavirus ,” said a civic official.“As it was Janta curfew on Sunday, we did not disturb the citizens. We cleared all the black spots that we found in open spaces and along the side of the roads. We lifted 575 tonne of garbage,” said the official.The civic administration also hired some tractors equipped with spraying machines from grape farmers to spray anti-germicide in the city.“We started spraying in Nashik West division on Friday. We deployed 34 tractors with spraying machines in all the six divisions of the municpial corporation on late Saturday night. The tractors finished spraying in all the divisions on early sunday morning,” said the official.He added that spraying activities had also been undertaken in Ramkund, Dutondya Maruti and the river bank of Godavari from Holkar bridge to Talkuteshwar.

Title: Teaching activity suspended at MS University till Mar 29
Content:
The stretch from Fatehgunj to Saffron Road wears an empty look during the curfew on Sunday

VADODARA: Based on a notification issued by the education department of Gujarat government, M S University issued fresh directives in connection to COVID-19 on Sunday.

Going by the directives, teaching, research and central assessment work on the university campus will remain suspended till March 29.

The university will, however, witness presence of nearly 50 % staff members.

“Deans of faculties, principals of constituent colleges, directors of institutions, head of departments, coordinators of cells and centres, section heads, press manager, in-charge director of physical education, auditorium in-charge, university librarian and all concerned except chief warden, medical officer, cleaning agency supervisor and vigilance officer have been advised to depute 50 % of their teaching and non-teaching staff from class two, three and four on rotational basis at concerned offices from Monday to March 29,” the circular issued by MSU’s officiating registrar K M Chudasama read.

“Appropriate and substantial steps of cleanliness of buildings have to be ensured and supervised regularly at faculties, colleges, institutions, departments, cells/centres, sections, press, pavilion, auditorium premises, library among others by deputing concerned staff on rotational basis,” it further mentioned.

The staff has also been asked to take steps of cleanliness and sanitization of hostels, guesthouses, health centre and to supervise them on regular basis.

“All the staff on duty are advised not to leave the concerned offices or places of work and remain standby for necessary duty as required by the administration,” the circular further mentioned.

Title: Hyderabad: Three held for provocative statements
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: Police arrested a councillor of Sangareddy municipality and two of his associates for making provocative statement over ‘ janta curfew ’ on Sunday. The accused are municipal councillor Mohammed Sami and his associates — Arafat and Baba Chawoos .

According to police, Sami asked people from a certain community to boycott ‘janta curfew’. “The video was uploaded by Sami on social media, following which a cases was registered. We arrested them on Sunday,” Sangareddy DSP, P Sridhar Reddy, said.

Case was registered under Sections 188, 124-a and 153-B of the IPC. Sami won the municipal polls as an independent candidate and later joined TRS.

Title: Hyderabad: Man selling masks at inflated price held
Content: HYDERABAD: A person, who was found selling disposal masks at an inflated price, was nabbed by the Taskforce sleuths on Sunday. The Taskforce officials, in a press note, said that O Ganesh was allegedly selling masks for Rs 20 instead of the government prescribed price of Rs 8.Ganesh and his brother have been into the business of manufacturing and selling masks. After conducting the raid, police seized 10,000 masks from his possession and Ganesh was handed over to Kulsumpura police. He was arrested under Section 420 (cheating) of the IPC and the Essential Commodities Act.

Title: New York turns into unknown city
Content:
From the 42nd floor balcony of my Manhattan residence, I get a clear view of the Hudson. New Jersey City on the other bank of the river is known as Little India for the number of Indian population living in the state. As New York , a city which never sleeps, gradually inches towards an absolute lockdown amid the novel coronavirus crisis forcing us New Yorkers to stay indoors, the glimpse of the New Jersey skyline reminds me of my country.

New York has always been a city on the move. From ordering a pizza at midnight or calling for a radio cab in the wee hours — New York has made me fall in love with its charm and energy, a feeling which provides me comfort and wraps me like a warm blanket on a chilly winter night.

But, as I sit in my room tonight, after taking a stroll in the sprawling and the most popular urban park of the city — the Central Park — I realize that New York has turned into an unknown city.

The oddity of the situation struck me hard during my visit to one of the supermarkets. I found that endless racks which are otherwise stacked with myriad varieties of necessary daily commodities are running dry. My other Bengali-speaking friends, too, met with a similar fate that made them trigger a panic button and predict an impending crisis.

On a dull Tuesday evening in Manhattan, as I entered a local store to pick up my daily dose of milk, I was astounded by the unusual sight of a crowded hall where buyers formed an endless queue, waiting patiently to make their way into the store. The very sight took me back to a packed Durga Ashtami evening at a popular south Kolkata pandal.

As I tried to connect with a friend over WhatsApp, who lives in a small town on the outskirts of Chicago , to share my story, she shared a similar experience. The mother of a five-year-old kid, who has been living with her techie husband at the address for the last two years, had faced a distressing time when she encountered empty counters without eggs, milk, water or even the easy-to-procure desserts.

Our days are now being reoriented as we learn to experiment cooking with the limited and available ingredients, video-chat with families, assure parents of our well being sitting in a country thousands of miles away from home.

I always remain glued on to Bengali news channels that keeps me updated about the information of my state. It is heartening to know our beloved ‘Didi’ has taken adequate precautions for the well-being of West Bengal. Everyday, I get concerned thinking if India will be able to survive the onslaught of the virus. More than the view of the New Jersey City skyline, I wish to see the future when India soars past the predicted difficult times ahead.

(The author, who lives in Manhattan/NYC, is a senior manager of a multinational company)

Title: 19 essential services to continue in city
Content:
Lucknow: Although the lockdown has been extended till March 25, you will be able to avail of banking, insurance, telecom and postal services, besides purchasing fruits, vegetables, milk, grocery items, medicines, fuel and LPG. These are among 19 essential services that will continue.

However, you will have to use your own vehicles to get them because all modes of public transport — including city buses, auto-rickshaws and e-rickshaws — will remain suspended. Continuance of app cab services has been left to the discretion of operators. The LMC and LDA offices will remain open.

Commissioner of police, Lucknow, Sujeet Pandey said elaborate arrangements had been made to check hoarding. The district administration has also formed 10 separate teams to ensure supply of essential commodities.

Helplines for the elderly and for those suffering from ailments requiring immediate medical attention have also been floated. “People can dial 112 for help,” said ADG (UP 112) Asim Arun.

Title: Life in a metro: Without home and means to fight the coronavirus
Content: NEW DELHI: How do you observe janata curfew if you don’t have a home? This was the plight faced by the homeless on Sunday as they didn’t know where to go to remain safe.Indulekha, her husband and five children were among those clustered under Nizamuddin flyover who didn’t have any masks or sanitisers to keep themselves safe. “We have been living on the streets for the past seven years, but have never felt so unsafe. We don’t have an option. The government should show concern about those who have no means to safeguard themselves,” said the woman who sells balloons to make a living. Sunday was a tough day for her as there was no one to buy balloons.“It’s a double whammy for us. While we live on the streets, now there is the fear of our catching the virus. There is little we can do to protect ourselves. I’m not afraid for myself but for my children who are as young as three, five and eight. I don’t know how to protect them,” said 37-year-old Sumanti Devi, who lives on the streets of Karol Bagh.Sumanti also feared for loss of livelihood. “We sell candy floss, but people have become wary of buying it. We feel so helpless. If not from the virus, we are going to die of starvation . I don’t have money to feed my family. My husband died after our third child was born,” she added.After living on the footpaths for years across Delhi and UP, 68-year-old Surinder Singh started sitting outside Bangla Sahib Gurdwara three months ago. “Had the virus only been in Delhi, I would have moved to another city. Where should I go? I’m old and don’t have a family. I’ve heard the virus affects the elderly the most. I’m scared that if I or someone around me catches it, I won’t recover. This thought has been giving me sleepless nights,” he said.There were many who had shifted to shelter homes fearing they would be more prone to the infection if they stayed outdoors. “I used to live on the streets with my family even during winter. But now we have shifted to a rain basera. We are trying to find a safe spot for ourselves,” said Kapil Kumar.The shelter homes, which otherwise wear a deserted look round the year, now have full occupancy.

Title: Maharashtra: Commute at a standstill to curb Covid-19
Content: PUNE: Citizens of Pune and the rest of the state will not be able to travel by local or state transport buses, or trains easily to any place until March 31.All trains, including mail, express and local, have been suspended by the Central Railway till the month-end to contain the spread of coronavirus.The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) authorities on Sunday said only 10% of the PMPML buses, between 100 and 150, would ply from Monday till March 31. PMPML’s traffic manager Anant Waghmare said the buses would be only for government officials.“The state government has clearly said citizens should remain indoors and work from home. Hence, the services of PMPML, during the said period, would only be for government employees who are bound to come to work and for authorities of the emergency services. The buses will not ply beyond the PMC and PCMC limits,” a PMPML official added.PMPML authorities said all pass centres would remain shut. “Night buses that ply from Pune station will stop as no trains are plying,” another official told TOI.All long-distance buses, including those from the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation , and private ones, plying between cities in the state or outside the state, have been cancelled, the authorities said.“All buses leaving from Pune to different cities in the state or plying to cities outside the state have been cancelled until March 31. Also, if at all any buses ply, it will be for emergencies which the district collector will decide,” Yamini Joshi, divisional controller of the MSRTC, Pune told TOI.Around 2,000 state transport buses ply each day from Pune to different places in the state and to other states like Goa.Prasanna Patwardhan, president of the bus and car operators confederation of India said no private buses from Pune will ply. He estimated the losses between Rs 35 and Rs 45 crore.“Our buses halted operations from Saturday. they will stay off the roads till March 31 as directed. There are around 800-900 private luxury and semi-luxury buses going from Pune to different districts and cities like Mumbai and Indore. We are looking at heavy losses running into crores of rupees,” Patwardhan, who is also an advisor at the Pune district luxury bus owners association, told TOI.Babasaheb Khadekar, the president of the association, said the losses are expected to touch Rs 4 to Rs 5 crore per bus.Officials at Pune rail division of the Central Railway told TOI that with all the trains cancelled they expect another wave of people at different stations, including Pune, coming to cancel their reserved tickets.“Those who have got tickets from the counters will get refunds. They must not panic and be assured that they will get their money back. A full refund of all cancelled train tickets can be availed till June 21,” Pune rail division’s public relations officer Manoj Jhawar told TOI.There was some worry despite these announcements. “My family of six was to travel to Kolkata by Duranto Express later this month. We cannot afford flight tickets. We don’t have any choice now,” a Baner citizen said.People travelling between Pune and Mumbai every day are particularly tense. “I work in a small company in Navi Mumbai and we are not working from home. I take the train every day. I cannot afford to go to Mumbai by cabs,” a middle-aged man told TOI.Dilip Datta, who has booked an ST ticket to Nashik said, “ ST officials must tell us about how we can get refunds.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Four kin of critical woman test positive, but not her mother, daughter
Content: PUNE: Four family members of the 41-year-old woman, who tested positive for the coronavirus infection and is currently on ventilator support at Bharati hospital, were also found infected with the contagion on Sunday. However, the tests of the woman’s 64-year-old mother and 21-year-old daughter , who live with her, turned negative.The four who tested positive are the woman’s 17-year-old son, her sister and brother-in-law and their daughter. They are residents of Katraj and Sinhagad road.The tally of positive coronavirus cases in Pune since March 9 has now reached 28 — 15 from areas in Pune city and 12 from neighbouring Pimpri Chinchwad. The jurisdiction of one case, of an IT engineer, remains uncertain.Seven of the 15 patients from Pune are residents of housing societies on Sinhagad road.The critical woman, who lives at Vadgaon Budruk on Sinhagad road, has no known history of foreign travel or any proximity to close contacts of people who have tested positive for the novel coronavirus. Her throat swab sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) to rule out swine flu (H1N1) turned out positive for coronavirus on March 20.A state health official said, “Surprisingly, the woman’s 64-year-old mother, despite living in the same house as her, tested negative for the infection. There are theories that older people are at greater risk of contracting the infection.”The official said the four family members who tested positive have been admitted to the Naidu hospital.“This is the second case in Pune where more than one member of a family has been found infected, the first instance being the other Sinhagad road family whose three members tested positive on March 9 and 10 after their return from Dubai. The three were also the first positive cases in Pune,” he said.The official said the four who tested positive on Sunday have flu-like symptoms. “None of them are exhibiting any severe symptoms. They have been put on anti-viral medications including oseltamivir which is used in the treatment of swine flu,” he said.The woman’s sister who tested positive is a nurse at Bharati hospital. “She had got her sister shifted from a private hospital on Sinhagad road to Bharati hospital on March 16 after she was diagnosed with viral pneumonia,” official said.The 44-year-old sister is a resident of Katraj. “She, her 47-year-old husband and 21-year-old daughter have been diagnosed with the contagion. Their close contacts are now being traced. The report of the 41-year-old woman’s husband and four other close contacts are awaited,” the official said.Meanwhile, the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) said its team of 244 health officials and volunteers have surveyed 3.37 lakh people in the township.Around 910 people who returned from abroad over the last month have been asked to maintain home-quarantine.

Title: Woman who died in SSG tests negative for coronavirus
Content: Vadodara: The 65-year-old woman, who died while being treated as a suspected COVID-19 patient in SSG Hospital on Sunday, has tested negative for Coronavirus . This was confirmed by state health commissioner Jaiprakash Shivhare. However, samples of a 50-year-old man who died later in the day, are awaited.Neither of the two had any travel history.According to hospital authorities, the woman who was already critical and admitted in the isolation ward died at around 10.30 pm on Saturday night. “The woman had no travel history and had co-morbid conditions including diabetes, hypertension, respiratory illness and obesity. She had shunted to two or three private hospitals, was already on ventilator before she was admitted at our hospital,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.The male patient was already admitted in the hospital but was shifted to the isolation ward because of new guidelines issued by the government that all those who have serious chest infections should also be treated as COVID-19 suspects.The female was a resident of Manjalpur area while the male hailed from Dabhoi, sources said. The Dabhoi native too did not have any foreign travel history nor had he travelled outside Vadodara in the recent past.By Sunday night, Vadodara city and district had three confirmed COVID-19 positive patient while reports of seven others, who are being treated as suspects, are awaited. Of the seven, six are currently admitted at SSG’s isolation ward which on Sunday screened 100 fresh individuals.“There are presently 442 individuals in Vadodara who are under quarantine,” said Dr Uday Tilawat, chief district health officer.The three positive cases which are undergoing treatment include a patient who has travel history of Spain and two others who have travel history of Sri Lanka.

Title: Defence schools in city close down, plan online classes
Content:
Secunderabad: With all defence-operated educational institutions in Secunderabad Cantonment and Golconda announcing closedown from Sunday, online classes have been planned for the new academic session starting April 1.

According to an official release, all gymnasiums, swimming pools, clubs, golf courses and function halls will also remain closed till April 15, while public gatherings and sporting events will be restricted.

Defence authorities have also suspended official meetings, seminars and conferences involving more than 10 members till April 15, and are looking at using video-conferencing as an option.

Based on orders issued by the ministry of defence, authorities have cancelled training courses as well as deferred posting of all ranks.

All personnel on leave have been instructed to extend their leave. tnn

Title: Time stops with family time, books & skygazing
Content:
bonding in the time of corona

Lucknow: Spending quality time with loved ones doesn’t leave room for complaints, said businesswoman Sneha Charan, one among the several lakh city residents who stayed home on Sunday as part of a nationwide social distancing exercise amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.

“As a working mother, I am always guilt-tripping because I don’t get enough time with my children. The ‘janata curfew’ helped me overcome a bit of that guilt. I spent the whole day with my two kids. We read books together and played games,” the 30-year-old Mahanagar resident said.

RK Shukla of Aashiana said he counted his blessings because his wife and son were with him and safe. “When children leave home and city for further studies, parents can’t stop worrying or missing them. My son Madhumesh is back home for now and we all played a game of carom. Guess what? I won!” Shukla said.

If family time topped the to-do list of citizens confined indoors, some cosied up to nature and recorded bird videos, some rustled up happy meals, some pored over books and many took up spring cleaning to fight off the virus.

Hindnagar resident Devendar Kaur cooked the favourite dishes of her two grandchildren before the whole gang sat down for a movie marathon. “We have got together after two years. To me, March 22 is not a curfew day, but one that brought my family closer,” said the 65-year-old woman.

Vasvi Verma of LDA Colony kept herself busy by making handmade cushions while Aashiana resident Urvi Singh painted a canvas for her Instagram handle. Doting father Sandeep Ahuja shared a video clip of his daughter reading a book with him. “My isolation looks like this,” he wrote in his post.

Designer Shraddha Singh uploaded a video of her verdant neighbourhood on Instagram with the caption: “Clear sky with birds chirping, twittering. Let’s all try our best to not to harm nature.”

Twitter user @PragatiSrivastava felt closer to nature. “Enjoying #JanataCurfew. Got chance to listen chirping of birds, rustling of leaves,” she wrote. Another user, @RaghavMishra, tweeted: “How I am beating boredom in the time of Janata Curfew? Gaming.”

Title: Janata curfew: Violators get taste of police medicine
Content:
Hyderabad: With the entire city shutting down for ‘ janata curfew ’ to contain the spread of Covid-19, those found loitering on the roads got a taste of police medicine. They were punished and told to hold placards with messages about coronavirus.

The law and order police and traffic personnel, who were deployed across the city, were seen stopping motorists and others to check their identity proofs to ensure they were not violating the curfew rule without a valid reason.

Speaking to TOI, Banjara Hills traffic inspector B Prasad Rao, who was manning the streets at KBR Junction, said, “We did not allow anyone to come out on to the streets without a valid reason. In case, someone was found outside without a valid reason, we made them hold placards to educate others about Covid-19 and the importance of staying indoors.”

At KBR Junction, Panjagutta Junction and Jubilee check post, the placards read, ‘Social distancing is social responsibility’, ‘Safe hands save from corona’, ‘Please support janata curfew’ and ‘Use your forearm when you cough or sneeze’.

At Panjagutta junction, the traffic police were seen giving counselling to motorists on why it was important to stay at home during the curfew period before they handed them over placards to create awareness.

“We allowed only essential travel. Those who came out for other reasons were counselled and then asked to create awareness on the infection. Except a few isolated cases, the curfew has been successful as the streets were mostly empty,” Panjagutta traffic inspector M Ravi said.

At some places, police themselves were holding placards to educate the people, while some were requesting them with folded hands to stay indoors. The law and order and traffic police personnel of all three commissionerates —Hyderabad, Rachakonda and Cyberabad — took steps to ensure that the ‘janata curfew’ was successful as the state recorded 22 Covid-19 positive cases so far.

The Begumpet traffic police stationed at Hyderabad Public School identified a person with symptoms of Covid-19 and sent him to Gandhi Hospital for further tests. The traffic police called 108 after they noticed the man was suffering from cold, cough and fever.

Title: MSRTC, BEST services only for essential services’staff
Content:
Mumbai: MSRTC will operate buses every five minutes from railway stations beyond Mumbai municipal limits to a changeover point in Mumbai. The points will be at Borivli station (E), Thane Khopat, and Vashi railway station for Western, Central and Harbour respectively. BEST will operate routes from those points to various locations in Mumbai. MSRTC and BEST operations will only transport persons engaged for essential services, said BEST general manager Surendrakumar Bagde.

BEST will also keep three buses at each of its 27 depots for exigencies. For assistance on BEST services, citizens engaged in essential duties can call toll free 1800227550 or 022-24146533.

The buses will come from Palghar/Virar to Borivli (E) station and Virar to Dadar via Western Express Highway and also from Vasai/Nallasopara to Borivli. Similarly, buses will come from Asangaon/Badlapur/Ambarnath to Thane (Khopat), Kalyan to Dadar, and Kalyan/Dombivli to Thane. On Harbour, there will be a special MSRTC bus from Panvel to Vashi railway station and another to Dadar.

Some BEST bus services: 504 Ltd, Vashi rly station to Wadala depot; 440 Ltd, Borivli station (E) to Wadala depot; C-12, Cadbury junction in Thane to Sion; 202 Ltd, Gorai depot to Mahim; 4 Ltd, Oshivara depot to Hutatma chowk; 33, Goregaon station to Pt Paluskar chowk; Corridor route, Dahisar bus station to Santacruz bus station; 718 Ltd, Dindoshi bus station to Bhayander station (E); 302, Sion to Mulund; 8 Ltd, Shivaji Nagar to Hutatma chowk; 25 Ltd, Sewree to Vihar Lake; 7 Ltd, Backbay to Vikhroli depot; 396 Ltd, Agarkar chowk to Mulund (W); 403 Ltd, Agarkar chowk to Mulund (E); 461 Ltd, Mulund to Gorai depot; 398 Ltd, Dindoshi bus station to Mulund bus station.

Title: Pune: Shortage of public conveyance leaves passengers stranded at station, airport
Content:
Passengers waiting for a train take shade beneath a tree outside Pune railway station

PUNE: Chennai resident Vinod Samant was a worried man on Sunday after his mother and wife landed at the city airport around 10.30am and were stranded in the absence of any transportation to Pradhikaran .

“After receiving their calls, I tried to help them but in vain. Both went to the cab pickup point, but there were no cabs. They waited at the airport till 1.30pm. They finally got an Uber cab around 1pm,” Vinod told TOI over the phone.

Samant’s family was not the only ones to face such a situation in the absence of public transport. Kondhwa resident Rohit Nagarkar, who had to go to the airport to catch a flight to Jodhpur, was also tensed. “I tried all options, including autorickshaws and cabs, right from 7am. My flight was at 11:30am. I finally had to hire an autorickshaw and its driver charged me Rs600,”he said.

Hinjewadi resident Vaibhav Dubey said, “A friend of mine booked a cab to the airport for Rs350. But once the driver came, she was told to pay Rs1,000. We cancelled the ride and booked another cab. The driver came and said that she had to Rs500 as ‘emergency service’, besides the usual fare. Her flight was around 11:35am and she had to accept it.”

Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) said there were some passengers in the morning at its Swargate depot. “All services of the MSRTC have been closed and no buses are plying. Still quite a few people came claiming that they had no idea about the suspension of services. They had come walking from Camp,” an official said.

A few trains operated from the railway station. “Till the afternoon hours, around 130 passengers reached the station by trains. Around 70 passengers took trains out of Pune. Long-distance trains from other cities which are already on they way are reaching and the passengers are finding it difficult to get a public transport,” a station official said.

Pune airport authorities said they have not got any information related to suspension of flights from Monday.

Title: Companies declare 3-day shutdown
Content:
VADODARA: Hundreds of engineering and chemical firms located in and around the city will come to a grinding halt for the next three days from Monday to March 25.

Industrial and business associations from the city have decided to keep their factories and offices shut following a meeting of representatives of the associations and Vadodara district collector Shalini Agrawal on Sunday.

The meeting was attended by office-bearers of Federation of Gujarat Industries (FGI), Vadodara Chambers of Commerce and Industries (VCCI), Ranoli GIDC Association, Makarpura GIDC Association, Savli GIDC Association, Waghodia GIDC Association, BITA and Exim Club. These GIDCs are home to medium and large scale engineering and chemical units that supply products locally and even export to different countries.

“After the meeting all the representatives agreed to remain shut to avoid risk to the life of thousands of workers who come to work on a daily basis,” said Agrawal.

“Wages of employees won’t be deducted during these days when the firms will observe a shutdown,” she said, adding that pharma companies, API, masks and other firms making essential products will continue to function as normal.

The state government on Saturday had announced lockdown in Vadodara, Ahmedabad, Surat and Rajkot in the wake of Coronavirus threat.

Members of some associations, however, said that such a shutdown will affect their targets for local supply as well as exports as it is March end. “Also, if small firms remain shut down for a longer time, they can’t afford to pay salaries to the employees. The government has to step in with some financial package,” said Nilesh Shukla, president of India SME forum, Gujarat chapter.

Title: Thanks to RISE, it’s no more a stigma. Period.
Content:
NGO RISE has undertaken initiatives to address sanitation issues for underprivileged girls and women

Nagpur: It was the idea of making people ‘period-friendly’ that changed the lives of thousands of young girls.

While working in different social avenues including education and welfare of orphaned kids, inmates of old-aged homes and the underprivileged, city-based NGO RISE (Rising Infinitely For Social Empowerment) came upon the fact that nearly 40-50% girls including daughters of commercial sex workers and those residing in slums were using pieces of cloth instead of sanitary pads during menstruation.

This was around one-and-a-half-years ago. Since then, the organization has installed over 75 vending machines and incinerators at Zilla Parishad schools , orphanages, hostels, slums and offices under its ‘My Health’ project. “We were the first ones in the state to initiate the movement of eliminating the stigma around periods by addressing the unaddressed sanitation issues,” says founder-president of the NGO Gargi Vairagare.

While the NGO would install sanitary pad vending machines to ensure cheap and fast access to pads for every girl, it soon realized that a major problem was disposal of sanitary waste. “To ensure scientific and safe disposal, we started setting-up incinerators,” says Vishal Joshi, outreach resource at the organization.

All the installations done by the group are followed by a session on menstrual hygiene by a panel of dedicated experts. Says Dr Jagdish Deshmukh, a doctor on panel, “We have our team of gynaecologist, nutritionist, psychologist and counsellor who inform women about usage of pads, their disposal and menstrual hygiene.”

After installing the machines, the organization also takes care of its maintenance. “Every month, our volunteers refill the sanitary napkins. We make sure the machines are being used effectively,” says Sumeet Jadhav, outreach resource.

RISE is at present working in districts of Nagpur, Wardha and Amravati. “Menstruation continues to be a taboo in our country. From making women talk about their periods and intimate hygiene issues, to making them switch to pads instead of cloth in many regions and further ensuring proper waste disposal was a challenging journey. But we have been successful in creating an impact for more than 10,000 girls and women,” says counsellor Roopa Kumar.

Apart from this, the NGO has been working on other significant projects too. Under its ‘Annapoorna’ project, the group has been ensuring nutritional diet for thousands of underprivileged including kids. We consult dieticians and doctors before providing the food. Our typical Annapoorna basket contains foodgrains, pulses, glucose biscuits, dates, fruits etc,” says outreach volunteer Prathamesh.

Another impactful project has been the ‘My Mains’ under which the group enables the underprivileged to raise their standard of living. “We do this by providing essentials required for day-to-day living. The kit includes shampoo, bathing soaps, washing soaps, toothpaste, toothbrush, hair oil, sanitary pads, undergarments etc. We first identify the people in need of these and then cater to them,” says Vairagare.

RISE, which is now aiming to expand its work across the country, was born in the city out of empathy. “I was at a restaurant in Bajaj Nagar when a young girl approached me. Showing her injuries, the girl said she had escaped from an orphanage and pleaded to be taken home. Not knowing what to do, I took her to the nearby police station and reported the matter. A few days later when I went to check on her, I couldn’t find her,” says Vairagare, for whom this incident became the initiation point of RISE.

Title: House burgled in Rajkot, valuables worth Rs 25L stolen
Content:
Rajkot: Burglars targeted a locked bungalow in Mawadigam locality of Rajkot and stole cash and jewellery worth Rs 25 lakh. Though the crime is suspected to have been committed between March 17 and Saturday, the complaint in this connection was lodged on Saturday.

The burgled bungalow belongs to Jitu Sorathia (40). Sorathia was away to Bhesan in Junagadh district when the crime was suspected to have taken place. Upon his return, Sorathia found Rs 12 lakh cash and gold jewellery worth Rs 13.20 lakh missing, following which he lodged the complaint.

“Sorathia has named Mahesh Bahadur and his wife Nirja Bahadur as prime suspects. While Nirja worked as a maid in Sorathia’s house, Mahesh used to come to wash Sorathia’s car,” said an official from Rajkot taluka police station.

Title: Pune: Corporators seek to string out budgetary allocations
Content: PUNE: Elected members of PMC, cutting across party lines, have cited the coronavirus situation while demanding an extension to the ongoing municipal budget session for fiscal 2019-20.The corporators tabled a proposal stating that budgetary allocations be extended for two months. The budgetary provisions would lapse after March 31 but the politicos want the use the allocations until May 31.The proposal is expected to be tabled on Tuesday before the standing committee . It states that access to PMC has been restricted for citizens in order to control the spread of the coronavirus. Moreover, a number of workers have left the city and markets and shops are shut.“The works for which the tenders and work orders have been issued before March 31, should go on. The civic administration should allow an extension to such projects,” said Avinash Bagwe , an elected member of the PMC.The civic administration claimed that the decision can be taken after getting a green signal from the civic standing committee and general body meeting. An approval from the state government would also be a must.

Title: Janta curfew: Hyderabad Cops stop delivery boys at signals, send them home
Content: Hyderabad: Even as the entire city came to a standstill due to ‘ janta curfew ’ on Sunday, delivery boys working for food delivery platforms and local eateries continued to serve customers across Hyderabad.“Despite the state government advising all eateries to remain closed on Sunday in accordance to central government directives, many delivery boys were seen on the roads with parcels to be delivered. We stopped many of them and asked them to return,” said a sub-inspector in Jubilee Hills.In an attempt to discourage them, cops made the delivery boys wait at the signals for a longer time so that they do not come back to deliver orders. However, most of them did not wear uniforms provided by their employer and were seen in plain clothes to avoid being caught.A pizza outlet located in Madhapur said that they are closed for dine-in, but were accepting online orders. “The outlet opened at 11am and within 15 minutes we received more than 18 orders,” said Rajesh, manager of the outlet. “The delivery boys are working voluntarily. We did not force them,” he added.Although the store claimed that they have permission to remain open, they were forced to close by afternoon.

Title: Hyderabad: 7 with quarantine stamps caught at Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station
Content:
Even though chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has urged everyone who have returned from foreign countries to ... Read More

HYDERABAD: Even though chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has urged everyone who have returned from foreign countries to stay under home quarantine, several people with stamps on their hands were caught by railway authorities and police officials roaming in public on Sunday.

Afzal Gunj police identified seven such people at Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station (MGBS). They arrived at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) from Dubai and reached the bus station on Sunday morning. While two of them are from Tamil Nadu and three from Karnataka, one of them is from Karimnagar while another from Nizamabad. They were admitted to Gandhi Hospital.

The state government had allowed all the international passengers, who were kept in quarantine rooms at RGIA, to go home and stay under quarantine after they assured to arrange for personal transport. However, they were caught trying to board buses and trains.

According to unconfirmed reports, a relative of a police official in Warangal was also found to be a suspected Covid-19 patient and sent to isolation ward.

In Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri district’s Bhongir station, police arrested a person with quarantine stamp travelling on an express train to Nagpur. His fellow passengers spotted the stamp and informed the railway authorities. The person informed the police that he returned from Sydney and explained that he was not tested positive.

A woman was reportedly identified by the police at Secunderabad railway station.

Meanwhile, Karimnagar police continue their investigation against the person they took into custody for giving shelter to people from Indonesia.

Title: Coronavirus scare: More companies move to work from home option
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Many companies have moved to work-from-home totally or are actively considering working remotely.

In recurring calls to industry representatives, government authorities have been telling companies to voluntarily comply with work-from-home arrangements.

“Members sought a day or two to comply. They have offered to shut down temporarily,” Prashant Girbane, director general, MCCIA, said.

Companies have decided to scale down operations. At least 4,000 small and micro supply industries associated with the Pimpri Chinchwad Small Scale Industries Association have said they will remain in shut-down mode till March 31.

“We have decided to rapidly scale down activities at Pune site to get to skeletal operations by end of Monday (March 23) and be ready for plant closure by end of Tuesday (March 24) if the situation warrants,” Tata Motors said in a statement.

TOI wrote to and followed-up with a dozen IT companies who had allowed only partial remote working option till Wednesday evening. None of the companies responded with the exact numbers working from home, but said they continue to watch the situation and weigh their options.

Companies like HSBC, Credit Suisse, Infosys have now told their employees to work from home. Infosys told its employees that it will enable remote connections from home by shifting desktops to the homes of staffers.

Harshvendra Soin, chief people officer at Tech Mahindra, said, “ We are arranging machines, if required, for our associates to facilitate work from home. We are taking all necessary preventive measures through sanitation, social distancing, etc.”

Automaker Mahindra and Mahindra said, “ We have decided to suspend the manufacturing operations at our Nagpur plant with immediate effect and Chakan (Pune) and Kandivali (Mumbai) from Monday night onwards”.

Title: Rajkot janata responds overwhelmingly to curfew call
Content: Rajkot: Rajkot janata responded wholeheartedly to the curfew call on Sunday along with the whole of Saurashtra region. While the city stopped to breathe easy from 7am onwards, except police vans and health officers, all the main roads wore a deserted look with people keeping themselves confined to their houses since early morning.Essential services like supply of milk, water continued as usual though milk supply was slightly disrupted as only a few dairys remained open in the morning to facilitate customers. The medical stores and emergency service were open. Local grocery traders had already forewarned customers to get their the stocks ready for Sunday.City bus service and auto rickshaws stayed off roads throughout the day. The main markets of the city including Dharmendra Road, Lakhajiraj Road, Kalavad Road, and Yagnik Road to kept shut.Racecourse too for once found no takers on Sunday except for the men in uniform who were there to ensure no morning walkers broke the curfew norms.In the eving , sharp at 5pm, the city reverberated with the sound of people cheering for the essential service providers, especially healthcare providers, with loud clapping, beating plates and ringing bells and conch cells. People cheered from their balconies, flats, houses and even terraces to thank those who are providing their services in this critical times to save the country from the menace of Coronavirus Meanwhile, Rajkot municipal corporation teams sprayed sterilised hypochlorous solution with the help of mini fire tenders in the affected areas of the city. According to district administration, nearly 600 doctors and 4,000 medical staff has been deputed to provide medical services to the people in this critical situation.Jamnagar and Bhavnagar city too remained closed along with rural areas of the Saurashtra region.Quote“We had requested all trade and industry to support the Janta curfew. Everybody has joined in this call in the city and all trade establishments remained shut on Sunday. Such a total shutdown is unprecedented and amazing to see people voluntarily taking part in the fight against the deadly virus.”-Parth Ganatra, VP, Rajkot Chamber of Commerce and Industry

Title: IMFL worth Rs 1.4L seized; 2 held
Content:
Rajkot: Two bootleggers were arrested with a total of 468 bottles of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 1.40 lakh at Aji Dam chowkadi in Rajkot on Sunday.

Police said the accused, identified as Mustaq Sama (21) and Arbaz Mumiya (20), were caught with an IMFL cache.

“We have also recovered an SUV and two motorcycles used in the crime from the accused. The accused said they had procured the liquor supply from one Rameez Seta, following which we booked him and launched a manhunt for him,” said V J Chawda, inspector with Aji Dam police station.

Title: Delhi: RWAs find fun ways to keep janta home
Content: NEW DELHI: Members of residents’ welfare associations mostly used social media to interact with, motivate and give information to people during janata curfew on Sunday. The idea was to keep them engaged and discourage them from coming out of their houses unnecessarily.MK Gupta, president of S-Block GK-I RWA, said that they had created groups to send information on Covid-19 to residents a long time ago.“We even placed sanitisers and soap at the gates. For the janata curfew, additional arrangements were made to dissuade people from coming out of their houses. We invited people to share activities being done by them at home on WhatsApp groups. We also sought their advice and suggestions on how to deal with the pandemic,” Gupta said.The RWA also restricted entry from a few gates in the colony. “The information of this change was also shared on WhatsApp,” said Gupta.KK Mittal, member of Federation of East of Kailash RWAs , said that besides messages, they also shared national and international news related to novel coronavirus with people. “Like other RWAs, we also kept all entry gates shut, except for one. However, guards were stationed at all gates to open them in case of emergency ,” he added.The RWAs even issued circulars restricting maids, servants and drivers from coming to work. Sulbha Gupta, president of Narmada Apartments RWA, said, “People themselves have given leave to their servants. We shared the idea of extending their leaves for another couple of days, but it was opposed by many residents. We are yet to decide on this.”

Title: Coronavirus in Karnataka: Six positive cases reported, highest in a day
Content:
Reprisentative Image

BENGALURU: Six more persons tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday in Karnataka, the highest ever on a single day, taking the total number of those declared infected in the state to 26. Three of the positive cases were from Bengaluru, while Chikkaballapura, Dharwad and Uttara Kannada districts reported one each.

The two in Dharwad and Uttara Kannada were the first positive cases in the district. In Dharwad, a 35-year-old man who had travelled to Dubai via Goa on March 11 tested positive, while a 64-year-old woman from Gauribidanur in Chikkaballapura district, who had travelled to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, was declared infected. On Saturday, her 31-year-old son, who had travelled with her to Mecca, had tested positive. Both are now being treated at a Bengaluru hospital.

The three Bengaluru positive patients were a 27-year-old man who returned from Germany on March 14, a 51-year-old man who came from London on March 13 and a 36-year-old woman, who had travelled from Switzerland on March 9.

A 22-year-old Bhatkal resident who arrived from Dubai on March 19 became Uttara Kananda district’s first Covid-19 patient. He was admitted to Wenlock Hospital in Mangaluru.

In all, 38 people were admitted at isolation facilities across the state on Sunday, including a dozen in Bengaluru. As on Sunday, 135 persons were in isolation facilities, while 28 suspected patients were discharged.

On Saturday, 1,406 international passengers from 11 flights were screened on landing at Kempegowda International Airport. Five of them were isolated and the rest were quarantined.

The government set up 50 home quarantine enforcement teams, each with an ambulance and comprising one Ayush doctor and a policeman with a wireless set. These teams will track people who are not following self-quarantine guidelines issued by the department. The teams will be alerted by Dial 100 or 104 helplines which get calls of home-quarantine people roaming around. The teams will take such individuals to the nearest police station and register a complaint before taking them to a mass quarantine centre.

The government said it will seek permission from Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and The National Institute of Virology (NIV) to allow government and private hospitals to test for Covid-19. Presently Karnataka has five testing laboratories.

New testing guidelines

The Directorate of Health and Family Welfare Services ordered all health workers complaining of fever, cough and difficulty in breathing to undergo testing.

The directorate’s new guidelines mandated all persons showing symptoms within 14 days of international travel, all symptomatic contacts of confirmed cases and all severe acute respiratory illness patients where other causes are ruled out to be tested.

Asymptomatic persons who have come in contact with a confirmed case should be tested once between day five and day 14 of coming in contact with the confirmed case. Direct and high-risk contact include those who live in the same household with a confirmed case and health workers who examined a confirmed case without adequate protection as per WHO recommendations.

Title: Telangana: CCMB, CDFD await kits for Covid-19 testing
Content: HYDERABAD: The Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB) and Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics (CDFD) are ready for Covid-19 testing, but they are still waiting to receive the testing kits from Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) or to be imported.On Saturday, the Centre had permitted the Telangana government to utilise the services of CCMB and CDFD for Covid-19 testing. The permission was given after a request by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao during the video conference with PM Narendra Modi on Friday.CCMB director Rakesh Mishra told TOI that they are making efforts to develop coronavirus testing kits. “Companies, including a few startups in CCMB lab, are working on it. We are hoping to achieve certain results in a couple of weeks.”Mishra said, “We haven’t got the kits yet and we have approached ICMR and other agencies concerned. We are also trying to import the kits, but there is a shortage going in. In CCMB, we have the capacity to conduct screening of 25,000 samples in two weeks. Every day we can do 1,000 tests. Other centres in Hyderabad may have a capacity of testing 100 each day. We will get clarity on availability of kits in a couple of days. We will also be validating which kits have to be used”Experts said if the community transmission happens on a large scale then there will be flood of samples and it would be difficult to handle the situation with the current number of kits available.Real-Time Reverse Transcriptase (RT)-PCR test is being conducted for coronavirus. Currently, Gandhi Hospital, Osmania General Hospital (OGH), Institute of Preventive Medicine, Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Hospital (MGM) in Warangal and Nizam’s Institute Of Medical Sciences (NIMS) have been given the nod to conduct Covid-19 test.A spokesperson from Telangana health ministry said, “Gandhi Hospital has been conducting the tests, while OGH has started conducting the tests recently. NIMS is working to establish the systems in a separate building, while Warangal MGM can’t conduct the tests immediately as it does not have the equipments. The state has decided to procure equipments from elsewhere as there is no import from China.”He said that CCMB has been training state staff for conducting tests. “We have trained staff of Gandhi Hospital, OGH and other institutes. Today, the first batch went out and tomorrow, the second batch is coming soon. We will be training around 25 lab experts,” said Mishra.CDFD director Debashish Mitra said, “We have initiated the process and we do have the required equipment. Once we are ready, we will need kits and will start conducting the tests.”

Title: It’s work as usual for water tankers
Content:
Hyderabad: Water tankers were the only vehicles seen on the deserted roads of Miyaput, Kondapur and Hi-Tec City areas on Sunday as many gated communities are heavily dependent on them for regular supply of water.

“There are 62 building in our enclave and to ensure sufficient water supply to every household we need at least 60 tankers every day,” said Sridhar Yalamachili, president of Gautami Enclave Resident Welfare Association in Kondapur. “We have installed meters for each house and charge as per usage,” he added.

Yalamachili further said that rainwater filters were installed in 2016, but they are useful only till February. “By end of February, groundwater dries up and we are dependent on tankers,” he said.

Meanwhile, due to ‘ janata curfew ’ many tanker drivers chose to remain at home. “Many drivers did not turn up for work on Sunday. So, those who were on duty had to cover more localities than usual,” said Krishna, a tanker driver, who was seen plying on Kondapur main road.

Title: 21 new ‘suspects’, total 52 in hosp quarantine
Content: Kolkata: Twenty-one patients were referred to ID Hospital in Beliaghata on Sunday. While 19 of them could be accommodated in the hospital, three others had to be referred to isolation wards in other hospitals.This was for the second time that the state nodal hospital for infectious diseases referred the patients to other hospitals. According to the state health department, 52 patients are in hospital isolation now and more than half of them are admitted to ID Hospital.The state also bolstered the ID Hospital’s frontline medical team by roping in Yogiraj Ray, an infectious diseases expert and an assistant professor at Calcutta School of Tropical Medicine.The developments coincided with the state’s first three Covid-19 positive patients — two youths, who had returned from the UK, and a girl, who had come back from Scotland, continued to respond well to the treatment. “Their condition is stable and they were given light diet. They did not complain of any complications or discomfort. Their conditions are being monitored closely,” said a senior official.Police on Sunday remained on their toes as complaints poured in that several foreign returnees had flouted home isolation norms. Nearly 1,312 people were advised home isolation on Sunday. The complaints about the norms being flouted came from different parts of the city—Dum Dum to Kasba to Tollygunge. Prosenjit Majumdar, a research scholar and a Garia resident, complained that he was being hounded by local club members and neighbours after he returned from the UK despite following all the norms.

Title: Curbs on tech sector’s working
Content:
Pune: Collector Naval Kishore Ram, late on Sunday, imposed stringent measures specifying closure and restrictions on the information and technology industries.

The orders issued specifies that while all IT companies should strictly follow the work from home policy, those IT companies that fall under essential services as specified by the district administration and cannot work from home should limit their staff to 20% of the employees otherwise working at the office location on a regular day. The collector has invoked section 2,3 and 4 of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897.

“We have classified essential services for the IT industries and manufacturing industries. The order has to be implemented,” Ram said. tnn

Title: Janata Curfew in Lucknow: Lucknow breathes easy in curfew, lowest March 22 AQI in 4 years
Content: LUCKNOW: Finally, some good news in this virus season. The city recorded its lowest pollution level since 2017 with the air quality index (AQI) staying well within the moderate bracket on ‘janta curfew’ Sunday.According to data released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the AQI in Lucknow was 118 compared to 120 on March 22 last year, 228 on the same day in 2018 and 302 in 2017.In fact, low traffic load, restricted market activities, closure of academic institutions and entertainment hubs, work-from-home orders and bar on construction projects — all meant to break the novel coronavirus transmission chain — have led to a significant drop in air pollution in the past 10 days.A TOI analysis of CPCB data of four years since 2017 suggests that the air quality between March 13 and 22 has been the best this year. Before March 13, the city witnessed a daily traffic burden of 21.9 lakh vehicles. That load gradually eased.

Title: Jail inmates to make 30,000 masks
Content: Rajkot: In a novel initiative , the inmates of Rajkot Central Jail have been given the task of preparing masks. The tailoring department of the jail has roped in 17 male and 10 female prisoners for this work considering the shortage of masks in the market. Jail authorities said in a statement on Sunday that the production cost of one mask is Rs 8 but they will be sold on no profit, no loss basis. They have got an order to prepare 30,000 masks by various government hospitals and civic bodies of Saurashtra . Of these, 6,000 masks have already been prepared.

Title: Hyderabad: Seafood exporters fear stock pile up
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: With exports to US, UK, China, and other eastern countries affected due to Covid-19, the seafood industry fears piling up of stocks.

“Around 25% of shrimp exports are to China and there is a significant fall in demand. This has already led to oversupply of shrimp in the Indian market,” a senior official from Seafood Exporters Association of India told TOI. “One of the major reasons for this is also because Chinese markets were not able to sell their inventory during the holidays and so they are not accepting new orders,” he added.

Seafood exporters in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh have informed that soorai (tuna), seerfish, kerai (yellow tuna), mayil (sailfish), cuttlefish, sardines, shrimp, silver, freshwater prawns, white leg shrimp, Tilapia, and black pomphret have seen a dipping demand in European markets which account for almost 20% of Indian exports.

“Most of the seafood consuming countries in the middle east and Europe like Italy, Spain, Greece, Portugal, and France have stopped imports and we are asked to stop sending shipments till the situation gets better,” an official from Usha Seafood in Kakinada told TOI.

Title: Uttarakhand: 3 made to do sit-ups for ‘violating Janata Curfew in Haldwani
Content:
Nainital: A video has surfaced from Haldwani area of Nainital district in which it is seen that three youths are being made to do sit-ups by policemen for allegedly violating the curfew .

NAINITAL:

In the video, which has been purportedly recorded at the Taj Chauraha in Haldwani on Sunday morning, some policemen can be seen ordering the three unidentified (two of them were wearing masks) to do sit-ups. The policemen later sent the youths home.

Speaking to TOI, an eyewitness said that the youths had violated the curfew by coming out in the market.

“While most of the markets remained closed, the three boys were roaming on the road. This is when the policemen ordered them to do some sit-ups and then asked them to go home,” the eyewitness said on condition of anonymity.

When asked about the video, Nainital senior superintendent of police (SSP) Sunil Kumar Meena said that though he has seen the video, police are yet not certain when and where it was shot. “It was a voluntary curfew and no forceful shutdown or compliance was ordered. Therefore, we are looking into the video to ascertain its veracity,” he said.

Meanwhile, in another video, some policemen can be seen seizing a scooter and stopping a biker for violating voluntary curfew. Defending the second video, the SSP said that the policemen had taken into custody the vehicle parked on the road and no challan has been issued to the man riding the bike as well. “As we have said, the curfew was not mandatory. Therefore, while most of the people chose to stay in their homes, some did come out. No fine has been issued to them either,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus in Gujarat: Government bans interstate private bus, taxi movement till March 31
Content: GANDHINAGAR: The state government, through a notification issued on Sunday, banned the movement of inter-state passenger vehicles like private buses and taxis until March 31.
