The notification will not be applicable to goods vehicles and personal use vehicles, along with vehicles used for maintaining essential supplies.The notification stated that inter-state transportation activity of public is one of the major factors for spread of coronavirus, and the state government finds it necessary to take immediate action to control passenger transportation between Gujarat and other states.Accordingly, private buses will not be permitted to operate between Gujarat and other states and they have been banned from interstate travel until March 31. The state-run GSRTC has already suspended its inter-state operations until March 31.The core committee formed to counter the Covid-19 pandemic, chaired by CM Vijay Rupani, met on Sunday and decided to include Gandhinagar in the list of cities which have been placed under lockdown until March 25. On Saturday, the state government had said that only essential services will be open in Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Rajkot and Surat until March 25.Supply of milk, vegetables, fruits, grocery, medical stores, clinics, hospitals and laboratories, along with health services will continue to function normally in these five major cities.In a significant decision, it was decided on Sunday to use the newly built 1,200-bed facility at the Civil Hospital in Ahmedabad, as ‘Infection Isolation Hospital’ for Covid-19 positive cases from Monday. Similarly, such ‘infection isolation hospitals’ will be made operational in Rajkot, Surat and Vadodara as well.In the meeting, it was also decided that to prevent transmission of Covid-19, 50% employees of the total staff of Class 2 to 4 in all government offices will attend their duties on rotational basis till March 29. However, this will not be applicable to employees and officials of local governing bodies who are connected with essential services and those who are directly involved in preventing spread of the virus.

Title: Non-essential services to remain closed in state
Content: Dehradun: As per orders issued by state health department on Sunday, lockdown of non-essential services in Uttarakhand would immediately come into effect and will remain in place till midnight of March 31.According to the orders signed by health secretary Nitesh Jha, the lockdown was being imposed to adopt strict social distancing and isolation measures to contain the spread of Covoid1-19, which is playing havoc in many countries of the world.The government order states, “Under the Uttarakhand Epidemic Disease Act Covid-19 regulation, 2020 for prevention and containment of coronavirus disease 2019, the government of Uttarakhand hereby notifies a lockdown of non-essential services in the state of Uttarakhand from 9 pm of March 22 till 11.59 pm on March 31, 2020.”The lockdown restricted public transport, including buses, autos, taxis, e-rickshaws, to run on streets. Vehicles that carry patients to hospitals and airports have been excluded from the lockdown but they would be required to show valid documents. Besides, all commercial establishments, offices, factories, workshops, godowns would remain closed.The government has ordered all domestic and foreign returnees in the hill state to remain under strict home quarantine up to the time period described by the heath authorities.“People are required to stay at home and step out only when required for basic services and follow social distancing,” said Jha.The government has excluded offices of DMs, SDMs, police and officers related to law and order and magisterial duties from the lockdown.Hospitals, medical stores, urban local bodies, fire, power, water, municipal bodies, telecom services, postal services and media would also be excluded from the lockdown.“Banks and ATMs, supply chain and related transportation, e-commerce delivery, including food and pharmaceuticals, grocery, milk, vegetable, fruits, warehouses and transportation of all these things related activities will be excluded from lockdown. Hospitals, drug stores, pharmaceuticals manufacturing and related transports would work as usual. Petrol pumps, LPG, oil and gas agencies will also remain open and so would be the manufacturing units engaged in production of essential commodities,” said the health secretary.The government has also allowed production and manufacturing units which require continuous process to function but they will have to take special permissions from district magistrates.As per the lockdown orders, interstate borders will remain closed except for the movement of vehicles related to essential commodities. People (more than five) will not be allowed to gather in public places, the order said.“Private organisations that support the essential services or are linked to them or which are linked to efforts for containment of Covid 19 will remain open but the respective DMs will judge if the organisation falls under that category or not,” stated the government order.It also ordered all district magistrates of the state, police and other related bodies to ensure compliance of the lockdown. Violation of the containment measures will be considered a punishable offence under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860), the order said.

Title: Resort staff quarantined after Dumpy’s son stayed there
Content:
Nainital: The Nainital district administration on Sunday quarantined the staff members of a resort owned by politician Amar Akbar Dumpy in Ramnagar area of Nainital district after his son stayed at the resort following his return from singer Kanika Kapoor’s party in Lucknow.

A team of police, district administration and health department officials visited the resort on Saturday evening and asked the staff not to leave the resort until they have tested negative for novel coronavirus.

Speaking with TOI, Ramnagar SHO Ravi Saini said that police have also informed their Delhi counterpart that Dumpy’s son, Azaan, has left Uttarakhand and is now in Delhi. “We along with officials from the administration and medical professionals had visited the resort on Saturday. The staff at the resort has been asked not to leave the premise nor is anyone from outside allowed to enter the resort till we are certain that no one is infected there,” Saini said.

Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor had arrived in Lucknow on March 11. Even though she had returned from London a few days back, she did not quarantine herself and went on with her social engagements. She was also present at a party that was attended by many, including former Rajasthan chief minister Vasundhara Raje. Azaan had also attended this party and then came back to Ramnagar.

Saini, meanwhile, added that the health department is yet to come up with the report of the staff. However, in the meantime, if Azaan tests negative, the staff will be allowed to leave the quarantine. “We have been informed that Azaan came from Lucknow and stayed in the resort for a night. He is suspected to have interacted others. Therefore, it was necessary that the entire staff should be screened,” Saini said.

Title: CMO wants Kanika FIR rectified, admits ‘errors’
Content:
Kanika Kapoor

Lucknow: Admitting lapses in the fact-finding on the basis of which FIR was lodged against Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor, the chief medical officer (CMO), Lucknow, Dr Narendra Agarwal, on Saturday wrote to the district magistrate and commissioner of police, requesting them to make ‘corrections’ in it.

The complaint filed by the CMO at Sarojininagar police station on Friday night had stated that Kanika had tested positive on her arrival at Amausi airport on ‘March 14’ and was asked to isolate herself for 14 days, but she continued socialising, which amounts to disobeying government order.

In his letter on Saturday night, the CMO clarified that Kanika had been advised 14-day self-isolation as per government guidelines when she landed at Mumbai airport from UK, and not at Amausi.

Kanika came to Lucknow on March 11 and kept moving around, meeting people, visiting places and attending parties. She also stayed in a five star hotel for two days during this period, the CMO says in the letter while requesting the administration to make corrections and take required legal action against the singer.

The complaint on the basis of which the FIR was lodged had several inaccuracies. It said Kanika had tested positive at Amausi airport, but the fact is that there is no Covid-19 confirmatory test which can be done at the airport. Only thermal screening is being done at airports, which only detects body temperature.

In Kanika’s case, she came to Amausi on a domestic flight while thermal scanning was being done only for international arrivals. Further, she arrived in Lucknow on March 11, but the complaint said she came on March 14 while her address was mentioned as ‘unknown’.

To a query, CMO said it was ‘clerical mistake’ and refused to comment further.

Title: Delhi: As vehicles go off road, PM2.5 comes down by nearly four times
Content: NEW DELHI: With almost no industrial units functioning in the capital and barely any vehicles on the road during the janata curfew on Sunday, pollutants, particularly NO2 and PM 2.5, showed a sharp decline by the evening. Delhi’s hourly PM 2.5 concentration halved in just 12 hours from 126 micrograms per cubic metre at 1 am — double the safe standard of 60 — to 57 micrograms per cubic metre by 1 pm, according to Central Pollution Control Board data. Four hours later, the reading had dropped to 33 micrograms per cubic metre.Track the pollution level in your cityNO2 concentration, primarily emitted by motor vehicles, showed a drop of 41% between 8am and 8pm against Saturday’s readings for the same period, as per data analysed by the Centre for Science and Environment. The analyses also determined a PM2.5 slide of 21%.“We are yet to analyse the 24-hour change, but the 12-hour average from 8am to 8pm on Saturday and Sunday showed a dip in both PM2.5 and NO2,” confirmed Anumita Roy Chowdhury, executive director, research and advocacy, CSE.CPCB’s data, however, showed an increase in pollution levels again from 6 pm onwards on Sunday, which experts attributed to an increase in emissions, largely the use of firecrackers. CPCB’s 24-hour daily Air Quality Index (AQI), released at 4 pm on Sunday, showed the city’s air in the ‘moderate’ category with a reading of 191. Officials said the impact of the reduced pollution resulting from the janata curfew was likely to reflect in Monday’s AQI.Chowdhury said the impact of a continued lockdown could be ascertained over the next few days. “When the city is in a lockdown, we can ascertain how a reduction in vehicle numbers and other sources of pollution impact Delhi’s air and by how much,” she added.The System of Air Quality and Forecasting and Research, a forecasting body under the Union ministry of earth sciences, said PM2.5 concentration had been showing a declining trend in Delhi over the past few weeks. SAFAR analysed data from March 5 and found a reduction in PM2.5 concentration in 2020 compared with the same period in 2018 and 2019. The stations that have recorded a drop in PM2.5 pollutant levels from March 5 onwards included Delhi University, Pusa, Palam and Lodhi Road, along with Gurgaon in NCR.Despite these readings, SAFAR forecast air quality to remain in the ‘moderate’ range over the next 24 hours.

Title: Uttarakhand announces lockdown till March 31
Content: DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Sunday announced that the state government has decided to enforce lockdown in the hill state till March 31 to contain possible spread of novel coronavirus . The decision was taken in an emergency meeting chaired by the CM and attended by chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, DGP Anil Raturi and health secretary Nitesh Jha.“In order to win this war against coronavirus, the state government has decided to enforce lockdown until March 31. The decision was taken after observing the positive response of people during today’s Janata Curfew,” said CM Rawat.During the lockdown, all inter-state and local transport services will remain suspended to curb the movement of people, the CM said.He added, “Essential services such as health, food supplies etc have been kept out of the ambit of the lockdown to ensure minimum inconvenience to the public.”The CM added that district magistrates have been asked to take decisions as per the situation in their area. He added that unless it was absolutely essential, people should avoid travelling anywhere and not leave their village, town or colony.The CM also announced that a grant of Rs 1,000 will be given to each labourer registered with the government to help those working as daily wagers meet the crisis.

Title: Victoria’s Covid-19 makeover a logistical challenge
Content:
Bengaluru: Chief minister BS Yediyurappa, on Sunday, announced Victoria Hospital will be a dedicated Covid-19 facility, but it might take some time to implement the decision given the logistics involved. Three high-level meetings were held during the day to thrash out the details.

Yediyurappa, however, did not refer to his government’s earlier decision to convert an unused BBMP hospital on Broadway Road, Shivajinagar, into a dedicated Covid-19 facility. However, the Broadway Hospital has to set up from scratch and that too will take time.

Yediyurappa said the dedicated facility at Victoria Hospital and all its annexes will have 1,700 beds. The chief minister said the government is set to extend support to shift all in-patients who are presently undergoing treatment to other facilities. But doctors and medical education department officials, under whose jurisdiction the hospital falls, said that they will not shift patients who are critical and will continue to treat them, but they will not admit fresh patients.

However, Victoria Hospital is the nerve-centre of public healthcare in Karnataka. The campus also houses a trauma care centre, PMSSY superspecialty hospital, Institute of Nephro Urology, Minto Eye Hospital and Vani Vilas Hospital dedicated to maternity and pediatric issues. The hospital’s 50-bed burns ward is one of its kind in the state getting up to a dozen patients every day.

Jawaid Akhtar, additional chief secretary, health and family welfare department, told TOI a plan has been drawn up to establish exclusive hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients and they will be rolled out. “A detailed action plan for Victoria Hospital is being prepared and will reveal it in one or two days,” Akhtar said.

Dr PG Girish, director of medical education and special officer, PMSSY hospital, said, “Victoria Hospital henceforth will admit only emergency patients who are in need of critical care. Other patients will be diverted to other hospitals where facilities are available. The intensive care unit and burns ward will continue operations as usual.”

He said that for a week now they have been reducing the number of intakes at Victoria Hospital by diverting patients to other facilities.

“In some cases, if required, we have also considered shifting patients to private hospitals for treatment. The government will pay for the treatment,” said deputy chief minister CN Ashwath Narayan.

Title: Followers catch up on church service streaming live on various platforms
Content:
Aurangabad: Following the strict protocol of janata curfew, many churches in the Marathwada region streamed their Sunday service live on various social media platforms.

Amid coronavirus outbreak, the churches had announced that they would not be having the usual Sunday service.

The Makasare family in Chikalthana, who regularly go to church in the morning, were disappointed. According to 65-year-old Prakash Makasare, the grandfather of the family, this is the first instance in his lifetime that all the churches are closed.

“Sunday service and fellowship is very special to us and we never miss it,” he said.

However, his disappointment went away after his grandchildren told him that their church will be streaming the service live on Facebook. The family joined in and heard the sermon live.

The district and civic administration had earlier given orders to cancel any gatherings until March 31, as a preventive step as India entered the third phase of the Covid-19 outbreak.

Chandrakant Mhaske, a pastor at Satara Nazarene church, shared a message from the book of Isaiah during the live streaming.

“Just like the times of the Bible, it is needed that we stay indoors and look to God. This is the time to introspect and strengthen your relationship with Jesus,” he said.

Prabhakar Mhaske’s family in Cidco N-6 observed the janata curfew but tuned in to the live Sunday mass on Youtube.

Sharad Timothy, a pastor at World Mission church, appealed to his congregation to co-operate with the government in containing the spread. He encouraged people to live right so that their prayers can be heard and the land can be healed.

Title: 3,000 in city under home quarantine
Content:
Rajkot: The Rajkot Municipal Corporation traced 1 ,154 people who have returned from foreign tours to the city. Of them, 1,136 people haven’t shown any symptoms of the virus, said Rajkot municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal while addressing media persons on Sunday.

All the reports of Rajkot sent for tests have turned out to be negative, while one more report sent on Sunday is pending, he said.

Total 476 people have successfully completed their quarantine period and 668 are still under home quarantine with their families. According to the civic body, there are 3,000 people under home quarantine in Rajkot city.

“They are not infected but are potential carriers. Hence, they are under observation. If we will find any symptoms in these people they will be shifted in the isolation wards,” Agrawal said.

RMC formed 21 teams to keep watch on the home quarantine people and police too have joined forces with the civic body teams. Agrawal also said that if anybody is found violating the home quarantine rules, FIR will be registered against them under IPC section 188. Such flouters will be forcibly shifted in government quarantine facility or isolation ward in the civil hospital, he added.

Title: Retired army man murdered
Content:
Rajkot: A retired army man was stabbed to death in Madhapar village of Bhuj taluka in Kutch district on Saturday evening. Police said the body of the deceased, identified as Musar Gorkha (60), was found lying in a pool of blood in his house by his nephew Suraj Gorkha (19) who had come to visit Musar’s house from Gandhidham on Saturday evening.

According to the police, Suraj called up his father Shaktiram Gorkha who informed the cops. As there was no valuable missing from the house, it did not appear to be the case of a robbery.

“Musar’s postmortem report indicates that he was stabbed four times in his stomach by unidentified assailants whose numbers could not be ascertained. We are probing the call details of Musar to find out to whom he had spoken last. We are also investigating whether he had any enmity with anyone,” said an official from Bhuj B division police station.

Title: Sanskarinagari gives thumbs up to shutdown
Content: VADODARA: If the yawning stretch at the otherwise bustling Mandvi Road is any example of how Banyan City responded to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call for janata curfew on Sunday, the answer is wholeheartedly.Not only Mandvi Road, but all other roads in the city, including the narrow ones in the walled city areas that usually come alive with maddening traffic at the crack of dawn on normal days wore a deserted look on the curfew day.Every shop in the city, except medical stores, remained closed the entire day making the curfew a total success. “All the roads were completely empty as people voluntarily stayed indoors. The police, though, was patrolling in different areas till late in the night. No untoward incident was reported from any area,” said Anupam Singh Gahlaut, city police commissioner.The bustling railway station too remained silent all day while no auto-rickshaws or public transport buses too plied on the roads. Residents of western parts of the city including Alkapuri, O P Road, Bhayli-Vasna Road, Gotri and Akota confined themselves to their homes. “The janata curfew was announced for the betterment of citizens and ensure that Coronavirus doesn’t spread further. So we all decided to stay indoors on Sunday,” said Devdutt Pandya , a resident of Manjalpur.Barodians, however, flocked to their respective balconies and terraces sharp at 5 pm to express gratitude towards every fellow Indian who is fighting against the deadly virus, clapping and clanging steel vessels to thank the doctors, nurses, medical staff and every fellow citizen risking their individual lives to stop the pandemic.Some blew conch cells, some even burst crackers for about 10 minutes following which the surroundings became calm again.Youths, and even entire families came out on bikes and cars to express solidarity leading to mass vehicular movement on Mandvi Road and other walled city areas forcing cops to put up barricades at Laheripura Gate. While the locals took internal roads to escape barricades, cops at Sayajigunj stopped bikers and requested them to go back home.“I watched movies, prepared for an academic conference and made meals for myself. But I did not miss clapping for the medical staff from my balcony in the evening,” said Varun Vyas , a student living in Sama.In Panchmahal, most parts of Godhra remained closed. But at Polan Bazaar, citizens moved around in groups without any concern about the curfew or virus infection. On Sunday, a video of Dahod police beating up two bikers, who came out during janata curfew, with lathis near Yaadgar Chowk went viral.

Title: Pune: IT engineer tests positive for coronavirus
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: An employee of an IT firm at Hinjewadi Phase 2 has tested positive for the novel coronavirus.

“All our buildings on campus are in the process of being fumigated and sanitized — the process will take 48 hours. The contacts of the employee are being traced for the 14-day quarantine process,” the company said.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: Suspected patient in the first row, Captain disembarks via cockpit
Content: NEW DELHI: A suspected corona patient being seated on the first row of an aircraft led to such a scare that all the passengers disembarked from the rear exit and the pilots via the cockpit. This happened on AirAsia India flight I5-732 from Pune to Delhi on March 20. The passengers were subsequently screened and tested negative.An AirAsia India spokesperson said: “There was a case reported of suspected Covid-19 passengers aboard I5-732, Pune to New Delhi on March 20. The passengers were subsequently screened and tested negative. As a safety measure after landing, the aircraft was parked at a remote bay and suspected passengers disembarked from the front door. All the others, escorted by the crew, disembarked from the rear door.”The spokesperson added that the crew in the cockpit self-quarantined till the cabin environment near the primary exit was ascertained to be safe. The captain elected to disembark from the secondary exit using a secure trestle, given the close proximity of the seats from the cockpit. The aircraft was fumigated and a thorough disinfection and deep cleaning was carried out, he said

Title: Goa: Away from churches, Christians keep the faith with online Mass
Content: PANAJI: In an unprecedented scenario, lakhs of Christians across the state stayed away from Sunday Mass services as churches remain closed in view of Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call for a nationwide curfew.There are 172 parishes in the state.Devotees who would otherwise never miss the obligatory Sunday Mass, heeded the government and the archdiocese of Goa and Daman to help stop community transmission of coronavirus The experience of using technology to participate in and celebrate Sunday Mass was a novel one for both, the faithful and the clergy, who used everything from television, YouTube, Facebook and WhatsApp.However, nothing could stop some determined senior citizens habituated to heading to church for their dose of spiritual nourishment.Maria Vas from Margao managed to work her way around the Janata Curfew . She followed her two-decade-old daily routine of waking up at 5am and proceeded to church in her Sunday attire. “There were only three of us in church. I said my rosary and prayers and left the church at the same time I always do. I made sure I didn’t touch or kiss the statues and reached home before 7am,” she told TOI.In Corlim, Maria D’Cruz’ daughter said she had to play ‘hawaldar’ and wake up at 5.30am to stop her mother from heading to church. “I’ve never seen such a day in my lifetime. I asked God for forgiveness and prayed for better days to come. These are testing times for us and I understand that we have to each contribute in our own little way,” D’Cruz said.Devotees watched the Mass on their TVs, laptops and phones as some churches livestreamed services. Others recorded and then uploaded them on Facebook and shared links on WhatsApp.The Monteiros in Loutolim not only watched the Mass on a laptop but participated in it as a family. “We gave our responses, stood up when we had to, in deep reverence, as we do in church. But not being able to receive Holy Communion left a great hollow,” Noemy Monteiro told TOI.Aldona resident Robert D’Costa accepted it as “God’s plan”. Instead of three Masses, CCR TV aired three masses in Konkani, English and Marathi with repeats. Its YouTube channel, that records between 20 and 70 new subscribers each day, saw a surge of 700 new subscribers on Saturday.Many other faithful preferred watching the Masses livestreamed by their own churches as they said it made the experience “more personal”.Youth in churches helped parish priests record and even livestream their services. “I took out my DSLR camera and the youth used Google and figured how to go about it,” parish priest of St Francis Xavier Church in Chicalim, Fr Bolmax Pereira, told TOI.During his Sunday sermon, Pereira urged the faithful to observe a “forwarding curfew” by not sending out any fake and negative messages that create more problems. “Unless these are messages related to essential services, we discouraged the laity from forwarding them,” Pereira said.At the Mother Church of the archdiocese, Se Cathedral, the youth also helped the priests record and then upload a video of the Mass online. Celebrating Mass in an empty church was not a pleasant experience, parish priest Fr Alfred Vaz told TOI. “I felt disconnected from my people,” he said.Last week, archbishop of Goa and Daman, Filipe Neri Ferrao, dispensed with the obligation of Sunday Mass for all the faithful and urged priests not to celebrate Mass with a congregation to observe the 14-hour Janata Curfew. He urged them to instead use modern means of communication to reach the Mass to their faithful.

Title: Industrial units to stay shut till March 25
Content:
Ahmedabad: Following the announcement of lockdown in four major cities of Gujarat – Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Surat and Rajkot – by the government of Gujarat, a number of industrial estates have announced shutting of their industrial units for at least three days. These include manufacturing units in Naroda GIDC, textile process houses in Narol, garment manufacturers and dyestuff manufacturers across the state.

“Some 1,300 units in Naroda GIDC will remain closed till March 25 and we have informed the staffers that this may be extended. These include units manufacturing dyes, chemicals, intermediates and other products. We have also assured all the workers that their salary will not be deducted,” said Shailesh Patwari, past president, Naroda Industries Association.

A similar decision was taken by Gujarat Dyestuff Manufacturers’ Association (GDMA) which announced on Saturday itself that the units will be shut for three days. “Some 1,000 dyestuff manufacturing units across the state will remain closed till March 25. The decision has been taken in the interest of public health and safety,” said Yogesh Parikh, president, GDMA. Industry estimates suggest that the shutdown will amount to losses worth Rs 25,000 crore per day for the dyestuff manufacturers.

Gujarat Garment Manufacturers’ Association (GGMA) too announced a shutdown of their units. “We had already announced three days of shutdown for all garment manufacturing units from Saturday to Monday. Now that the government has announced a shutdown till March 25, we will obviously comply and have informed our workers accordingly,” said Arpan Shah, honorary treasurer, GGMA.

Ahmedabad Textile Processors’ Association (ATPA) members too said they will shut manufacturing units till March 25 and take a call on whether to continue with shutdown, based on the situation.

Title: Trichy: 24-hour drinking water supply scheme in pipeline
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Round-the-clock drinking water supply has been one of the ever increasing demands of the city residents ever since the civic body was upgraded into a municipal corporation in 1994. To meet it, the civic body under the smart cities mission has proposed a 24-hour drinking water supply scheme in the 7 sq.km area around Rockfort . The civic body has also plans to expand this facility to other parts of the city. Smart water meters will be affixed to water connections for calculating water charge.

Since the city do not have quality groundwater to meet the demand of people at many places, a demand to ensure 24-hour drinking water supply was mooted in the late 1990s. However, the expensive project was delayed. Meanwhile, utilising Rs 106.62 crore from smart cities mission fund, Trichy City Corporation has proposed to implement a 24-hour water supply scheme for the area based development (ABD) zone (7 sq.m around Rockfort). The civic body officials had inspected working models in Manila, Philippines for the purpose. Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition ( SCADA ) enabled system, an automated mechanism, will ensure equal pressure and water flow in the selected areas. The project will be implemented in two phases; one phase for drilling new water sources on the Cauvery River bed and for laying new pipelines.

Automatic water meter reading (AMR) meters will be fixed in the piped water connections. At the end of the billing cycle, AMR will send text messages to the user and the civic body about the quantity of water consumed. Residents will have to pay water charge based on consumption. “Round-the-clock water supply will prevent people from relying on private players,” V B Jaganath, a resident of Karumandapam , said. Charge based on consumption will also plug revenue loss. “Metered water supply will make people use water judiciously. Fund sources will be ascertained to implement the project in the entire city,” a senior corporation official said.

Title: Bachelors find it tough in lockdown
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: While families enjoyed a comfortable Sunday by locking themselves in the houses, bachelors and people who stay in private stay facility (locally called mansion) in the city had a tough time in sourcing food. Though online food delivery platforms were operational in the city, the high demand owing to the extended lockdown has put them in a misery.

“Fortunately, there was food delivery option available in the mobile application. But many of the inmates in my mansion had managed to feed their hunger with bread and biscuits they purchased on Saturday,” R Aravind, a student residing in a mansion at Woraiyur , said.

The youths residing in the mansions have managed to stock eatables and snacks from a few tea shops and cafés that were opened on Sunday morning. Bachelors residing in mansions said that their friends in the city came to their rescue by bringing cooked food. tnn

Title: Woman from Australia quarantined in Rishikesh
Content: HARIDWAR: A 25-year-old-woman from Australia who reached Rishikesh on Sunday has been quarantined in a hotel room by the health department. She had come to India around a one month ago. She was stopped by Haridwar police on Narsan border and was then asked to report to a government hospital. However, police later found her in a hotel room.Senior sub inspector of Muni-ki-Reti police station told TOI, “Haridwar police shared information about the Australian woman who was stopped on Haridwar-Narsan border by Haridwar police and asked her to report to a government hospital. Later we traced her to a hotel and informed the health department. Her condition is normal and she has been quarantined for the next 15 days as per government guidelines.”Meanwhile, CMS Haridwar government hospital Dr Rajesh Gupta told TOI, “We do not have any knowledge about the visit of an Australian woman to our hospital. It is possible that she visited the Flu clinic.”

Title: Cured educator’s college marked safe from virus
Content:
Aurangabad: The faculty member at a city-based educational institute, who had tested positive for the virus last week, was declared free of coronavirus on Saturday. The institute where she worked has also been marked free of virus following an extensive screening of all its students and staff and negative reports of suspected cases. The students and staff, however, continue to be in quarantine until March 26.

Alarms had gone off after the 59-year-old educator was detected with Covid-19 on March 15. Incidentally, the woman, who had travelled to Russia and Kazakhstan and had returned to Aurangabad on March 3, had conducted lectures at the institute between March 4 and 7. As soon as she tested positive for Covid-19, the civic and health authorities jumped into action and noted down details of the people she had come in contact with. Subsequently, 480 students of the institute and 32 of the woman’s close contacts were screened and put on home quarantine.

Almost 90% of the institute’s students are from outside the city.

AMC commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, municipal officer of health Nita Padalkar and city engineer Sakharam Panzade had gone to the hostel where the students were quarantined and helped boost their morale.

The district civil hospital had sent swabs of the people with Covid-19-like symptoms for testing. District civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni said all swabs of the students and staff of the institute and close contacts of the patient had tested negative.

On Saturday, as soon as the woman was declared free of coronavirus after testing negative in two consecutive tests, the students at the institute, the women herself and her family heaved a sigh of relief. “We have won one war. The district is made free of coronavirus. The thorough testing and screening of the students at the institute have ensured that they are marked safe from the virus attack,” Kulkarni said.

In a letter issued on Saturday, the institute’s principal said that all the students have tested negative, but added that the institute would follow the instructions of the city administration on following the home quarantine protocol.

Kulkarni said the students continue to remain on precautionary quarantine. They will be able to step out of the home quarantine after March 26, he said.

Title: Man held for spreading rumour about coronavirus
Content: Dehradun: A man was arrested in Dehradun on Sunday for allegedly spreading rumours on COVID-19.Prakhar Gupta, a resident of Kalidas Road in Dehradun, circulated a message on WhatsApp claiming that the daughter of a popular medical shop on Rajpur Road had returned from USA recently and is infected with CONVID-19.The WhatsApp message also advised people to refrain from visiting the medical shop.On the basis of the complaint, SSP Dehradun Arun Mohan Joshi formed a team, which found out that the message was originally sent by Prakhar Gupta, who has now been booked under section 151 of CrPC."The daughter of the medical shop owner came back from USA on March 19 and has been quarantined at home since then. She is healthy and the information of her being infected with coronavirus is not true," police said.

Title: Newspaper vendor loses Rs 1.2 lakh to cyber crooks
Content:
Vadodara: A newspaper vendor in Karjan lost Rs 1.2 lakh in cyber fraud. The victim Darshan Shah was promised of personal loan of Rs 3 lakh instead he ended up paying the money to the accused Vinay Sharma and Vikas .

Shah told police that he had seen a finance company’s page on facebook and applied for loan on January 21 as he wanted to expand his business. A week later he received call from Vikas informing that his loan had been cleared but he will have to pay Rs 2,500 as registration fees. Until February 3 he received calls from Vikas and Sharma and was asked to pay money in different amounts for no-objection certificates, processing charges among other things.

Shah was told that he will receive the money back along with his loan amount, so he willingly transferred the money through netbanking application. After transferring the amount, Shah went to his bank several times to check whether he received the loaned amount or not. As the amount had not been credited, Shah called Sharma and Vinay but their phone numbers switched off. It was only then Shah realized that he had been conned.

On Saturday, he approached Karjan police station with his complaint based on which offence of cheating and under Information Technology Act was registered.

Title: Maharashtra: Covid-19 testing to begin at GMCH
Content: AURANGABAD: The Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) will start conducting Covid-19 tests from the coming week, district civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni said on Saturday.Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had sought additional testing centres for Covid-19 from the central government. Subsequently, GMCH will be getting a testing centre.Currently, all swab samples for coronavirus tests are being sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune. However, due to increasing load of tests, demand was being made for increasing the coronavirus labs.On March 15, public health minister Rajesh Tope had announced that coronavirus laboratories will soon be started at the government medical colleges in Dhule, Miraj, Solapur and Aurangabad On Saturday, Aurangabad district civil surgeon said the testing facility will be started at GMCH anytime this week.GMCH is the only state-run tertiary care hospital in the district. The hospital caters to patients from nearby Jalna, Jalgaon, Ahmednagar, Parbhani , Beed, Osmanabad and Hingoli on a large scale.So far, 43 patients who were check for coronavirus from Aurangabad have tested negative. According to the data released by district disaster management authority on Sunday, as many as 1,043 people have been quarantined at different institutions and at home across the district. This includes 205 people with travel history.The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has screened 59,253 people at 6 of its screening centres until 2 pm on Sunday. Of these 56 people were found with symptoms like fever, cold and cough. “These people were referred to the GMCH and Chikalthana district civil hospital,” AMC said in a release.

Title: PM Modi’s Janata Curfew call brings state to a halt
Content:
The CM, along with thie family, lends support to professionals involved in essential services working during c... Read More

Dehradun/Nainital/Almora/Roorkee: The Janata Curfew call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi received widespread support across the state.

In Dehradun, city roads wore a deserted look on Sunday and the shops remained shut. On the day, Dehradun residents took to various indoor activities like reading books, gardening, cooking, and others. The WhatsApp groups of different RWAs were flooded with updates from residents posting pictures of what they were doing.

Along with the police, social organisations also kept themselves on alert to provide any possible help to the senior citizens. “We received calls from different parts of the city from senior citizens who wanted to ensure if we would send them a vehicle in case of any heath emergency. We also provided hand sanitisers to some people and resolved queries of many senior citizens living alone in the city,” said Vimal Kumar from Apna Aasra, an NGO.

In Nainital, almost all roads and major locations remained deserted and people chose to stay inside. Markets like Tallital, Bara Bazaar and shops on Mall Road remained shut the entire day. Speaking to TOI, traders said that this was a necessary step to combat the Covid-19 threat.

“We chose to shut our shops today (March 22) as we understand how grave the situation is. Social distancing is extremely necessary,” said Raees Ahmed, owner of a restaurant on Nainital’s Mall Road.

Janata Curfew also received overwhelming support from almost all the areas across the Kumaon region. Even the most crowded markets of towns like Haldwani, Kichha, Rudrapur, Kashipur, Almora, and Bageshwar remained shut. Kaushal Singh, a Haldwani local, said that though some people did go out for essential things, but most of the people obeyed the curfew.

The police and administration officials also said that the they did not use any restraint and people voluntarily chose to stay inside their homes. “Police personnel were present at almost all the locations. People cooperated with police and we reciprocated,” said Nainital SSP Sushil Kumar Meena.

Residents of Almora town also followed PM Modi’s call for Janata Curfew. The streets wore a deserted look and hardly a few people were seen in the markets that otherwise remain abuzz throughout the day. Only those involved in providing people with essential services moved out of their homes for work on the day.

As requested by PM Modi, people came out on their balconies (or in courtyards) at 5 pm and banged utensils and applauded all those who are working to help people in times of coronavirus outbreak.

In Roorkee too, movement of people was almost negligible. Commercial establishments in Roorkee and nearby rural towns like Manglaur, Narsan, Jhabreda and Laksar remained completely closed on Sunday. Meanwhile, the sanitation workers utilised the Janata Curfew to sanitise the city. Roorkee’s additional sub- divisional magistrate Gopal Singh Chauhan told TOI that no untoward incident was reported on the day.

Title: Case registered against 65 people over wedding party
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: On a day when the entire nation put aside political and religious differences to unite for the fight against Covid-19 pandemic by observing ‘ janata curfew ’, a family in the city chose to host a party in connection with the wedding of their daughter . The act landed the family in trouble after the local police reached their residence and stopped the party. The cops also registered a case against 65 people who were at the spot for violating the order of the district collector prohibiting gathering of more than 50 people at an event.The incident took place at Panankara under Vattiyorkavu police station limits. Besides registering cases, police also arrested four people, including the bride’s father Ramakrishnan at whose residence the event was held. The others arrested are identified as Ratheesh Raj, Santhosh Kumar and Sony George. They were all let off on bail after arrests were recorded.Police said the wedding was held at 12.40pm. Police reached the residence around 2pm after alerted by local residents.“We were told that more than 200 people attended the wedding. When we reached the spot many of them had left and we registered cases against those present there,’’ said additional sub-inspector Shoukath Ali of Vattiyoorkavu police station. Police have invoked Sections 269 and 188 of IPC, 118e of Kerala Police Act, 51(b) of Disaster Management Act and 71 of Kerala Public Health Act.The police officer said the actual venue of the wedding was Mass Auditorium at Vattiyoorkavu. However, the venue was shifted to the residence in view of the pandemic spread. Yet, the family invited too many people to home, putting lives of other residents in the neighbourhood at risk, he said.Besides this, two more cases were registered in the district against individuals who breached home isolation. One case was registered at Attingal police station and the other case was registered at Pallickal police station. In both the cases, the individuals booked are expats who returned from Gulf countries. At Attingal, the individual had returned from Oman eight days ago. Though he was advised self-isolation, he went out of home and met with an accident near Chathannoor in Kollam while travelling in a car with two friends on Friday night. He is being treated in the ICU of Thiruvananthapuram Government Medical College Hospital. At Pallickal, the individual had returned from Bahrain a few days ago. He was booked after locals alerted the cops that he was going out of home.

Title: UP invites online applications to set up sanitiser production units
Content:
in safe hands

Lucknow: In view of growing demand for hand sanitizers as a preventive measure against Covid-19 infection, the state government, in a major policy shift , has invited people to apply for its manufacturing and get online permission immediately.

Speaking to TOI, principal secretary excise and sugar, Sanjay Bhoosreddy said that expecting a likely shortage of hand senitizers, it has been decided that the sugar millers and distilleries apart from any other individual fulfilling certain conditions can get online permission for manufacturing sanitizers.

He said that the big companies which had been manufacturing hand sanitizers felt shortage of raw material suddenly, so the sugar millers and the distillers which have alcohol with them in abundance can provide raw material to sanitizer manufactures and if they want to set up their own brands to sell in retail, they can also go for it.

In another step, the state government has allowed sanitizer manufacturing companies to procure ethyl alcohol more than the stipulated capacity for production of sanitizer in adequate quantity.

In a communiqué sent all district excise officials, excise commissioner P Guru Prasad has said that ethyl alcohol is available in adequate quantity to Indian Sugar Mills association and All India Distilleries Association. The sanitizers are otherwise manufactured from Iso-propyl alcohol which is not available in required amount and therefore manufacture of sanitizer from denatured alcohol is required, the letter, dated March 20, said. Prasad said that the sanitizer manufacturing units be provided ethyl alcohol through passbook facility.

The department has also directed that permission be granted to distilleries interested in bulk production of sanitizers. Directions have also been issued for manufacture of sanitizer in three shifts for which facilities be provided to the units.

Meanwhile, UP medicine manufacturing association sent a letter to UP chief minister seeking his intervention in expediting the production of hand sanitizer in the state. President of the association, Prashant Bhatia said that the World Health Organization has found ethyl alcohol based sanitizer appropriate to tackle the menace of Corona Virus. He said that the state has adequate quantity of ethyl alcohol but it is subjected to decision by the excise department.

“This is causing hindrance in supply of ethyl alcohol to the sanitizer manufacturing units,” he said. Bhatia said that while ethyl alcohol is available at a price of Rs 41 to Rs 50 per litre, the iso-propyl alcohol is subjected to black marketing and is available at Rs 360- per litre.

Title: Trichy Corporation’s homeless shelters running at full capacity
Content: TRICHY: The homeless people who usually hang out in mass gathering places have been moved to the Trichy Corporation ’s all-weather shelters ahead of the pan-India lockdown in the fight against Covid-19. Around 150 people have been accommodated at the shelters and being fed by the civic body. Homeless people who were still found on the streets were fed by the good Samaritans as most of the eateries remained shut on Sunday.Under the scheme for urban homeless through the national urban livelihood mission, Trichy Corporation in 2016-17 had established all-weather shelters for homeless in three locations - EB road, Bharathiyar road and Madurai road, with a capacity to accommodate 50 people each.All the 150 inmates in the shelters are being provided food three times a day. “Homeless people, mostly aged citizens, who were spotted near the railway junction and bus stand were moved to the nearest homeless shelter. The shelters have achieved full capacity,” a corporation official said.As few homeless people were found in the underneath bridges and bus shelters, people belonging to various trusts distributed food for them. No Food Waste Trichy Chapter had sourced excess untouched food from wedding halls and distributed them near MGM Government Hospital

Title: 8 arrested for keeping paan shops open
Content: Rajkot: Rajkot police arrested four persons , mostly paan shop owners , for violating the notification mandating closure of shops and hotels. They were identified Kishen Jivrajani, Uday Koli and Taufeeq Sakhva, all paan shop owners, and Amar Jhapda, a tea stall owner. In Junagadh , four paan shop owners - Pintu Patel, Atul Barad, Ruda Chauhan and Tekchand Vasvani were arrested on the same grounds. All were later released on bail. TNN

Title: Trichy stays indoors to observe ‘Janta curfew’
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: ‘Janta curfew’ was successful in Trichy city with people preferring to stay indoors on Sunday. All the commercial outlets, except fuel stations and pharmacies, remain closed. Later in the evening, residents in groups gathered outside their houses to clap and thank the various professionals who are fighting Covid-19 outbreak.

The Central bus stand wore a deserted look as buses were moved to five TNSTC depots in the city. With the state government extending the deadline of the curfew, TNSTC officials said that bus services may resume on Monday morning based on the directives from the authorities. The major hubs of commercial activities such as Big Bazaar Street, NSB Road and Main Guard Gate were completely free from public movement. Youths played cricket on the deserted road.

Though the curfew started at 7 am, a few meat stalls did business for a few hours as there were customers.

However, the shops were closed after the curfew kicked in. “Around 60,000 shops in the city and 30,000 shops in Trichy district remained closed. All the traders extended their cooperation to the call of the governments in combating the virus outbreak,” said Ve Govindarajalu, state general secretary, Tamil Nadu Traders’ Federation. Traders said that they await further instructions from the government regarding the reopening of shops as the curfew was extended till Monday morning.

Despite the curfew, weddings that were scheduled earlier were held in various parts of the city. Wedding organisers said that they have hosted the event with a minimum number of people by providing hand sanitiser for everyone entering the halls. Around 90 halls were booked in the district on Sunday.

Around 5 am, people gathered near their houses to clap and cheer the medical professionals, paramedic staff, local body workers and law-enforcement agencies in fighting Covid-19.

“Medical professionals and other warriors including police are fighting an invisible and unpredictable enemy, we are grateful to them,” said Dr V Badrinath , a resident of KVM Subha Mangala apartments, Srirangam.

Title: Gujarat: Stern action against medicine hoarders, say officials
Content: AHMEDABAD: The state food and drugs control authority has issued a stern warning against those hoarding hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin, which viral social media messages claim are prophylactic (preventive) drugs against COVID-19. On Sunday, food and drugs commissioner H G Koshia asserted that these drugs cannot be sold without a prescription as they are Schedule H drug under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act. "Stern action will be taken against any pharmacist or customers who try to hoard these medicines," Koshia said on Sunday."I have issued an order asking all drug stores, wholesalers and retailers, to keep a detailed account on whose prescriptions they are selling these two drugs. Surprise checks will be conducted." Sources in the state health department said that two major manufacturers of hydroxychloroquine in country are located in Gujarat and have a combined capacity of producing 7.4 crore tablets whenever the need arises. But a proper need assessment of the country will be carried out first, the sources said.

Title: 500 Nepalese workers stranded in Mathura amid janata curfew
Content:
Agra: More than 500 Nepalese workers were left stranded in Mathura on Sunday as no public transport was in operation in view of the ‘janata’ curfew across the country to combat spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.

The stranded workers, who were mainly working in Mumbai, were on their way home due to the “uncertainty over total lockdown”.

One of the workers, Padam Singh, said that most of them work in Mumbai, Pune and other cities, but with the uncertain situation, they have decided to return home and be with their families. “There are direct buses to Gauriphanta from Mathura. So, we all came here and are hopeful that we will get a bus after 9 pm,” Singh said.

According to official at local administration, the medical examination of these workers is being done to check for Covid-19-like symptoms. A few shops at bus stand have been allowed to remain open during the ‘janata’ curfew to cater to such people.

Meanwhile, the temple town of Mathura witnessed a total shut down on Sunday with all temples, including Banke Bihari and Sri Krishna Janamsthan, shutting their doors for general public.

While Chandroday temple, Priyakant temple and Banke Bihari temple in Vrindavan have been closed till March 31, Daan Ghati temple and Govardhan temple have been shut for public till Monday. The situation would be reviewed by the temple managements and the administration before opening them for public, the officials said.

Banke Bihari temple manager Munish Sharma said, “On the orders of civil judge, junior division, Mathura, the temple has been closed till March 31 for public.” He added paying of obeisance to the principal deity would continue as usual within the temple. The 22-kilometre Parikrama of Govardhan has also been suspended.

Title: When bird songs replaced street din
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Waking up to birds chirping near your window is something that few witness in the capital as these cheerful sounds are drowned by the incessant noise of cars, motorcycles and trucks from 7am onward. However, the janata curfew changed all that on Sunday.

With no one venturing out, the streets were taken over by strays, who usually get to frolic in free space only at night. Apart from dogs, monkeys were spotted on the roads near central and northern ridge. The situation only changed around 5pm when birds and stray dogs started scurrying for cover, perhaps taken aback by the sudden din occurring around them.

Experts said a reduction in noise pollution, apart from a visible lack of human presence, helped animals and birds venture out freely, who otherwise have adapted to a more dormant approach during the day.

Faiyaz Khudsar, scientist in-charge at Yamuna Biodiversity Park , said, “Once the noise level goes above 20 decibels, it becomes stressful for birds and they tend to become quieter. With little or no noise around, birds have been chirping all day long, mirroring what they do early in the morning. We’re getting a lot of reports of parakeets and barbets being particularly loud on Sunday.”

Referring to stray dogs and monkeys found roaming on the streets freely, Khudsar said human habitation plays a key role in the behaviour of animals and how they interact with their urban surroundings. “Over time, these animals have become accustomed to human presence around them. They are intelligent species that focus on survival. If there is no threat or human presence around them, it is natural they will venture out,” he added.

M Shah Hussain, scientist in-charge at Aravalli Biodiversity Park, too, felt the lack of disturbance aided in bringing out more wildlife to the urban setting. He added, “Birds and stray animals like dogs and monkeys have adapted to living near human settlements. But with little to no interference, they become more undeterred and roam around freely. This was what was observed on Sunday.”

Zoologist and birder Dr Surya Prakash said the situation changed at 5pm, with flocks of birds fleeing from his colony. “We recorded a number of birds, simply through their sounds, but the din created at 5pm disturbed them. It is just a small indicator of how noise can impact birds,” he added.

Title: Janta Curfew: Delta districts come to a standstill
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Delta districts came to a standstill with deserted roads and vacant bus stands as people observed Janta Curfew on Sunday. Despite the curfew, several weddings took place in the districts, particularly in Kumbakonam in Thanjavur and Mannargudi in Tiruvarur districts.

Following the call for Janata Curfew by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, people in delta districts like Thanjavur, Thiruvarur and Nagapattinam stayed at their houses since 7 am in the morning on Sunday.

All the shops, markets, commercial establishments, churches, temples mosques and cinema halls remained closed. Trains, buses, auto and taxi services were also completely stopped.

However, most of the marriage halls were seen busy as weddings as planned earlier were solemnized, with very few relatives attending the ceremonies. Being a 'Muhurtham day' (an auspicious day for marriage) more than 25 marriages were solemnized including 13 marriages in Mannargudi town itself in Tiruvarur district on Sunday.

Being a temple town, more number of weddings took place in Thanjavur district , particularly in Kumbakonam. However, all the relatives including bride and bridegrooms were allowed to the marriage halls only after thermal screening. Almost all the weddings witnessed low attendance of guests. The weddings were conducted in short and simple way.

Thousands of fishermen from the coastal hamlets in Nagapattinam district remained at their houses skipping fishing activities. Velankanni Basilica and Nagore Dargah also remained closed.

Title: District admin to take legal action against those defying home quarantine advisory
Content:
Agra: Legal action would be taken against those who are not following the health department’s advisory of 14-day home quarantine for all foreign returnees, contacts of those people who tested positive earlier and other individuals with Covid-19-like symptoms, according to Agra district administration on Sunday.

District magistrate Prabhu N Singh said that action would be taken under section 107/116 of CrPC (breach of peace and disturbing public tranquility) and the person may be even sent to jail for 14 days.

“From Monday onwards, anyone who had been advised home quarantine by the health department or travelled abroad in the past 14 days and found outside the house will have to face action under 107/116 CrPC. The individual will be sent behind the bars for 14 days. At present, 1,816 individuals have been advised to maintain home quarantine in Agra,” the DM said.

Meanwhile, six residents, including a woman, who had recently travelled overseas, were admitted to the isolation ward at district hospital on Sunday to check Covid-19-like symptoms. They were referred to the isolation facility by the health department’s surveillance team.

Superintendent in-charge of district hospital, Satish Verma, said, “The six people who have been admitted are asymptomatic. They have been kept in isolation ward on the basis of their travel history. Blood, nasal and throat swab samples of these people, along with 12 other suspected cases, have been sent to Lucknow’s King George Medical University (KGMU). The reports are likely to be received by Monday afternoon.”

Also, samples of 14 suspected cases sent to KGMU on Saturday were found to be negative.

Chief medical officer Mukesh Kumar Vats said, “All the 21 samples sent to KGMU has been tested negative for Covid-19. So far, eight positive cases have surfaced in Agra. Out of them, seven people have recovered and the rest home quarantined. A woman who tested positive is being treated at SN Medical College. People are advised against leaving their houses unnecessarily.”

Title: Dehradun Smart City Limited to monitor isolation wards and quarantine spots
Content: DEHRADUN: The authorities of the Dehradun Smart City Limited will now monitor the coronavirus isolation wards at various hospitals in the city and other quarantined persons via the Integrated Command and Control Centre — Sadaiv Doon — to ensure their security.Sources said that DSCL has already set up CCTVs at Doon, Coronation, Gandhi Shatabdi and Subharti hospitals, and Taqgene hotel. They added that the primary objective of the arrangement is to provide 24x7 security using CCTV surveillance system and the video feed of the same would be stored at ICCC. DSCL CEO Ashish Srivastava said, “We are making all arrangements to protect people from coronavirus. The installation of CCTVs is yet another step to ensure that the service providers along with those under quarantine are safe and secure.”

Title: Uttarakhand: Man booked for posting fake rumour on Facebook
Content: ALMORA: A resident of the town was booked for spreading fake news on coronavirus on social media on Sunday.According to police, the man, a Gopaldhara resident, posted false information on his Facebook timeline saying that a Covid-19 positive patient has been found in Almora. "A case under Section 505 (1) B and 188 of the Indian Penal Code has been filed against the accused for violating the instructions given in connection with coronavirus pandemic. Necessary action is being taken,” Arun Kumar Verma , inspector-in-charge, Kotwali Almora , told TOI.SSP Prahlad Kumar Meena said that he has appealed to the people of Almora to not spread panic. "Do not share any false information on social media platforms. Strict action will be taken against those who do so,” added Meena.The official added that district administration has made adequate arrangements for screening of commuters.

Title: Hundreds defy ‘janata curfew’ in Aligarh & Moradabad to protest against CAA
Content:
Agra/Bareilly: While their cities wore a deserted look, women in UP’s Aligarh and Moradabad defied the self-imposed curfew and gathered in hundreds to protest against CAA, notwithstanding appeals given against it by religious leaders, police and administration. In Moradabad, police have decided to book the protesters who had gathered at Eidgah on Sunday.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi had given a call for ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday to curb the spread of now novel coronavirus-- a highly-contagious disease. Even in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh-- which inspired similar sit-ins across UP and other parts of the country-- the protest became symbolic and the size was cut to just five.

In Deoband, the home to one of the largest Islamic seminaries of the world, the anti-CAA protest was called off. Several religious and political leaders of the community have asked people not gather for any protest. Moradabad MP Dr ST Hasan had also asked people of his city to stay indoors.

But, not heeding to the appeals, the protesters, mostly women, came out and staged a sit-in at Moradabad’s Eidgah, putting local police and the health department in a fix, which is already facing a tough time after surfacing of positive case of coronavirus in the city.

“Around 500 protesters reached Eidgah ground and started a sit-in protest there. Their act may fuel the epidemic. We are going to book them under IPC section 188 (disobedience of order duly promulgated by a public servant) and other relevant sections for posing threat to others’ lives,” said Amit Kumar Anand, additional superintendent of police (city).

One of the organisers at the sit-in site, Waqi Rashid, said, “Coronavirus cannot be controlled by a one-day curfew.”

While in Aligarh, over 500 women protesters continued with their sit-in against the Citizenship (amendment) Act (CAA). The protest against CAA is going on at Aligarh’s Shah Jamal Idgah ground since January 29.

The district administration had served a notice to the organiser two days ago asking them to vacate the place for 10 days amid coronavirus fears or “face legal action”. However, neither the protesters nor the organizers have paid heed to it.

Talking to TOI, Aligarh district magistrate (DM) CB Singh said, “Action will be taken against them.”

However, remaining parts of Aligarh, including Muslim-dominated areas of Jeevangarh, Jamalpur and Upper Kot, followed the appeal of PM Modi and stayed at home.

The administration has, meanwhile, decided to screen people coming from Delhi, Noida, Agra and Mathura.

‘Munadi’ (announcement) was also made by the municipal corporation officials urging people to stay indoors to combat spread of Covid-19. Confirming this, municipal corporation sanitary enforcement inspector Bishan Singh, said, “Munadi was organised in seven zones on Sunday to make people aware about the disease.”

Title: Gurugram doctor among seven new Covid-19 patients in Delhi-NCR
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: The number of patients in Delhi’s hospitals with Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, touched 30 on Sunday with three more confirmed cases. Two new cases in Noida and two more in Gurugram the same day pushed the number of patients with the same disease in both neighbouring cities to 8 each.

Two of those who tested positive in the capital have travel history to nations affected by the pandemic while one is a contact of a 38-year-old woman who had tested positive on March 17, after returning from Saudi Arabia a week before that. Health officials said she is a resident of Dilshad Garden, and not Shahdara, as reported earlier.

A woman and her son, residents of Sector 2 in Greater Noida, tested positive. Though the son (37) returned from Denmark on March 9, it was his 62-year-old mother who first reported symptoms. Both were tested and quarantined on March 19 and are now admitted to Government Institute of Medical Sciences. Three other family members are in isolation at home.

A team of 150 personnel from the health department and local administration carried out a sanitisation exercise in Sector Alpha 1 of Greater Noida where a 30-year-old man had tested positive late on Saturday. The sector has been sealed till 7am on March 24.

“We are alert for the purpose of protecting and containing the novel coronavirus from spreading among residents. Keeping this in view, the administration started immediate action after a person was found infected with coronavirus in B block of Alpha 1,” said district magistrate BN Singh.

A similar drive was carried out in the Sector 74 society where a resident had tested positive earlier this week. “Following the detection of one person who tested positive for Covid-19, we have put 23 families under home quarantine and their homes have been marked with a poster,” said the DM who urged residents to cooperate with the health department team that went door-to-door to initiate home isolation and quarantine measures even as the police personnel ensured no movement to and from the sector. This will also continue till March 24.

In Gurugram , a 35-year-old doctor at the Sector 10 government hospital has tested positive. She is a resident of Sector 9A. Test reports of a 22-year-old man who had returned from London and is admitted at a hospital also confirmed Covid-19.

A total of 17 samples were collected in the city on Sunday for testing. The numbers of positive cases are likely to rise in the coming days, health department officials said. So far, 4,455 people have been screened for Covid-19 in Gurugram .

“The 22-year-old man is from Palam Vihar. The patient had travelled to London in January and returned recently. We have collected samples from the area,” said JS Puniya, chief medical officer, Gurugram . The health department said an MCG team was conducting active surveillance and sanitisation of the Palam Vihar area.

In Ghaziabad, the doctor screening coronavirus patients at the nodal MMG Hospital is down with fever, cold and cough. His samples have been collected and sent for examination. The doctor has been asked to quarantine himself at home till the reports come.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Painting, poetry contests for students
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The Pudukottai district administration has announced poetry and painting competitions - with Covid-19 awareness as theme - for school and college students in Tamil Nadu .

The district administration has asked students to WhatsApp their entries by March 31. Prizes and certificates would be given to students who sent the best entries, district collector P Uma Maheswari said.

Students from classes I to V should WhatsApp their entries to 98651 20738. Students from classes VI to VIII are asked to WhatsApp their entries to 94434 88869 while students from classes IX to XII will have to send them to 73737 97250. College students can send their entries to 97863 82393.

Title: Covid-19 testing delays Poovar man’s autopsy, final rites
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: There is uncertainty over the death of a 58-year-old Poovar man, who had recently returned from UAE . On Sunday, doctors at the Thiruvananthapuram Medical College Hospital collected swab samples from the body and sent them for testing for coronavirus infection . The man had died on Saturday afternoon after he collapsed at his residence. He was under self-isolation at home.MCH superintendent M S Sharmad said the test is being carried out as he had returned from a Covid-19-affected region. If the test returns negative, the body of the deceased will be handed over to the family for funeral. But, if the result is positive, hospital authorities will cremate the body following protocols.According to police, the deceased reportedly fell from the staircase, injuring his forehead, at around 3.30pm on Saturday. Though he was rushed to the primary health centre at Vizhinjam, doctors declared him dead on arrival.Cops are still unclear whether the deceased fell from the staircase owing to illness or as the result of a mishap. Though the body was shifted to MCH mortuary for postmortem, health department authorities put off the examination and are awaiting the test result.Police said that as per their inquiry, the deceased had not displayed any symptoms of infection on arrival and was sent home from the airport after initial screening. He was also advised to go into self-isolation at home, which he followed.

Title: ‘I thought virus is too far from me. But...’
Content:
Ahmedabad: How does a person feel when despite taking all possible precautions, the Covid-19 strikes? This was the crux of a heartfelt post by one of the first Covid-19 positive patients from Ahmedabad posted on a social media platform on Sunday. The woman with travel history to Finland is currently under treatment at an AMC-run hospital.

She stated in her post that travel to Finland was a gift to herself as she wanted to see the northern lights. She knew about the Covid-19 outbreak in Wuhan since January 15 but ‘I thought it’s too far from me... I’ll take necessary precautions,’ she wrote.

She flew to Finland in the beginning of March and took multiple domestic and international flights. ‘I wore an N99 mask, sanitized my hands a 100 times, washed my hands for 30 seconds as many times as I could, put the air vents on in my seat, sanitized my tray table and armrests,’ she wrote, adding that one cannot but use hands to touch masks due to security checks, passport controls, eating and drinking. But still there were only 10 cases in Finland at the time. And she thought the chances of her contracting the disease were close to non-existent.

When she returned, Covid-19 was already a pandemic but India still had few cases. She took the precaution of maintaining safe distance from families and other family members to the extent of isolating herself, washing her utensils and clothes with disinfectant and hot water. But on March 14, she got the first signs in the form of a slight fever. The general practitioner she saw advised her antibiotics. But as it persisted, she was tested and was found to have mild upper respiratory infection. On March 16, she visited a doctor friend at SVP where her samples for Covid-19 were taken and turned out to be positive. ‘As long as the numbers are few, this can be managed to a large extent,’ she wrote, adding that she’s worried about her parents even as they are fine currently.

‘Please take care guys whether you are sick or not sick, it’s not worth the risk. However, if you do think you’ve got it, please do not panic’ she wrote.

Title: First +ve Covid-19 case reported in DK
Content: Mangaluru: The first Covid-19 positive case was reported in Mangaluru on Sunday. A 22-year-old passenger from Dubai , who hails from Bhatkal in Uttara Kannada, tested positive for Covid-19. The passenger had arrived at Mangaluru International Airport in a SpiceJet flight at 5.40 pm on March 19.He was symptomatic during medical screening at the airport. Following this, the health staff immediately shifted him toWenlock Hospita where he was admitted in an isolation ward.Dakshina Kannada deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said the patient is stable. “It is an ideal case of surveillance. The patient was not allowed to move freely, and he was shifted immediately to Wenlock Hospital in an ambulance. His throat swab was collected and sent for testing on March 20. The report arrived on Sunday, and has confirmed him to be a positive case of Covid-19,” the DC said.The health department and the district administration have already obtained the list of 165 co-passengers in the flight the patient was travelling in.“We are in touch with all the passengers, who are in home quarantine,” the DC said, adding that more than 2,000 people are in home quarantine in the district.While 15 samples were sent to be tested for Covid-19 on Sunday, reports of seven cases arrived, and only one patient from Bhatkal tested positive. Meanwhile, the last international flight before the ban, landed at MIA with 109 passengers from Dubai on Sunday. The DC said all the passengers were screened and sent for home quarantine. “All the passengers were asymptomatic and they have been sent for home quarantine,” she said.Meanwhile, district minister Kota Shrinivas Poojari warned that cases will be booked against the people in home quarantine, if they are found to be roaming outside in violation of guidelines.He also requested people not to step out of the house unnecessarily till March 31.

Title: Trichy: Spotted deer saved from sea off Manamelkudi coast
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Fishermen rescued a four-year-old male spotted deer that was struggling to stay afloat in sea off the Manamelkudi coast in Pudukkottai district on Sunday.

Fishermen from Krishnajipattinam village spotted the deer in the morning and ventured into the sea in their boats. They brought the deer ashore and informed the forest department.

Pudukkottai district forest officer (DFO) M Anand Kumar said that the deer, that was in a good condition, was released in the wild in the Aranthangi reserve forest. He said there are no spotted deer in Aranthangi forest but there have been instances when spotted deer were seen here along the coast.

The DFO added the deer could have come from Point Calimere Wildlife Sanctuary in Nagapattinnam district as they can travel miles during summer in search of food and water. Usually deer won’t venture in the sea. “But this one could have been chased by stray dogs forcing it enter the sea,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak in Delhi: Public transport goes into shutdown mode
Content: NEW DELHI: Even before chief minister Arvind Kejriwal announced lockdown of the capital on Sunday evening, the city was already a ghost town since morning with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call for “janata curfew” receiving overwhelming support.As a majority of Delhiites remained indoors, the roads were weirdly deserted on Sunday. While Delhi Metro Rail Corporation had earlier announced that its train services would be completely closed, other modes of transport were soon added to the list. All autorickshaw and taxi unions announced that they would not operate their vehicles in support of the call given by the PM.Sarvodaya Drivers’ Association of Delhi, which represents drivers of app-based cabs, said that they would stay off the roads. Aggregators Ola and Uber said that while they had requested riders to stay at home, a nominal number of cabs were available to meet urgent and essential travel needs of commuters.The only form of public transport visible on the roads were buses of Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and cluster scheme operated by Delhi Integrated Multi-Modal Transit System. Delhi government had decided that 50% of buses would run on Sunday. “While around 80% of the fleet of both DTC and cluster scheme are deployed usually, this Sunday only 50% were on the roads,” a Delhi government official said.There were just a few autorickshaws and cabs occasionally seen on the roads. Though the frequency of buses was more regular, not more five passengers could be seen in them. In fact, the only people seen were those waiting for public transport at bus queue shelters.While Indian Railways suspended all train operations around noon, people could be seen at all major railway stations. The roads outside were, however, deserted.The Interstate Bus Terminals at Kashmere Gate, Anand Vihar and Sarai Kale Khan wore a forlorn look because of lack of commuters as well as buses. “These three ISBTs together register a footfall of more than three lakh every day. Sunday witnessed a rare scene as people voluntarily cooperated in the fight against Covid-19 ,” the official said.

Title: Life comes to a standstill in Agra city during janata curfew
Content:
Agra: The city observed a complete shutdown on Sunday following a call for a janata curfew by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The bustling roads wore a deserted look as people remained indoors to avoid spread of the novel coronavirus. The silence was almost deafening.

No shops, except pharmacies, were open. All public transport, including auto-rickshaws and e-rickshaws, were off the roads. Bus and railway services remained suspended. The out-patient department (OPD) at SN Medical College and district hospital were closed for the day. Petrol pumps were also shut.

Few civilian vehicles were seen on the roads, save the official vehicles of police, administration and health department in the city.

Meanwhile, rumours on the social media caused panic among people. Health department officials and coronavirus control room received hundreds of distress calls, regarding queries about Covid-19 infection. Meanwhile surveillance and rapid response teams were on their toes all day long as they went from one place to another throughout the day to verify the information about “patients” and take necessary action.

In Agra, people voluntarily participated in the Janata Curfew. Those running makeshift shops and street vendors also kept away.
