Parks and gardens were deserted despite being a Sunday as people did not venture out or allow children to play outdoors.

In the morning, police used public address system to advise people to stay at home. Those driving private vehicles were stopped and asked to return home. In the evening, some people who came out to buy vegetables found the vendors missing.

Head of the district rapid response team for coronavirus, Dr Anshul Pareekh, said, “I have personally got hundreds of calls regarding suspected Covid-19 infected persons. The chief medical officer, district administration officials and control room also received a large number of calls. We are screening all suspected cases. Rumours on social media are causing a major problem. However, the level of awareness among people have also increased. Those with a recent travel history having flu-like any symptoms voluntarily came to give samples for laboratory testing. Everyone should practice social isolation to prevent the spread of the disease,” he added.

Meanwhile, Agra Municipal Corporation workers on Sunday conducted rigorous fogging in different parts of the city as a precautionary measure in the fight against spreading of coronavirus.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak in Gurugram: Suspend our services too, say wary Kherki Daula toll staffers
Content: GURUGRAM: With hardly any vehicles at the Kherki Daula toll plaza , it was an unusually quiet Sunday morning for the operators, giving them a break from their daily routine.However, some employees voiced resentment that their services hadn’t yet been suspended in view of Covid-19 outbreak. The lockdown in city and other districts does not cover them, as trucks that carry essential goods are still operating and cross the toll.The toll management has called upon the NHAI and the ministry of road transport and highways to provide some relief. Some workers urged authorities to let them put themselves in self-quarantine.“Services were stopped during demonetisation too. The current scenario is much more serious and risks human lives. The ministry must show some sensitivity towards toll plaza workers as we are more exposed and vulnerable to the transmission of the virus,” said a Skylark official, not wishing to be named.While the toll management has provided masks and sanitisers to staff, there is anxiety owing to the fact that the workers have been dealing with thousands of people on a daily basis, many of them heading to or returning from the airport. “Are we not humans or do we not deserve to quarantine ourselves? Until now the city wasn’t locked down so we still consoled ourselves. But now transportation activities will be shut. Relaxing our services for a week or so won’t disrupt anything,” a toll operator said.Many employees claimed that they struggled on Sunday to get to the toll plaza as public transport was largely suspended. They fear, their daily struggles are only going to compound. “From tomorrow, when the borders are sealed, even fewer people would be able to come. Why not allow a complete lockdown for us too?” said another lane operator.A Skylark official said operators and supervisors are vulnerable to infection. “Despite FASTags and cashless transactions, these workers still come in contact with thousands of people. It’s high time the authorities suspended the services, at least till March 31,” the official said. Sources in NHAI, however, said there was no such plan to suspend services at the moment. However, the ministry may come up with a necessary advisory if the need is felt. Officials also claimed that with FASTag being implemented at toll plazas, more than 80% of the transactions have gone digital, with either no or limited human interaction.

Title: Uttarakhand: Hotel owner booked in Mukteswar for renting room to tourists
Content: NAINITAL: The Nainital district administration booked a hotel owner in the Mukteshwar area on Sunday after it was found that the hotel had rented out rooms to tourists from outside the state in violation of orders from both the district magistrate (DM) and senior superintendent of police (SSP) that ordered shut down of all hotels, homestays, and resorts across the district.According to the district administration, an FIR was registered against the hotel owner under several sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) for “willfully violating the orders of a public servant as well as for malignantly spreading an infectious disease”.In a statement, the district administration said that the hotel had rented rooms to tourists which aggravated the chances of people becoming infected with the disease.“The reckless behaviour of the hotel owner poses a threat to people’s health. The hotel violated the orders and let some tourists in. Therefore, an FIR has been registered against the owner under section 269 (unlawfully or negligently doing an act which is likely to spread infection, section 270 (malignantly doing any act which is likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life) and section 188 (offence of disobedience of an order by a public servant) of the IPC,” read the statement.Meanwhile, an administration official also told TOI that three youths who had come to Lalkuan area of the district have been tested for coronavirus and have been advised to quarantine themselves in their homes for two weeks.“These three youths along with ten others had come to Nainital’s Lakuan area. The health team will visit them daily and check on their condition during the period of their quarantine” the official said.

Title: Railway workshop to be shut for 3 days in Trichy
Content: TRICHY: As a precautionary measure against the spread of Covid-19, Ponmalai Railway Workshop has announced holiday for three days from Monday. Similarly, Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited in Trichy (Bhel) has modified shift timings in such a way that employees can have lunch at their home, as the company has shut it canteens to avoid mass gatherings.According to a senior official from Ponmalai Railway Workshop, all the 30 shops in the workshop will be remain closed till Wednesday, the official said. The workshop employs nearly 1,000 employees in the diesel shop. To avoid transmission, workers have been divided into two shifts.As per the new timing, the first shift begins at 6am and would end at 2pm. The second shift would start at 4pm and extend up to 12am. Earlier there was only one shift which began at 7am and ended at 4.30pm. For women employees, the earlier timing of 7am to 4.30 pm would continue as usual, officials said.At Bhel, the shift timing has been brought down to five hours from eight. The shop floor would function from 7am and would end at 12pm. The second shift would begin at 1pm and end at 6pm.

Title: 60% kids from government homes sent back
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Following the guidelines issued by the department of health in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, 2,757 children, out of 4,803 children from 72 child care institutions (CCI), have been sent along with their parents and guardians in delta districts on Saturday.

Children in need of care and protection are placed in child care institutions such as children homes, open shelters, observation homes, special homes, places of safety and specialised adoption agencies. Most of the children staying at these homes are orphans or have single parents.

There are 72 such homes functioning across delta districts including Thanjavur , Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam . In Thanjavur, 2,513 children are residing in 33 homes, of which 1,517 children have been sent along with their parents, while 996 are at the home itself.

In Tiruvarur, there are 10 homes with 306 children, of which 217 have been sent back, Tiruvarur District Child Protection Officer P Selvaraj told TOI.

In Nagapattinam, 1,984 children are staying in 29 homes, of which 1,023 have gone back with their guardians, officials from Nagapattinam district said.

Title: Textile showroom owners, tailors join hands to make masks in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

TIRUVARUR: Nesakaram, a non-governmental organization in Mannargudi in Tiruvarur district has brought textile shops and tailors together to manufacture face masks. The masks will be handed over to hospitals and organisations in town as there is an acute shortage of the same. Initially, the textile shops will provide the required cloth free of cost while tailors will stitch the masks without charging any money.

Cities and towns in the central region have largely run out of masks. A few days ago, contract staff at the government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur had staged a protest demanding safety equipment including the face masks. The initiative by Nesakaram is aimed to help ease the situation by making masks available at hospitals and in medical shops.

“Textile shop owners and tailors in Mannargudi have extended their helping hands to by manufacture face masks at an affordable price. We have decided to produce as many masks as required and hand them over to the government hospitals”, Marutham Goki , one of the organisers of ‘ Nesakkaram ’ said.

The face masks will be sold at a meagre price. Using the money generated from the sale of masks, we have decided to produce more masks to cater to the needs of hospitals and the general public, Goki said.“As many as 1000 masks were produced on Saturday and they will be handed over to the hospital authorities on Monday”, he added.

Title: Janta curfew: Empty roads & the sound of silence
Content: Pushed into action by the unfolding global Covid-19 pandemic, India on Sunday practised social distancing on a never-before scale through a“janata curfew” that kept the country’s 1.3 billion population indoors all day and delivered more than a few fringe benefits — sparrows and pigeons frolicking on otherwise congested streets, national landmarks bereft of surging weekend crowds and air purer than it has been in a long time.Pictures of Delhi’s Connaught Place overrun by flocks of pigeons trended on social media, inviting philosophical responses that spoke of the one bright spot in the looming coronavirus cloud — a bustling, overcrowded city finding safety and solace in the sound of silence.Behind closed shutters at some of the popular weekend haunts, cafe stools were stacked upside down. Lanes lined with party places and in-trend stores were pitch dark. India Gate, which sees a footfall of more than 50,000 every day, had just PCR vans for company.The few faces that popped up on the streets were either of those whose curiosity had got the better of them or people who had to step out for something that couldn’t be avoided or postponed. The only stretches of road where some honking could be heard were, ironically, the no-honking zones outside hospitals. From one of Mumbai’s high-rises, the sight of the empty arc of the Queen’s Necklace was nothing short of surreal.“Marine Drive, Mumbai, this morning... this is what national discipline means... Jai Hind,” tweeted Amitabh Bachchan. “I’ve never seen it (Marine Drive) like this. Let’s remind ourselves that today isn’t the end but the first day in battle...” tweeted Harsh Mariwala, chairman of Marico.A few buses did ply in Mumbai, but passengers were few. At train stations, roving squads were deployed to check identity cards and make sure only those associated with essential services commuted. The two airport terminals, which together have a normal daily staff strength of 45,000, on Sunday functioned with barely 2,000 employees handling everything from facility management to duty-free stores.In Bengaluru, nothing moved till 5pm except police vehicles and ambulances. Several churches made arrangements for digital prayer services on Sabbath day so that the faithful wouldn’t have to step out. It wasn’t until 5pm that the self-imposed shackles broke, with a section of residents in some localities spilling out in groups during the show of support for those on the front line of the Covid-19 fight.For Kolkata, where bandhs were a way of life not long ago, Sunday’s total shutdown was ostensibly unlike anything the city had experienced before. Twitter user Chandreyi Sharma posted a picture of a barbet hooting away in front of her home with the caption: “He has been singing for the last 3 hours.” According to the pollution control board, the city’s air quality had improved by several notches since Saturday. Chennai’s Marina beach was deserted for the first time in recent memory.

Title: Be ready for more janata curfews: CM
Content:
Lucknow: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday asked citizens to be prepared for more janata curfew-like measures to combat coronavirus, which has infected more than 325 people across the country. Yogi’s statement came on a day the country observed a complete self-lockdown on the appeal of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

“Hume ye koshish karni hai ki coronavirus se sankramit logon ki sankhya aagey na badey…Iske liye janata curfew ke jaise karyakramo ki liye tayyar rehna hoga (We will have to work to ensure that number of people affected by coronavirus do not increase. We will have to take measures like janata curfew in future),” said Yogi.

In UP, as many as 28 covid-19 cases have been reported and state government authorities have ratcheted up measures, including halting public transport, including Metro rail to curtail potential threat by the virus. Of the total, 10 have recovered and others are stable or recovering fast, the CM said.

Yogi said the appeal for a janata curfew has been given to protect 130 crore people of the country. “I appeal to people to play their role in fighting the virus. The state government has taken adequate steps to serve people in time of crisis,” the CM said. Yogi appealed to people not to get scared of the virus, but launch a fight. “Prevention is better than cure and steps are taken to prevent people from getting affected,” he said. Yogi said, the state government had 2000 isolation beds in the state. “This has been increased to 10,000 in last two days,” he said.

Asking people to maintain social distance, Yogi said, people should abide by suggestions of doctors and cooperate with officers and security agencies. “The government will not allow shortage or hoarding of essential commodities,” he said.

Yogi said, the state government has already taken steps to provide essential commodities to people. The CM warned shopkeepers not to sell utilities for more than the MRP or else the state government would take strict action.

Title: Prime Minister Narendra Modi applauds Garhwali folk singer Pritam Bhartwan for corona-theme song
Content: DEHRADUN: Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised Dehradun-based Padma Shri awardee folk singer Pritam Bhartwan for composing a Garhwali song exhorting people in the hill state to follow the Janata Curfew called to fight Covid-19.On Sunday, PM Modi tweeted a video link of the song that Bhartwan has composed. The PM’s tweet said that Pritam Bhartwan has given the message of Janata Curfew in a unique and melodious way through the song. The song has been viewed over 33,000 times and the number is rising steadily.“After hearing the PM’s call for Janata Curfew, I composed this song. I am so happy that our PM has taken note of the song and appreciated it,” Bhartwan told TOI. He further said that his aim was to encourage social distancing.“The first line of the song urges people to avoid mass gatherings and going outside — the major causes of spread of coronavirus . The song asks people to remain indoors and follow the Janata Curfew,” added Bhartwan.The 49-year-old folk singer also clanged utensils on Sunday evening to hail all those working for public amidst coronavirus outbreak. “We must follow social distancing to contain the spread of the deadly virus,” urged Bhartwan.Padma Shri Pritam Bhartwan is well-known for popularising Jagar music of the Garhwal region. Born in a village in the Raipur area of Dehradun , Bhartwan has already recorded over 1,000 songs in 40 albums.

Title: A fine Sunday of family time online mass & spring cleaning
Content:
Central Market where people went on a buying spree on Saturday is empty on Sunday due to ‘janata curfew’

Mangaluru: Following the PM’s call for a ‘ janata curfew ’, Sunday was a complete shutdown in the coastal districts of Dakshina Kannada and Udupi – a first in their lifetime, residents recalled, over a non-communal issue. The streets were largely empty, barring the odd car or auto-rickshaw; public transport too was on an essential basis.

Private bus operators had announced earlier that they would not ply on Sunday and only a small trickle of commuters was seen in public buses. Voluntary organisations provided food packets at KSRTC bus stations to passengers who were forced to wait for the bus forward or home.

With few vehicles on the road, the skeletal staff at retail fuel stations had little work. The Karnataka State Federation of Petroleum Dealers had intimated in advance that fuel sales for the day would be restricted to vehicles involved in delivery of essentials and emergency services. Hospitals too attended only to emergency cases.

Residents put the forced confinement to good use – enlisting the entire family for spring cleaning and other chores. Others are finding a bonus of quality time.

While Dr Ananth Pai P, a paediatrician who is usually swamped with weekend patients, attended to emergency cases, his father Ramdas played chess with his grandson Aniruddh Pai, barred as they were from morning and evening walks or outings.

Temples were closed or requested people to stay away as a precautionary measure. Churches remained open only for funeral services, one of them being for the mother of Robert Miranda, the bishop of Kalaburagi diocese.

The gurudwara has for now done away with the bhajan and langar held every Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon. Fr Vijay Victor Lobo, PRO of Mangalore diocese, said funeral mass would be held without the customary procession till the lockdown is in force.

As Sunday mass has been cancelled, Mangalore bishop Peter Paul Saldanha celebrated mass with other priests at Bishop’s House which was live-streamed online.

“The diocese will take a decision on celebration of Holy Week events after consulting with the archdiocese of Bangalore,” he said. Taking the clampdown for social distancing forward, cross-sections of trade – automobile, jewellery and all those dealing with non-essential items – are set to suspend all commercial activity for a staggered number of days starting Sunday.

Title: With 3 new cases, now 7 in MGMGH’s isolation ward
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The number of patients under observation in the isolation ward of Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital (MGMGH) in Trichy has gone up to seven on Sunday with three new patients being admitted including a three-month-old baby.

According to doctors in the MGMGH, a three-month-old baby from Malaysia was brought to the hospital with Covid-19 symptoms. The baby is being kept under observation. A patient, who returned from Malaysia and another patient in Trichy approached the hospital with the symptoms. They, too, have been kept under observation.

Samples of all the three patients have been sent to the viral research and diagnostic laboratory (VRDL) from government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur district .

Samples of the existing four patients were also sent a few days back and the results are awaited. There has not been a single Covid-19 positive case at MGMGH so far.

Meanwhile, public health and preventive medicine department sent 22 passengers including 10 men and 12 women to the makeshift quarantine facility setup at Central market for vegetables, fruits and flowers at Kallikudi.

Out of 458 passengers, who landed at Trichy international airport by five flights from Sharjah, Dubai and Singapore, 34 passengers including 25 men and nine women were diagnosed with mild cough and cold and sent to the makeshift quarantine facility on Saturday.

Following the nationwide shutdown on Sunday, public and private transport services were not operated. District collector S Sivarasu thanked the public for their active participation in the Janata Curfew called by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to contain Covid-19.

Title: Gujarat: Lockdown in 4 major cities, industrial units to stay shut
Content:
AHMEDABAD: Following the announcement of lockdown in four major cities of Gujarat – Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Surat and Rajkot – by the government of Gujarat, a number of industrial estates have announced shutting of their industrial units for at least three days. These include manufacturing units in Naroda GIDC, textile process houses in Narol, garment manufacturers and dyestuff manufacturers across the state.

"Some 1,300 units in Naroda GIDC will remain closed till March 25 and we have informed the staffers that this may be extended. These include units manufacturing dyes, chemicals, intermediates and other products. We have also assured all the workers that their salary will not be deducted," said Shailesh Patwari, past president, Naroda Industries Association.

A similar decision was taken by Gujarat Dyestuff Manufacturers’ Association (GDMA) which announced on Saturday itself that the units will be shut for three days. "Some 1,000 dyestuff manufacturing units across the state will remain closed till March 25. The decision has been taken in the interest of public health and safety," said Yogesh Parikh, president, GDMA. Industry estimates suggest that the shutdown will amount to losses worth Rs 25,000 crore per day for the dyestuff manufacturers.

Gujarat Garment Manufacturers’ Association (GGMA) too announced a shutdown of their units. "We had already announced three days of shutdown for all garment manufacturing units from Saturday to Monday. Now that the government has announced a shutdown till March 25, we will obviously comply and have informed our workers accordingly," said Arpan Shah, honorary treasurer, GGMA.

Ahmedabad Textile Processors’ Association (ATPA) members too said they will shut manufacturing units till March 25 and take a call on whether to continue with shutdown, based on the situation.

Title: Firm’s stolen database sold on social media, FIR lodged
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Deepak Savaliya , 36, of Nikol has lodged a complaint with Krishnanagar police station on Friday that a man named Ankit Limbachiya has stolen his company’s logo and is selling his company’s GST-approved data at Rs 1999 through Facebook . Police have registered a case under relevant sections of IT act against one Ankit Limbachiya operating from Naroda.

According to the FIR, Savaliya works as regional manager of a Noida-based firm India Mart – Intermesh Ltd. The firm is a platform for selling and purchasing goods. Currently, Savaliya is operating and handling about nine states from a rented office in Krishnanagar.

Savaliya has stated in his complaint that about four months ago, his friend Kalaj Sojitra told him that his company’s logo which is used on WhatsApp is being used by someone else on Facebook to sell the company’s data.

“Sojitra sent Savaliya the link. Apart from using the company’s logo, it was specifically written that at Rs 1,999, four crore GST approved details will be available. Savaliya called on the number mentioned on the advertisement. The person speaking from the other side told him that all data are genuine and that he will send the details of one sample for verification,” said a police official.

According to the FIR, the case was referred to the company’s legal adviser Danish Khan who also got the same reply when he called on the number. However, through his men, Khan found out that the bank account the man gave is of one Ankit Limbachiya of a nationalized bank located at Kapadwanj, Motizur and the address is of Naroda.

“We have lodged a case and with the help of cyber cell are hunting for the accused. We have written to the service providers to obtain the IP log of the device from which the Facebook account was created and operated,” said a police official.

Title: Gujarat: Five more held in thumbprint scam
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Five more persons have been arrested in connection with the fair price shop scam involving use of forged fingerprints.

The accused used to make silicone fingerprint casts of ration card holders and divert foodgrains and other material meant for the card holders to the open market from fair price shops.

The five accused, Bhimji Chavda, 43, of Bhuj, Natvar Sheth , 62, of Bhuj, Ravindra Maheshwari, 36, of Anjar, Vikas Thakkar, 45, of Anjar and Pranlal Thakkar, 45, of Anjar were arrested by city cyber cell on Saturday. A woman, Bhavna Patel, 26, of Kheda was also taken into custody.

Until now, 59 persons have been arrested in this case that was detected in December 2019.

Inspector Sajan Muchal of cyber cell said that on March 7, Khuma Rabari, Manojkumar Patel, and Mahesh Patel, all of Banaskantha were arrested.

The key accused, Bharat Chaudhary, 26, of Sargasan, Gandhinagar was arrested by Muchal in December.

“Chaudhary used to get the data of customers of fair price shops, including their thumbprints. He then used to take the thumbprints’ soft copy and print them on a rubber like material. Chaudhary then used to sell the thumbprints to accused fair price owners who used to make fake bills using the thumbprints and sell the ration in open market at higher price,” Muchal said.

Title: People staying at home: Online shopping sites see a surge in biz
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: From hike in the number of orders to ‘ silent delivery ’, online shopping sites are trying various options to cater to the demands of customers in the time of Covid-19 . With several people staying back at home to avoid getting infected by coronavirus, the online shopping of grocery, vegetables and milk saw a surge in the last couple of weeks in the city.Vinod NR, MD of online grocery shop Spenlo.com, said they are not able to quantify the demand after the surge in the past few days. “We had around 500 active customers and it increased to 1,000 in the past two weeks. We have accepted orders till March 25. The demand is such that we are not able to provide alternate or substitute brands and have to inform the customer that the product is out of stock. We are working on doubling the potential,” Vinod said.Despite the busy schedule, the online stores have taken measures to ensure safety of their staff. Staff members have been provided masks and gloves while delivering products.‘Silent delivery has also picked up these days. Customers under home quarantine ask for silent delivery where the products are left at doorsteps or near apartment entrance without physically meeting the customer.Online store ‘amneeds.com’ saw a demand in vegetables in the last couple of days. “We have demand for milk and milk products. Besides that, in the past few weeks, more customers are demanding for fresh-cut and uncut vegetables. We supply products to around 3,000 houses. The workload has increased as we have added 100 new customers in the past one week,” said Sujith Sudhakaran, CEO, AM Needs.The online purchase also indicated a demand for healthy alternative.Another online store The Farmers Fresh Zone (www.farmersfz.com) is receiving huge demand for leafy vegetables. The online store which provided delivery of products twice in a month made the service daily last week.“People may be more health conscious now, as we see an increase in demand for seasonal fruits such as watermelons and mangoes and leafy vegetables. There is an increase in 40% to 60% sale in the past week,” said Haani Hashim, SVP, head of product, Farmers Fresh Zone.

Title: Clapping in unison, city residents express gratitude to health workers
Content:
People come out of their house balconies in Mangaluru to applaud the efforts of essential workers as the natio... Read More

Mangaluru: After silence being maintained for the entire day, the city resonated to the sound of bells from churches and instruments used for prayers at 5pm. This resonance also saw people come out of their homes on Sunday.

Mangaluru responded positively to Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call to thank healthcare providers and emergency responders who are on the front line to combat Covid-19, across the country. Courtesy Janta Curfew, for a change, people could hear birds chirping instead of vehicles honking.

As the clock struck 5, people were seen standing on the balconies of apartments and terraces, or in front of their houses, either through clapping or with instruments such as conches, small bells, jagate and tala (instruments used during prayers) and plates and spoons to express gratitude to the nation’s caregivers for nearly 15 minutes.

Officers, sailors, civilians and their families of the Indian Coast Guard joined the rest of the country by applauding from their balconies at the Coast Guard residential area, Kunjathbail.

Coast Guard Karnataka stood together to applaud doctors, nurses and other healthcare workers, who were putting themselves at risk on the front lines of the pandemic that is forcing most residents to stay home.

The idea of community clapping,while practising social distancing, appears to have inspired the Coast Guard.

BJP state president and MP Nalin Kumar Kateel participated in the movement by clapping at his residence. Mangaluru City South MLA D Vedavyas Kamath also participated. He not only clapped, but also connected his mobile phone with bluetooth speakers and played the sound clip in full volume, which has gone viral.

Meanwhile, at the entrance of Venkataramana Temple, a group of youth gathered to express their gratitude toards healthcare workers.

Techie Krishna Pawan took this opportunity to play his flute outside his house at Urva Store, as a mark of tribute to those infected with Covid-19 and healthcare and emergency service providers.

Title: Coronavirus fighters hear Delhi applaud effort loud & clear
Content: NEW DELHI: Even before the clock struck 5 on Sunday evening, the ghostly silence that had enveloped the city through the day was suddenly broken by the rhythmic beating of thalis, blowing of conch shells, ringing of bells and clapping. As the noise rose to a crescendo, birds took flight and stray dogs barked nervously. People had emerged from their houses to thank the healthcare workers in this unique gesture, as requested by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Balconies filled up quickly and many spilled out of their homes on the streets.The din lasted for about 10 minutes as the city thanked doctors, nurses, paramedics, municipal staff and airport workers, who are fighting Covid-19 from the frontlines. People across the city — and the country — were united in purpose for the long battle ahead which will call upon all their reserves of patience and fighting spirit.“There can’t be a better way of supporting and thanking all these people who, wiout bothering about their own lives, are tracking or reating patients of the coronavirus. That’s why we all did our share of clapping and cheering. It was a great sight...to see so many people cheering loudly from their terraces. Even bells in nearby temples were ringing so loudly,” said Chitra Jain, a resident of New Friends Colony.Ruchin Garg, who stays on Ramjas Road, Karol Bagh, had a similar experience to share. “The area reverberated with the sound of conch shells. My children too joined me. We were excisted to see so many people actually coming out to express their gratitude,” he said. One spotted a young woman beating a thali, all the while chanting, ‘Go corona, go!’ Another young woman held up a placard which read, ‘Equipment for doctors, nurses’, mixing her applause with concern.Sarika Shukla of Adarsh Nagar, however, cautioned that all this din may have obscured the fact that we have a serious situation on our hands and people need to understand the relevance. “At some places, the beating of thalis and clapping by children went on for a long time. “I think parents should have made them understand the purpose of the exercise.”Karan Khanna, a resident of C Block of Janakpuri, shared her concern. “There’s a reason why a janta curfew was called in the first place, and at many areas, people defeated that purpose by gathering on the streets as they could have done the same thing from their balconies. I hope everyone stays safe and better sense prevails,” he said.At Pocket B and C of Sector A in Vasant Kunj, the thanksgiving started somewhat early. “Tough times are ahead and we need to acknowledge the healthcare professionals who are toiling day and night with great risks,” said Seema Sharma, 31. One could also hear hymns being played on a speaker and some firecrackers going off at a distance.“We should respect life and rejoice. And these events teach us to do so,” said Amit Kumar, a 42-year-old businessman. “We take things for granted and have the luxury to stay at home in these times. The ones fighting for us deserve more than a clap. More than 10 minutes of organised noise.”

Title: Musicians prefer artistic tribute over utensils
Content:
Musician Srija Chakraborty

Kolkata: Inspired by Italy, a group of young musicians chose to sing their favourite songs, play drums, ukulele and guitars from their balconies instead of clapping and clanging utensils at the end of the ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday.

Around 11am, Supriyo Dawn posted on Facebook inviting all musicians on his friend list to sing songs and play musical instruments at 5pm to “thank our heroes and fight this crisis together by staying at home”. Soon, there were many others who commented on his post and shared their will to take part in this initiative in self-quarantine.

Dawn, a Khanna resident, played ‘ Bella Ciao ’, ‘Imagine’ by John Lennon and Bengali song ‘Kotoi rongo dekhi duniyae’ on ukulele and guitar from his balcony. “It is better to sing songs and play musical instruments to pay tribute to our heroes, who are working in these times to save us, instead of clanging utensils,” Dawn said.

Guitarist Abhijit Kundu, a resident of Ultadanga, played ‘Jesu, Joy of Man’s Desiring’ by JS Bach. He said that when he started playing the song on his guitar, neighbours and passersby cheered him to play more. “Italy and other foreign countries have shown us the way. We should follow the government advisories, stay home and spread art to cope with boredom and mental health issues in such a trying time,” Kundu added.

Salt Lake resident Rohan Bakshi, who played drums from his balcony, said, “The idea was to spread art and motivate our neighbours to stay indoors in such a situation. I had asked all my friends, band members in different pockets of the city to pay tribute to the heroes musically, which I feel is a better option than banging utensils.”

Echoing Bakshi, Patuli resident Srija Chakraborty said that music can be a great healer in situations like this. I hope more people stay indoors and take up art and music to get out of boredom.” Chakraborty sang ‘Let it be’ by Beatles while playing the keyboard.

Title: Over 1 lakh Catholics attend online Eucharist mass
Content:
Archbishop Thomas D’Souza held the service from Archbishop House that was streamed live on YouTube

KOLKATA: Nearly one lakh Catholics in the city and some living abroad , attended the Holy Eucharist mass online, read out by Archbishop Thomas D’Souza fromArchbishop House on Park Street. The Archdiocese of Kolkata, which governs Roman Catholic churches in the city, called it an extraordinary measure taken to minimise chances of the spread of the novel coronavirus, which had forced different parishes not to hold individual mass, despite it being the fourth Sunday during Lent.

The 40-minute service was streamed live by the TV channel of the Archdiocese on YouTube from 8am on Sunday so that all parishioners could attend it from their homes. Initially, when Archbishop D’souza’s instructions went out that it would be unsafe to hold Sunday congregations, the community reportedly felt unhappy as they considered the mass during Lent an important religious activity. “We took this step so that all believers could stay at home and pray with the Archbishop as he read out the prayers, focussing on the troubled times and how to ask for grace to help us navigate it,” said vicar general Dominic Gomes . “For many, attending Sunday mass in church is an obligation, but that shouldn’t be the attitude.”

Reading out from Bible, the Archbishop advised people to believe that Jesus was the Shepherd who would lead people from the current crisis unto light and beyond. After the online service was over, congratulatory messages poured in from parishioners of 65 churches. “The online mass was soul-filling. This was so thoughtful of the Archbishop,” said Shipra Goswani, who attends St Patrick’s Church Dum Dum. The vicar general’s brothers, Joseph and Paul Gomes, who live in the US and the UK, attended the online mass with their families. “The service brought us close to Kolkata,” one of them said.

The Church of North India decided to keep all churches and services shut. Bishop Paritosh Canning had earlier suspended church services and with the developing situation, all the 45 member parishes, including St John’s Church and St Paul’s Cathedral, were shut.

Title: Madras HC dismisses petitions challenging collector’s order to desilt waterbodies
Content:
Madras high court

MADURAI: The Madras high court has dismissed a batch of petitions filed by chairpersons of various panchayats who challenged Madurai district collector’s order calling for tenders to desilt waterbodies.

The court observed that these petitions were a direct attempt to scuttle and put an end to the scheme initiated by the collector for the welfare of the people.

The petitioners had challenged the order on the ground that it was the exclusive right of the panchayat to frame schemes, based on resolutions passed by the panchayats.

The petitioners stated that the collector's order was a direct encroachment on the power and financial status of the panchayats.

Hearing the plea, Justice C V Karthikeyan observed that the panchayat chairpersons, who have been elected to do public good, would be expected to join hands with the officials in execution of such work and not to obstruct it.

The judge observed that the petitioners did not question the estimate or whether these waterbodies require desilting and deepening.

“When a decision had been taken for public good and welfare, and it would be sanguine on the part of the panchayats to join hands in this welfare object. The panchayats can pass resolutions to second the objects, but taking efforts to scuttle the objects cannot be appreciated,” the court said.

Observing that this court could not be used to prevent a laudable object being implemented for public welfare, the judge dismissed the petitions.

Title: KMC responds to citizens’ calls, starts special clean-up
Content:
KOLKATA: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation has deployed 10,000 workers for cleaning of streets, hospitals, housing complexes and markets as part of a special cleanliness drive to keep neighbourhoods clean in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak. According to a KMC solid waste management department senior official, the demand for garbage cleaning was growing across the city. The official said the civic body was receiving 50-60 calls every day from various areas, requesting to undertake cleaning operations twice a day.

Waking up to the challenge of keeping the city clean at this crucial juncture, the KMC formed a quick response team to reach any neighbourhood to take up cleaning operations. The department also introduced a special three-shift system last week that will continue till March 31. “We have introduced additional manpower to clean the city even at night. We shall continue the drive till March 31,” another official said.

According to him, frantic calls from some housing complexes in Behala, Garden Reach, Kidderpore , Jadavpur , Ballygunge, Tollygunge, Kankurgachhi, Ultadanga and large areas off EM Bypass had prompted the civic body to divide the quick response team into small groups and send the trained workers to the neighbourhoods where their services were urgently needed.

Mayor Firhad Hakim has instructed the solid waste management officials to arrange for adequate masks, gloves, soap and hand sanitizers for on-ground civic workers. In fact, Hakim has been personally checking whether the conservancy workers are facing any difficulty in conducting the cleanliness drive. “For now, we have sufficient stock of such essential materials needed for the huge task force. But we need to send fresh requisitions to the civic top brass by next seven days,” another senior official said.

Title: Delhi: People ignore lockdown restrictions, vehicles out in large number on roads
Content: NEW DELHI: The capital may be headed for a curfew with Delhi Police beginning to enforce the lockdown meant to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus . On Monday, entry and exit to and from the city through the 151 border points were restricted through strict checking, with those entering Delhi required to show proof of the purpose of visit.At least 8,000 vehicles were turned back from the border posts. Cars on city roads were similarly treated when found to be driving without a specific purpose.In stark contrast to Sunday when the janata curfew turned Delhi into a ghost town of sorts, Monday was a grim reminder of the challenges the government would face in locking down the city. Many people were out in the open. A few traffic jams were even reported in some areas. While public transport like Delhi Metro , buses, autorickshaws and app-based cab services have been prohibited, many people were using their private cars on Monday.Atul Goyal, president of the United Residents Joint Action, an apex body of city RWAs, rued, “After Sunday, people thought that things had normalised. While the situation was under control in many of Delhi’s colonies, some places still saw large gatherings. A complete curfew, as announced by central government, would be the only way to fully implement the lockdown.”Amid all this, police were forced to register an FIR against four people, including an Air India employee, for violating conditions of their home quarantine. They have been charged under the Epidemic Act.Traffic built up at the borders due to the bar on entry, but the cops held meetings with their counterparts in UP and Haryana to provide turnaround facilities to non-destined vehicles being denied permissions to enter Delhi. By noon, thousands of daily wagers were seen walking past the border posts to reach their working destinations in the capital. They were allowed entry in batches of two-three people because of the prevailing Section 144 of CrPC banning the assembly of more than five people.In the morning, police made rounds of the city announcing the new shopping guidelines. Shop owners were asked to ensure that only one customer was present at the counter at a time, the others required to be queued up at a distance. Police also advised children playing on the streets to go indoors. Morning walkers and joggers were similarly asked to head home. Patrols were conducted near popular food hubs to ensure only takeaway services operated.Arun Sharma, a resident of Vasant Vihar in southwest Delhi, said that the inner lanes in his colony appeared to be fairly peaceful on Monday, but saw all sorts of vehicles on the main road when he went to the local market for groceries. “It seemed like it was any other day. It was as if an official lockdown and prohibitory orders weren’t in operation. People appeared to be moving freely,” he said.Himanshu Chhabra, a resident of west Delhi’s Punjabi Bagh, also reported a large number of private vehicles moving around in the locality. “I woke up in the morning and went to the balcony when I heard someone honking continuously. I was surprised to see that everything looked the same as on a regular day. It looked nothing like a lockdown,” Chhabra said. “People don’t care about their health and are still taking things casually. For a place like Delhi, a curfew like the one on Sunday has to be implemented. Only such a measure can force people indoors.”Many like Navneet Singh of Hari Nagar made a conscious choice not to venture into the streets. He had to, however, make a quick dash to the grocery shop to stock up on essentials, especially for the needs of his small child. “The panic is getting to us. A person living in our colony recently returned from Canada and his entire family has been requested not to come out from their house,” Singh said. “Delhi is such a place that even if one person catches the virus, it will affect a huge number of people around him or her.”

Title: Households divided over paid leave for help
Content:
KOLKATA: Paid leave for the blue-collar workforce or the daily grind? The white-collar workforce seems undecided as of now. While some of them feel they can work from home only if their domestic help turn up every day as usual, others are demanding leave for domestic help and drivers without pay-cut. A campaign has started on Facebook to allow temporary or flexible workers to stay at home without losing their pay.

Fossils manager Rupsha Dasgupta , her husband, singer-composer Rupam Islam, and their 10-year-old son Rup have become adept at sweeping floors, washing clothes and doing other household chores over the last three days, ever since the couple decided to let their daily help Kajol and Anita go on paid leave. Their 3BHK South End Park flat may not be sparkling, but it still looks pretty clean.

“Between the three of us, we are managing with the housework quiet well,” said Rupsha. She recently changed her Facebook display picture, puting up the #stayhome frame, said, “To fight covid, we must learn to do without our maids for a while and start doing the chores ourselves to fight covid.” The working mother also feels this is a chance to let kids learn basic housework. “Believe me, Rup is cleaning pretty well,” she said.

Having lived on his own in the past, Islam claimed to be more used to housework than his wife. “Doesn’t make sense if only a section of the community practises and the others are left to fend for themselves,” he said.

Before asking her help Bishakha not to attend work from Thursday, homemaker Sudeshna Basu told her to strictly stay at home. “I told her to tell the other people she works for that she needs to be at home for everyone’s safety. It is not easy doing everything. I am cleaning the house every alternate day. It looks a bit messy, but can’t be helped,” the Shyambazar resident said adding, “Bishakha needs to travel in auto from her Ultadanga home. That’s too risky, I thought.”

Swati Biswas Deb, a doctor at BP Neogi Hospital, started a social media campaign titled, “Will you pay your maids, drivers and househelp if they can’t come to work?” But it hasn’t received everyone’s support.

Purnima Haldar, who works as a domestic help, has not missed a day at five Salt Lake households. Asked about her safety, Haldar said, “Who will do the work if we stay at home?”

Title: Fitness trainers send pointers via WhatsApp
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Stuck at home with all fitness centres — like gyms, cricket camps and football coaching centres — closed, trainers have started sending fitness and training regimens, including videos, to their trainees over WhatsApp .

Head coach of a cricket coaching camp at Naktala in Tollygunge Rahul Deb said he had been making his students wear masks and had fewer trainees from the second week of March. Now that the camp has closed down, he has prepared a fitness chart for his trainees that he is sending via WhatsApp. He has asked them to practise using the chart at home.

“I have made a separate schedule for bowling and batting. Batting schedules range from front-foot defence with or without the ball and holding the bat in one hand and tapping the ball 1,000 times. Bowling schedule involves ball rotation and spot bowling or one- or three-step bowling shadow practice,” said Deb, of Bidhanpally Chhatra Sangha Cricket Academy.

Ex-cricketer and former national selector Sambaran Banerjee, who also runs a cricket coaching centre, stressed that trainees should utilize the time watching cricket and practising shots and bowling techniques at home.

“We closed our camp well in advance to reduce risk. We all need to be calm while dealing with this situation,” Banerjee said.

Major fitness chains in the city are preparing customized regimens for their trainees to make workouts engaging at home. “People are confused. They call me every now to ask what to do. I tell dem we don’t always need machines and tools. We can do a lot with our body weight only to stay in shape,” said Rupam Chakraborty a fitness expert.

Cricket and football coaching camps in the city had started closing down from the beginning of the last week when the nation saw some of the major sporting events, such as the India-South Africa cricket tournament get scrapped, the IPL deferred and the I-league, suspended midway.

“We had closed our practice sessions last Monday. We made provisions for handwash and repeated hygiene maintenance options. We had also divided the students into smaller groups during training. But considering the aggravated situation, we closed down our training sessions. However, we asked our students to continue freehand exercises and knock-&-dodge practises at home or terrace to stay in touch with the game,” said Arijit Majumdar, secretary of Bulan Football and Cricket academy at Vivekananda Park.

Title: Janta curfew works, not Section 144
Content: NAGPUR: The Vidarbha region, including Nagpur city and district, came to standstill on Sunday as citizens observed ‘Janta Curfew’ to stop coronavirus epidemic. There was an peaceful, but also eerie, feeling on the vacant streets as appeal of prime minister Narendra Modi did what action by official machinery could not.The stunning emptiness of the public places during the Janata Curfew was broken for brief moments at 5 pm when citizens started clapping and beating utensils, like bells, as a mark of gratitude for the medical fraternity, civic and police department who are fighting Covid-19 outbreak. Chants at temples and intonations were also heard at many places like Khamla, Sonegaon. A handful spoilsports watered down the genuine emotion of the citizens by bursting crackers and police had to intervene to stop them.During the curfew, actually second day of the lockdown, city police detained 878 persons and registered 35 offences for the violations of orders. Also, 297 persons were challaned at 66 nakabandi points across the city. City police launched the crackdown, under CP BK Upadhyay and Joint CP Ravindra Kadam, on the violators under ‘Operation Lockdown’ which will remain in place till March 31. “There were already fewer people on the road. We had to be strict when required and send back people to home if they did not have any genuine reason to be out,” said Upadhyay.Police had to act tough at Mominpura with the residents not in a mood to stay inside houses. A squad of riot control police (RCP) had to be deployed along with staff from Tehsil police station and headquarters.The Nagpur rural police too had deployed nakabandi at state borders and checkpoints disallowing entry of vehicles or people into Maharashtra without valid reason.City police, in a fresh development, have now declared prohibitory orders between 9 pm on Sunday and 5 am on Monday during which the citizens would have to abstain from gathering at public places or face action. Sources stated the top brass decided to bring in the order to ensure there are no gatherings on the road when end Janata Curfew and an overnight ritual of a community coincided.In city, citizens’ response to Curfew call left the main roads, lanes and highways wearing an unprecedented deserted look with only the cops seen at otherwise busy junctions. Negligible numbers of vehicles and people were found straying onto the road only to be strictly sent back by the police unless they could furnish reasons of emergencies like heading for hospital or pharmacy and so on. Main markets like Kalamna, Cotton market, Kamal chowk and such places remained closed.The locations like Hingna, MIDC and Buti Bori too were found closed with no industries or factories operating.With shops and establishments, including many essential services, closed, the shutdown was one that the city had not seen in the past one decade over any issue. The absence of autos, cabs, buses and Metro, shut as a part of the lockdown declared by the district administration, added to the effect of the complete shutdown.Citizens, apart from co-operating with police at most places, also showed concern for the khaki department personnel who were on the road since early morning. Citizen groups, like residents of Vaishali Nagar, along with some individuals came forward to serve tea, snacks and water to the cops at many places as no outlets or kiosk were open. Some resident groups, like from Bhaldarpura, also were found offering eatables to homeless and beggars.The regular rush at the Outdoor Patients Department and casualties were also much less at Mayo and Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) with crimes and vehicular accidents remaining negligible. The regular rush at Nagpur railway station, Ganeshpeth bus depot and Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar international airport too was absent while security personnel could be seen all day long.In Amravati, barring some essential commodity shops and sporadically moving police or health department vehicles, there was no life to be seen on roads. The public transport too was not seen. Bus stands in Amravati and Badnera wore a deserted look. Main markets at Rajkamal square, Shyam Chowk and other areas remained closed. Similar was the response in all 14 taluka headquarters and towns and villages of the district.In Wardha too, the response to the Janata Curfew was unprecedented. So far, 107 people are under quarantine while 53 are in home quarantine. Not a single person has been found positive in the district. 93-year-old Bhaiyaji Mashankar said he had not seen such a response for a curfew in his life.In Chandrapur too the shutdown was total during the day. However, after beating of claps and utensils at their home at 5 pm, people started stepping out breaking the curfew. The district administration immediately ordered them back by making public announcements that restrictions had been extended till 5 am on Monday. Police was told to intensify the patrolling and force the people back into homes.

Title: Plea for compassionate appointment nixed by Madras HC
Content:
Madras high court

MADURAI: The Madras high court has dismissed a plea of a woman seeking compassionate appointment after her mother, who was working as a sanitary worker, died in 2011.

Justice J Nisha Banu passed the order while hearing the plea moved by P Sathya who sought compassionate appointment after the demise of her mother, Pavunthai. Pavunthai was working as a sanitary worker in Usilampatti municipality in Madurai district . The judge observed that as per the GO passed by the labour and employment department in 1995, time limitation of three years has been fixed for the legal heirs to submit an application for compassionate appointment. Her mother had died in 2011 while she filed an application seeking compassionate appointment in 2013, according to her counsel.

The same was rejected in 2018 on grounds that it was not submitted with three years. The authorities stated that she had submitted her application only in 2017. The judge noted that the petitioner could not produce any proof to show she had submitted an application within three years. Hence, the judge dismissed the petition. “The object being of providing compassionate appointment is to enable the family to get over the financial crisis which it faces at the time of the death of the sole breadwinner. Compassionate appointment cannot be claimed when the crisis is over,” said the judge.

Title: Janta curfew done, Nagpur braces for 9-day lockdown
Content: NAGPUR: After an extremely positive response to janata curfew on Sunday, Nagpurians now have to brace for a nine-day lockdown due to imposition of Section 144 till March 31.Commissioner of police BK Upadhyay said the strategy and deployment of the bandobast would be retained till March 31. “There would be no changes in the plan of action of police till the last day of the lockdown,” he said.Commute by public transport comes to a virtual standstill with the government now upping the ante in the fight against coronavirus . From Monday, no city buses will ply at all thus freezing local commute. Even metro rail has announced suspension of services from Monday till further orders. Private autos and cabs have already been grounded since the district authorities implemented the shutdown. State transport buses too will cease operations till further orders.Indian Railways has already announced shutting down all passenger trains with immediate effect till March 31. Only those trains, which started their journey prior to 4AM on Sunday will run till their last stop. For Nagpur station, Kerala Express arriving on Sunday night, going towards New Delhi, will be the last passenger train to halt till at least March 31. Freight trains will continue to operate as per schedule.Air travel is another sector bracing for the impact as all international arrivals at Nagpur airport have been stopped as per Central government’s directions. Domestic routes will continue to operate though the frequency of flights is likely to be reduced.All private establishments in Nagpur, except those dealing in essential items/services, have been ordered to remain shut till March 31. Only those providing essential services or goods will remain open. But since every such outlet will work with very few workers, Nagpurians are advised to avail their services only in case of emergency. MS Lamba, a petrol pump owner, said, “We too are working at reduced staffing levels. I urge people to fill up the tank completely so they don’t have to worry for quite a few days.”Government and semi-government offices will work with just 5% strength to maintain essential activities from tomorrow. Energy minister Nitin Raut announced physical meter reading won’t be done and an average bill will be generated. No bill payment counters will be open. MSEDCL workers will be on duty to attend to repairs and breakdowns.All religious placed have been requested to close down for public, though daily prayers can be offered by the priests. Gurvinder Singh Dhillon , president of Baba Deep Singh Nagar Gurdwara, said they had shut the langar service. “We will support the government completely and since crowds have to be avoided, langar service has been stopped. We are however thinking of distributing foodgrains to daily wage labourers in the vicinity,” said Dhillon.Industries and other commercial establishments, except those engaged in businesses covered under the essential commodities’ list, are expected to remain shut. Pratap Motwani , secretary of Itwari Grain and Seeds Merchants Association , said the grain traders have been specifically asked by the district administration to keep their establishments open so there is no shortage.Rajesh Chabrani, former director of the agriculture produce marketing committee (APMC) at Kalamna, said firms trading in all other commodities except fruits will continue business. The fruit vendors guild has, however, decided to keep business shut for three days.Industry associations too have decided to keep the manufacturing units closed. Nitin Lonkar of Butibori Manufacturers’ Association said all the units except those engaged in food processing business will remain shut during the lockdown.Bullion traders have decided to extend the closure till Monday. However, the association is yet to take a decision on full lockdown, said a source. Atul Pandey, the former president of Vidarbha Industries Association, said there was no question of cutting workers’ pay for the 15 day period. “I am sure every industrialist will rise to the occasion,” he said.

Title: Homeless people to be taken to shelters
Content:
Aurangabad: The Beed district collector has appealed to people to contact the district administration if they find any homeless or people with disabilities on the streets. The district administration will move them to safe shelters, he said.

In the wake of the lockdown imposed on the district to contain the coronavirus spread, the Beed district administration has realised that people, who end up living on roads due to economic, social or mental conditions, have nowhere to turn to and are vulnerable to the viral threat.

District collector Rahul Rekhawar got to know of a sub-inspector tending to one such homeless person from a photograph taken by a local journalist. Subsequently, Rekhawar made an appeal in which he sought cooperation from the general public asking them to notify about homeless or disabled people. Amid the coronavirus scare, such people face the threat of contracting the infection if they continue to live in public areas, the administration stated.

The municipal councils have arranged for night shelters for such people. Accordingly, the administration will move them to night shelters or mental health facilities where the arrangements of their accommodation, food and sanitation can be done. District social welfare assistant commissioner Sachin Madavi has made the arrangements for the same.

People can call on 7720839155 or 9561840184 and share the information.

Title: Coronavirus in Goa: 8 quarantined after travel with Covid-19 patients
Content: PANAJI/MARGAO: A person who admittedly came in contact with a patient from Mumbai who tested positive for Covid-19, and seven others who travelled on the same flight with a person from Dharwad who also tested positive for the viral infection, have been quarantined at the isolation ward of the TB hospital in Margao, deputy director, health services, Ira Almeida, told TOI “Their swab samples will be taken for testing on Monday,” Almeida said.A bulletin released by the directorate of health services on Sunday evening stated that 17 persons have been home quarantined, while 29 have been placed in the facility at ESI hospital, Margao. Six suspects were in the isolation ward of Goa Medical College (GMC) and hospital, Bambolim and another eight at the isolation ward of the TB hospital in Margao.Laboratory test reports of four Covid-19 suspects have turned out to be negative while the results of six, including four samples sent on Sunday, are still awaited.As many as 257 passengers were screened at the international airport at Dabolim on Sunday.Health minister Vishwajit Rane welcomed state government’s decision to extend the lockdown period by another three days. “ People will be inconvenienced, but it is the need of the hour ,” said Rane.

Title: As city’s buzz tapers off, nature chimes in
Content:
Panaji: The state capital, which otherwise bustles with the commotion of office-goers, traffic and the hum of market activity, was virtually deserted on Sunday owing to social-distancing measures to thwart the potential spread of the novel coronavirus.

However, the silence was offset by the sound of chirping birds, and, for the first time in decades, squirrels and butterflies were seen on Panaji’s otherwise busy streets.

“This seems like the Goa of the pre-Liberation times,” residents said, as they participated in the 14-hour nationwide lockdown.

Clifton Afonso’s family has lived in the heritage quarter of Fontainhas for generations. Located in an extremely busy area with three schools and eateries frequented by tourists, the family has rarely enjoyed the quiet solitude that one would romanticise with the quarter.

There was a shift in this scenario as Sunday’s lockdown materialised.

“We got to spend time with our families and breathe fresh air today. Hearing the birds and enjoying the natural surroundings is a huge contrast from our day-to-day lives. My mother said this takes her back to the time when there was no traffic and the the population was lower,” Afonso said.

Many of the city’s inhabitants had to give the Sunday morning mass a miss. Even the gates of the Don Bosco shrine were kept locked in the morning half to let church-goers know that prayers were suspended.

“We don’t regret missing mass because it’s the need of the hour to avoid gatherings. It is absolutely understandable therefore that the mass was suspended as a precautionary measure against the coronavirus,” a Panaji resident said, adding that he would pray from home instead.

A little ahead, the residents of Mala were cooped up in their homes. The Patto trade centre, which sees people moving about on Sundays as well, wore a deserted look. The solidarity of the city’s inhabitants and professionals was therefore visible.

Transportation was also limited. Buses were stationary at the Panaji bus stand. The yellow and black taxis, motorcycle pilots and rickshaws were not operational, either. The Panaji ferry point was inaccessible as the gates were locked, and the river route closed.

The busy 18th June Road, which sees crowding even at night, resembled a ghost town. For the first time, the adjoining arterial roads had ample parking space.

Heaps of garbage bags lay at nooks and corners of these roads as CCP workers were not working.

The city's roads were near-empty with only a few stray cars and bikes moving around once in a while. The few motorists who were out, were out either looking for food, or a medical store.

While business establishments, grocery stores and most restaurants dropped their shutters for the day, two eateries kept theirs open.

The staff at both these joints said their bosses had asked them to keep the kitchen running for hungry citizens, but advised against letting people sit inside and eat. Only parcels and online orders through Swiggy/Zomato were operational.

While the majority of citizens paid heed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's call for self-isolation and social distancing, a few were seen walking in the market area. These were workers employed at the hole-in-the-wall hotels, who, for the first time since they started working, had a day off to themselves.

Some were seen soaking the sunlight at the Jardin de Garcia Orta, also known as the Panaji municipal garden.

One of them, Vijay Naik, a resident of Mala, reasoned that he neither has a cough or cold and is sitting by himself in the garden, therefore following the social distancing protocol.

“I had read about the curfew in the newspapers. However, I cannot sit indoors for long periods. I had to venture out,” he said.

While he and a few other men sat there rebelling without a cause, birds, insects and rodents from the garden made merry, feasting on fallen berries, scrambling on the roads or merely enjoying the solitude of the space that was free of humans for the first time in decades.

Title: Civic chief heaps praise on 2,145 sanitation workers
Content:
Aurangabad: Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey was full of praise for the solid waste management department, which recorded 100% attendance on Sunday — a day when most citizens were indoors observing the janata curfew.

As many as 30 sanitation inspectors, 115 ward supervisors and 2,000 sanitation workers were on their toes since early morning. They discharged their duty of sweeping the roads and other public places, collecting waste from every household, transporting the waste to garbage depots and processing waste. The sanitation workforce has been put on alert from around two weeks ago, ever since the higher authorities sounded the alarm for coronavirus outbreak in the city.

In the letter written to the head of the solid waste management cell, Nandkishore Bhombe, and addressed to the cleanliness staff, Pandey said that the sanitation workers were the pillar on which the city and the civic body were standing. “We are safe here because you are doing your duty. I know you are doing your job 100%. Hats off to you,” wrote the civic chief adding that they should let him know if they faced any problems.

Sanitation inspector Vishal Kharat said, “The workers are at their jobs on all public holidays and festivals. The appreciation from the civic chief means a lot.”

“The civic body has asked its ward officers, waste collection agency as well as the waste processing agency to ensure the sanitation workers are given masks, gloves and gumboots so that their health is not at risk,” said Bhombe.

Title: Madras HC upheld the acquittal of man charged with murdering grandma
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Dismissing an appeal, Madras high court confirmed the order of the trial court, which acquitted a person on charges of murdering his grandmother over property dispute at Karur in 2008.

The prosecution case is that Selvaraj had picked up a quarrel with his grandmother Veerammal seeking a share in the property on December 25, 2008. Since Veerammal refused to concede to his demand, Selvaraj is alleged to have murdered her on the same day. The Lalapet police registered a case and arrested Selvaraj. The Karur sessions court acquitted Selvaraj in the case in 2010. Challenging the order of the trial court, Subbulakshmi who is the paternal aunt of Selvaraj, filed a revision petition before the Madurai bench of the high court in 2010 and subsequently the revision petition was converted into an appeal in 2018.

Hearing the appeal, a division bench of Justice P N Prakash and B Pugalendhi observed that the case of the prosecution rests on the eye-witnesses – her husband Murugayee , Subbulakshmi, and her husband Thangavel . The judges noted that the trio had filed a partition suit against Veerammal and Selvaraj in 2002 and the same was suppressed by them. The judges noted that only during the cross examination, the defence was able to establish that the trio had filed a partition suit.

The judges also noted that the trial court had the opportunity to see the demeanour of Thangavel, Subbulakshmi and Murugayee and had chosen to discard the testimonies of these three eye-witnesses on the ground that they were not reliable. The facts and circumstances show that they had a better motive to get rid of Veerammal, since they had filed the suit, which was pending as on the date of occurrence. The judges observed that while dealing with an appeal against acquittal, it is well settled that when two views are possible, the view that favours the accused merits acceptance. Hence, the judges dismissed the appeal.

Title: We’ve full supplies: SUMUL Dairy
Content:
SURAT: To stem the tide of panic buying of milk and milk products, the managing director of Surat District Co-operative Milk Producers’ Union Ltd (SUMUL Dairy), S V Chaudhary, issued an audio message to residents of the city assuring them of having stocks full. He said that the dairy is functioning as usual and will continue to supply dairy products in normal mode and implored people not to worry about it. He also asked them not to believe in any rumours.

“I want to assure all our customers that you don't need to worry about milk and other dairy items. All our outlets are working normally and will continue to be operational and customers can buy these dairy products as usual. All our chilling centres too are operational. We ensure that milk supply will continue in the coming days. It has remained with citizen in every calamity in the past and will continue to do so,” he added.

Title: With eateries closed, Amma canteens come to the rescue
Content:
MADURAI: P Selvam, 55, an electrician from South Gate, who resides in a rented room and dependant on roadside eateries, was able to have a hot plate of idli and pongal at the Amma canteen, on Sunday during Janata curfew, as all other eateries in the town were closed.

“The canteen came in handy when all other shops were closed. I would have gone hungry if I did not fine one since I am single and there is no one to look after me,” he said.

Amma canteens run by the Madurai corporation came to rescue of many people like him in the city, especially the homeless and marginalized. They had idly at Rs 1 each and Pongal for Rs 5. For lunch, sambar and curd rice were served at Rs 5 and Rs 3 respectively.

A self help group worker from CMR Road Amma Canteen said, “We sell tiffin worth Rs 800 on most days. This Sunday there was less crowd and sold only of Rs 300. We were prepared only limited food.”

The corporation decided to keep Amma canteens open so that homeless people would not go hungry. There are 12 canteens functioning in the city at Arapalayam, Anaiyur, K Pudur ITI, Gandhipuram , Ramaraya Mandapam , Government Rajaji Hospital , New Ramnad Road, CMR Road, Sundararajapuram Market, Palanganatham, Thiruparankundram Bus Stand and Melavasal near Periyar Bus Stand.

V Mageswari, who had lunch at the Amma canteenat Ramaraya Mandapam said she thought it would have been closed since all other shops were closed.

Title: Docs accused in Tadvi suicide case, get court nod to go home
Content:
Mumbai: In light of the coronavirus pandemic, a sessions court on Saturday granted permission to three doctors accused of abetting the suicide of Dr Payal Tadvi to go their homes across the state. Out on bail, Hema Ahuja, Bhakti Mehare and Ankita Khandelwal told court the owners of their guest houses had told them to vacate in light of the pandemic and they had no homes in the city.

The defence told court the women would travel to their native places by private transport to prevent spread of the virus.

While granting them relief until April 1, the court said it was common knowledge that due to the outbreak of Covid-19, hotels and guest houses are being shut and vacated to avoid spread of the virus.

“Considering the circumstances, it is clear the applicants will have no place to stay in Mumbai. When the entire world is fighting to check the pandemic, it is against human rights to tell the accused to stay in Mumbai despite they not having a place to reside,” the court said.

Tadvi had hanged herself in her hostel room at B Y L Nair Hospital, Mumbai Central, on May 22. While the charge-sheet has been submitted in the case, charges are yet to be framed.

Tadvi’s mother, Abeda Tadvi’s advocate, submitted that the doctors’ pleas were against restrictions of travel imposed by the government. The lawyer said the doctors were recently allowed to travel. The lawyer also submitted that if their travel is advisable, she had no objection.

The judge pointed out due to outbreak, courts were only taking up urgent matters, such as bail, anticipatory bail and remand applications.

Last month, while Ahuja had been allowed to visit her home in Satna from the evening of March 10-18, Warud native Mehare and Ankola native Khandelwal had been granted permission to travel from March 9-16.

Title: Loliem civic body restricts visits
Content:
Poinguinim: Village panchayat of Loliem- Polem has asked people not to visit the panchayat office, beginning Monday, till Thursday, in view of the coronavirus threat.

Sarpanch Shailesh Pagui urged the people of the village to visit the office only for matters of urgent importance. tnn

Title: Bank NPA norms amendment urged
Content:
Surat: Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) has made a representation to Union minister of finance and Reserve Bank of India governor to amend the norms of non-performing asset (NPA) for banks considering the adverse impact of coronavirus on trade and businesses.

SGCCI has suggested the time period in this case be changed to 180 days instead of 90 days and for crop loan non-receipt of realization be increased to three crop seasons instead of existing two. Non receipt of realization from loan against securitization of assets be also increased to 180 days from 90 days, it says, adding that the entire last quarter of current fiscal has got destroyed. TNN

Title: Clergy appeals to Muslims to avoid gathering for prayers
Content: AURANGABAD: The clergy has come forward to urge Muslims not to gather in large numbers at mosques in the country.The appeal comes after administrations in districts issued an advisory asking religious leaders of all communities to stop gatherings for prayers and rituals at religious sites.Muslim leaders cited examples from countries that have asked people to abstain from prayers at mosques.Advocate and preacher Faiz Syed told TOI: “Islam’s holiest sites — Mecca and Madina — have stopped visitors. In addition to this, countries including Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Malaysia, Indonesia and Kuwait, have stopped mass gatherings for prayers in mosques. They have advised people to offer prayers at home.”Senior members of the clergy said mosques across the country, including in Bengaluru, have been closed for prayers. The Saudi government has also called off the Umrah, the mini pilgrimage, including one during the month of Ramazan, for people from across the world.A communique in Urdu, on behalf of district collector Uday Choudhary, which also cited the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad, urged Muslims to avoid gathering at places including mosques. A couple of rulings from the community’s leading clergy has also been cited in the communication to convey the gravity of the situation.Even for Shab-e-Meraj, celebrated by a large number of Muslims, followers have been asked to offer prayers at home.Maulana Mohammed Naseemuddin Miftai, the principal of the Jama Masjid-based Jamia Islamia Kashif-Ul-Uloom — the biggest madrassa in the region — came forward with a public appeal asking Muslims to avoid visiting mosques during the Shab-e-Meraj prayers.“I, along with other religious leaders, appeal to the community members to abstain from gathering at mosques for Shab-e-Meraj and carry out prayers from home. This will help in preventing the spread of this disease,” he said.

Title: People remain indoors, vehicle off roads and markets shut for janta curfew in Odisha
Content: BHUBANESWAR: People from all walks of life remained indoors, vehicles stayed off the roads and business and commercial units kept their shutters down across Odisha in compliance with the countrywide daylong janata curfew and the state government’s week-long lockdown in five districts and nine cities to prevent the spread of coronavirus Chief minister Naveen Patnaik was all praise for the people of Odisha for extending their support to the janata curfew, a clarion call by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to keep Covid-19 at bay. The chief minister expressed his gratitude to the people of Odisha for lending whole-hearted support to the curfew. The CM has also appealed to the people for a similar cooperation for the seven-day lockdown in five districts and nine cities in the state from Sunday, a written statement issued by the state information and public relations department said.The state government also released a video of Naveen clapping and clanging a roti-roller against its board in appreciation of the doctors and others rendering emergency services in this time of crisis. Several bureaucrats, including chief secretary Asit Tripathy, 5-T secretary V K Pandian and police officials also clapped in acknowledgment of the work of the emergency service providers.The effects of janata curfew were visible right from the morning till the night with the roads wearing a deserted look and shops, barring those selling essential commodities, remaining shut across the state.
