Police personnel were deployed in the districts to dissuade people from venturing out of their homes.“We did not receive reports of any untoward incident during the janata curfew and the lockdown. It was incident-free. We are thankful to the people of Odisha for supporting the government in fighting Covid-19,” director general of police Abhay said.In Bhubaneswar, the commissionerate police provided passes to some people, who had come out for emergency work. “Our personnel also helped those in need and stranded on the streets by dropping them to their homes or other destinations. The staff of Khandagiri Police station provided cooked food, free of cost, to passengers stranded at the Baramunda bus stand,” additional commissioner of police Anup Kumar Sahoo said.Odisha Police said the state government’s week-long lockdown in five districts — Khurda , Cuttack, Ganjam, Kendrapada and Angul — and nine cities — Sambalpur , Rourkela, Puri, Jharsuguda, Balasore, Jajpur Road, Jajpur, Bhadrak and Brajrajnagar— will be strictly implemented to contain the spread of Covid-19. Odisha has so far reported two novel coronavirus positive cases.

Title: Janta curfew: Indoreans stand united in isolation
Content: INDORE: Responding to the call of Janata Curfew by PM Narendra Modi , Indoreans on Sunday stood united in isolation against coronavirus pandemic.As the whole city unified against Covid-19 by abstaining from socializing throughout the day, Indoreans expressed gratitude towards on-duty medical staff by sounds of clapping, beating utensils and ringing bells.The whole city bore a deserted look right from the morning. People across the city whole-heartedly supported the Janata Curfew call. However, there were few incidents of adrenaline and emotions taking over. Some city dwellers to express gratitude towards medical staff gathered to make sound at 5pm for around 10 minutes.“Instances of violation of Section 144 are under investigation. We will see what actions can be taken. Police officials dispersed crowds immediately as they reached the spots in the evening,” said DIG Ruchi Vardhan Mishra.At Khajrana Ganesh Mandir, priests blew conch while pandits also rang bells at Mahakal temple in Ujjain. The aim of Janata curfew was to discourage gathering of large number of people at public places.Some over-enthusiasts flocked the streets with dhol in long processions ironically defeating the purpose of Janata Curfew. At Rajwada, a large crowd gathered with dhols to celebrate closure of Janata Curfew. In Patnipura and many pockets, people assembled together at the end of the curfew.Amidst the coronavirus outbreak, Prime Minister had urged people to observe nationwide self-isolation on March 22 from 7am till 9pm calling it as Janata Curfew and later make sound by clapping hands, ringing bells, blowing conch, banging utensils together at 5pm.

Title: Madurai: Good Samaritans help the elderly, stranded passengers
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Idhayam Trust along with the city corporation and the police department came together to rescued around 80 homeless elderly people in the city. Volunteers from the organization led by founder G R Sivakumar gave the homeless a wash and a hair cut. They were also given first aid for injuries and health issues.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that the rescued were accommodated in three night shelters run by the corporation.

C Sudhakar, a resident of KK Nagar, provided snacks and water to police personnel and corporation employees on duty on Sunday. He was going around the city in his car loaded with biscuits, apples and water bottles along with his family members. He said he used to offer food and water during the Chithirai festival, adding such people should be encouraged during such difficult times.

Madurai chapter of Red Cross society along with NDR Vaigai Club and Happy Sunday , a voluntary friends group, distributed food and water to the needy in the city. They went around various spots in the city supplying water and face masks to the elderly and needy. A team consisting M Gopalakrishnan , A Rajkumar from Red Cross and advocate Muthukumar distributed food in various parts including Poonga Murugan temple, railway junction and Puthupalam in Simmakkal.

Volunteers from Masjid Al Bilal Forum based in SS Colony provided free food including chicken biriyani to those who were stranded due to lack of transportation.

Title: Two brothers found dead in Madurai district
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Two brothers were found dead in their house in a village near Vadipatti in Madurai district late on Saturday night. The cause of death is unknown, police said and added that they are investigating all angles.

They were identified as P Vinothkumar , 30, and his brother P Sivakumar, 39, from Neerethan village. They had consumed liquor the whole day on Saturday and were found dead later in the night. The bodies were shifted to Vadipatti government hospital, where postmortem was conducted.

Based on a complaint, a case was registered with the Vadipatti police station under CrPc 174 – suspicious death. Police suspect that they could have died due to food poisoning. However, they have not ruled out foul play and are pursuing all angles in the incident.

A police officer said that Sivakumar got married, while Vinothkumar was a bachelor. The two drank liquor purchased from a Tasmac shop on Saturday noon. They had rasam for lunch and then continued to consume liquor. Their bodies were recovered when other members of the house reached home. Based on an alert, a police team reached the house and conducted an inquiry.

Before death, the duo also had dysentery. The parts from intestine will be sent for lab testing after the postmortem. Based on the lab reports, further inquiry will be conducted, the police officer said.

Title: Goa court extends custody of rape accused
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

MARGAO: A local court extended the police custody of 23-yr-old Melvin Antonio Fernandes , arrested by the Maina-Curtorim police on charges of raping a 13-yr-old girl at Ambaulim , Quepem, by three more days.

He was produced before the court on Sunday on the expiry of his 10-day custody. The survivor , who had sustained injuries on her head and other parts of her body, was on Sunday discharged from the Goa Medical College and hospital, Bambolim. Police sources said that her statement will soon be recorded.

The police had arrested Fernandes, a resident of Moll, Sao Jose de Areal, on charges of abducting and raping the minor.

While the survivor was walking home from school, the accused offered her a lift on his motorcycle, but instead took her to a hillock in distant Ambaulim near Quepem, and raped her.

The accused, police sources said, assaulted her and even banged her head on the ground after she tried to resist his advances. As the victim became unconscious, he abandoned her and fled the scene of the crime.

While his two-wheeler was attached, Fernandes was arrested under sections 363 (kidnapping), 307 (attempt to murder), 376 (rape) of the Indian Penal Code , Section 8 of the Goa Children Act and Section 4 of the Protection of Children against Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act.

Title: Life in the time of lockdown: Web series, ludo & more...
Content:
INDORE: Binge watching web series to playing ludo and carrom, Indoreans struck a balance between the old ways and the new to keep themselves entertained during Janata Curfew on Sunday.

For safety of near and dear ones, Indoreans followed the appeal made by PM and stayed at home while practising a 14-hour self-imposed curfew.

“Since all of my family members were home on Sunday, we decided to binge watch web series. We had made lunch and dinner and then started watching series at 11am and finished it by 8:00pm. None of us stepped out of the house,” said Shivani Wadekar , an IT engineer from Mumbai, who is staying in city and working from home. Similarly, people revisited old traditional games like ludo and carrom and played it with family members. “We went to the store and bought three board games and cards to play on Sunday. I believe that the situation is going to continue and we should have something to keep ourselves entertained,” said Rahul Sharma, professor, resident of Bhanwarkuan.

Societies also encouraged people to stay home by restricting use of common gardens and play areas.

“We had shut our clubhouse and garden since past one week and common doors have also been permanently opened such that people don’t touch the handles while passing through the doors. People followed Janta Curfew in the township religiously,” said Madalsa Vyas, director of a township at Bypass.

Some dog owners claimed that they also trained their pets to use washroom at home to avoid taking them for a walk. “The times are going to be really bad in future and so we should make sure that our pets are trained,” said Shibby Thomas, a student.

Some working locals planned to spring clean their houses to pass time. “I have a full-time help at home but I decided to help her clean the house and cupboards since we had nothing to do on Sunday,” said Himani Victor.

Title: Nagpur Municipal Corporation begins household drive to check Covid-19 cluster patients
Content: NAGPUR: To control Covid-19, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has launched a door-to-door containment drive in areas situated within 3km radius of the homes of four positive patients.The drive will check whether there are any clusters of Covid-19 patients and also whether people on home quarantine are complying with instructions.NMC’s additional medical officer, Dr Bhavna Sonkusre , and assistant medical health officer, Dr Praveen Gantawar , said, “The city recorded four positive patients. The central government has directed us to conduct the containment drive within 3km radius of homes of positive patients. Four positive patients are from Laxmi Nagar and Dharampeth Zones. We may extend the survey up to 5-7km radius covering nearly 90,000 houses in these two zones.”Giving more information regarding the drive, Gantawar said, “Around 260 health staffers have been engaged in the drive. Sixteen teams comprising 26 staffers each have been formed. Two staffers will form a group and visit homes. They have been instructed to keep a one-metre distance from people. The drive is to prevent the spread of Covid-19. We are requesting everybody to cooperate and provide all the necessary information.”The team will ask for the name, address, age, contact number and whether they have come in contact with positive patients or whether they are suffering from fever or any acute respiratory diseases since the last few days. “Teams will also ask whether anyone from the family has visited any foreign country in the recent past,” added Gantawar.Sonkusre said, “The team also comprises of doctors. In case of any suspected patients, we will advice them to go for a check up.”The drive covered 15,000 houses in Bajaj Nagar and Abhyankar Nagar on Sunday. The NMC team is also monitoring the health of over 485 people under home quarantine on a daily basis.Areas like Laxmi Nagar, Swawlambi Nagar, Shankar Nagar, Sneh Nagar, Daga layout etc will be covered in the coming days.Initially, there was some discontent among NMC staffers who were called to the Laxmi Nagar Zone office, but were not informed about the drive. Later, they were given a short training and sent on the job. Wearing masks, all were reportedly trained in a hall and were given forms to be filled up by citizens during the drive. Apart from staffers of health centres, NMC also roped in employees of the malaria and filarial department.On seeing a large gathering of NMC staffers at the Laxmi Nagar Zone office, some residents reportedly alerted the police control room. After checking facts, the cops went back.NMC assistant commissioner Raju Bhivgade said that no complaint was made and neither did the police come to the zone office.Since Covid-19, this is for the first time that a door-to-door survey has been started by the NMC. Till now, only flyers were screened and their samples were tested.

Title: A first: All of Delhi under prohibitory orders
Content:
SARAI KAALE KHAN -TIME -10.45AM-----EMPTY ROADS NEAR INDRAPRASTHA PARK NEAR SHANTI STUPA ON SUNDAY JANTA CURFE... Read More

NEW DELHI: The national capital is entirely under prohibitory orders for the first time. Delhi Police imposed Section 144 of the CrPC from 9pm on Sunday to implement the lockdown necessitated by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The order will remain in force till March 31.

With all of Haryana under Section 144 and Noida and Ghaziabad as well, it means the restrictions that don’t allow five or more people to gather in one place now extend across the vast urban sprawl of Delhi-NCR. Delhi Police will allow no demonstrations, processions, protests or social gatherings. Only shops selling essential commodities such as milk and vegetables will remain open.

“Any gathering — social, cultural, political religious, academic, sports, seminar, conference — is prohibited. Organisation of weekly markets (except for vegetables, fruits and essential commodities), concerts, exhibitions, etc is prohibited. Guided group tours, conducted by various private tour operators, are prohibited,” said the order signed by the Delhi Police chief.

Police have also specified that any individual who has tested positive for Covid-19 or is suspected to have it has to take measures for prevention and stay in home or institutional quarantine. “The person shall co-operate to render assistance or comply with the direction of the surveillance personnel,” said the order. Violations of this are punishable under Section 188 (disobedience of an order duly promulgated by a public servant).

Asked about the impact of the prohibitory orders on the ongoing Citizenship Amendment Act protest at Shaheen Bagh, a police officer said, “We went to the protest site and hardly three to four people were present. If more people gather and violate the order, action will be taken.” Besides, with state borders also being sealed, Delhi Police will keep a check on any vehicle entering the capital. Delhi Police spokesperson Mandeep Singh Randhawa said, “Apart from emergency and essential services, we will prevent all vehicles from entering. If any commuter wishes to enter the city, they would be screened and asked about their urgency to travel before being allowed to enter.”

Police have advised Delhiites to avoid travelling to NCR cities like Gurgaon, Noida, Faridabad and Ghaziabad unless it is for essential work. Vehicles belonging to doctors, army personnel and the media have been exempted from the curbs.

According to the order, police will also not allow any goods carriers except ones carrying food or other essential items. Gurugram police did not issue any orders but police chief Mohammad Akil told TOI people had willingly complied with lockdown and they did not want to put unnecessary restrictions.

Title: Nagpur: Gratitude, appreciation in the air as citizens respond to 5pm call
Content: NAGPUR: The entire city reverberated in the sounds of clapping, utensils clanging, cheering and praying at 5pm from almost all houses, balconies and doors. There were few who did not turn out to express their solidarity and love towards the selfless heroes working tirelessly for humanity during the coronavirus outbreak. Doctors, policemen, house helps, professionals, and media persons all found themselves receiving people’s appreciation and blessings amid the Janata Curfew.Zingabai Takli saw people playing dholaks and banging utensils, while in Ramdaspeth and Manewada people were even bursting crackers.Sadhana Hajare, a homemaker at Rajendra Nagar , Hingna Road, was joined by all other ladies in the locality in the balcony and at their doors. She blew the conch while male members clapped loudly expressing their gratitude towards the selfless workers. “We all blew the conch and also banged utensils, especially children had great fun banging away to glory in excitement,” she said.People at Hanuman Nagar stood barefoot on the footpath, which should have been avoided. Yet, in housing societies at Nandanwan and Sonegaon area, all one could hear was sounds of utensils and sight of people standing in the balconies.Aishwarya Choubey, a law student who resides in Itwari area, said, “People in my society came out on the terrace and started clapping loudly. It felt like India has won the world cup, and we will surely win over this virus. My salute to all the media men, police and unsung heroes of today’s time.”Sangeeta Deshpande, a Kathak teacher in Gandhi Nagar, came up with an innovative idea. She and her daughter distributed an audio clip through social media to all her Kathak students and started dancing and clapping to the beats at around 5pm. “We had an audio clip with a traditional Kathak beat, and we wanted to do it in a unique way, hence we danced and clapped while doing our steps,” she said.Navin Kulkarni, a café owner who stays at Laxmi Nagar, said people were so excited for the 5pm clapping and ringing bells that people even called out his grandparents, who were sleeping, to participate in it. “People in my area woke up my grandparents. People stood in balconies clapping, ringing bells, and also banging utensils,” he said.People also went live on their Instagram handles and were chanting, ‘Go Corona Go’, and also played loud music and danced to the same tune.Beside the usual clapping and ringing, some people also came out with musical instruments such as dholaks, manjeera and conches, which made a loud noise. “Our apartment folks played theme music we all had bells and conch. Some young folks also whistled loudly, and many were live online. It was indeed wonderful. When everyone came together and united to get rid of this fatal ill virus,” said Urmi Chakraborty, a professor.At Pritam Complex in Lakadganj, no balcony was empty as all residents came out and banged utensils, instruments, and clapped. Nachiketa Pandey, a working professional, said, “My brother blew the conch and the bugle in the apartment. We came together to appreciate all the people working day and night in this time,” he said.Madhur Gandhi, a company secretary, gave some glimpse of the situation at New Mankapur. “People played loud music on speakers and burst crackers as a congratulatory gesture to express our gratitude,” he said.Kshipra Banode, a housewife residing at Patrakar Sahniwas on Amravati Road, said, “People were playing manjeera, dholak and what not. It was a sight to behold as people came in unity to support and stand together against the illness,” she said.

Title: Goa: With help from delivery boys, two eateries get food on plates
Content: PANAJI: App-based food delivery personnel found themselves on the front lines doing home deliveries on Sunday as people from within and beyond Panaji stayed indoors as part of the nationwide lock-down. But in all these, the police and some locals had an unsavoury role to play.Even as most restaurants and bars temporarily shut, two Panaji eateries – Navtara and Gastronut - kept their kitchens running for take-outs and home deliveries only. Delivery boys played a vital role in getting food to residents who stayed indoors.“Serving food is of great pride now when there is a lockdown. By not venturing out of their homes despite being hungry, they’re doing us a service. So we have no hesitation in delivering food,” said a delivery boy, Abdul Gani.Aditya Tavora from Navtara said, “We followed the PM’s message to have essential services like home food deliveries running and decided to keep six of ten units open. We only had online deliveries running. Police entered our Porvorim restaurant at 10:30am to shut the kitchen. We spoke to a senior police official who checked with a bureaucrat and were told to shut.”At Siolim, locals abused the restaurant staff and despite food delivery app riders willing to deliver, they said they were scared of being assaulted. Tavora said they finally stopped deliveries by 2pm. He also said that at the Navtara unit at Panaji, the police forcibly pulled shutters down and tore a poster which said only online deliveries were open.“Police are stopping to ask us where we’re going, confirming which restaurant we belong to. Our company asked us to be on duty since they anticipated orders. We started our duties at 8am,” said Krishna Chhetri , another delivery boy. However, app-based delivery service personnel are geared to continue their work in the face of an extended curfew.“We want to serve the people. Even if the curfew goes on for a few weeks, we would still deliver food because we don’t want people to go hungry,” said delivery executive Jaspal Singh.Seven people working for two different food delivery apps were on Sunday detained by Panaji police for a few hours, as they were see loitering around the city.The delivery boys came to Panaji hoping to do good business as they assumed the Janata Curfew would be relaxed by afternoon, police said. They were later released.

Title: Delhi Airport: Domestic flights to operate at IGI Airport, doubts over connectivity
Content: NEW DELHI: Domestic flights will continue to operate to and from the Delhi airport and Indira Gandhi International Airport will not be part of the national capital lockdown announced by the state government. The aviation ministry spokesperson categorically said, “IGIA shall remain functional” on Sunday evening, after the state’s lockdown order said “all domestic/international flights arriving to Delhi during this time shall be suspended”. Schedule international flights in and out of any Indian airport are not allowed till next March 29.However, how passengers, crew and other staffers of airlines, airports and other agencies commute between the airport and their homes/hotels across NCR remains to be seen. As part of lockdown, no public transport services including Delhi Metro, private buses, taxis and auto-rickshaws are allowed to ply. DTC buses will operate at 25% capacity for employees of essential service agencies like DJB, BSES and health department. Delhi’s borders with Haryana and UP are also sealed during the lockdown.The Directorate General of Civil Aviation is going to seek exemption from these restrictions on commute of aviation personnel and passengers between IGIA and their homes/hotels in private cabs. Delhi Police and its traffic wing come under Centre (home ministry) and will play an essential role in making this possible.A standoff is likely as the Delhi government stood by its order issued with the approval of lieutenant governor and reiterated that neither international nor domestic flights would operate in the wake of complete lockdown. Domestic flights operating despite lockdown in Delhi may leave flyers stranded at the airport due to absence of public transport.Airlines have cabs to transport pilots and cabin crew. Other staffers mostly use personal or public transport. “Let us see how many of our required staffers we are able to ferry between the airport and their homes across NCR,” said an official.“We are seeking exemption on Sunday-Monday night itself before the lockdown kicks in to avoid inconvenience to passengers,” said an aviation official.Immediately after the Delhi government order, top levels of aviation ministry went in a huddle. “It was felt that air connectivity, anyway in very limited now and that too to only schedule domestic, is an essential service that needs to continue,” said a senior official. IndiGo, India’s largest domestic airline, is cutting flights within India by 25% due to reduced demand.The Delhi Airport tweeted: “As per the recent directives by DGCA, domestic flights to/from Delhi shall continue to operate as usual.”

Title: Covid-19 scare: Swachh Indore sanitised to the core by civic staff
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

INDORE: The 14-hour long ‘Janta Curfew’ on Sunday gave Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) an opportunity to carry out an extensive sanitisation drive in all areas of city. A team of some 500 staff and officials were pressed into service to carry out the mega sanitisation activity that started from early morning. All major roads, footpaths, ATMs, commercial outlets and parking lots that come in direct contact of people were thoroughly cleaned up and sanitised with the help of disinfectants.

The civic body also took help of two drones for spraying biological sanitiser on landmark areas of all 19 zones such as MY Hospital , high court tri-circle, Regal square, Rajwada, Vijay Nagar , Patnipura, Radisson square and Mhow Naka among others.

IMC additional commissioner Rajneesh Kasera said that the ‘Janta Curfew’ gave them an opportunity to carry out extensive sanitisation drive across city in absence of vehicular and pedestrian movement.

“We had divided the drive in three parts- use of disinfectants like sodium hypochlorite during day hours, spraying of biological sanitiser with help of drones at landmark locations and use of fogging machines in densely populated areas during night hours to maintain hygiene,” he said. “Other tasks like road sweeping and waste collection work also went smoothly in absence of traffic and pedestrian movement,” he added.

IMC health department officials said that the drive will continue in near future to contain Covid-19. “As many as 200 manual sprayers and four tractors were also pressed in service to carry out the drive,” IMC health officer Akhilesh Upadhyay said.

Title: Human skeletal remains unearthed in Konthagai
Content:
MADURAI: The skeletal remains of an ancient human being, believed to be inhabited Keeladi in Sivaganga district , have started surfacing at Konthagai, which is believed to be the burial site of the civilization. It is two kilometers away from Keeladi.

Keeladi has revealed that an ancient civilization thrived on the banks of the Vaigai more than 2,600 years ago. It has long been believed that the habitation at Keeladi may have extended to the neighbouring areas of Konthagai, Manalur and Agaram, as ancient artefacts have also been found there.

Burial urns were discovered at Konthagai even before the excavation began at Keeladi. It is believed that Konthagai was the burial site of Keeladi, where first level and second level burials could have been conducted. Sources at the state archaeology department said that people could have either been directly buried there or those who died elsewhere could have been brought and laid to rest here in the urns.

Madurai Kamaraj University has signed an MoU with the archaeology department to conduct research on the remains, especially bones and other artefacts at the site. The bones were discovered on Saturday. A team from MKU led by vice-chancellor M Krishnan, professor K Balakrishnan from the department of immunology, retired professor Pitchaiappan, deputy director of archaeology Sivanandam, and archaeologists B Asaithambi and Baskaran inspected the site, when the top portion of the skeleton was revealed. It is believed that the remains are of a person who was buried in a seated position. What has been revealed are two hands.

The vice-chancellor said that it would take about three days for the archaeologists to bring out the entire skeleton, which may reveal more details. This is supposed to be the remains of the first level burial. It may be recalled that nearly eight burial urns of various sizes and smaller pots have been discovered at Konthagai, since the excavation started on February 19 this year.

Title: Madurai observes Janata Curfew, residents stay indoors
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: All the shops and commercial establishments remained closed in Madurai to observe the Janata Curfew called on by Prime Minister Narendra Modi as part of precautionary measure for Covid-19. Transportation came to a grinding halt as buses, auto rickshaws and private vehicle stayed off road on Sunday.

Roads and traffic signals wore deserted look as people stayed indoors. There were no cars to be seen on the roads, although a few people used two-wheelers to commute between short distances. People had already stocked essentials like vegetables and grocery items a day before. Bus terminals like Periyar, Arapalayam and Mattuthavan were also found deserted.

A few, who took up travelling, were stuck at Mattuthavani bus terminal. With no shops open to buy water and biscuits, they had to go hungry. After an alert made by TOI, the Madurai Corporation commissioner S Visakan arranged for food for those stuck at the terminal. Zone four sanitation officer Rajkannu brought food from a nearby Amma canteen to feed 35 people. They said they will stay at the terminal until transport department resumes service.

Shanmuga Raja, a native of Nagercoil, was returning home from Bengaluru, where he works in a windfarm. He got stuck at Mattuthavani. He said that he would not mind staying at the terminal if food, water and toilet facility are available. “I booked ticket long back and could not cancel it. I thought I can somehow manage to reach home, if I reached Madurai. But never thought it would be a total shutdown and I would be stranded,” he said.

Some auto rickshaw drivers cashed in on the situation, as they fleeced Rs 300 per person to transport them to Periyar, while a trip itself costs Rs 150 under normal situation. Similarly, auto rickshaw drivers came forward to transport those, who were stranded in terminals to as far as Ramanathapuram, Virudhunagar and Kovilpatti. They charged not less than Rs 1,500 per person.

Police personnel, who were deployed at important junctions and street corners, ensured that people did not wander outside unnecessarily. They stopped people and questioned their need to come out. They sensitized them on the importance of staying at home and asked them to return home.

The corporation utilized Janata Curfew to disinfect public places. Sanitation employees were deployed at Madurai railway junction and bus terminals. They disinfected all public places, hand rails and door handles. Only a few outlets like fuel stations, medical shops, milk booths and hospitals remained opened. Similar situation prevailed in all the districts in southern Tamil Nadu.

Title: Weddings held in low-key manner
Content:
Madurai: While people extended their full cooperation to the Janata Curfew call by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi, weddings that were to be held on Sunday, were held as low key affairs because it was not possible for few people to cancel or postpone it.

As soon as the Prime Minister announced the Janata Curfew for March 22, about 24 families that had planned to conduct weddings on Sunday took the decision to postpone them to a later date. Meanwhile, seven weddings were conducted in the Poonga Murugan temple, which is under the control of the Madurai Corporation at 5 am. The priests had been informed in advance and they came to the temple and conducted the ceremonies one after another. Meanwhile, a bigger ceremony, which had been organized in one of the oldest and biggest halls in Madurai, Raja Muthia Mandram, was conducted in a simple manner. Sources said even the local ministers were expected to participate in this function but it saw a very low attendance on Sunday. Athavan, one of the bridegrooms said that his wedding had been planned as a big ceremony with many rituals and a feast. They were unable to cancel it at the last moment and hence, organized it as a simple ceremony. “The government is doing it for our welfare so we should also co-operate,” he said. In Dindigul, a wedding was conducted with about 50 guests early in the morning and hand sanitizers were distributed to all the guests, who came there. The feast was also reduced to an ordinary meal.

In Tuticorin, a couple Shankar and Sivashankari, had a low key wedding in Kovilpatti with just their parents and a handful of relatives in attendance. They also wore masks as a protective measure. The wedding was planned to be held in the Shiva temple in Tuticorin, but as it was closed, they decided to hold it in a smaller Mariamman temple in Muniasamy puram.

Title: Interstate bus services suspended in Odisha
Content:
Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The state government has intensified restrictions as the week-long lockdown of five districts and nine urban local bodies began on Sunday.

The government has suspended interstate bus services to and from Odisha till next Sunday. Movement of goods carriers will continue as usual.

“Interstate buses coming from other states will not be allowed to move in Odisha after 11 am on Monday. No interstate bus will be allowed to operate to leave the state after the same time,” transport commissioner Sanjeeb Panda informed RTOs in a letter.

The government has constituted a seven-member team of senior bureaucrats headed by water resources secretary Surendra Kumar to ensure smooth movement of essential goods into and within the state. The unit will take immediate action to remove any bottlenecks without waiting for instructions and approvals.

There shall be no restriction on the movement of permitted goods including coal and other minerals. All permitted goods vehicle shall be allowed to move unhindered, said the government’s statement.

The Jharsuguda administration also put Brajrajnagar town under lockdown on the basis of the power given to the district collectors.

Title: Businesses in Marathwada to remain shut till March 31
Content:
Aurangabad: After citizens in all the eight districts of Marathwada observed the janata curfew from 7am to 9pm on Sunday, several district administrations brought in another curfew from 9pm on Sunday to 5am on Monday.

Authorities said that instructions issued previously for two days to all business establishments, except for essential services, to keep their operations closed, would now be in place till March 31. When asked, deputy commissioner of police (zone-I), Aurangabad city, Nikesh Katmode Patil confirmed the extended curfew. “Police are open to register offences against those found violating the extended curfew,” he said.

Roads in the Marathwada region wore a deserted look barring a few stray incidents of people or establishments violating orders. Only police teams and a few ambulances could be spotted on the streets.

Chikalthana police said that a company in its jurisdiction sanctioned leave to its permanent employees and summoned contract workers to work in two shifts. When police reached the plant, the security guard at the gate lied that the unit was closed. Superintendent of Aurangabad rural police Mokshada Patil said, “We have registered an offence against a company in Chikalthana for functioning during the janata curfew.”

In Aurangabad city, authorities went all out to ensure the appeal for janta curfew was honoured. Commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said, “Janta curfew has remained successful due to cooperation of the commoners as well as the business and industrial establishments.” He warned to take strict action against those violating the orders that would be promulgated by the district administration from time to time.

Vehicles, except for those belonging to essential services, have been barred from entering the districts in Marathwada region. “We have set up check posts at all the entry points. If any vehicle even belonging to the essential services fails to carry the necessary sticker, they will not be allowed in any of the districts,” said superintendent of police Harssh Poddar.

He added that 25 offences have been registered so far. The people booked in these offences have been slapped with section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the IPC.

Osmanabad superintendent of police (SP) Raj Tilak Roushan said that four cases had been registered for violating the Janta curfew on Sunday.

Jalna SP S Chaitanya said that while 32 people were booked in 16 offences on Saturday, three cases were registered on Sunday in which 16 people were booked.

Nanded district collector Vipin Itankar imposed section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code, restricting assembly of four or more people in any public place in the district.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Passenger count low like never before
Content: INDORE: Passenger movement to and from city remained low like never before on Sunday with most trains and buses discontinued due to coronavirus threat. All interstate and intercity bus operations were shut, movement of all passenger, express, superfast trains and DEMU including those operating from Indore were also cancelled. Movement of passenger buses was also halted. This gave a hard time to people travelling from nearby districts like Sagar, Guna, Bhopal, or even Ujjain to Indore as their tickets were cancelled last minute. Entry of passengers at Indore and nearby stations and at railways reservation counters were also closed as preventive measure by divisional railway authorities.“All passenger trains including mail and express have been cancelled till March 31 with immediate effect to prevent spread of corona. Railways reservation office and ticket counters will also remain closed during this period,” spokesman with Ratlam division of Western Railway said on Sunday.“A decision in this regard has been taken by railway board,” he added.Some of the airline continued domestic flight operations to and from Indore under strict watch of airport authorities. “Around 20 flights operated to and from Indore while 19 were cancelled by airlines,” said officials. Airport director Aryama Sanyal said that all possible arrangements have been made to ensure safe movement of passengers to and from airport. “We are keeping a close watch on passenger movement with emergency as well as health desk facility available for passengers’ assistance,” she said, adding that they have closed down most commercial outlets on airport premises to control additional pressure of passengers. “We have appealed to passengers not to spread rumours or create panic in case of emergency,” she added. TNN

Title: Nine samples sent for testing negative: Odisha government
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Odisha government heaved a sigh of relief when all nine samples sent for testing for Covid-19 found to be negative on Sunday. With 3,474 foreign-returned people registered with the government till Sunday, the state is on its toes to check the coronavirus outbreak in the state with a slew of preventive and precautionary measures. Two positive cases have been reported from the state so far.“The health condition of the two coronavirus patients is stable. The first patient is undergoing treatment at Capital Hospital and the second one is at AIIMS, Bhubaneswar. Their family members have also been kept in home isolation,” said Subrato Bagchi , government spokesperson on Covid-19. Besides, 28 persons are in isolation wards in different hospitals in the state, he added.In case of the second patient, an official said, 56 persons had came in contact with him. Communication has been made with 53 persons while effort is on to communicate rest three. Nine monitoring teams are working for the purpose, Bagchi added.The state government on Saturday announced lockdown in five districts —Khurda, Cuttack, Ganjam, Kendrapada and Angul and eight major urban centres — Puri, Rourkela, Sambalpur, Jharsuguda, Balasore, Jajpur Road, Jajpur Town and Bhadrak in first phase till March 29. People have been asked to stay indoors and not to come out without any emergency.Expecting people’s cooperation during the lockdown, Bagchi said, “Lord Jagannath experienced lockdown like situation 22 times in the past. This fact indicated that when Lord Jagannath can experience lockdown during emergency or difficult times, we humans must obey the instructions and stay indoors. The chief minister had clearly mentioned that strong action will be taken against those who will violate the instructions during the lockdown.”The state government also imposed restrictions on plying of private vehicles during the lockdown and those want to buy necessary items like grocery or milk should go by walking, a senior officer said.All the sports hostels running under the sports and youth services department have been closed from March 23 to May 5. The inmates will be given food expenses and allowances for this period and paid travelling expenses for safe return to their homes.

Title: Anticipating 3-day break, horticulture corp doubles vegetable order
Content:
Edited_340 words

Panaji: Though essential commodities to be supplied to Goa from other states will continue despite the border control on vehicles, anticipating a three-day break in the coming week, the Goa State Horticulture Corporation Limited (GSHCL) doubled its order for Saturday's supply (which will reach Goa on Sunday) to ensure vegetable availability in the state.

Since the Belagavi market will be closed on Sunday owing to the nationwide janta curfew, the vegetable supply scheduled for Monday morning is suspended. With Tuesday being the weekly market off in Belagavi, followed by Gudi Padwa holiday on Wednesday, the supply stays suspended further for two more days. Hence, GSHCL ordered 200 tonne of vegetables to tackle the situation ahead of the three-day break.

The corporation orders around 100 tonne of vegetables which lasts a few days at the horticulture outlets. Now, the horticulture stores are witnessing panic-buying by consumers owing to which the corporation decided to be prepared.

“Vegetable supply to Goa is not going to be affected since it will be covered under ‘essential commodities and groceries’. We kept most horticulture outlets open on Saturday so that people can come out and purchase for the coming week,” GSHCL managing director Sandeep Faldesai said.

“We constantly keep telling the consumers that there will be no shortage and there is no need to buy in bulk. However, they don’t seem convinced, so we have stocked up double the quantity so that there is no shortage of vegetables at the horticulture outlets in the first half of the coming week,” Faldesai added.

Vendors in the Panaji municipal market, however, are less worried. “We are aware that the supply will be suspended till Wednesday. However, most of our customers have stocked up in bulk due to the janta curfew so that should last them until the first half of the coming week,” Jaffar Mokashi, a vendor said.

“As far as our stores are concerned, we will have fewer vegetables but things will normalise once supply resumes from Thursday onwards,” another vegetable vendor said.

Title: 200-bed medical facility to be set on NCH campus
Content:
Facility to be set up in 72 hours

Surat: Government Medical College (GMC) and New Civil Hospital (NCH) authorities on Saturday began work to set up a 200-bed treatment facility for COVID-19 patients on their campus. Authorities plan to set up the facility in 72 hours as per the instructions of Kishore Kanani , minister of state for health, and Harsh Sanghvi , BJP MLA from Majura constituency. Both the politicians visited the hospital to inspect existing infrastructure on Saturday.

The facility is being developed at the existing 10-storey building, which remains unutilized since its construction. The building was to house a stem cell hospital but barring a few floors it remains incomplete.

"Three floors have complete flooring, plaster and electrification. We are trying to start medical facility for coronavirus patients in 72 hours as per the instructions of the minister and MLA,” GMC dean Jayesh Brahmbhatt said.

"For the medical facility, the project implementation unit that works under the roads and buildings department has been instructed to begin work. We can create 200-bed facility from the existing equipment and furniture in the hospital,” he added.

After receiving authorization to start a testing facility for Covid-19 patients, NCH started a laboratory on its campus on Saturday. Meanwhile, top government officials on Sunday asked SMIMER hospital authorities to develop a 100-bed facility for treatment of coronavirus patients.

Title: Four nodal cops only to attend bail plea hearings
Content:
Coronavirus banner put up on the closed court building gate

Surat: Officials of Surat district and sessions court and police in their efforts at crowd management on Sunday decided to reduce the number of cops who need to remain present during the hearing in bail applications. In a temporary arrangement that has been worked out, four cops appointed as nodal officers will represent the entire city police in different courts during the hearing in the bail applications of accused. Papers and other material relating to bail applications will be sent to the courts concerned by the police stations through email.

Currently during the hearing in the bail applications of accused, three cops from each police station remain present in a court. Their total number comes to 150, sources said.

"The court has tried to reduce crowd on its campus by rescheduling hearings, but for daily matters which include bail applications, policemen have to remain present. This adds to the number of persons on the court campus and in current situation because of coronavirus, it is risky," district government pleader Nayan Sukhadwala said.

"It has been planned that a policeman each from four zones of city police will remain present on behalf of the police stations of a zone assigned to them. The police station concerned will send papers directly to the public prosecutor through email. The papers will be used in the court during hearing," Sukhadwala added.

Police can send important points related to applications and affidavit to the public prosecutor for argument in the court. "In a very important case, the investigation officer can remain present," he added.

"We will immediately start this new arrangement. This is a very good decision and will help reduce number of people on court campus. The courts have already issued directives asking applicants and lawyers to avoid coming to the court campus unless it is very important," city police commissioner R B Brahmbhatt said.

"The courts have already asked police to return the recently issued summons and warrants back to them. The court will issue fresh summons and warrants once the situation becomes normal," Brahmbhatt added.

Title: ‘Caremongering’ in times of corona
Content: NEW DELHI: When Madhavi Juneja reached a gated society in Noida to deliver essentials to a family on Saturday, the colony had already been locked down due to a suspected coronavirus positive patient. Police personnel had surrounded the perimeter, and all the shops in the area were shuttered.“There were a dozen men in orange and black suits, probably from the disaster management team, stationed outside the society. There was also a vehicle meant to transport the suspected patient to the hospital,” the 37-year-old psychotherapist told TOI on Sunday.Juneja is a part of a collective called “caremongers”, who have banded together to “assist” vulnerable people in times of lockdown due to Covid-19. Apart from Noida, they have reached out to people in Jaipur, Gurgaon, Delhi and Bangalore. The group was founded on by 38-year-old Mahita Nagaraj, a digital marketer based in Bengaluru, barely a week ago.“The idea came up because a friend of mine from the UK called me recently to check in on her parents. Hours after I did that, another friend from the US called me with a similar request, which made me realise that there must be hundreds of people in need of assistance,” Nagaraj said.So, she wrote a Facebook post, asking people to get in touch if they needed assistance, and the response was overwhelming. It was then that she decided to start a “helpline”. She made a poster with the message, “Let’s move from scare mongering to care mongering,” and made it public, along with helpline. On the first day, she got over 350 calls. Thereafter, Nagaraj started a Facebook group calling for volunteers and in just two days, 2,000 people had signed up from across India. Juneja was one of them. The group provides assistance to people in four categories: elderly, parents with infants aged below one, people with pre-existing medical conditions and physically challenged individuals. Juneja delivered groceries to a family which was out of milk for their infant. “It took me over two hours to purchase milk and other essentials and to deliver to the destination,” said Juneja. She wasn’t allowed inside the society, but she left the items with the security personnel and the family collected it from there. “When Ispoke to the family, they kept thanking me. But for me, the idea is to be there for each other. As a mother of two, I understand it can be very difficult to live in a lockdown, especially with an infant,” she said.Another volunteer, Aishwarya Subramanian, offered to drop off food items on her bicycle to the “elderly” in Bengaluru on March 20. Her post received over 5,000 tweets and over 20,000 likes. Aishwarya has since joined the caremongers Facebook group.In Punjab , Mohit, a young professional circulated a similar message on his social media handles. “Hello folks, if your elderly parent or relatives live in Chandigarh/Mohali/ Panchkula and need help with groceries, medicine or any other supplies, please feel free to call me. I’ll purchase them and drop them at their home,” he wrote in a message, along with his phone number. The post went viral on WhatsApp as well as other platforms. “I think caremongering as a concept started in Canada, where a group of people came together to provide essential services. It was also meant to counter scaremongering that had become common during the crisis. I thought it was apt to use it here in the current scenario,” Nagaraj said. As Aishwarya put it, the idea is to “make the world a little less lonely for people right now”.

Title: Staying At Home To Keep Corona Out
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Empty streets and roads famous for traffic snarls with no vehicle in sight. Large stretches of shops and markets closed. Offices, educational institutions in city shut. These were the scenes of Visakhapatnam on janata curfew on Sunday.

As people observed the self-imposed curfew in a bid to arrest the spread of Covid-19, they spent time with family, watched films that have been in the watch-list for long, shared meals while maintaining hygienic distance and practiced yoga. Some, finally even picked up a book.

On the other hand, there were many who decided to spend the day trying to help people at this time of need. Students and others joined hands (not literally) and made hand sanitizers and masks for people who need it, but have not been able to procure.

Four students who run a start-up called ROHA Biotech prepared 150 sanitizers and distributed it among traffic police personnel, GVMC sanitation workers, fruit vendors and auto-rickshaw drivers.

Vivek, one such student said, “People need to avoid crowded areas including long queues in medical stores. After we distributed sanitizers to people in public places, we got a call from an old-age home to prepare 5liters of sanitizer. We are following WHO norms in making sanitizers.”

Ravikanth Reddy of Fluentgrid said, “Sanitizers are being sold at exorbitant rates. Hence, we made 25litres of sanitizers for office staff and distributed it.”

Meanwhile, NGOs who work in the city took strides towards working remotely. Chandra Mohan Pasari, member of Junior Chamber International (JCI) said, “We had a training session on how to organise virtual meetings. Over 45 people connected. We learnt a lot of things.”

Many also took their old dusty indoor game sets and settled down to play with family. Bhavesh Kumar, a college student said, “My entire family loves to play carom. However, we haven’t played together in years. Janata Curfew gave us an opportunity.” Anjali Dange, on the other hand, decided to enjoy the leisure without being pressed for time.

Title: 120 passenger trains passing through Vizag to go off track
Content: Visakhapatnam: The Union government announced on Sunday that all passenger rail services across the nation have been suspended till March 31 as part of efforts to combat Covid-19 A total of 120 trains that pass through Visakhapatnam would go off the tracks. A number of trains had been withdrawn from Friday itself.A spokesperson of the Waltair railway division informed that while goods trains will keep running there will be no movement of passenger trains.The spokesperson further said that the Waltair division has already incurred a loss of Rs 4 crore and the division would lose Rs 1.5 crore every day till March 31.“Overall, the division will incur a loss of Rs 30 crore due to suspension of passenger services to combat Covid-19 pandemic,” the railway officer said.The railways have already started refunding ticket amounts for cancelled trains.Arrangements are also being made to facilitate hassle-free refunds. Refunds will be applicable to trains cancelled between March 21 and June 21.In case a train is not cancelled, but it is the passenger who seeks to cancel the journey, the passenger can apply for a ticket deposit receipt. Railway authorities in Visakhapatnam would close the entrance and exit to the railway station from Monday night.The sanitation department of railways would take control of the station. Authorities will carry on works like cleaning of tracks and washrooms.

Title: Vizagites meet on social media during curfew
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The janata curfew and the advice of social distancing have made people more active on social media. At this moment of a global crisis, social media has emerged as the place where people can connect on information about the crisis as well as organise.

With offices locked down and people working from home, residents of Visakhapatnam are spending their urge to socialise by chatting on social media, organising group video conferences for fun and even writing poetry or singing and posting it on groups.

N Ramachandra Reddy, one such active social media organiser said that his group is trying to spread awareness about the infection and is also organising activities around the PM’s call to appreciate health workers, cops and those in essential services.

Ch Adinarayana, DCP (traffic) said that the curfew got 100% response from people. He informed that 450 cops were pressed into service.

Title: CII suggests ways to boost economy
Content: Visakhapatnam: The global spread of Covid-19 might well send the world into a global recession. Policymakers around the world are devising measures to fight the slowdown. India, which was already facing growth deceleration, the impact of Covid-19 is likely to pull it down further in the fourth quarter.In this context, Chandrajit Banerjee, director general of CII (Confederation Of Indian Industry) said, “Fiscal and monetary stimulus measures need to be announced urgently.”According to Banerjee, first, the government may consider a strong fiscal stimulus to the extent of 1 per cent of GDP. Second, in order to improve market sentiments which are witnessing extreme volatility, the government may consider long-term capital gains tax of 10% and fixing total dividend distribution tax at 25%.Third, GST payments should be on collection of bills rather than raising invoices. he CII director general further said that the RBI may consider relaxing NPA (non-performing asset) recognition norms.

Title: Doctors perplexed as patients in quarantine throw tantrums
Content: Visakhapatnam: While both state and Union governments are intent on checking the spread of Covid-19 by sending all foreign returnees and suspected cases into quarantine and isolation wards, doctors are perplexed with people seeking facilities of a high-end hotel at a hospital or quarantine camp.As per data provided by the district administration, 22 people have been kept in quarantine wards of Visakha Institute of Medical Sciences (VIMS), while 12 people who are being treated as suspected cases in isolation wards of Government Hospital for Chest and Communicable Diseases (GHCCF). Many of these people in isolation wards are foreigners or non-resident Indians (NRIs).Narrating the situation with patients in quarantine and isolation wards, a senior doctor of a government hospital said, “The initial tendency of patients, especially those with foreign connections, is to somehow escape quarantine and leave the hospital. Recently, a US-based woman doctor threw a tantrum because of a four-minute delay in receiving lunch.”“They are somehow in a stage of anxiety and stress, but the moment her report came out negative, her demeanour changed and she felt sorry for her behaviour,” related the doctor.The doctor also spoke of another incident where the authorities had to warn a Belgian national of police action because he was trying to leave the hospital before his test results arrived.In order to help them bide their time while waiting for test results, people in quarantine and in isolation wards have been provided with free Wi-Fi, books and have also been provided with smartphones.Moreover, those with family in the city have been allowed to let their family members bring food in sealed disposable containers. The relatives have to submit the food with staff guarding the entrance to the wards.Doctors pointed out that they are facing a scarcity of grade-IV staff as many are refusing to clean the wards apprehending risk to their lives.

Title: Crew operating flights to corona hotspots being ostracised, says Air India
Content: NEW DELHI: Minutes after 5pm on Sunday, when all of India clapped to thank corona warriors like Air India crew operating flights to bring back Indians stranded in Wuhan and Iran and others in the frontline of this war, AI sent an emotional appeal to neighbours of its crew members to stop “ostracising” them. The airline said resident welfare associations (RWAs) of crew who operated special flights to fly Indians stranded in corona hotspots like Wuhan, Italy and Japan are “obstructing them from performing their duty or even calling in the police, simply because the crew travelled abroad in the course of their duty.”AI has said it is following all precautions to ensure safety of everyone — crew and passengers on these flights — by proving the required personal protective equipment. It may be noted AI is the only Indian carrier that has operated special flights to bring back stranded Indian from China, Italy and Japan. “We do not get our salary on time. We do not know when we will get it either. We do not think about ourselves whenever being called to fly to war zones and now corona hotspots to evacuate Indians. Our salary, which for months has not come on time, is being deducted and on top of this we are facing this ostracisation from our neighbours and RWAs. We are humans, don’t break us,” said a crew member on condition of anonymity.Given the extent of the issue, AI issued a statement Sunday saying: “..it is alarming to note that in many localities, vigilante resident welfare associations and neighbours have started ostracising the crew, obstructing them from performing their duty or even calling in the police, simply because the crew travelled abroad in the course of their duty. These vigilantes have conveniently forgotten that many a spouse, parent, sibling child and near and dear one have been brought home safe and secure from affected countries thanks to the heroic efforts of these Air India crew.”“We would like to appeal to all concerned, particularly the law enforcement agencies, to ensure that our crew are treated with the courtesy, respect and freedom that every citizen of this country deserves especially in light of the fact of their having undertaken flight duties to affected countries to bring back Indian citizens,” the statement added.AI has reiterated it is taking all possible “precaution to ensure the safety of its crew and protect their well-being for each and every fight they have undertaken to fly to cities affected with Covid-19 with all essential and non-essential measures to arrest the spread of coronavirus amongst crew and passengers.”The Maharaja ensures sufficient quantity of hand sanitisers, gloves and masks for crew and passengers are on board. Crew members coming to India from affected cities are sent on home quarantine and also to designated hospitals for check-up as part of the protocol. Hazmat suits are also placed in the cockpit for use in aircraft by crew in the event of any suspect corona case being on board.

Title: India has issued unique ID cards to just 32L of its 2.7cr disabled
Content:
NEW DELHI: Around 32.38 lakh unique disability identity (UDID) cards have been issued by the central government across 682 districts, as per data shared by the department of empowerment of persons with disabilities (DEPwD) with the parliamentary standing committee on social justice and empowerment. The committee gave its report to Parliament earlier this month.

The 31-member committee chaired by BJP ’s Rama Devi noted that the performance of some states was quite poor. West Bengal was highlighted where just four cards were issued against the Rs 23 lakh released under the project. The committee also pointed out that many states, like Bihar , Assam , Telangana , Tripura and Andhra Pradesh, did not receive any funds till 2018-19.

Data from 2016-17 to 2019-20 showed that UDID cards were issued to 32,38,703 disabled persons. Given that the 2011 Census put the number of disabled people at 2.68 crore, a significantly large number of disabled persons is yet to be covered by the UDID project. After West Bengal, those with very few cards issued included Dadra and Nagar Haveli (25), Lakshadweep (27), Goa (78), Nagaland (204), Sikkim (369), Arunachal Pradesh (584), Daman & Diu (742), Manipur (734) and Delhi (918). The maximum number of cards have been issued in Telangana (4,77,106) followed by Madhya Pradesh (3,57,167) and Andhra Pradesh (3,49,300).

The UDID project was initiated by the government to create a national database of persons with disabilities and also for the purpose of issuance of UDID cards which would be valid throughout the country. The DEPwD told the standing committee that all states/UTs have started implementing the project.

The department told the committee that data of 1.5 crore legacy certificates issued by states had been taken on board in the Unique Identification Cards System, an online portal. It was pointed that states were not re-validating those certificates because of which people had to go to the CMO again.

To overcome this, the DEPwD has asked states to upload the re-validated certificate to generate a UDID card and medical examination would be required only for newer disabilities listed in the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016. “Even for that, the procedure has been streamlined and norms for constitution of medical teams have been relaxed,” the panel said.

The department said it had given webcam, computer and online password to every CMO so that there was no delay in uploading legacy certificates. For newer disabilities, a team of doctors is required to enable certification. In such cases, the central government has said if a state does not have enough doctors, they could empanel private doctors or take doctors from other states.

Title: Curfew shows vehicles, commercial activities make Delhi’s air toxic
Content:
Deserted view of a road in New Delhi after the lockdown announced by Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal amid COVID... Read More

Nagpur: The novel coronavirus outbreak-related lockdown has reinforced the fact that transport sector, commercial activities and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are majorly responsible for the toxicity in New Delhi’s air, say scientists. They feel that a review needs to be done on the source contribution aspect of ambient air pollution, including contribution of stubble burning on the Capital’s air crisis.

Stating that air pollution levels have improved following the lockdown, senior principal scientist Padma Rao, of CSIR National Environmental Engineering Research Institute’s (Neeri) air pollution control division, said: “Before the lockdown, the pollution levels in Delhi were high in spite of no significant stubble burning. A one-day lockdown brought significant reduction in the pollution, implying that transport, commercial and small medium-scale industrial activities are mostly responsible and need regulation.”

Rao added that contribution of re-suspended road dust as part of vehicular movement also needs to be reviewed. “During next few days of lockdown we may obtain some more data of city’s improved air quality say scientists,” she said.

TOI analysed the data of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) which revealed that in many areas of New Delhi, levels of particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and carbon monoxide (CO) plummeted drastically, thereby improving the overall Air Quality Index (AQI).

For instance in Mundka, the level of NO2 went as high as 119 micrograms per cubic metre (mpcm) on the night of March 20. The next night too, the NO2 level reached 87 mpcm. However, following the lockdown, the pollutant’s levels nearly reduced to half and was 49 mpcm on Sunday night.

The CO level too saw a similar fall post the janata curfew. From 243 mpcm on March 21, Mundka’s AQI dropped to 119 mpcm after the lockdown.

Most of the other areas witnessed a similar trend of reduction in pollutants. In Ashok Vihar, the levels of CO were 124 mpcm and 105 mpcm on the nights of March 20 and 21, respectively. However, post the lockdown, level of the toxic gas went down to 43 mpcm on the night of March 22. The AQI of the area, which was mostly close to or above 200 mpcm, reduced to 128 mpcm post the curfew.

Air quality monitoring stations at other areas including Anand Vihar, ITO, Jahangirpuri, Lodhi Road etc recorded a similar improvement in the air quality levels.

“The shutting down of transport sector along with other non-essential activities has brought enormous decline in NO2, CO and particulate matter which are majorly emitted from vehicles and fuel burning. The curfew has been a blessing in disguise for Delhi as we can now define the pie of source contribution,” said Rao.

The senior scientist further suggested that at time of emergency and health crisis, the government can introduce such lockdowns to curb air pollution. “Major reforms are needed in transport sector to improve Delhi’s air. Alternate options like use of electric/ CNG/ Clean fuel etc for commercial vehicles will prove to be effective. Apart from this, transition towards BS-VI standard, rationalization of use of cars, improved signalling and traffic decongestion will help in significant reduction of pollution,” said Rao, adding that use of public transport should be encouraged.

The scientist also stated that more information on air quality data of coming days of lockdown will throw major insights on air pollution mitigation, thus providing inputs in streamlining the action plans.

Title: Joggers, walkers avoid parks and gardens, prefer exercise indoors
Content: Hubballi: Although Prime Minister Narendra Modi sought the voluntary cooperation of the people for the ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday, fear appeared to have kept many people from otherwise popular public spaces such as parks and gardens in Hubballi-Dharwad. Joggers and walkers were near permanent fixtures in the morning and evening at Indira Glass House, Nrupatunga Hills, Unkal Lake, Tolanakere, Sadhanakeri and Kelageri Lake, among other lungspaces in the twin cities. However, fears over contracting the novel coronavirus or Covid-19 has kept a bulk of them away, resulting in these lush green spaces losing some of their sheen.Forced to shun gardens and parks, joggers and walkers are contenting themselves with strolls on their terraces, or strolling the periphery of their homes. Unsurprisingly, treadmills are in demand, with people refusing to abandon their physical regimen. But there are many with pre-existing conditions such as diabetes worried about keeping themselves in good shape in times such as these.Sharanappa Kotigi, a social worker in Lingaraj Nagar, said that he had not stopped going to the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC) Garden near Adarsh College. “I go for a walk between 6.30am and 7am, and there would be around 30 people strolling with me. Now, there are hardly three or four people in the park. But I simply cannot stop taking a walk in the morning, and I have put my faith in God, and will continue to visit the garden,” said Kotigi.On the other hand, Sunil Nalavade, an activist, said that he had stopped visiting Indira Glass House for his daily stroll. “I have started walking along the roads of my locality. Of course, I miss the company of friends I had made at the Indira Glass House, but it is impossible to keep a safe distance while strolling there. But we are staying in touch via online chatting,” Nalavade said.General secretary of the Nrupatunga Betta Vayuviharigala Sangha Siddu Mogalishettar admitted to a marked decline in the number of regular strollers at the Nrupatunga Hills. “The thing is, the garden at Nrupatunga Hills is vast, and it will not be very hard for people to keep themselves at a safe distance from others. With gymnasiums having been closed, many people are coming to this garden. But it is good to see that all visitors to the garden, including the children, are wearing masks,” Mogalishettar said.Raju Habib, a businessman in Old Hubballi, said that he had taken to strolling on the terrace of his home instead of his regular walks at the neighbourhood park. “But it is not as enjoyable. So I am mulling over buying a treadmill soon,” Habib said.Ottilie Anbun Kumar, another activist in Dharwad, said that he had started doing yoga at home, and had taken to walking at a nearby farm, after he decided against walking at the Botanical Garden at Karnatak University.

Title: Containment orders clamped within 3km radius of Hosayallapur
Content: Dharwad: Amid rising panic levels over the spread of the novel coronavirus or Covid-19 , the residents of Dharwad district on Sunday woke up to the distressing news of its first case. Dharwad deputy commissioner Deepa Cholan on Sunday confirmed that a 33-year-old man in Dharwad had tested positive for Covid-19, the 21st in Karnataka. The Hosayallapur resident had arrived in Dharwad March 13.Doctors at a private nursing home where he was admitted after he complained of illness alerted officials in the health department when he started to display symptoms of Covid-19. He was subsequently shifted to the isolation ward at the Karnataka Institute of Medical Sciences in Hubballi. The report of his medical tests came through on Sunday, confirming that he was infected.The district administration wasted little time in pulling all stops to contain the spread of Covid-19. Within hours of getting the result of the test, the district administration sealed all areas within a three-kilometre radius of Hosayallapur in Old Dharwad.The residents have been strictly asked not to venture outside their home until further notice from the district administration, in addition to being asked to keep their homes and surroundings spick and span. The district administration has barred any assembly or congregation of more than five individuals, while sporting events, cultural activities and weddings have also been banned. However, the district administration is allowing the free movement of essential goods such as vegetables and milk.Ban on entry of vehiclesDharwad deputy commissioner Deepa Cholan said that, in pursuance of the steps taken to contain the outbreak of Covid-19, said that entry of all vehicles from Goa and Maharashtra to the district had been prohibited till March 31.Deepa further said that the Hubballi-Dharwad Bus Rapid Transit System (BRTS) services had been suspended, as were operations of the Bendre buses between Hubballi and Dharwad.HDMC staff have been directed to spray sodium hypochlorite on vehicles passing through checkposts at Nuggikeri and Kelgeri, Deepa added. “In fact, the chemical is being sprayed in various commercial areas such as markets and other densely populated areas across the twin cities. We are ensuring that all citizens are being subjected to thermal scanning at checkposts. We are also sanitising the whole of Hosayallapur,” Deepa said.Five test negativeOf the 10 samples sent for medical examination, the results of five have been returned as negative, while patient from Hosayallapur tested positive. The district administration is awaiting the results of the four other samples.

Title: Sounds of silence echo on the streets of Hubballi
Content: Hubballi: Silence echoed along the vast sweeping distances of roads in Hubballi, as most people chose to stay indoors on Sunday respecting the call of ‘ Janata Curfew ’ issued by Prime Minister Narendta Modi to help contain the spread of novel coronavirus or Covid-19 Business more or less ground to a halt in Hubballi, with most shops barring those dealing in essential goods remained open in the city. While most petrol bunks stayed shut across the city, the few that chose to function on Sunday registered little to no business. Most arterial roads in Hubballi, where the bustle of activity is often heard before it is seen, were silent. However, this calm was pierced in some places by some youngsters taking selfies with empty streets in the backdrop, while some could be seen huddled in clusters in front of shut shops.Interestingly, police vehicles too remained off the roads, for the most part. Police personnel, were, however, deployed in small numbers in ‘sensitive’ areas to prevent anti-social elements and miscreants from abusing the ‘curfew’ as a window for crime. While North West Karnataka Road Transport Corporation (NWKRTC) suspended its operations for the entire day, the number of local buses that functioned in Hubballi was not many. Similarly, autos and taxis too stayed off the roads.Sushmita Toshikani, an optometrist, said that the curfew had afforded her family a great chance to spend some time with one another, since all members were seldom home together. “My father works in Hescom and he often had to attend emergencies even on Sunday. After a very long time, we spent some quality time with each other,” said Sushma.Meanwhile, Sanju Thakur enjoyed the calm silence that made regularly inaudible sounds such as the chirping of birds and the rustle of leaves on a tree vividly clear. He was not alone. Many residents in Hubballi were greeted in the morning by the cooing of sparrows and other birds, with no man-made noises to drown out the sounds of nature.The usually chaotic Koppikar Road too was completely silent on Sunday, a perfect indicator of the success of Narendra Modi ’s ‘Janata Curfew’.

Title: More Indians brought back home before flight ban
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The government has brought back 400 people from Singapore and 250 from Amsterdam — all transit passengers — in the last few days. India is still trying to bring back stranded passengers from Malaysia and London , official sources said.

In the past couple of days, India has had to bring back hundreds of transit passengers stranded in different airports around the world, as different countries, including India, imposed travel bans. While this has been an enormous logistics exercise, it has also resulted in enormous hardships for passengers who have endured hours-long wait at Indian airports for screening, blood tests etc before going home or on an isolation routine.

“There may be many people returning from abroad who would be feeling inconvenienced. Officers and employees are putting in hours and days of work to make their safe return possible,” a government source said.

Getting back transit passengers is different from bringing back people from high risk areas. The government has also been running special flights from Iran and Italy after testing passengers for the virus.

Foreign minister S Jaishankar and foreign secretary Harsh Vardhan Shringla have been holding video conferences with Indian heads of missions in different regions. The government’s message is that Indian missions have to be more responsive to the concerns of Indian nationals stranded in different cities and airports.

The MEA has been working overtime to facilitate bringing back stranded Indians. The government has stopped all commercial flights to India from March 21.

Title: Medical team at forefront of fight against the coronavirus
Content:
Representative Image

MUMBAI: A team of 137 doctors which has been at the forefront for the last 20 days to welcome thousands of passengers arriving from Covid-19-affected countries found Sunday a bit relaxing as only two flights landed at the city airport.

This team of doctors has been dealing with passengers flying into the country, including those who could possibly be affected.

These doctors, most of them interns from the civic-run Sion, Nair and KEM hospitals, had to convince their family members and relatives who were concerned about their safety. They have been posted on duty at the airport to examine every passenger arriving at the airport.

BMC’s deputy executive health officer Dr Santosh Revankar was heading the team of doctors and 24 counsellors who deployed at the airport in three shifts.

Dr Revankar said that the relatives of the interns as well as several of his own friends and acquaintances kept calling him to enquire about the situation prevailing at the airport. “Even my family members would keep calling to ask about messages circulating on WhatsApp. I only advised them to avoid reading such messages or watching videos as these only end up creating unnecessary panic.”

The medical team had a tough time over the last week especially as some unscheduled flights also landed at the city airport, adding their workload, said Dr Revankar. He added, “But we ensured passengers that their screening would be done between within 25 seconds to ensure minimum waiting period. Sometimes, multiple flights landed one after another, thereby increasing sudden load at the screening counters.”

Although they suggested that passenge give their details so that it can be easily available with the doctor. But many labourers returning from the Middle East had a difficult time filling up forms after which airport operators asked to arrange few men for assistance.

After medical clearance, the passengers were counselled. Suspect cases were immediately shift them to Kasturba Hospital. Senior citizens were taken to Seven Hills Hospital for quarantine and the rest were recommended self-quarantine.

Revankar said, “Sometimes we didn’t get proper sleep. We were so occupied with the work, there was no fear in our mind. What guided and inspired, “’Ours is not to question why, ours is to do and die’.”

Title: Mumbai: 15 who escaped quarantine camp brought back, stamped flyers breaking ‘home-quarantine’ warned
Content:
Representative Image

MUMBAI: Fifteen men who ran out of the quarantine facility after landing in the city from Dubai were tracked down and taken back on Sunday. The men, who hail from Punjab, had been stamped for quarantine. They left the quarantine camp, boarded a local train from Andheri and travelled to Khar when they were tracked.

The state ministry has directed concerned agencies to keep a track of all the flyers stamped with self-quarantine, and to check whether they were following instructions.

A team comprising of the Mumbai collector, civic officials and police were kept on alert after learning that 15 people had been reported missing from the quarantine facility on Sunday.
