Though no positive case has been reported from Dakshina Kannada, the district faces restrictions as a man from Bhatkal (Uttara Kannada district) tested positive had arrived in Mangaluru from Dubai on March 19. Three fresh cases were from Bengaluru, and one each from Chikkaballapura, Dharwad and Uttara Kannada districts.Essential services — pharmacies and grocery shops — will remain open. Industry has been told to operate with 50% staff strength; IT and BT firms will opt for work from home wherever possible.After chairing a meeting of the task force, chief minister BS Yediyurappa appealed to the people to cooperate with the government to ensure peaceful closure of borders. Four of Karnataka’s six neighbours had closed borders. Andhra Pradesh and Telangana were allowing people across the border.

Title: ‘Oil windfall can fund income support’
Content: NEW DELHI: The government should use the gains from a sharp slide in global crude prices to fund measures to combat the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic — key among them being cash transfers to the worst hit people, top economists have said.“Fortuitously, the coronavirus crisis has coincided with a sharp decline in oil prices (more than 30% since March 1). Given its vast imports, India gains $15 billion for each $10-per-barrel decline in oil price. With the price declining from the average of $65 per barrel to $30 per barrel, India gains approximately $50 billion,” said Arvind Panagariya, former NITI Aayog vice-chairman and Columbia University professor.“Even if half of this is converted into revenues via higher excise tax, the government will have enough extra revenue to finance extra spending. So, the government can and should stay within its 3.5% fiscal deficit target,” said Panagariya.Some economists expect the deficit to widen beyond the target and agreed with the view to use the gains from the crude oil price slide to help cushion the economy. The pandemic has come at a time when the economy is already in the grips of a slowdown. Sluggish revenues as a result of the slowdown will weigh heavily on any effort to stimulate the economy.“Even without the impact of Covid-19, the fiscal deficit in the current year would have been higher than what was indicated in the Budget. With the impact of the virus in terms of additional expenditure for prevention, testing and healthcare, the deficit will go up further. Thus, the scope for additional stimulus is limited,” said C Rangarajan, former RBI governor and former chairman, Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister.“At best, one can think of the additional stimulus being equal to what the government will collect as a result of additional excise duty imposed on petroleum products,” Rangarajan said.Several state governments are contemplating measures to shield people from the devastating impact of the coronavirus outbreak (see box) . “The compensation should come out of the windfall gain that the government has got from free fall of crude prices. No extra fiscal stimulus,” said Ashok Gulati, Infosys chair professor for agriculture, Indian Council for Research on International Economic Relations.Soumya Kanti Ghosh, group chief economic adviser at SBI, said, “We strongly recommend that the increased excise revenue from oil should not be used to bridge the fiscal gap and please the markets…”

Title: For ‘janata curfew’, busy Gurugram turns into ghost town
Content:
Millennium City turned into a ghost town that was barely recognisable as vehicles kept off the usually busy ro... Read More

GURUGRAM: At 12 noon on Sunday, the only living beings seen at a Golf Course Road roundabout were a bunch of grazing cows, along with a few cops who sat nearby. As Gurugram observed a ‘ janata curfew ’ — a full lockdown in response to the Prime Minister’s call — the Millennium City turned into a ghost town that was barely recognisable, as all establishments stayed shut and vehicles kept off the usually busy roads.

Coronavirus in India live updates

“In all my years as a cop here, I haven’t seen anything like this. Even at the time of the Jat agitation, the roads weren’t empty like this,” a cop at the MG Road police post said.

For several kilometres, only police officials could be seen other than commuters who were travelling and were stuck. “I came from Orissa this morning till Delhi and managed to reach here somehow. Now, I’m not able to get home despite waiting for almost an hour,” said Ankit Kumar, a resident of Laxman Vihar .

Similarly, a family of 20 people that came from Lucknow stood at Gurugram bus from 4am till 2pm due to suspension of public transport. “We have to go to Hyatpur, but it looks like we are stuck here for now. We do not have enough money to rent a room either,” said one of the women, not wishing to be named.

Neither Haryana roadways buses nor autos and cabs plied on Sunday. An auto driver out on the roads found himself snubbed by a PCR van in Sector 15. The cops also asked the only two grocery shops open in the area to shut down and asked those looking for groceries to go home. “I went out to get milk and bread but the cop asked me to go home,” said Shweta Goyal, a resident.

At Rajiv Chowk junction, two men who had just returned from Dubai waited with their luggage.

“We reached today as it was the last day of flights. We managed to get a private cab till here. But now we need to get to Behror and are unsure when will we’ll reach,” said Islam, one of the men.

Without public transport, it was a tough commute for those employed in the delivery of essential services too. Madhu Sharma, a toll plaza operator at Kherki Dhaula said, “I live in Sector 4 and had to take a ride in a private cab till the highway. Then I waited for an hour at Rajiv Chowk. Finally, I convinced a private car to drop me by promising to waive off their toll plaza.”

She added that they haven’t been provided proper masks, gloves and sanitisers by their employer. And dealing in cash all day, they are highly exposed to the virus.

Sanitation workers were also visible on the roads. Wearing masks and gloves, most of them were out all day. “We have to work unless the government issues an order,” said an MCG contractor, requesting anonymity.

A group of men from the Gurugram Vaishya group, meanwhile, went around town distributing masks, sanitisers and gloves to cops.

“In these difficult times, we all need to come together and help each other. We are just doing our bit,” said Gaurav Agarwal, one of the group members.

5pm soundtrack

Answering the call of the prime minister to give thanks to all those in the forefront of the fight against the spread of the Coronavirus, residents across Gurugram came out of their houses or gathered in balconies to express their gratitude — and make some noise to dispel the negativity and downbeat atmosphere of the last few days.

As if on cue, at 5pm, the sound of clanging could be heard all over, as the young and the old grabbed pots and pans, or anything else they could lay their hands on, to provide a soundtrack to the Sunday evening. A boy was seen playing the drums on his high-rise balcony, but a lot of it was improvisatory.

Some chanted the Gayatri Mantra or sang the Arti, yet others turned to their speakers to play religious songs. Plenty clapped in support of the quiet endeavour of healthcare workers all over. “We wanted to salute the protectors of the nation by beating plates and ringing bells,” said Umed Singh of Sector 21, one of the many happy to take part in this communal event.

But there were voices of disapproval, who lamented that such a din would end up disturbing and even traumatising the inhabitants of the wild, on a day when both fauna and avifauna enjo-yed welcome relief from human activities. “This will have a severe impact on the birds and animals around us,” warned a message on a WhatsApp group.

Title: Sunnis partially suspend congregational prayers
Content: MUMBAI: Under pressure from the administration and a section of community leaders to comply with health guidelines in view of coronavirus spread, the Sunnis have partially suspended their congregational prayers at mosques.According to the arrangement made in many mosques, the muezzins’ call for namaz is immediately followed by an announcement asking people to pray at home. The imam, muezzin and a few locals offer namaz at the mosque. “Most of the muftis (those who issue fatwas) endorsed my suggestion that congregational prayers should be suspended and just a few people should offer daily namaz at the mosques,” said Maulana Mahmood Daryabadi of All India Ulema Council.On Saturday night, Maulana Daryabadi took the lead in consulting a number of senior muftis, including Mufti Azeezur Rahman Fatehpuri , held in high regard in the community, and sought their opinions on whether congregational prayers can be suspended. The muftis agreed that human life should not be endangered and gatherings should be avoided.Mufti Ashraf Raza Qadri of Idara Sharia (Maharashtra) also said that, except the imam, muezzin and a few locals, the rest should pray at home.Meanwhile, in a strongly-worded open letter, former vice-chairman of the state minority commission, Abraham Mathai , said heeding to the pleas of experts and their own community leaders, Sunnis should suspend congregational prayers at mosques.In Nalasopara, former deputy mayor of Vasai-Virar Municipal Corporation, Sagheer Dange, said most of the mosques in Nalasopara had stopped amplifying the ‘azaan’ through microphones to avoid a rush to the mosques for daily prayers. “Just a few people offer prayers at mosques. We are complying with guidelines as it is important to avoid gatherings to check the spread of coronavirus,” said Dange.Maulana Khalilur Rahman Noorie, imam of a mosque in Andheri, said the number of worshippers at mosques had reduced substantially.

Title: Punjab: FIR against financier in Batala for excess gathering
Content: BATALA: Batala police on Sunday filed an FIR against a man for holding a gathering of over 60 persons at his house. According to Jasbir Singh Rai , Batala superintendent of police (SP), headquarters, Sukhraj Singh , a financier from Sarchur village, had held a religious function at his house in which more than 60 persons were present.He said to contain the spread of coronavirus , the administration had banned gatherings of more than 10 persons in the district. Police had filed an FIR under sections 188 and 269 of the IPC against Sukhraj, he said.However, he was later released on bail. The SP said Batala police were pleased with the gratitude of the citizens towards them. “While patrolling in the city, at around 4.45 pm, residents came out of their houses and started clapping in appreciation of our work and to encourage us,” Singh added.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: MCG releases guidelines for RWAs to ensure hygiene in residential areas
Content: GURUGRAM: The set of guidelines released by the Municipal Corporation of Gurugram MCG ) for the residents has brought uniformity in what needs to be followed by the RWAs.The civic body has asked the RWAs and facility managers of the condominiums and gated societies to make residents follow a specific set of guidelines to combat novel coronavirus “We have released a set of guidelines and recommendations for the residents and also distributed pamphlets in the condominiums and gated societies, ensuring they are followed,” said an MCG official.The official added that the RWAs have welcomed the step which specifies uniform guidelines to be followed all across. “I had been discussing with the authorities that there is a need to ascertain a set of guidelines for the residents to follow. Now, that we have the specific steps in place, it would be easier to bring uniformity,” said Sudhir Sacdeva, a resident of Sushant Lok-1.Residents said that in the absence of guidelines, there was no uniformity in what needs to be followed. The recommendations include temperature screening for all workers/visitors, guests, delivery personnel; hand sanitizers at the entrance; additional wiping down of elevators, handrails and common surfaces with disinfectants; supply of soaps/disinfectants to all workers and security personnel for their home use; masks for security guards and gloves for the housekeeping staff.Moreover, it is also recommended to educate the housekeeping and security staff about the measures. “If your community is using a gate security app for visitors, do ensure that it is not touched by the visitors. Wipe with cloth and disinfectants every two hours. Reduce group activities for kids and parents in the apartment complex and avoid visitors as far as feasible,” read the guidelines released by the MCG.

Title: Chennai slips into quarantine mode
Proposal for desalination plants for southern Tamil Nadu put on hold
Content:
A defunct desalination plant at Naripaiyur village in Ramanathapuram

CHENNAI: It is going to be yet another tough summer for residents of rain-deficit Ramanathapuram and Tiruchendur as the Central advisory body had denied permission for setting up desalination plants due to environmental concerns.

As the proposed site was near Gulf of Mannar National Marine Park , Union environment ministry's Expert Appraisal Committee (EAC) recommended a different site to be chosen.

Tamil Nadu Water and Drainage Board (TWAD) had proposed to set up two desalination plants at Kuthiraimozhi and Alanthalai villages in the said districts.

Each of these plants was to have an output capacity of 60 MLD and cost around 1,350 crore.

EAC, while deliberating about the Kuthiraimozhi project, noted that the proposed site was only 25 metres away from a national park and choosing such an eco-sensitive zone was unacceptable.

"It was observed that fishermen are dependent on the Gulf of Mannar for their livelihood and the release of brine certainly will impact not only on fish catch but also the reefs, seaweeds, seagrass and the overall ecosystem of the area," EAC observed. The committee said that the proposal did not discuss how brine, considered toxic, was returned into the sea after production.

Also, no detail Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) study, explaining impact on flora, fauna and coral reefs etc, was carried out as mandated by law.

The committee further noted that the project did not have brine dispersion model result which is important to understand the fate and dispersion of the brine discharge from the desalination plant.

So TWAD deferred the proposal and advised TWAD to give up the proposal at Ramanathapuram and instead compensate by doubling the capacity at the other proposed site -- Alanthalai in Tiruchendur.

This means these rain-deficit districts will continue to suffer from water crisis this summer as well. "The state government has been lethargic in this aspect as the district collectorate, TWAD and port authorities are blaming each other and no progress has been made despite funds being sanctioned," said K Navas Kani, Ramanathapuram Member of Parliament (MP).

The district needs 85 MLD but only 30 MLD is actually provided through Combined Cauvery Water Scheme and right now people are managing because of decent monsoon. The district has a population of 20 lakh, according to official data.

Though locals had proposed to revive a defunct desal plant at Naripaiyur instead of constructing a new plant, the government is reluctant because of political reasons, the MP added.

Title: Karnataka: SSLC, II PU exams postponed; fresh dates in April 1st week
Content:
Representative Image

BENGALURU: Monday's only pending II PU exam (English) and SSLC exams scheduled to start on March 27 have been postponed due to Covid-19 concerns. The new dates will be announced in April first week.

The decision was taken after a meeting with chief minister BS Yediyurappa on Sunday morning, said primary and secondary education minister S Suresh Kumar. Around 8.25 lakh students are to appear for the Class 10 exam.

"I appeal to SSLC students not to get frustrated. I know you're fully prepared, fully geared up. But this is a peculiar situation which calls for hard decisions. The new timetable will be published very soon. Students should treat is as an extended study leave. Please revise more. Do not treat this as a relaxation time. You'll have plenty of time to relax after the exams," he said.

The government also postponed exams of classes 7- 9 and a decision will be taken after March 31.

KG Jagadeesh, commissioner, DPI, said the new dates will be announced with sufficient time for students to prepare.

Earlier in the day, the II PU exam was to be held as scheduled but by evening, the department decided to postpone it when concerns were raised about transportation facilities available for students.

"Thousands of students come to Karnataka from neighbouring states like Kerala, Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh . In order to avoid any risk, we had a rethink about conducting the exam on Monday. No single student should miss the exam or suffer. So we decided to postpone it. The new date will be announced after March 31," Suresh Kumar said.

Teachers, PU lecturers to work from home

Tthe Department of Public Instruction directed teaching and non-teaching staff of government-aided and unaided schools to Work from Home (WFH) till March 31. The PU education department announced holidays for all teaching and non-teaching staff of government, aided and unaided PU colleges till March 31.

The department were asked to fulfil their duties assigned as per a previous order (prepare timetables and schedules for the next academic year) during this WFH period. They have to prepare the necessary material needed for online teaching and valuation as well as develop a teaching programme for the next academic year.

The authorities have been asked to provide necessary support to hostels and residential schools.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 1,000 Ghaziabad families chant mantra to stop pandemic
Content: GHAZIABAD: As people across the country stayed home on Sunday to observe the nationwide ‘janta curfew’, and blew conch shells and sounded the bells in large numbers exactly at 5pm, residents in several societies of Crossings Republik went a step ahead and chanted the ‘Mahamrityunjaya Mantra’ in chorus. The sacred utterance is believed to assure longevity, ward off the evil, and prevent calamities and untimely deaths, the residents said.At 4pm, they connected their phones or music systems with stereo speakers through Bluetooth and played the mantra across the residential blocks. “More than 1,000 families from as many as 18 societies of Crossings Republik held a one-hour-long chanting of the mantra, which removes fear from the mind of people and fill them with positive energy, from 4 pm to 5 pm, said Ujjawal Mishra, general secretary of Crossings Republik Flat Owners Association.Mishra added that it was a spontaneous decision. “All of us were sitting at home due to 'janta curfew' and thought of doing something creative. As many people were already doing pujas and chanting the mantra inside their respective houses, we thought of doing it together, at a mass level,” he shared.What followed was quick coordination. Two WhatsApp groups were formed and within half an hour, more than 500 joined the groups and expressed their willingness to participate, said Kshitiz Singhal, a resident of Paramount Symphony.Singhal informed that since the district has been put under lockdown till March 25, Crossings residents have decided to hold this particular event every evening.Many residents appreciated the effort and said at a time when people in every corner of the world are scared due to the deadly coronavirus infection, the event created a festive atmosphere.After completing the chanting, residents came out to their balconies and terraces to clap and blow conch shells to express appreciation for those providing essential services as suggested by Narendra Modi.

Title: Janta Curfew in UP: Many key services shut during ‘Janta curfew’
Content: NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: A large number of residents across Noida and Ghaziabad participated enthusiastically in the ‘janata curfew ’ on Sunday, staying home in view of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak and applauding health workers and other essential services across the country.However, they were hit hard as some of those essential services, including groceries, pharmacies and petrol pumps, remained shut too.In Sector 19 A block market, all shops, including dairies and general stores, were shut around 1.30pm. Medical stores in Atta market in Sector 27 opened only around 4pm while almost all the grocery shops remained closed.Though most people had stocked up on essentials, some faced difficulties in accessing the market. They were able to buy groceries after trying their luck at several stores.Sanjay Agrawal, a general store owner, opened his shop towards 2pm. He told TOI he didn’t have milk, so customers returned empty-handed.Madhusudan, a resident of Sector 19, told TOI the family bought milk, but with difficulty. “We spoke to the dairy owner twice but he said he didn’t have milk. We went later when he got the supplies,” he said.Cops remained on patrol across Noida, issuing directions to those who were out on the roads. At some places, they warned they would have to resort to using sticks in case people don’t listen.Two dairy owners alleged they were thrashed by three cops from the Sector 24 police station police and forced to down shutters despite being in the essential services category. Gurbachan Singh, the owner of Rajput Dairy, said almost 384 litres of milk, worth around Rs 25,000 was wasted.S Biswas said he was asked to shut down his clinic by cops. “They told me to show my degree and said that since I did not have it, I couldn’t keep it open,” he said. DCP (Noida) Sankalp Sharma said they had received the complaint and the ACP of the area had been asked to look into the case.Meanwhile, without domestic helps and cooks on Sunday, those who were banking on food apps had a tough time getting the delivery person allowed inside the society premises. “I am not an expert cook and the help has stopped coming. The pizza delivery boy was stopped by policemen. I reached the main gate and showed them what services were exempted under the curfew. They allowed me to collect it then,” Amal Nair, a resident of Sector 122, said.While most societies didn’t allow anyone to enter or exit in the morning, people started heading out after 5pm.In Ghaziabad, some residents called the PCR about grocery stores in Vijay Nagar and Loni areas, alleging they were trying to fleece customers. “But by the time police team reached, the shops were shut,” said Ghaziabad SSP Kalanidhi Naithani.

Title: Tamil Nadu's move to provide reservation in MBBS may revive government schools
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The state government's move to provide special reservation for NEET qualified government school students may revive the state-run schools as it gives hope to the students to join MBBS.

Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami announced that the state government would form a committee headed by a high court retired judge to make recommendations on this regard. The special reservation would be provided within existing 69% reservation.

The number of students joining medical colleges from government schools has reduced from 34 in 2016 to 2 last year following the NEET based medical admission. Though more than 2000 students from government schools qualified in NEET only two students were able to join due to the increase in the MBBS cut-off last year.

"It is an excellent move. More students will join the government schools thereby they would flourish again. It also would help government school students to study in government medical colleges," said G Shanmugavel, headmaster, Government Higher Secondary School in Chennai.

He said government school students are equally talented when compared to the private school students but not able to give repeat attempts to crack the test. Last year, about 70% of students joined MBBS courses were old students. "We have been demanding it for many years. Students' strength in government schools would be increased," said R C Saraswathi, headmistress of Government Girls Higher Secondary School, Ashok Nagar.

Another headmaster from a city school requested the government to relax the Class I to XII rule and asked to make it either Class I to XII or Class VI to XII. "Many government schools do not have primary sections. So, parents are admitting their wards in neighbourhood primary schools. They mostly come to government schools only in Class VI," he said.

However, educationist Prince Gajendrababu called it as a populist announcement. "The state government has failed to understand the problem. The move has to clear several hurdles," he said.

Title: Dancing & Gymming are like my two eyes, says Bharath
Content:
Six or seven hours of sleep

Good litres of water every day

Lots of fruit and vegetable intake

Keep it simple with workouts and diet

Actor Bharath politely asks us to wait for a couple of minutes before excusing himself to break a sweat, as we landed up at his gym a few days ago. Following rounds of weight training, the actor sits down with us at his workout space in Mogappair. “If I don’t gym at least for an hour every day, I feel quite sick and feverish. It has become a lifestyle for me, just like eating three meals a day. When you sweat, you feel nice and fit,” he says with a smile, wiping down beads of sweat.A common misconception about fitness is that people think they can get away with eating whatever they want as long as they work out, Bharath says. “Eighty per cent of your body made in the kitchen and 20 per cent of it is what you burn. Once they sweat for one hour, they eat whatever they want. So, when they go to the gym the next day, they sag on the same weight. They then blame the gym. You need to control your tongue to see the results.”Sivakumar, Bharath’s trainer adds that people need to fix their diet according to their body type. “The same goes for workout routines, too. Not everybody can do everything. For instance, if someone is injured during cross or weight training, they need to change their muscle pattern accordingly. The diet depends on metabolism,” notes Sivakumar, who has been training Bharath for the past 12 years.Gymming apart, the actor is absolutely big on dancing, something that his films, too, often depict. “I have been dancing all my life, which helped me in agility and flexibility. Once I started training with Shiva, I got my muscles,” he observes. However, there is this perception that dancing could cause you to lose your endurance and flexibility, he says, adding, “That is not at all true. Hrithik Roshan and Tiger Shroff are the biggest examples of this. It is all about how you strike a balance between the two.”The actor makes it a point to dance at least thrice a week. “I have always been into western classical, which includes styles like jazz, ballet and hip-hop. Dancing and gymming are like my two eyes,” he says with a grin.Since food is what shapes a person’s fitness quotient, how does Bharath cope with cravings? This question is not really applicable to the actor, as Bharath is far away from being a foodie. “I am gifted with an attitude of not being a foodie. If you are a foodie, you need to control your cravings. That is where the frustration begins. It might look like I am lying for the interview, but I am honestly not a biryani lover (laughs). I don’t eat chocolates or ice creams.However, I do indulge in it rarely, once in three months or so.”Ask Bharath about cross-training and TRX, which have now come to the forefront of India’s fitness landscape, and he explains, “The culture of TRX, cross-training and resistance bands started in Indian gyms just about six years ago.And in the last couple of years, it has been at its peak. This can be proved by how more and more gymnasiums are now calling themselves fitness studios rather than just ‘gyms’. Endurance, agility and functional training are extremely significant today.”Portions of protein, vegetables, eggs and ragiBrown rice, spinach, veggies and chickenEggs and nutsRotis, dal, rajma and a cup of green tea before bed

Title: Corona crooners in Chennai keep the cheer up on social media
Content: CHENNAI: As Covid-19 continues its relentless march across the world, musicians and singers are taking to social media to sing 'corona' numbers to lighten the mood.Memes and jokes apart, social media is breaking into melodies and operas on the global pandemic. While the Italians serenaded from their apartment balconies, closer home, it was 'curfew kutcheris', 'gana padal' and 'harikathas' on social media.Just a few days ago, opera singer Laura Baldassari sang out of her window in Milan, Italy, for a flash mob during the nationwide lockdown in a show of mass bonding to cope with the Corona emergency. Last week, in India, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi completed his 30-minute address, there was a flurry to create song scripts and a corona raga.In the run up to Sunday, the curfew kutcheris with their corona theme caught the imagination of audiences. A nationalist and an academician teamed up to jot down the lyrics and help Carnatic singers add zing to the 'corona thillana'. "The lyrics were set to different tunes including a bhajan, vruttam, folk song and a pure desh-raag based Carnatic tune," said Sastra University vice-chancellor S Vaidhyasubramaniam The lyric was composed by Chennai-based literary enthusiast Rangam Balaji , daughter of former attorney general K Parasaran. Sunil Gargyan, Palghat Ramprasadh (grandson of Palghat Mani Iyer), Sivasri Skandaprasad and Sriranjani Santhanagopalan rendered the classical numbers with the theme - 'Nam Prathamar sonnathu, ithil artham ullathu..." (What our PM said makes sense...). The lyrics focussed on prevention, social distancing, janata curfew and breaking the Covid-19 chain.Tuticorin-based Madhu, a trained classical singer, got hold of a script that went thus: 'Thottaal flu malarum, thodamalum flu paravum...(you will get flu if you are in contact; it will spread without touching too...) from the 1960s song 'Thotaal Poo Malarum...' from the film Padagotti starring MGR and Saroja. "I sang and circulated it on our various whatsapp groups," said Madhu. The song is now popular among kids and elders in her community.The same day, March 14, when T M Soundarajan's song hit the corona circuit, Rashmi Shaarvi floored social media with her 'corona' English number, a takeoff from Camila Cabello 's 2018 song Havana. Others took the corona route for the Shah Rukh Khan 'Chalte Chalte' movie song Suno Na Suno Na.Soon, this inspired Tamil singers, both well-known and little known. 'Corona, Corona...' (Thillana, Thillana from Rajni starrer Muthu) and Gana padal singer Sudhakar joined in. Sudhakar's corona awareness folk number comes down hard on China with a cheap jibe on its popular snake meat dish. But no offence taken. It is all in the Covid spirit - a sweet tango to lighten the dark mood.

Title: Karnataka: Burglars smell chance in lockdown, target school and college in a week
Content:
Representative Image

BENGALURU: A college and a high school have been burgled in the city over the past week, with culprits sensing an opportunity in the closure of educational institutions over Covid-19 concerns.

A gang of burglars struck St Francis De Sales College near Hebbagodi and took away computer processors and RAMs worth Rs 10 lakh on March 18 night. The incident came to light around 8am the next day, when a staff noticed the broken locks.

Hebbagodi police registered a case of burglary based on a complaint filed by college principal Roy Father.

The complainant told police burglars broke the locks of the computer science and mathematics labs. “In all, 56 processors and RAMs were stolen from the computer science lab and 30 processors and RAMs from the mathematics lab,” a police officer said.

In another incident, burglars took away Rs 78,800 cash from Loyola High School in Konanakunte area on March 17 night.

Police registered a case of burglary based on a complaint filed by Fr. Edward Rodrigues SJ, principal of Loyola High School on Bannerghatta Main Road. Police said they had locked the school on Saturday (March 14) and on March 18 morning, found some miscreants had broken the back door and the staff room.

“The miscreants took away Rs 78,800, the application fee collected by teachers, and a mobile phone, laptop bag and mobile chargers from the spot,” the principal told police.

Title: #CoronaLockdown: Online sessions & work on new projects keep namma artistes busy
Content: Chennai-based veena player Rajhesh Vaidhya was supposed to have given his concert on Saturday; whereas, theatre artiste V Balakrishnan had planned an international tour to the US with other artistes to stage their play. However, in the wake of the outbreak of Coronavirus pandemic, all those plans had to be put on hold, especially after the state government announced lockdown till March 31. Of course, it’s a lot of revenue loss, but the artistes seem to be trying to tide over the situation, using the time productively by engaging with their audience via online platforms and working on their new productions.Bhargav Ramakrishnan, a stand-up artiste from Chennai, sees this as an opportunity to gain online traction for his work. “Everyone is at home and glued to the screens. What better time to catch the attention of online viewers? So, I’ll be releasing my standup special, titled ‘Kung Fu Bonda’ online,” he states.Kanjira artiste KV Gopalakrishnan , who has gone to the US for a tour, has now decided to stay back there until April as per the initial plan and keeps himself occupied with online classes. “Concerts getting cancelled were totally unexpected. But we’ve decided to avoid travelling back to India at this time. To make the best use of the free time here, I’ve started taking Skype classes,” he shares.Arkay Ramakrishnan of Arkay Convention Centre says if the situation continues longer, he will consider live-streaming performances.“As of now, the plan is to reschedule the concerts. But we’ll think of alternatives if the situation looks bleak even beyond March. I might invite the artistes alone to the concert hall and live-stream their performances. We might have thousands of them watching if we do live streaming.”A bunch of storytellers from Multistory in Chennai has already had two live online storytelling sessions for kids. “We felt this was the best way to keep kids engaged productively while they have their inevitable screen time during the school shutdown. The challenge is on the performer to adapt to a new medium,” says Amrutash Misra from the group.The focus is on online videos, says Coimbatore-based miniature artist, M Savithru, too. “All the workshops have been cancelled. So, I am focusing on working on my online videos now. I see it as an opportunity to promote my work on a different platform.”It is important to keep in touch with the craft, feel artistes, as they try and meet for practice session. Be it individually or in small groups, they are making use of this no-shows period to prepare for their upcoming productions. Says Balakrishnan, “Our group, Theatre Nisha, isn’t a big one in terms of number of people. So, we are meeting and preparing ourselves to stage Girish Karnad’s Crossing To Talikota, by the end of April. We avoid physical contact as much as possible. Also, the space is disinfected before the rehearsal and we ensure that all of us thoroughly wash our hands. Those who are unwell are advised to stay at home. If not meeting for rehearsal, each of us individually work on our writing skills.”Rajhesh Vaidhya concurs, “Individual practice session is part of the daily routine. So, that’s not interrupted at all. Now, I’ve rescheduled my concert to June 13.”Leon James, a musician and theatre artiste, says all his workshops lined up for the next few weeks have been cancelled, but this unexpected free time is fully utilised. “I do workshops on traditional wind instruments. Even after the lockdown is lifted, I am not sure if people will be comfortable with workshops, where it requires a lot interaction. So, I’ve holed up myself, working on new music and developing fresh content for the future workshops.”And Rajhesh Vaidhya says he is also working on his new single, titled Distracted, now. “The whole world is disturbed now. Finding peace in disturbing times is what this single is about. I am planning to launch it in April.”Singer Prithvee Rajesh (of Nerkonda Paarvai’s Agalaathey fame) says, “Last week, I had a concert, which I was really looking forward to. But that got cancelled. Now, until things are back to normal, I’ve decided to work on a new song which I had written some time ago.”

Title: Grateful to Rahman sir for Jwalamukhi: Poorvi
Content: If there’s an album that could be extra special for AR Rahman , it has to be that of 99 Songs , a film that he’s co-written and produced, apart from composing music for. No wonder then that Poorvi Koutish is thrilled to have sung not one, but three songs for the Isai Puyal in the multilingual. “I’ve sung Jwalamukhi in Hindi, Tamil and Telugu,” she beams. She’s also rendered Voice Without Words in English and Veere Kadh De in Hindi for the film.But this is not the first time that Poorvi has associated with Rahman. “After my stint in the music reality show Indian Idol, in 2012, I wanted to learn Broadway music. But I didn’t find any course like that in Mumbai. Much later, I found out that Rahman sir’s KM Music Conservatory taught Western Classical and even Opera, which came very close to Broadway. So, I joined the course in Chennai, and simultaneously started doing demo work here,” she reminisces, “During my last year there, in 2017-18, Rahman sir saw one of the performances I put up and appreciated me. He asked me what my plans were and I told him I wasn’t sure and was considering studying music abroad. So, he suggested that I intern at his studio and take that time to figure out what I wanted to do. While that was very sweet of him, I told him I had no experience in music production and wasn’t sure what I’d intern as. He said I could explore my options, and I am forever grateful to him for saying that, because it’s only because of him that I understood the process of making a song. I learnt everything there — from music production to video production and even editing.”So, how did Jwalamukhi happen? “Rahman sir initially called me to sing just one word in the song — Jwalamukhi. The rest of the lyrics were being written and he wanted me to sing gibberish of the composition for the lyricist to write. So, I kept singing different sets of lyrics in Hindi, Tamil and Telugu until things were finalised. But turns out, he used my voice for the final cut as well. I’m grateful to him for giving me the Tamil version as well,” she says, adding, “I think the emotions in the song are raw, and sometimes, I love the Tamil version more than the Hindi one.”Ask Poorvi if she is familiar with Tamil, given that she’s stayed in Chennai for a few years and has also sung Veriyera for Anirudh in Ajith’s Vivegam in the past, and she says with a laugh, “Well, I have to thank Anirudh for being patient with me because I was taking time to get every word right in the song. But yes, Tamil konjam theriyum, like I can speak to cab drivers and vendors. I’m still making progress in that zone.”

Title: Bengaluru: Wing mirror leads cops to Mercedes which killed one
Content:
The Mercedes Benz involved in the accident last week

BENGALURU: A speeding car which mowed down a 39-year-old businessman crossing Ballari Road near Le Meridien last Wednesday midnight has been identified as a Mercedes Benz belonging to a Malleswaram resident. Cops zeroed in on the vehicle based on its broken right wing mirror that was found at the spot.

High Grounds traffic police seized the Benz and issued a notice to its owner, who is also a businessman. "We have asked the owner to furnish details of the driver, who was at the wheel when the accident took place. We will nab him soon," they said.

According to police, Yelahanka resident and real estate businessman Krishnamurthy and his friends Prakash and Munirathnamma were returning home on Wednesday midnight when their car's tyre went flat in front Le Meridien. They called a mechanic, who took the tyre to fix the problem. Krishnamurthy and the mechanic were crossing the road when a car moving towards High Grounds from Windsor Manor junction knocked Krishnamurthy down. The driver sped away, police said.

"The right wing mirror of the car was lying at the accident spot. Krishnamurthy was rushed to hospital where he succumbed to injuries around 5.30am. Eyewitnesses told us the car which caused the accident was a white Benz, but they weren't sure about its registration number," a police officer said.

Police verified CCTV footage of nearby junctions. "We were unable to find the car's registration number. But our staff took the mirror found at the spot and visited a few sales and service showrooms of Benz. Based on their information, we traced the car to Malleswaram," a police officer said.

Title: Chennai: After taking down post, Twitter calls Rajinikanth ‘Thalaiva’
Content:
File photo of actor Rajinikanth

CHENNAI: A day after taking down a tweet of Rajinikanth on Covid-19 for violating norms, Twitter India on Sunday addressed the actor as ‘ Thalaiva ’.

Extending his support to Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call for a ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday, Rajinikanth had uploaded a video saying the 12-14 hour break would help destroy the virus out in the open and help prevent India from getting into stage 3 of the outbreak.

Many questioned the scientific validity of his statement, and asked how remaining inside the house for 12-14 hours would help destroy the virus; some termed it fake news.

Eventually, Twitter took down the video. Twitter India tweeted in Tamil, when translated, read: Thank you for joining us in ensuring the dissemination of accurate information about Covid-19, Thalaiva.

Rajinikanth on Sunday clarified that in his speech he had mentioned that staying indoors for 12-14 hours regularly would help to break the chain. But it was misconstrued as staying indoors only on Sunday, he said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Section 144 in Pune until March 31, essential services exempted
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: District collector Naval Kishor Ram on Sunday night issued prohibitory orders under section 144 (1)(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) banning the assembly of five or more people at public places and private workplaces from 5am on Monday till March 31.

The Pune police also issued similar prohibitory orders under the same section later.

“We will be very strict about the implementation of these prohibitory directives,” Ram told TOI. He said the order excludes essential services.

The orders will apply to areas coming under municipal corporations, civic councils, nagar panchayats and industrial estates across the district.

The orders put a total restriction on the plying of vehicles carrying five or more people, the movement of five or more people on the roads, their assembly at one place and idling time on the roads. There will be no bar on people going out for essential services, but they cannot go out in a group.

On Sunday, the ‘janata curfew’ across the country from 7am to 9pm was immediately followed by a curfew imposed by the police from 9pm to 5am on Monday. This was done as a measure to prevent people from stepping out in large numbers after the ‘janata curfew’ deadline.

Section 144 until March 31; essential services exempted

Joint commissioner of Pune police Ravindra Shisve referred to the 5pm citizens’ initiative of acknowledging the work done by medical staffers in addressing the crisis. He, however, said, “We saw that many people came together to clap and beat thalis. It defeated the purpose of social distancing. Hence, we decided to issue the curfew order.”

Meanwhile, the prohibitory orders issued by the district collector will ban workshops, ceremonies of all types, cultural, religious and entertainment programmes, festivals, fairs, sports, camps, training classes and meetings which do not involve essential matters.

Public buses, railway services, all private corporates, shops and services establishments, canteens, lodges, messes, shopping complexes, malls, supermarkets, clubs, sports grounds, auditoriums, museums, art houses, video parlours, online lottery centres, paan shops, beer bars, permit rooms, schools, colleges, private coaching classes and training centres will remain closed during this time, the orders stated.

There will be restricted movement of vehicles around the isolation centres and quarantine wards.

However, the prohibitory orders will not be applicable to government, semi-government, state corporations, state establishment and post office employees. Similarly, it won't apply to hospitals, pathology labs, drug and medical stores, health care equipment manufacturers, vegetable and fruit sellers, milk vendors and grocery shops, online food delivery services, student messes, college canteens, vehicles engaged for plying officials and employees engaged in emergency services, medical and nursing colleges, and the performing of last rites in case of death, the orders said.

Also excluded are RBI banking services, ATM services, insurance, online delivery services, telephone and internet services, water, electricity, petroleum, oil, power supply, media of all types, warehouses, waste management and cleanliness services and ecommerce services, among others.

Earlier, the railway ministry announced cancellation of all local trains on the Central and Western railway, while the state imposed section 144 in all urban areas, discontinued state transport and private bus services, and metro services. Only goods trains carrying essential items will be allowed to operate.

Health minister Rajesh Tope said the state government was also considering closing of state borders as the risk of the outbreak spreading to and from the neighbouring states was also high.

Announcing the imposition of section 144 in all urban areas of the state, chief minister Uddhav Thackeray said, “We have shut all inter-state buses and now within the state buses too are being suspended. City bus services will only be used for emergency service staff.” He also said that government offices will work at 5% attendance, down from 25% announced earlier this week. The shutdowns have been announced till March 31, but if needed they may be extended.”

Title: 10 close contacts of two Thai nationals isolated in Chennai
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: At least 10 people, who had came in close contacts with the two Thai nationals who tested positive for Covid-19, have been admitted to a government hospital and will be under observation, public health officials said on Sunday.

The contacts, including a guide, a driver and helpers, were tagged as high risk by the government. "We will be monitoring them. If there is any symptom, they will undergo tests," officials said.

In addition to close contacts, 126 more people who visited two mosques in the area have been advised to stay on home quarantine. "These people have low risk and will be taken to hospital if they show symptoms. All 136 people are being tracked from the state Covid-19 control room," an official said. The mosques have been disinfected. Health department officials have advised mosque authorities to restrict entry.

The two patients were among seven Thai nationals who travelled to Erode. Health officials said one of them 49-year-old Thailand national, who tested negative for the viral infection, died at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital (CMCH) last week after he had complications of diabetic nephropathy , sepsis and pulmonary oedema. However, Vijayabaskar tweeted in the evening "He tested negative for Covid-19. He is not connected with the two Thailand nationals."

Public health officials track sheet show that the two Thai national who are under treatment arrived in New Delhi on March 6. Officials said that they were going around the capital for about four days and boarded the Millennium Express to Erode on March 10.

After they reached Erode, they spent time in at least three mosques until March 15, the officials said, adding that when the 49-year-old Thailand national died at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital (CMCH) last week, doctors said he had complications of diabetic nephropathy, sepsis and pulmonary oedema.

However, after his death, these two patients were isolated at IRT Hospital in Perundurai. Their samples were taken on March 17 and they tested positive on Saturday. The department sought information from the railways about the passengers who travelled with them in the same coach. Health officials are also visiting the mosques to quarantine maulvis and workers in the mosque.

Health secretary Beela Rajesh said the state had decided not release details of Covid-19 positive patients. "It involves patient privacy. There is a lot of stigma around it. We don't want release details now," she said.

Title: Lockdown in UP: Lockdown till March 25 in 16 districts of UP, essential services on
Content: LUCKNOW: In view of overwhelming response to ‘janata curfew’ observed on Sunday on the call of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced a complete lockdown of 16 districts till March 25.These districts include Lucknow, Gautam Buddh Nagar, Ghaziabad, Agra, Varanasi, Lakhimpur Kheri, Kanpur, Aligarh, Gorakhpur, Azamgarh, Saharanpur, Bareilly, Prayagraj, Meerut, Pilibhit and Moradabad.“The lockdown has been announced to sanitise cities to stop the spread of Covid-19,” said Yogi, who himself joined people in clapping, clanging plates and blowing conch shells at 5pm to express gratitude to people at the forefront of fight against coronavirus.Deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya also joined the people by blowing conch shell outside his official residence at Kalidas Marg.“There is no need to panic. The decision has been taken to combat the disease at this stage in which virus spreads fast. People affected in these districts will be isolated and quarantined,” the CM said.Yogi said the districts bordering Nepal should also take precautions and urged people, who have travelled to the Himalayan state recently, to stay indoors. “During lockdown, the state government will completely stop mass transport services including Metro trains and city buses. Intercity buses will also stop operations. Only essential services will be available,” the CM said.

Title: Supplies hit, demand drives up veggie rates across Pune
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Prices of herbs such as coriander and fenugreek, and that of leafy vegetables like spinach have increased almost 40-50% in the last two days due to soaring demand and lack f supply.

One main reason behind such a price hike can be attributed to the closure of the Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC)-run Shri Chhatrapati Shivaji Market Yard and farmers' mandis at different parts of the city since Thursday.

The APMC officials said there were high chances of surge pricing in the coming days."A bunch of coriander, fenugreek and spinach was sold in the range of Rs40-50 by local vendors against the APMC market rate of Rs5-6. These vendor stocked up on enough vegetables on Thursday and since all markers are closed, they are selling the items at will," said Dipak Dighe, a wholesale trader of the APMC market.

"In the wholesale market, the highest quality onion is priced at Rs15/kg but vendors are selling the same at Rs40/kg. A similar trend can be observed in case of tomatoes and potatoes," said Omkar Khatal, another trader of the APMC market.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Education staff back at work to give medical proof
Content: GURUGRAM: The education department employees who have returned from abroad will now be allowed to resume their work only after submitting their detailed medical reports. The instruction was issued by the Directorate of Education (DoE) in the wake of recent spike in Covid-19 cases.According to the department, utmost care is being taken to contain and break the chain of transmission of the virus. And, in an effort to align the department’s efforts with the state’s and Centre’s measures like complete lockdown of schools, required steps have already been taken. The recent decision comes after the number of cases have started rising. In several cases, people are hiding their travel history or not following the self-quarantine protocols for all returnees from other countries, especially Europe. Thus, the department felt an urgent need to track the travel history of all its employees who would have travelled abroad in the recent past. Under the new circular issued on Saturday, the department asked all officials — teaching and non-teaching staff — to follow the mandatory medical protocols. The department’s employees who are returning from foreign travel have been asked to submit the reports to the civil surgeons upon their arrival. Thereafter, the civil surgeon of all districts will issue medical fitness certificates. This certificate will be mandatory for all employees to resume their work.All district education officers have been strictly asked to examine the medical fitness certificates, and then allow these officials to resume their services.“The steps are being taken after the number of Covid-19 patients started increasing. There have been instances of people not revealing their travel history, which makes it difficult for the government to fight the coronavirus . The department doesn’t want to take any chance,” an education department official told TOI.

Title: US Senator Rand Paul tests positive for coronavirus, forcing quarantines
Content:
More on Covid-19

WASHINGTON: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has tested positive for the novel coronavirus , becoming the first case of Covid-19 -19 in the Senate and raising fears about the further transmission of the virus among Republicans at the Capitol.Paul, an eye surgeon, went into quarantine Sunday after learning his results. He said he has not had symptoms and was tested out of an abundance of caution due to his extensive travel and events. He said he was not aware of any direct contact with any infected person.His announcement led Utah’s two GOP senators — Mike Lee and Mitt Romney — to place themselves into quarantine, stepping away from negotiations as the Senate worked on a $1.4 trillion economic rescue package for the coronavirus crisis. At least five senators, including Paul, were in self-quarantine Sunday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said.“The coronavirus has hit the Senate today,? said McConnell, R-Ky. “It’s not just back in our states but right here in the Senate.?Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat from Arizona elected in 2018, chastised Paul on Twitter, saying his decision to return to the Capitol after he was tested — but before he learned the results — was “absolutely irresponsible.?Sinema said she has “never commented about a fellow Senator’s choices/actions. Never once.?But she added: “This, America, is absolutely irresponsible. You cannot be near other people while waiting for coronavirus test results. It endangers others & likely increases the spread of the virus.?Other senators, including Ted Cruz of Texas and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, had gone into self-quarantine while they awaited the results of a coronavirus test. Both were negative.Responding to criticism on Twitter, Paul’s office said, “We want to be clear, Senator Paul left the Senate IMMEDIATELY upon learning of his diagnosis. He had zero contact with anyone & went into quarantine. Insinuations ... that he went to the gym after learning of his results are just completely false & irresponsible!?Paul’s office did not say when he was tested. Representatives of his office could not immediately be reached for comment.President Donald Trump called Paul “a great friend” and said he’s “always there when we needed him.?Paul’s diagnosis came after two House members, Reps. Mario Diaz Balart, R-Fla., and Ben McAdams, D-Utah, tested positive for the virus. Trump said the positive test results showed the virus was “hitting quite close to home. It’s a terrible thing that’s going on.?Paul and other lawmakers “are going to be fine,? Trump said. ”I hope they’ll be fine.?Paul, a deficit hawk, was among eight Senate Republicans who voted against a House-passed bill last week that provided more than $100 billion to boost testing for the coronavirus and guarantee paid sick leave for millions of workers. He also was the only Republican senator who opposed an earlier bill authorizing $8.3 billion for the initial response to the coronavirus.The senator was on Capitol Hill this past week, including at a luncheon Friday among GOP senators. He spoke on the Senate floor on Wednesday afternoon, addressing the cornonavirus and a failed amendment he sponsored that would have paid for virus relief efforts by withdrawing U.S. forces from Afghanistan.A spokesman for Sen. Jerry Moran, R-Kan., said Moran briefly saw Paul at the Senate gym Sunday morning and that he shared that information with GOP colleagues at a policy meeting. Moran “followed CDC guidelines and kept a safe distance between him and Sen. Paul,? spokesman Tom Brandt said. Moran has spoken with the attending physician at the Capitol and has been told he does not need to self-quarantine, Brandt said.South Dakota Sen. John Thune, the second-ranking Republican senator, said on the Senate floor that lawmakers will consult with the attending physician about all senators who have been in contact with Paul.Romney said he was praying for Paul and noted that Paul’s health is compromised. Paul, 57, broke several ribs in 2017 when a neighbor assaulted him over a long-standing landscaping dispute. Paul, who was later awarded $580,000 in damages and medical expenses, had surgery last year to remove part of a lung damaged by the assault.The Senate was in session Sunday seeking a bipartisan response to the pandemic. If approved, the bill would be the third measure Congress has approved in response to the coronavirus this month.The White House has increasingly emphasized that testing should prioritize the elderly and health care workers who have symptoms of the virus. While most cases of Covid-19-19 are mild and tens of thousands of people have recovered, older people and those with underlying health problems are at higher risk for more serious problems, such as pneumonia.“We don’t want everyone to go out and get a test because there’s no reason for it,” Trump told reporters Friday.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention tells people to seek testing if they have certain symptoms of the flu-like illness caused by the coronavirus — fever, cough and trouble breathing — and if they have traveled recently to an outbreak area or have been in close contact with someone who is infected. They should first be tested for the flu and other routine infections.The vast majority of people recover from the new virus. According to the World Health Organization, people with mild illness recover in about two weeks, while those with more severe illness may take three to six weeks to recover.

Title: Aligarh Muslim University to test Covid-19 cases from Gautam Buddh Nagar
Content: NOIDA: A backlog of pending tests of Covid-19 has prompted Gautam Buddh Nagar health department to send testing samples to Aligarh.The tests are being sent to the microbiology department of the Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College (JLMC) in Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) as the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is piled up with pending test reports.“We have decided to use JLMC lab facilities at AMU for the Covid-19 tests from GB Nagar. Since we have this additional facility nearby, the decision was taken to send collected samples to JLMC. We began sending the samples to the college from Friday (March 20) with around 100 samples. By Sunday, we had received 36 results out of which two tested positive from Greater Noida and 34 were negative,” said Dr Sunil Dohare, additional chief medical officer. Dohare added that the entire faculty of microbiology department is carrying out the lab test procedure.“We don’t know how many members are there in a team but the entire faculty of the microbiology lab is engaged in the sample testing process,” he said. On Sunday, total travellers that were kept under surveillance were 1,657 out of whom 297 samples were collected, 8 were positive while 221 negative. According to sources, results of 69 people are awaited.About 134 are hospitalised which include 7 positive at GIMS (one is a tour guide from Noida who is being treated in Delhi), 36 under observation at Dr Ambedkar SC/ST Hostel in Gautam Buddh University, Noida, 88 under observation in new district hospital building in Sector 39 and 3 at Child PGI hospital in Sector 30.

Title: Women's U-17 World Cup qualifiers on hold, organisers tense
Content:
HOW THINGS STAND

Only 3 teams -

Women's U-17 Euros -

CONMEBOL

CHENNAI: The Under-17 Women's World Cup might be seven months away from kick-off but the threat of Covid-19 is certain to have thrown a spanner in the works of the tournament which India will be hosting for the first time.While the five venues - Ahmedabad, Bhubaneswar, Guwahati, Kolkata and Navi Mumbai - might be ready in time, the ongoing crisis has forced majority of the qualifying tournaments for the event to be postponed.Out of the 16 teams that will take part in the World Cup - which is scheduled to be held from November 2-21, this year - Japan and North Korea are the only sides to have qualified so far. They had emerged as the top two teams - having played in the 2019 AFC U-16 Women's Championship final from the Asia (AFC) region. India, as hosts, are the third team in the tournament. FIFA spokesperson acknowledged the crisis at hand. "We are currently monitoring the situation regarding Covid-19 in India in close collaboration with the Local Organising Committee (LOC) as well as other key stakeholders, including the AIFF (All India Football Federation ), sports ministry and relevant authorities in the country. With public health and safety in mind, we are also working with the LOC to identify any potential impact on preparations for the tournament, as well as finding alternative solutions to upcoming events that were planned in the lead up to the tournament. Regarding qualifying tournaments for the event, we are currently working closely with confederations regarding alternate dates," the spokesperson told TOI.Among the qualification tournaments which have been postponed are the CONCACAF Women's U-17 Championships (originally scheduled for April 18-May 3 in Toluca, Mexico), South American U-17 championships (April 15-May 3 in Venezuela), Oceania U-17 Championship (April 6-19). But the worst hit is UEFA . The European body has postponed this year's U-17 Women's Euros to be held in Sweden from May 9. The event would have served as a qualifying tournament for the World Cup - top three teams make the cut - and the body is yet to work out an alternative date. The only qualifiers which are still happening is in the African region (CAF).Roma Khanna, the tournament director of the LOC, allayed some of the fears and feels alternate dates could be worked out since the tournament is still seven months away. "We are in contact with FIFA on the qualifying events. FIFA is working closely together with confederations on their respective qualifying tournaments. Locally, we had to postpone our Kick off the Dream football carnivals (promotional events) for this month. We will continue to monitor the situation in relation to future events that are planned to take place in host cities and around the country," Khanna told TOI.However, what will reduce some of the LOC's woes is that work at two new venues - Ahmedabad and Bhubaneswar - are nearing completion and the stadiums will be ready in time. "Things are on track at all the five venues. Three of these (Guwahati, Kolkata and Navi Mumbai) have already hosted U-17 World Cup in 2017 matches and already meet the majority of FIFA requirements. The two new venues planned for the tournament, Ahmedabad and Bhubaneswar, also have the basic infrastructure ready and work at the training sites is underway. The state authorities have also assured us of full cooperation and we appreciate the efforts being put by them in line with public health measures put in place," Khanna said.Japan, South Korea and India (as hosts) - have qualified so far.serving as UEFA qualifiers - to be held in Sweden from May 9-22 has been postponed.decided on March 19 that their qualification tournament would be postponed to late August and early September.

Title: Himachal Pradesh bans contract carriages, closes OPDs in three medical colleges
Content:
Representative image

SHIMLA: After banning the entry of all domestic and foreign tourists, the Himachal Pradesh government has banned the entry of all contract carriages and inter-state stage carriage. HRTC will only provide limited services not exceeding 10% with proper arrangements for sanitisation on busy destinations like Delhi, Haridwar and Chandigarh till further orders.

Additional chief secretary (health)-cum-nodal officer for Covid-19, R D Dhiman said the 12 samples tested on Sunday were reported negative. Till Saturday, 1,030 cases were under surveillance in Himachal Pradesh. Of these, 387 have completed 28 days and are safe from the disease.

Addressing reporters in Shimla on Saturday evening, Dhiman said isolation wards have been established in Indira Gandhi Medical College , Shimla, Government Medical College , Tanda and Government Medical College, Ner Chowk, Mandi. He also said OPD's of all three medical colleges have been closed from March 23 as a preventive measure. According to him, testing protocol has been changed and people coming from foreign countries are being screened. Persons with severe respiratory symptoms will also be tested, he said, adding that 515 persons are under surveillance in the state.

Dhiman said all educational institutions have been closed and exams have been postponed. Teachers have been exempted from coming to educational institutions and deputy commissioners concerned can requisition their services as and when required for IEC activities, he said.

Controlling officers have been asked to stagger Class III and IV staff to prevent heavy rush in government offices. The employee roster will be prepared in such a manner that they report to work in two lots on alternative days, Dhiman explained. He said 50% of employees would attend office every day while the remaining 50% would work from home. Arrival and departure timings of officials would also be staggered to prevent overcrowding.

He said that employees who do not attend offices will not leave the station and be available on phone and other means of communication. They will attend office if called for any exigency. The order shall not apply to field staff engaged in maintenance of essential/emergency services and those directly engaged in measures to control the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Lockdown imposed in Kangra, in rest of HP ‘janta’ curfewed themselves
Content: SHIMLA/MANALI: Roads and streets were deserted across Himachal Pradesh , as people heeded enthusiastically Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s ‘janata curfew’ call on Sunday. Meanwhile, considering the detection of two positive cases of Covid-19 from Kangra district, state government on Sunday ordered complete lockdown in Kangra district.People who returned from foreign countries on or after March 9 are asked to observe strict quarantine at home.In an order issued by the health and family welfare department, it has been stated that complete lockdown has been ordered keeping in view the influx of large number of persons from other countries and other states and the confirmation of Covid-19 in residents of Kangra district. “It is imperative that strict measures should be undertaken with immediate effect,” it added.During the lockdown, all interstate and intrastate movement of public and private stage and contract carriages, including taxis and auto rickshaws are prohibited. Trains and commercial aircraft are also prohibited from operating. Only vehicles for emergency services would be allowed to ply during the lockdown. All shops, commercial establishments, factories, workshops and godowns will close down their operations except shops selling groceries, food items, medicines, petrol pumps and LPG.Order said people will stay in their homes and will come out only for basic purpose like a visit to grocery shops, vegetable shops and chemists, while no mass gathering would be allowed for social, religious or political purpose.In the state, 31 suspected samples were tested for Covid-19 on Sunday of which 24 samples were found to be negative while result of seven samples are still awaited. Totally, 1,237 people who have been to Covid-19 affected countries are under surveillance. Of the 1,237, Bilaspur district has 39, Chamba 31, Hamirpur 114, Kangra 545, Kullu 10, Kinnaur 3, Mandi 122, Shimla 126, Sirmaur 58, Solan 113, Una 75 and Lahaul-Spiti 1.Meanwhile in Manali, even as people stayed the whole day at home for ‘janata curfew’, a large number of migrant workers, who do not have the social security to distance themselves, moved about, causing headache to law enforcers. Also, despite ban, police detained two tourists at Kullu on Sunday and they were taken for medical examination.At 5pm, the residents clapped their hands and banged utensils to express gratitude to all those participating in the war against coronavirus . Even at many temples, drums and trumpets could be heard at the appointed hour.The residents here want the government to impose similar curfews for few more days to fight the virus.“The shops, hotels and private offices are already shut. Government offices too have limited functioning. This is the right time that government should announce curfew like situations till March 31 or at least for a week. This will prove a boon in containing the spread of the Covid-19,” Mukesh Thakur , a resident, said.

Title: Unaided colleges offer hostels as isolation wards
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Federation of Self-Financing Technical Institutions (FSFTI), Punjab Unaided Colleges Association (PUCA), Punjab Unaided Technical Institutions Association (PUTIA), along with many other unaided colleges’ associations, have come forward to offer their campuses as isolation centres.

PUCA & FSFTI president Dr Anshu Kataria said to extend the support, a letter has been written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Punjab chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh that all technical institutions across the country will not only offer their campuses, but also hostels and paramedical staff of nursing and pharmacy for isolation and care.

Title: CBSE starts toll-free helpline on Covid safeguards
Content: LUDHIANA: While the 23rd edition of free-of-cost CBSE annual pre-exam psychological live tele-counselling for students taking Class X and XII exam in 2020 is currently on from 8am to 10pm, the board has recently decided to also start a helpline for students to create awareness on coronavirus . This facility is available on the same toll-free number: 1800 11 8004 from 8am to 8pm, initially up to March 31.CBSE has also played a proactive role in creating mass awareness in the public by way of memes on social media platforms, issuing guidelines to students/parents and schools for creating awareness about the virus and its prevention, or even changing seating arrangements in exam halls to avoid the spread of the virus.As a precautionary measure, on March 18, the board decided to rescheduling the remaining Class X/XII exams, scheduled between March 19 and 31, and has also suspended evaluation work. The dedicated coronavirus safeguard tele-counselling service will be provided by additional trained counsellors, who will deal with students/parents for preventive interventions, reducing transmission, and counselling on first aid to stop the spread of the virus. They will also assist students to engage in useful and productive activities while at home.

Title: When clock struck 5, Ludhiana stood united against killer virus
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Loud banging of plates, music on speakers and thunderous claps is what the city descended into as the clock struck 5 pm during ‘Janta Curfew’ on Sunday. The sound therapy, advocated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi , was followed seriously by the masses.

People of all age groups were seen on terraces, balconies and roads outside their houses, banging plates and ringing bells. Every family member in each household stood up as a mark of gratitude to those fighting relentlessly helping people with Covid-19.

Residents of the city, specially Kitchlu Nagar D block, marked it with fervour. Aman Kochar, a resident, said, “We cheered for healthcare professionals for their relentless work in this critical situation. We felt proud to chant and be a part of this positive energy that our PM Modi has urged us to radiate. We stand as one, we fight as one. Stay home and stay healthy.”

Her 14-year-old son, Dhruv Kochar , said the clapping was a good way to make citizens feel comfortable as panic was not the answer. “We are thankful to live in such a great country. Our doctors and nurses should be thanked for their services, despite knowing it is dangerous for them too. Let’s all get united and obey the rules made by our government to make our nation free from Covid-19,” he said.

A resident of Tagore Nagar, Swati Gupta , said smiles on people’s faces amid such gloomy times reminded them of the power of unity and oneness. “The move can easily be called a positivity endorsement drive,” she said.

“Ludhiana is geared up for the long battle against the virus. Hopefully, the menace is eradicated with self-isolation. A deep gratitude was expressed to all those helping Covid-19 victims get better and those unsung heroes fighting tooth and nail to prevent further spread of the virus,” she added.

A resident of Kitchlu Nagar D block, Megha Bector, said , “We appreciate the PM’s idea to express gratitude to all those who do not have this luxury of staying at home and working tirelessly to keep us safe.Thank you to all essential service providers for their selfless work, so that our nation is freed of Covid-19.’ Aggar Nagar resident Sudhir Gupta said it felt good to see all his neighbors on the terrace at the same time. “That feeling of unity and togetherness gave me goose bumps,” he said.

Title: Ludhiana: Fearful of Covid-19, villagers ask Nihang Sikhs to leave
Content: LUDHIANA: Tension gripped Ghudani village of Payal after locals resisted the entry of about 70 Nihangs in their village on Sunday, after they learnt that the group was returning from Hola Mohalla celebrations in Anandpur Sahib where a coronavirus-infected person had gone before dying. Ghudani sarpanch Harinderpal Singh said around 10am on Sunday, 70 Nihang Sikhs had come to a gurdwara in the village. He said after villagers came to know that they had come from Anandpur Sahib, there was a sense of fear among them.The sarpanch added villagers made the announcement from another gurudwara, after which villagers gathered outside the gurdwara where the Nihang Singhs had come. He added police and representatives from civil administration later reached the spot and persuaded the Nihang Singhs to leave the village.Payal DSP Hardeep Singh , who was in the team of police officers who visited the spot, said the group had come with 100 horses and were on their way to their headquarters in Chabba village on Amritsar-Tarn Taran road. He added they spoke to them and made them understand that since they were coming from Anandpur Sahib, where a Covid-19 patient from Banga had visited before dying, so villagers would let them to stay in the village.He added they told the Nihang Sikhs to that they could not cannot stay in the village in a group of 40 or 50 and could stay outside the village in a group of 8-10 persons only.The DSP said they told the Nihang Sikhs that thet would have to get all of them tested and they would have to go to their headquarters if they wanted to stay together. He added they then agreed to leave the villag. The police official said the Nihang Sikhs told them that everyone among them was fine and no one had any problem. He added the Nihangs were on way to their headquarters in small groups.

Title: Ludhiana: MC field staff to be available on phone
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Zonal offices of the MC will remain closed for public dealing from Monday to March 31, but field staff would be available on the phone, said a spokesperson on Sunday.

It is yet to be decided how people will be able to clear property tax dues by March 31. Residents have demanded that last date be extended. Ludhiana mayor Balkar Sandhu said people should sit at home and, in case they have to move out, they should take preventions.

Officials will not sit in offices, but will be available for essential services like water supply and removal of complaints related with sewerage choking. Officials are encouraging people to make tax payments online.

MC commissioner K P Brar said field staff would remain on duty. She said they would also continue sanitisation in every ward for preventing spread of this disease. “We will try to arrange some staff for collecting property tax at the MC office,” Brar added.

Title: No case of Covid-19 yet: Ludhiana DC
Content: LUDHIANA: Deputy commissioner Pradeep Kumar Agrawal on Sunday said there was no positive case of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in Ludhiana district so far. He said all the samples sent for testing were negative. He also thanked residents of Ludhiana for supporting ‘Janata Curfew’, which was announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.Agrawal chaired a meeting on Covid-19 in his office in the evening, also attended by commissioner of police Rakesh Kumar Agrawal , ADC (development) Amrit Singh, MC additional commissioner Sanyam Aggarwal, ADC (general) Iqbal Singh Sandhu , ADC (Jagraon) Neeru Katyal Gupta , ADC (Khanna) Jaspal Singh, ADCP Deepak Pareek , all SDMs, civil surgeon Dr Rajesh Kumar Bagga , DFSCs, and several others. The DC said the common man would not suffer in coming days.The DC said in exercise of powers under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, the Punjab government had already issued the Punjab Epidemic Diseases, Covod-19 Regulations, 2020, for the containment and prevention of the virus. It is imperative to put in place strict measures of isolation and social distancing to contain the spread of Covid-19 in the district, teh DC said.Whereas in exercise of the powers conferred under the Rule 12 of the Punjab Epidemic Diseases, Covid-19 Regulations, 2020, a lockdown had been directed in the territorial jurisdiction of the district in public interest with immediate effect upto March 31, 2020 (inclusive), he said.All shops, commercial establishments, offices and factories, workshops, godowns etc. shall close their operations, no public transport services including operation of taxis/auto rickshaws etc. shall be permitted except transport of all kinds to and from hospitals, airports, railway stations, bus terminals/bus stands.
